HEADLINE: ENRON'S COLLAPSE: THE RIPPLES; 
Fallout From Enron Continues to Take Toll on Power Sector

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. and ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
The power companies that not long ago were criticized as profiteers responsible for the California energy crisis are now reeling from Enron's collapse. 
 Their stocks and bonds have tumbled in recent weeks as investors have retreated, worried about whether the companies' financial statements can be trusted and whether their profits can grow if natural gas and electricity prices remain low. Regulators and lawmakers, stung by the California energy crisis and Enron's demise, are talking tough. And Wall Street bankers who raised tens of billions of dollars for the companies are now pulling back, threatening to slow construction of power plants that a few months ago were a national priority. 
 All this is happening despite assurances by analysts and regulators immediately after Enron's bankruptcy filing that the company's collapse was unlikely to cause big ripples in the power industry. 
Since the end of October, the shares of the El Paso Corporation have fallen 16 percent; Dynegy, 30 percent, Calpine, 36 percent: and Mirant, 28 percent.
"Investors are just fleeing the sector," said Carol Coale, an analyst with Prudential Securities in Houston. "I'm not sure it's going to make a turn for the better between now and the end of the year. There's no positive support in any of the stocks."
To allay investor concerns, several of the companies took steps to shore up their financial positions, easing some of the market pressure on their stocks yesterday. 
El Paso, which owns the nation's largest gas pipeline network and is the fourth-biggest gas producer, announced a broad restructuring plan. El Paso said it would sell $2.25 billion in assets, cut capital spending, issue new stock and eliminate off-balance-sheet activities that have raised investors' eyebrows.
The move is, in part, a reversal for El Paso, which recently completed an off-balance-sheet financing. Investors who only a few months ago were encouraging energy companies to grow as fast as possible are now focused on the risks that heavy debt can bring. As El Paso explained yesterday, "It has become clear in the last month that the market now expects energy companies to maintain lower leverage and more simplified balance sheets."
The plan buoyed the company's shares, which rose 4.9 percent, to $41.07.
The company hit the hardest has been Calpine, which operates power plants and is based in San Jose, Calif. Yesterday, Calpine officials told investors that the company would buy back some of its debt, and S.& P. said the company's credit rating, though below investment grade, was not in jeopardy of falling and that the company's fundamentals had not deteriorated. Investors have grown concerned about how much of Calpine's profits are coming from trading electricity and whether it can continue to finance its aggressive growth plan.
Ms. Coale of Prudential said she was encouraged by El Paso's move, and hoped that other companies would follow its lead. Within the last few days, she said she has gotten fewer calls from hedge funds -- which are often making short-term trades or are betting stocks will fall -- and more from mutual fund and pension fund managers who are more likely to buy and hold. "That's the encouraging thing," she said.
So far, the stock market's concerns have been confined largely to electricity and natural gas companies. The average large-capitalization stock rose yesterday and is now up about 5 percent since Enron began its slide in mid-October. But as the stocks and bonds of energy companies plunge, analysts are now wondering whether the sell-off will spread to other companies that have heavy debt burdens and opaque financial statements.
"There is clearly a crisis of confidence," said Glen Grabelsky, senior director of credit policy for Fitch, a credit rating agency. "Anyone who's been in the news recently has been pretty much locked out of the capital market."
The situation could broaden the scope of the current credit squeeze, which is making it hard for highly leveraged companies to roll over loans or bonds when they come due.
The last time Wall Street faced the specter of a widespread credit squeeze was the fall of 1998, after the Russian debt crisis and the failure of Long-Term Capital Management, a hedge fund. Stocks dropped 19 percent from July to early October of that year as investors worried that the economy might fall into recession.
But the Federal Reserve and major securities firms came together to dispose of Long-Term Capital's portfolio, and the Fed cut short-term interest rates to make credit more widely available.
This time, the economy is in recession, and the Fed has already cut short-term interest rates 11 times this year. There is little more it can do if the problem spreads. 
Because debt may be harder to roll over, Mr. Grabelsky said he had asked Fitch's analysts to review the bonds of any company that will need to refinance its debt in the next few months, especially if the company already carries a low credit rating.
Credit rating agencies also say they plan to pay more attention to the interaction between stocks and bonds, especially at companies that issue debt that they can be forced to repay if their stock falls below a certain price -- one contributor to Enron's downfall.
Last week, Moody's Investors Service, a major bond rating agency, announced that it would pay closer attention to such triggers, and Mr. Grabelsky said Fitch would take similar steps.
The retrenchment in the merchant energy industry follows an extraordinary period of rapid growth prompted by legislative and regulatory changes in Washington -- promoted by Enron and other companies -- that created a vibrant wholesale market for both electricity and natural gas. These changes prompted old-line pipeline companies and electric utilities to get into the highflying energy-trading business, and led to the creation of new companies that built power plants, financed by billions from investors.
Total debt issued by merchant energy companies soared from $23.6 billion in 1999 to $48.6 billion this year, according to Thomson Financial. 
But after Enron's downfall, investors are skittish. "The highly leveraged, undercapitalized firms are going to have trouble getting capital," said Philip K. Verleger Jr., an energy economist and former Treasury Department official in the Carter administration. "Some of these generating plants that looked like they were going to be real money makers turned out to be losers."
Conversely, the companies that are now replete with assets -- power plants and other tangible items as opposed to just trading and marketing operations -- will be better off, he said. Even if another major energy trader or merchant company collapsed, it would probably not upend the economy, he added. "It would be very surprising if Enron's failure and even the failure of one or two other energy companies has any real long-lasting impact on economic activity," Mr. Verleger said.
Investor squeamishness may make for a bumpy ride for a while. At Dynegy, a major marketer of natural gas, some investors are nervous about its cash position, as cash and available short-term credit fell from $2.04 billion on Sept. 30 to $900 million on Dec. 6, according to public filings and statements from Dynegy.
Meg Nellen, Dynegy's senior vice president for investor relations, said $600 million was used to purchase natural gas storage sites in Britain in November. Dynegy also used $300 million in short-term debt to finance partnerships that are building electric plants around the United States, she said. The company used the other $240 million to pay for other capital expenses and business needs, like buying natural gas that will be sold this winter.
"There is not a liquidity crisis at Dynegy," Ms. Nellen said.
But short-sellers, who will make money if Dynegy's stock declines, questioned why the company had drawn down its short-term credit lines to finance long-term projects at a time when Wall Street wants energy companies to have a cash cushion. Acquisitions and investments should be financed with long-term bonds, not short-term corporate debt or bank loans, they said.
"If that's the way they're treating the function of corporate finance at this company, heaven help them," said James Chanos, president of Kynikos Associates, a New York hedge fund.
The problems at Enron have already put added pressure on companies to disclose more information to investors, especially about partnerships between companies and outside investors. Yesterday, the Securities and Exchange Commission said it planned to consider new rules next year that would force companies to make more precise disclosures about the assumptions behind their financial statements.
"Each company's management and auditor should bring particular focus to the evaluation of the critical accounting policies used in the financial statements," the commission said. The statement comes on the heels of a promise last week from the five major accounting firms to work to improve financial disclosure.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: ESTATE PLANNING; 
Jolted by Sept. 11, Many Rush to Make Wills

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Ellen and Mark Genender showed up at their lawyer's office in Manhattan at 9:15 a.m. Friday to complete a task they had begun more than a year ago, but could never quite bring themselves to finish. They signed their wills and put their affairs in order.
 For Mr. and Mrs. Genender, a couple in their 30's who live with their three children on the Upper East Side, that hour at their lawyer's office was the uneasy, and possibly inevitable moment familiar to trust and estate lawyers everywhere: an implicit, if grudging, acknowledgment of mortality. 
 And in the three months since the attack on the World Trade Center, it has taken place across New York, and to a lesser extent the nation, at a brisk and unabating pace. 
If there is any business that is booming since Sept. 11, it is the business of writing wills. Starting about 10 days after the collapse of the towers, and continuing ever since, trust and estate law firms say, they have been overwhelmed with requests from people who suddenly want to prepare their wills. A specialty of law once noted for its procrastinating clients and mordant put-the-client-at-ease jokes has suddenly become serious and urgent.
Many of the requests are from people like Mr. and Mrs. Genender, affluent families with children -- though Mr. Genender, a partner in a private equity firm, has the added prods of working on the 59th floor of a Midtown office tower and flying often on business.
But estate lawyers say the influx is astonishing for its breadth as well as its volume: from people of all ages and economic classes, from married and gay couples and singles, from people with children and without, and from all neighborhoods. (People who work or live near the trade center site, though, have shown a particular eagerness to prepare a will, said Anita S. Rosenbloom, an estate lawyer at the downtown office of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan.)
In the normally sleepy business of writing wills, it is now not uncommon to hear of a three-week wait to get an appointment with a lawyer, or to get the first draft of a will back.
"We've been incredibly busy," said Barry S. Berger, an estate and trust lawyer with Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson. "There has been a tremendous upsurge in people who are first beginning to think about their estate planning, and there has been an inordinate number of our clients who have been sitting with will drafts, who have now seen a new sense of urgency in bringing their wills and planning up to date." Gloria S. Neuwirth, of Davidson, Dawson & Clark, who drew up the will for the Genender family, described a heightened sense of urgency: "It's 'I want to get my affairs in order. I want to make sure my children are protected. Let's get this over.' "
This change in the tempo and tenor of the process -- best known for the awkward dance in which lawyers nudge clients into considering the improbable event of their own demise -- suggests a fundamental change in the way many people have come to think about their lives. Suddenly, the notion of dying at an early age -- before one's parents, and with children still growing up at home -- is not an irrational fear, but the kind of reality that long ago became familiar to people living in places like Jerusalem or Beirut.
For people like Mr. and Mrs. Genender, a project that was started and then forgotten in the day-to-day bustle of raising a family in New York suddenly became critical. Mrs. Genender, who is 34, said: "After everything that happened, and after having three small kids, we decided it was time to do something. Time to sign it."
Mr. Genender, who is 37, said: "We were dragging our feet on getting it finished. The 11th made me realize that you're more vulnerable than you thought. And you can't control the circumstances."
The phenomenon is not confined to the city where the attack took place. Dennis I. Belcher, the chairman-elect of the American Bar Association's section on real property, probate and trust law, who is based in Richmond, Va., said lawyers across the country had reported an upsurge in requests for wills. The wave was accelerated by the rush of anthrax scares and a series of terrorism alerts from the Justice Department.
Still, not surprisingly, the interest in estate planning is most intense in New York, where so many people are reminded of their vulnerability by the changed skyline, the still occasionally pungent smell of smoke in the downtown air, the debris trucks rolling along the Hudson River, the daily obituaries with photographs of young and vibrant people, and, of course, the patch of downtown that remains a barricaded crime scene.
"It puts things in perspective," said David C. Levine, 35, a tax accountant who lives in Chelsea, Manhattan, and who sat down with his lawyer on Monday to tend to his will. Mr. Levine had a particularly persistent reminder: his office was on the 13th floor of 7 World Trade Center, with a view of the north tower. He emerged from the subway station at Cortlandt Street just after the first plane struck that tower.
"I realized it was time to put things in order," he said.
The events of September have, it seems, changed the atmosphere that surrounds the preparation of a will. Lawyers say it is hardly uncommon for a client to expect that a will be done overnight. "I've gotten calls from someone who was delaying, saying, 'Could you come over right now and talk about my will,' " Ms. Rosenbloom said. Lawyers say there has been an epidemic of what are darkly known in the trade as "runway wills" -- overnight wills sought by people who learn of a major plane crash just before they are to fly. 
Even though lawyers usually try to move things along with a bit of Addams family humor, the atmosphere at law firms these days does not lend itself to levity. "It's really hard to keep it light in this environment," said Judith E. Turkel, a Manhattan lawyer. "People come in with emotions running very high, with tremendous fear, and with the realization that they could die in a way they didn't realize before."
There are other factors that lawyers point to in explaining the rush. In a manner reminiscent of how people responded when AIDS was diagnosed in the early years of the epidemic, before there were effective treatments, "sometimes people feel they are gaining some control by putting their affairs in order for their loved ones," Ms. Rosenbloom said.
Joshua S. Rubenstein, who oversees an estate department of 24 lawyers at Rosenman & Colin, said his firm's business had more than doubled over the last three months. "Sept. 11 took away the ability to do what people do when they come in to talk about wills, which is to say, 'Here's what I'd like to do if I die' -- as if they have a choice," Mr. Rubenstein said. "Now it's not if but when."
A number of lawyers suggested that the very nature of the attack meant that the rush in estate planning was not about to fade. Since so many of the victims were so young, it is just a matter of time until their estates wind up in court, the subject of litigation and confusion over the intentions of men and women who never expected to die without a will.

HEADLINE: Need Coasters? Dust Off Those LP's 

BYLINE:  By HILLARY ROSNER 

 BODY:
SHOSHANA BERGER sleeps on a "meat cart" bed. At her office in Berkeley, Calif., she keeps a blanket of stitched-together sweaters wrapped around her legs for warmth. She has jumped on the paint-by-numbers revival.
 Two years ago, Ms. Berger, a writer who did a stint as a trend spotter for Young & Rubicam, was discussing Martha Stewart with a friend. Ms. Stewart had created an impressive empire -- but for 20- and 30-somethings, Ms. Berger said, Martha Stewart Living "is their mother's magazine." 
 "We were talking about what an amazing uberbrand she'd created," said Ms. Berger, 32. "And my friend was like, 'Nobody's doing this for us.' " 
This week, Ms. Berger introduced ReadyMade, her do-it-yourself magazine for the MTV generation, with the tag line: "Instructions for everyday life." It is an irreverent indie-rock Martha Stewart Living that combines cheeky writing with step-by-step instructions on how to make quirky items. Conceived as a Web site ("Right before the content sector of the Net crashed and burned," Ms. Berger said), ReadyMade the magazine will initially come out four times a year and be sold at newsstands, bookstores and branches of Urban Outfitters.
"I've always been a natural-born do-it-yourselfer," said Ms. Berger, who created the meat-cart bed, a plywood platform bed on wheels inspired by industrial food carts, for the magazine's first issue. "I was a total flea market hag. I spent a lot of time dragging furniture off the street and refurbishing it." Among those finds was a hulking metal cabinet from an oil refinery, which she spent three days stripping with vile-smelling paint removers. "My roommates wanted to put me in quarantine," she said. "But it's beautiful." 
Ms. Berger, whose father is a professor of mechanical engineering and a garage tinkerer, believes that common objects should be reused. This sensibility infuses the magazine, from its title -- a nod to Marcel Duchamp's object-as-art ethic -- to projects such as making an LP fruit bowl (which requires nothing more than a record, an oven and some peanut oil). Well-equipped do-it-yourselfers can tackle LP coasters, which require the use of a hole saw and C-clamps. (The coasters are for sale on ReadyMade's Web site in case you are unsure about your skill level: www.readymademag.com.)
ReadyMade's first issue offers instructions for making the sweater blanket, found-object clocks, a Fed Ex wallet and dozens of other items, including a "spice station" by Constantin Boym. But the magazine extends its how-to ethos to droll articles such as "How to Become a Famous Writer" by Neal Pollack, who wrote the tongue-in-cheek book "The Neal Pollack Anthology of American Literature" last year. At one point, Mr. Pollack was accused of being fictional, the alter ego of Dave Eggers, the author of "A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius."
Other ReadyMade headlines in the first issue include "I'm an Unlicensed Therapist, Here's My Card" and "How to Lose 40 Pounds," which begins "First, gain the 40 pounds."
Ms. Berger and Grace Hawthorne, the publisher, printed 50,000 copies of the first issue. They hope to reach 10 issues a year by 2004. The project has been funded by friends and family, Ms. Berger said.
Ms. Berger believes that ReadyMade is tapping into an underserved market: 21- to 34-year-olds who want dominion over their personal environments and who find satisfaction in creating something with their hands. People, that is, who are just too cool for Martha. Some of them reject the Gap-ing and Pottery Barn-ing of America. Others find themselves with B&B Italia tastes and jigsaw-in-the-basement budgets.
Sixty-one percent of American households consider themselves do-it-yourselfers, according to Home & Garden Television. Based on demographic figures, ReadyMade estimates that 33 million of them are between the ages of 21 and 34. In research conducted in June, the Home Improvement Research Institute, which tracks the broad industry, predicted that home improvement product sales would grow by 3.9 percent in 2002.
OTHER attempts have been made to reach this market through decorating shows and books. Katie Brown was heralded as the Gen X Martha Stewart when she had a show on Lifetime (it has since been canceled). A Web site called GetCrafty.com, which features instructions on knitting a human skull, is devoted to "making art out of everyday life." Teen Magazine is even grooming a new do-it-yourself generation with a column (Su Casa) that promises "fun with chairs" and "it's time to customize your walls."
"We're seeing a continuation of the D.I.Y. phenomenon within youth culture, and it seems to be becoming more important now because of the state of the economy," said DeeDee Gordon, a president of Look-Look, a Los Angeles-based company that tracks youth trends. "Anything from baking to making your own CD's to making your own films to knitting."
Olivia Sammons, 26, a photographer's prop stylist in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, makes and sells her own skin-care products. "Martha doesn't represent the kind of woman who is from our generation," she said. "She's got great ideas, but you can say, 'I'd rather make it out of hot pink.' " Ms. Sammons owns two sewing machines; a serger for finishing edges; a well-stocked toolbox, courtesy of her fiance; a glue gun; and her favorite, a grommet kit. She recently took a felting class.
Ms. Berger would probably find her an ideal reader for ReadyMade. "We're more about invention than convention," she said. "People want to customize their environments. You see that in iMacs, the home-studio D.J., all that stuff. Martha totally hit a nerve for the over-40-year-old country-chic-loving market. We want the post-Martha market."
ReadyMade even has a column called Post-Martha, which puts an irreverent spin on a typical Martha project. "It's not about lampooning her," Ms. Berger said. It's about recognizing that Martha's crafty spirit has permeated the culture. 
Yet there are those who think it is a crazy idea to start a magazine when so many established publications are folding. "Advertisers don't really look at quarterlies," said Martin S. Walker, a magazine industry consultant in New York. "And they're operating in an arena that has large-circulation magazines, so if they don't get some size quickly, they're going to struggle." Mr. Walker likes ReadyMade's premise, but doubts it can succeed. "As an editorial idea, it sounds like it has merit, but I'm not sure it's a business idea," he said. "And you have to have both."
Dan Capell, the editor of Capell's Circulation Report, based in New York, also had some doubts. "It's such a crowded field to begin with," he said, "and the ad climate is so bad." Mr. Capell also questions whether, amid generally poor newsstand sales, customers will shell out $4.95 for ReadyMade's mere 76 pages, even if they are 50 percent recycled heavy-stock paper.
Nonetheless, ReadyMade hopes to engage its readers through its own kind of market research, which has been influenced by the give and take of the Internet. Ninety percent of the projects in the magazine's first issue were created and designed by readers who received a trial issue in April. Among the submissions, said Ms. Berger, were things to make with your first issue of ReadyMade.
Ms. Hawthorne, ReadyMade's publisher, previously worked at the failed media Web site Inside.com. Unlike the Oprah and Martha empires, which are celebrity-driven, she said, ReadyMade is intended to be community-driven. A "mini-manifesto" in the issue includes a vow of virtue, and the magazine seeks to debunk the maker-as-auteur. 
But even that conscious rejection of celebrity won't stop Ms. Berger and Ms. Hawthorne from trying to build a Martha-style universe, leading masses of glue-gun-wielding youths to ReadyMade product lines (like the paint-by-numbers kits, for which five artists have been commissioned), anthologies and, of course, television shows. "In terms of brand extensions, ReadyMade is one of the most ideal types of media properties," Ms. Hawthorne said. "It's evergreen content."
In other words, it may be time to buy that grommet kit and begin felting.

HEADLINE: Computer Consultant Giant In Europe to Lose Its Chief 

BYLINE:  By KERRY SHAW 

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 12 

 BODY:
Geoff Unwin, the chief executive of Cap Gemini, Europe's largest computer services firm, will retire in 2002, the company said today. Paul Hermelin, the chief operating officer and the architect of the company's acquisition of Ernst & Young's consulting arm last year, will replace Mr. Unwin.
 The company also announced that because of worsening erosion of its revenue after the Sept. 11 terror attacks, it will lay off 2,500 more workers, bringing the jobs cut so far this year to 5,400, or 9 percent of its former work force. 
 Mr. Unwin's announcement was unexpected, but the company said it was not a result of pressure by the board. Rather, the company said in a statement, it came from Mr. Unwin's desire to finish his career when he turns 60 next year. Mr. Unwin, who has been at Cap Gemini for 11 years, will remain on the board.
Mr. Hermelin, 49, joined Cap in 1993. He will retain the chief operating officer title after he takes over the top post in January.
The transition comes at a difficult time for the company. Like other technology consultants, Cap Gemini has experienced a sharp contraction in revenue in the last year, made worse by the newfound emphasis on United States business after the Ernst & Young deal, which brought to one-third the share of its revenue derived there.
Shares of Cap Gemini have fallen 53 percent in 2001, and closed today at 80.5 euros ($71.80) in Paris.
The job cuts announced today are expected to save the company around $715.6 million annually.
In a conference call today, Mr. Unwin said that Cap Gemini expected a decline in revenue in the first half of 2002, but that major outstanding contracts to be completed in the second half "should help lift revenue figures regardless of economic outlook," Bloomberg News reported.

HEADLINE: Political Memo; 
Bloomberg Appointments Trouble Some G.O.P. Leaders

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Shunning the political party that he adopted to successfully usher him into office, Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg has put together an inner circle that is nearly Republican-free. His selection of four deputy mayors, the corporation counsel and the leader of his transition team, registered Democrats all, has set off some grumbling among the state's and city's Republican leaders, some of whom believe that Mr. Bloomberg owes them at least a nod as he puts together his administration and who worry about what his choices may mean for city policies.
 "It was a pretty difficult campaign, and a lot of people extended themselves," said Guy V. Molinari, the Staten Island borough president, one of Mr. Bloomberg's earliest and most vocal supporters during the mayoral campaign. "One way you extend yourself back is by appointing at least one Republican, that is how the book runs. I hope going forward he becomes more sensitive to that fact." 
 In New York City, where Democrats outnumber Republicans roughly five to one, a qualified token hire might be enough to mollify many of the most conservative elected officials. But Mr. Bloomberg, who paid for his campaign with his own money and often boasted that this helped keep him from owing anything to any special interests, so far seems impervious to this notion.
On Tuesday, during a news conference in which he announced the appointments of Carol A. Robles-Roman as deputy mayor for legal affairs and Michael A. Cardozo as his corporation counsel, both were asked for their party affiliation. Mr. Bloomberg seemed genuinely surprised, looked at the two appointees with widened eyes and said, "I never asked you." Only Edward Skyler, his press secretary, is a registered Republican, and he changed his registration from independent over the summer, Mr. Skyler said.
Further, many of the state's more conservative leaders are concerned about the policy implications of key appointments: Marc V. Shaw, executive director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority; Dennis Walcott, the longtime leader of the New York Urban League; and Patricia E. Harris, who worked in the Koch administration, all named deputy mayors; and Nat Leventhal, who leads his transition team which is appointing commissioners.
The leaders say they are wondering whether Mr. Bloomberg, a lifelong Democrat who changed parties to run for mayor and who, near the end of his campaign, stood shoulder to shoulder with Gov. George E. Pataki and proclaimed himself a liberal, will remove some key pillars of the Giuliani administration. "I would like him to switch parties so when he starts his liberal policies I will better be able to attack him," said one leading Republican strategist who preferred not to pick a public fight with the mayor-elect.
Mr. Skyler said yesterday that critics should wait and watch. "The mayor-elect has tremendous respect for Guy Molinari, who was one of his closest advisers," he said. "He spoke to the borough president this morning and assured him that the process is still in its early stages." A few Republican leaders said yesterday that Queens party leaders had already been called, and that City Councilman Thomas V. Ognibene, among other Republicans, was being considered for a job. Mr. Ognibene did not return calls seeking comment yesterday. 
Many leaders accept Mr. Skyler's explanation and even say that Mr. Bloomberg's moves could bring newcomers to the party. "I am confident that there will be Republicans in key positions," said the majority leader of the State Senate, Joseph L. Bruno, yesterday. 
Still, several Democrats have looked upon Mr. Bloomberg's appointments with a smile. Mark Green said yesterday that he would have asked many of the same people whom Mr. Bloomberg has called on to serve in his administration had he managed to capture the mayoralty. Others said that unlike with the Giuliani administration, in which Democrats who joined found themselves scorned by their party for their disloyalty, no one cares this time around because Mr. Bloomberg's Republican stripes are nominal at best.
"Do you expect me to complain?" said Fernando Ferrer, who consults with Mr. Bloomberg regularly about various issues. Indeed, Mr. Bloomberg's first courtesy calls were to Democratic leaders including Mr. Ferrer, the labor leaders Dennis Rivera and Randi Weingarten, and the Rev. Al Sharpton. Mr. Bloomberg's other closest aides yet to be given formal titles include Kevin Sheekey, a former aide to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, and William Cunningham, a former executive director of the state Democratic Party.
Some Republican leaders said yesterday that given the anemic pool of registered Republicans in the city, Mr. Bloomberg best serves his party by simply governing well, regardless of the party affiliations of his appointees. "If Bloomberg ends up being a good mayor, that is what helps," said Kieran V. Mahoney, a Republican strategist. "People will then say, 'You elect Republicans and good things happen.' "
But others are concerned that it is only a matter of time before Mr. Bloomberg starts scuffling with Gov. George E. Pataki, who does not need tension with a leader from his own party during an election year. Because of tremendous losses that the city and state have incurred since the terrorist attack in September, Mr. Pataki will have to make tough budget decisions and cannot afford to alienate upstate voters, whose local economies have been troubled for years. But if Mr. Bloomberg begins to grumble about the city not getting its share, that could create tension between the two men, some party leaders said.
Already this week, Mr. Bloomberg has expressed disappointment over the governor's decision earlier this year to appeal a landmark court ruling that ordered a major increase in spending on New York City schools by the state.
"I am sympathetic with the plaintiff," said Mr. Bloomberg, referring to the Campaign for Fiscal Equity, which brought the suit. Mr. Giuliani had said earlier that he would have preferred that Mr. Pataki not appeal the decision.
Michael McKeon, a spokesman for Mr. Pataki, said yesterday: "We think it's important that he have a good team in place. In making his decisions the governor has focused on ability and merit, not on politics, and it seems Mr. Bloomberg is doing the same."
Many other Republicans said yesterday that it was still too early to draw broad conclusions about Mr. Bloomberg and his new policies, and that anyone who expected him to stack his administration with Republicans was fooling himself, given that the mayor-elect has never tried to cover his true political leanings. 
"We all knew where he came from, he didn't hide it," said State Senator Guy J. Velella, the Bronx Republican leader, who spoke to Mr. Bloomberg yesterday. "So am I overly concerned? No. But are their warning signs that we have to watch him and make sure he keeps the faith? Absolutely."

HEADLINE: City Has Idea (Think Office Buildings) to Stretch Midtown to Far West Side 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
The oversize maps propped up on easels in City Hall yesterday -- to help officials explain their plans to extend the Midtown business district to the far West Side of Manhattan -- discreetly omitted any mention of a new stadium there. 
 So Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the city's first sports fan and stadium booster, borrowed a black Magic Marker from an aide, strode up to one of the easels and scrawled "N.Y. Jets" and "Olympic Stadium" over a section of the map that had been labeled simply "the rail yards." "It's a nice spot," he said. 
 Stadium or no stadium, city officials said yesterday, the time has come to develop a new business district in a 59-square-block area stretching from West 24th Street to West 42nd Street, and from the Hudson River to as far east as Eighth Avenue. 
The city's Planning Department has issued a 65-page report that calls for extending tracks for the No. 7 train from Times Square south to Pennsylvania Station and west to the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, and changing the city's zoning rules to allow for the construction of bigger office buildings in the area. 
The new business-oriented approach is reflected in the name for the neighborhood: Far West Midtown. And although the World Trade Center attacks, the weakening economy and the city's looming budget deficits may make it seem like an odd time to unveil big plans for new development, Joseph B. Rose, the director of the city's Planning Department, insisted that the proposal was eminently doable. "This is not pie in the sky," he said. 
Mr. Rose proposed two ways in which the plan could pay for itself: levying a fee on developers who want to build bigger buildings at the new zoning levels, and dedicating part of the increased property taxes to backing capital-improvement bonds. 
But it could be a lengthy process. The subway extension is subject to an environmental review, the State Legislature would have to approve the plan to dedicate part of the taxes, and the Planning Department has to draft the new zoning regulations.
Mr. Giuliani applauded the plan, saying it would give an economic lift to an area he described as "underproductive." He said that the transportation improvements would pave the way for a new stadium or Olympic center, if approved, but would create a new business district in any case. And, he said, the plan takes on added significance as the city tries to find office space for businesses displaced from Lower Manhattan following the terror attacks.
In releasing the plan at the end of his mayoralty, Mr. Giuliani was, in effect, leaving it to Michael R. Bloomberg to put in place.
The governor-elect of New Jersey, James E. McGreevey, who met with Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Bloomberg yesterday, was less than enthusiastic about the thought of losing the Jets to New York. 
"It is incumbent upon New Jersey," Mr. McGreevey said, "to set forth a fiscally responsible and thoughtful plan toward encouraging a long-term commitment on behalf of the Jets management team."

HEADLINE: Swift Action Is Planned On Fare Plan In New Jersey 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, DEC. 12 

 BODY:
New Jersey Transit officials plan to move swiftly to raise fares next year, scheduling hearings and a vote for early January and the new rates to take effect April 1. 
 The date of the vote, Jan. 7, would allow Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco to approve the new rates a day before leaving office, sparing his successor, James E. McGreevey, the politically onerous chore of giving the increases his blessing. 
 The proposal calls for fares to increase an average of 10 percent next year. In each of the five following years, automatic fare increases would be pegged to the inflation rate. Fares last rose in 1991. 
Tom Wilson, a spokesman for Mr. DiFrancesco; a spokeswoman for Mr. McGreevey's transition team; and James Weinstein, the chairman of New Jersey Transit, all said today that there had been no discussion between the DiFrancesco administration and Mr. McGreevey's aides about the proposed increase. But at the board meeting, few were accepting the idea that the increases were about to be put into effect without the blessing of both the departing and arriving governors.
"They are sneaking it in the gap," said William Wright, a spokesman for the New Jersey Association of Railroad Passengers. "Plus they are holding the public hearings the day after New Year's Day, when a lot of people will still be out of town. It's all designed to cut down on opposition."
Mr. Wilson, the spokesman for Mr. DiFrancesco, said that although Mr. DiFrancesco had made no final decision, "it was certainly an appropriate time for an increase given the strains on the system."
The plan would mean an average fare increase of 10 percent in the first year for more than 90 percent of New Jersey Transit's 380,000 daily bus and rail commuters, many of whom buy monthly passes. But with the plan's elimination of some discounted round-trip "excursion" fares during off-peak hours, the increases for riders at those times amount to 44 percent to 89 percent on a number of lines.
The discount for people 62 and older would drop to 50 percent from 55 percent.
There would be no change in 2002 for the new Hudson-Bergen Light Rail line, which connects Bayonne and Jersey City and will soon extend to Hoboken. 
After that, the fare would rise with inflation -- a figure that Jeffrey Warsh, the agency's executive director, said was likely to be in the "2 to 3 percent range."
The increase would begin to close a gap in which revenues from fares declined 29 percent while costs have risen 67 percent. The agency is running an annual deficit of about $500 million, which has been covered in recent years by state subsidies and the use of some capital funds for operating expenses.
For commuters into New York, the proposal comes nine months after a large increase to ride the PATH into Lower Manhattan and at a time when concerns have been raised that increases may be needed in 2003 to run city buses and subways. 
The public hearings, on Jan. 2, will be at 8 p.m. at the following locations: the auditorium of the Atlantic County Office Building in Atlantic City, the council room of Freehold Borough Hall in Freehold, the multipurpose room at the Department of Transportation's headquarters in Trenton, the board room at the New Jersey Transit headquarters in Newark, Paramus High School in Paramus, and the lobby of the Walter Rand Transportation Center Terminal in Camden.

Details of Rate Plan
Here are highlights of New Jersey Transit's proposal to raise most train and bus fares by about 10 percent on April 1:
* Eliminate weekday rail round-trip excursion fares. This would increase fares 44 percent to 89 percent.
* Set a common rail fare -- $3.30 one way -- between Newark's two train stations and New York. The current fares are $2.50 between New York and Newark Pennsylvania Station and $3 between New York and Broad Street.
* Reduce the discount to 50 percent from 55 percent for people 62 and older.
* Raise the surcharge for buying tickets aboard trains to $5 from $3.
* Limit refunds to 10-trip and monthly passes. Currently the refund policy extends to one-way tickets.
* Combine one- and two-zone bus fares into one zone.

HEADLINE: The Center Can Hold 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
"Things fall apart," bemoaned the poet Yeats, "the center cannot hold. . . ."
 Not so today. In three critical areas, the center is holding up fine. 
 1. Missile Offense and Defense: The Shanghai "no-deal deal" between President Bush and Vladimir Putin, which seemed to go off the tracks at their summit in Crawford, Tex., is now back on. 
The U.S. will "unilaterally" reduce its offensive nuclear missile stockpile to 2,000 or less, a level that the Russians can afford to maintain. That's a relief to Colin Powell coalitionaries. Meanwhile, as urged by the Rice-Rumsfeld right, the U.S. will exercise its option to withdraw from the cold-war ABM treaty, enabling us to build a limited missile defense against rogue states and terrorist groups. 
In the U.S., this reassures hard-line strategists who are troubled by our huge stockpile reduction and who have insisted Bush live up to his missile-defense campaign pledge. Soft-liners like Senator Joe Biden and consterned scientists will grump, but their ranks are thinned by the growing prospect of a Saddam or independent terrorist buying or building a nuke that could take out a U.S. city. 
Putin will sulk about ABM withdrawal but has to accept the double unilateral. Result: weaker missile offense, stronger missile defense -- a good deal for all medium-liners. 
2. The Anti-Recession Deficit: The president and the Republican House steered right, offering speeded-up tax cuts for all taxpayers and a tax-cut bonanza for big business. The Democratic Senate steered left, preferring direct assistance to the growing number of unemployed. Result: impasse. 
But lo! Bush has just signaled his willingness to aid the jobless with longer benefits and assistance with health insurance, while denying major corporations much of the succor they seek. And the Democrat Tom Daschle, while still dragging a foot on speeding up cuts to individuals, responded with acceptance of tax breaks to business for job-creating investment. Both sides are flirting with the Republican Pete Domenici's idea of a short holiday from the payroll tax. 
In a recession, temporary red ink is desirable. It now looks as if the lefty spenders and the righty tax-cutters will eschew their old lock-boxing and meet in the popular middle. 
3. Prosecution of Suspected Terrorists: Only last week, Attorney General John Ashcroft was smearing all who opposed his proposed secret military trials in the U.S. as unpatriotic aiders of terrorists. He adjudged American judges unable to protect secrets and American juries too craven to convict terrorists. 
Evidently cooler heads are prevailing. The first indictment related to the Sept. 11 attack was filed this week in a civilian criminal court, not a military tribunal. The venue chosen by Michael Chertoff, head of Justice's Criminal Division, was the Eastern District of Virginia, where jurors are not easily intimidated and are not averse to the death penalty. 
Meanwhile, at the Defense Department, Secretary Donald Rumsfeld treated the concerns expressed about civil liberty as "useful." He turned for guidance on military tribunals for Al Qaeda leaders to such tough-minded and respected legal minds as Judge William Webster, former F.B.I. and C.I.A. chief, and Lloyd Cutler, adviser to presidents, it seems, since Lincoln. 
The Pentagon refinement of Bush's military order may well incorporate rights to the accused that are in today's Uniform Code of Military Justice but were expressly denied in his original, hastily drawn order. 
Such a defender of personal freedom as the conservative representative Bob Barr of Georgia does not challenge Bush's authority to convene a military tribunal overseas to do speedy justice to non-U.S. citizens. But if such trials are held inside the U.S., he says, the president is required to ask for a declaration of war (which Barr introduced) or to seek specific authorization by Congress. 
What we are likely to get, if Bush is wise enough to ask for it, is Congressional approval of overseas trials of terrorist leaders by military courts adhering to basic standards of U.S. military justice. Most civil libertarians as well as Ashcroftite zealots would express a degree of satisfaction with this, just as they have with the trial of the accused conspirator Zacarias Moussaoui in a regular criminal court in Alexandria, Va. 
Thus is the center holding. Nothing is falling apart. The falcon hears the falconer loud and clear.

HEADLINE: Making the City Whole 

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Who loves New York?
 During the unimaginable agony that followed the attack on the twin towers it seemed that everybody did. 
 Signs sprouted at sporting events from coast to coast saying, "We're all New Yorkers." Good wishes and emergency assistance flowed into the stricken city from every part of the nation.
Robert Byrd, a West Virginia Democrat and chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, dubbed himself the "third senator from New York." And when Senators Charles Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton met with President Bush in the Oval Office to explain the dire need for federal assistance, the president said to Mr. Schumer, "You need 20 extra billion for New York?" 
"Yes," said Mr. Schumer.
"You've got it," said Mr. Bush.
Hostility toward the Big Apple was put on hold. New York was part of the U.S., after all. And Rudy Giuliani, the fire-breathing autocrat who remade himself into a sensitive, caring leader, was touted as America's mayor. 
Things have changed. Not drastically. But somewhat. Americans, for the most part, are still concerned about the plight of New York. But as for the federal assistance so quickly and generously offered by the president -- assistance that is crucial to getting the city back on its feet -- well, the government now seems to be saying, "Not so fast."
The $20 billion promised to New York by the president is not really the issue. What is critically important, as members of the House and Senate debate various aid proposals this week, is whether the federal government will ensure that an American city severely damaged in an attack by a foreign enemy will be made whole.
New York is likely, eventually, to get $20 billion or something close to it in direct disaster aid from the Federal Emergency Management Agency. But the catastrophe that hit New York on Sept. 11 resulted in an array of problems far more complex and long-lasting than those that tend to result from an earthquake or a hurricane or a tornado.
"In the long run we are going to need more than $20 billion," said Senator Schumer. He noted that an enormous number of businesses, which collectively employ thousands upon thousands of people, are trying to decide right now whether to stay in Lower Manhattan, or even whether to stay in New York.
"No amount of FEMA aid is going to keep either Merrill Lynch or Joe's Hardware Store in Lower Manhattan, because FEMA doesn't pay for that," said Mr. Schumer.
The city is faced with a long list of similarly difficult and potentially debilitating problems. Other forms of assistance are essential, said Mr. Schumer. "The most important thing is to get as many ongoing revenue streams as possible early on."
The Senate has approved an appropriations bill that would bring the total federal aid to New York this year to $12.5 billion (about 60 percent of it FEMA money). The House has passed a bill that is substantially less generous. It would result in a total of $9.5 billion in aid for New York.
House and Senate conferees are trying to work out the differences, and the result of those negotiations will be telling. An agreement that is close to the Senate version would indicate a genuine national commitment to provide meaningful assistance to New York as it makes its comeback.
At the same time, Senators Schumer and Clinton have proposed that a national economic stimulus package (also being debated this week) contain a $5 billion program of tax cuts and other assistance designed to encourage businesses and residents to stay in Lower Manhattan.
Senator Schumer said he was optimistic that, despite some tough obstacles in Congress, New York in the long run would get the aid it needed. "I look at the glass as two-thirds full rather than one-third empty," he said. 
I asked the senator how he thought New Yorkers should view President Bush as the debate over assistance unfolds.
"His opening gambit was extremely generous," Mr. Schumer said. "I think he fully intends to give us the reimbursement money down the road. But I don't think, at least at this point, that he's fully on board that we should get this panoply of other programs that we need. On the FEMA side, he's good. But on the other side, he needs a little persuading."

HEADLINE: Armey Says He'll Retire, And DeLay Looks to Lead 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 

 BODY:
House Republicans began maneuvering for top leadership jobs today as Dick Armey, the majority leader, announced that he would retire from Congress after serving one more year.
 Tom DeLay of Texas, the House Republican whip, did everything possible to secure his position as the overwhelming favorite to replace Mr. Armey as the second-ranking Republican in the next Congress, which convenes in January 2003. 
 By some accounts, Mr. DeLay is already the most powerful man in the House. He has a network of about 65 deputies and assistants, close ties to scores of lobbyists and proven ability as a fund-raiser. 
Mr. DeLay, a hard-changing conservative known for his ability to round up votes in the House, is expected to play a central role in the party's effort to widen its House majority in midterm elections next year.
Representative Thomas M. Reynolds, Republican of New York, a deputy whip, said tonight that Mr. DeLay had commitments from 140 of the 221 Republicans in the House. "This freight train is moving down the tracks," Mr. Reynolds said.
Democrats said they were delighted to have Mr. DeLay as the public face of Congressional Republicans. They vowed to run against him as they ran in 1996 against Newt Gingrich, who was then speaker.
Representative Martin Frost of Texas, chairman of the House Democratic Caucus, said: "Tom DeLay is the most divisive figure on the Republican side of the aisle. If he moves up in the leadership, it would make clear that the Republican agenda is far right."
Mr. Armey, who has represented suburban Dallas for 17 years, confirmed his plans to retire in a speech today on the House floor. He threw a few backhanded compliments to his Democratic foes, whom he described as "constant, consistent and reliable."
Mr. Armey, who is 61, said he was "pretty exhausted" and wanted to spend more time with his family. His son Scott is expected to run for the seat Mr. Armey now holds.
House Republicans will choose their leaders after Americans go to the polls next November. In their maneuvering today, Republicans assumed they would keep control of the House. Their calculations could be upended if they lost their majority to the Democrats.
Mr. Armey's colleagues began jockeying for position even before he formally announced his plans. "If you want one of these jobs, you have to move quickly," said a senior House Republican. "Votes are being locked up."
The turmoil in Republican ranks will probably show up more in the race for majority whip than in the contest for majority leader.
Mr. Armey's position makes him second in the House leadership hierarchy, behind Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois. As whip, Mr. DeLay is the chamber's third-ranking Republican.
Mr. DeLay wants his chief deputy, Roy Blunt of Missouri, to succeed him as whip. But it is not clear that Mr. DeLay can force his choice on the party.
In the speaker's lobby, Republicans weighed their options and discussed their own ambitions.
Representative Ray LaHood, Republican of Illinois, said he was considering running for either majority leader or whip. "We need new faces, new blood and new ideas," Mr. LaHood said. 
Jennifer Dunn, Republican of Washington, said she believed that House Republicans should have a woman in one of the top jobs. She praised the Democrats for selecting a woman, Nancy Pelosi of California, to be their whip.
"I'd like to see us match what the Democratic Party has done with Nancy," said Ms. Dunn, who ran unsuccessfully for the job of majority leader in 1998.
Representative John A. Boehner, Republican of Ohio, has told colleagues he is considering a run for majority leader or whip. "I have not ruled it in or out," Mr. Boehner said.
A spokesman for J. C. Watts Jr. of Oklahoma, chairman of the House Republican Conference, said he too was "seriously considering" a run for majority leader or whip.
The one group on the sidelines, reserving judgment, was moderate Republicans. 
Representative Amo Houghton, Republican of New York, said he was not going to endorse anyone at the moment. "We should keep our powder dry, rather than just going in automatic lock step or rushing into a decision pell-mell," Mr. Houghton said.
Another moderate Republican from New York, Sherwood Boehlert, said: "I would love to see a moderate in the leadership, but I'm realistic. We are a minority in the majority, with 25 to 50 votes in the House Republican Conference."
The House has 221 Republicans, 211 Democrats, 2 independents and 1 vacancy. 
The majority leader sets the agenda of the House and decides what bills will be considered on the floor at what time.
If Mr. LaHood runs for a leadership position, he can count on support from some moderates. "Tom DeLay relishes the idea of being called 'the Hammer,' " Mr. LaHood said. "I'd rather be called the velvet glove."
Political advisers to President Bush said they were skittish about an increase in power for Mr. DeLay because he was a polarizing figure and would be an easy target for Democrats. Mr. DeLay is also more conservative than Mr. Bush on some issues, including economic policy. But the Bush advisers said the White House would not get involved in the House leadership races and would not push one candidate over another.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dick Armey, with his wife, Susan, just before announcing his retirement yesterday on the House floor. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
Suing the City For Sept. 11? Oh, Why Not?

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
THE MAYOR-ELECT, Michael R. Bloomberg, wants his administration to be less litigious than the current one. Would that Mr. Bloomberg's idea caught on with the rest of the world, which has this persistent habit of seeing New York as Fat City. Even now.
 Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has hardly avoided court. But the greatest number of lawsuits are filed against the city, not by it. The suits range from personal injury claims (the sidewalk broke my ankle) to allegations of police brutality. In the fiscal year that ended in June 2000, people filed 26,336 claims against the city, most for sidewalk injuries (3,975), followed by charges of police misconduct (1,781). 
 Settlements cost the city $459 million that year, the latest for which statistics are available. In the most costly category -- medical malpractice suits against the Health and Hospitals Corporation -- the city paid out $150.6 million. Recently, the number of suits has declined slightly, but the settlement costs have risen.
You might expect the litigation to slow down as a hurt and financially damaged city looks to rebuild and weather a recession. You would be wrong. 
In fact, the city is being sued for Sept. 11 and its aftermath. State law gives people three months from the date of an alleged injury or damage to file notice of intention to sue. The city has not yet tallied the claims it has received, and more claims are expected, including late ones that the city has indicated it will not thwart. Interviews with lawyers for the city and prospective plaintiffs indicate that the attack will generate substantially more than 1,000 notices of claim.
The most -- 1,050 so far -- come from firefighters, who contend that they did not have the proper equipment to protect against toxic substances at the attack site.
Their lawyers say they would much prefer not to litigate and instead be compensated by the federal fund that promises financial aid to victims of the attack and their families. But eligibility to share in the fund, sometimes called the superfund, has not yet been defined. So the claims filed by firefighters could function not only to preserve their right to sue, but also to lobby for their inclusion in the federal dollars.
"It would be a shame if they sue because I think the city and the mayor have gone properly out of their way to do everything to make sure uniformed families are taken care of," said Michael D. Hess, the city's corporation counsel. 
But Michael A. Barasch, who represents 700 firefighters who may sue, was not sympathetic. "What if they are not included in the superfund?" he asked. "Do we then say, 'Too bad, we feel so sorry for the city, you have cancer, but you shouldn't sue in behalf of your families' ?"
AN unknown number of lawsuits are also expected from residents of New Jersey, which even asked the city to extend the three-month time limit beyond last Monday for filing claims directly related to Sept. 11.
The Giuliani administration decided yesterday not to oppose late claims from New Jersey, which judges can grant case by case. Roger Shatzkin, spokesman for New Jersey's attorney general, John J. Farmer Jr., said he wasn't clear, though, on what grounds residents of his state might sue. 
He wasn't the only one.
"It's really a little bit of chutzpah," said Mr. Hess, the corporation counsel. "New York City is not negligent in any way. We didn't fly the planes, we didn't maintain the buildings; there's no basis whatsoever to sue the City of New York. However, the mayor feels that there may be a lot of people who have been so busy with other things legal, emotional, whatever, that they didn't know about the 90 days. If someone brings a case, we'll let the judge decide it. We are confident that when a judge does examine the merits of any case relating to that day, we didn't do anything wrong."
Mr. Hess exhorted those inclined to sue the city to realize that the taxpayer foots the bill. His boss's litigiousness aside, Mr. Hess has tried to discourage lawsuits, as have his predecessors. They make only a dent, even with the 1979 law that requires prior written notice of defective roads and sidewalks if the city is to be held liable for injuries and property damage.
Civil libertarians and lobbyists for lawyers successfully fight evergreen efforts in Albany to put limits on personal injury lawsuits. So the suits continue because, as at least eight lawyers said superfluously yesterday in interviews for this column, this is a litigious society.

HEADLINE: House and Senate Negotiators Agree to More Base Closings 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 

 BODY:
House and Senate negotiators reached agreement today on legislation that would close more military bases, starting in 2005.
 The measure also says the Navy cannot close its training range on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques until it finds a suitable replacement. The legislation cancels a referendum on the issue that was to have taken place in Vieques next month. 
 These issues and many others were addressed today in a bipartisan agreement on the Defense Department authorization bill for the current fiscal year, which began on Oct. 1. The House and the Senate are expected to approve the legislation in the next few days, clearing the measure for President Bush. 
The House also passed today an intelligence measure that would increase spending by 8 percent -- higher than the 7 percent sought by President Bush -- and puts renewed emphasis on the use of agents to gather intelligence. Actual spending levels are classified, but current spending is estimated at $30 billion.
The military bill provides legal authority for spending a total of $343.3 billion, the amount requested by Mr. Bush, plus $21 billion to respond to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
The House and Senate negotiators decided to provide up to $8.3 billion for continued development and testing of ballistic missile defenses. That sum, the full amount requested by President Bush, is $3 billion more than Congress provided in the last fiscal year. The president could use up to $1.3 billion of new money for efforts to combat terrorism.
Under the bill, military personnel would receive pay increases of 5 percent to 10 percent, starting next month. Noncommissioned officers and junior officers would get the largest pay raises.
The House had opposed another round of base closings, while many senators wanted them to begin in 2003. Lawmakers compromised on an elaborate procedure to review the nation's security needs and close bases in 2005. 
Senator Carl Levin, the Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said, "We are closing bases to make money available for homeland defense." 
Moreover, Mr. Levin said: "With our men and women putting their lives at risk, they need all the resources we can give them. It's inexcusable that we would maintain bases that are not needed when we've got people putting their lives on the line." 
The Bush administration had insisted that the Pentagon should have the right to close unneeded bases and had threatened a veto of any bill that omitted such procedures.
Closing bases is politically unpopular. Such installations provide thousands of jobs and inject millions of dollars into local economies. But Mr. Levin said many states had found productive uses for military bases forced to close in the last decade. 
House members argued that it would send the wrong signal if Congress moved to close bases while the nation was at war and the armed forces were gearing up for new battles against terrorism.
"Everybody's expressed concern that we should not be doing this while we're at war," said Bob Stump, the Arizona Republican who is chairman of the House Armed Services Committee. In the end, Mr. Stump said, most of the House negotiators accepted the compromise.
Four rounds of base closings since 1988 have shut down 451 installations, including 97 major bases, and have saved $15.5 billion, federal investigators estimate.
House and Senate negotiators said they had decided to delay the next round of base closings to 2005 so the economy could recover from the current recession and the Defense Department could assess its needs and the value of specific installations.
Under the agreement, the president would appoint a nine-member commission to realign and close bases. The commission would meet in March 2005. In May of that year, the secretary of defense would propose a list of bases to be closed. The commission could modify the list. The president would have 15 days to accept or reject the entire list. If he accepted it, Congress would then have 45 days to approve or reject the entire package.
If bases are to be closed, the Defense Department would not necessarily have to dispose of them. It could hold onto some of the bases, as a caretaker, if it believed that they might be needed for "national security purposes" in the future.
With the nation on a war footing, Democrats backed away from their demand that the Navy immediately halt bombing exercises on Vieques.
But the deputy secretary of defense, Paul D. Wolfowitz, sent a letter to Congress saying that the Navy was "planning to discontinue training operations on the island of Vieques in May of 2003, contingent upon the identification and establishment of a suitable alternative."

HEADLINE: Officials Recount Road to Deadlock Over Missile Talks 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER and PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 

 BODY:
Six months of negotiations between the United States and Russia over the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty failed because the Bush administration was unwilling to discuss each missile test with Moscow in advance, senior administration officials said today, and because Russia refused any change that would allow unrestricted testing.
 The officials said that the critical moments in their talks came when President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia told Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld in Moscow on Nov. 3 that the American plans for extensive testing would gut the landmark accord. 
 Mr. Rumsfeld shot back that if that was Russia's position, then the United States would withdraw from the treaty -- exactly what President Bush is expected to announce Thursday.
Any hope of reaching an accord was finally buried in the opening hours of Mr. Putin's visit to the White House on Nov. 13. Neither president had any new proposals to break their impasse, each recognizing that there was simply no way to accommodate the Pentagon's aggressive testing program in a treaty that was clearly designed to prevent just that. 
As one senior administration put it this afternoon, the American testing plan "would essentially negate the fundamental nature of the treaty."
Still, at a meeting between the two presidents two days later in Crawford, Tex., Mr. Putin signaled that American withdrawal from the treaty would not end his personal relationship with Mr. Bush, nor would it end Russia's desire to reduce nuclear weapons in tandem with Washington and fight terrorism through greater cooperation.
Mr. Bush also pledged to enhance Russia's role in the NATO alliance and help integrate Russia into the world economy, thus deepening the incentive for Mr. Putin to move beyond the dispute. 
Mr. Bush's expected announcement that the United States would withdraw from the treaty will mark the first time in the nuclear era that the United States has renounced a major arms control accord. His critics at home and abroad argue that it could incite a new arms race and undermine other major accords, including the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. 
A senior administration official repeated today the White House's past offers to Moscow to participate in developing missile defenses and cooperate with NATO in developing such defenses for the Western alliance.
"There is a whole list of potential cooperation on defenses that we intend to fully explore," a senior official said. 
Another official said, "I think cooperation now gets much easier."
The description of the negotiations came today from senior Bush administration officials, as they called around Europe and Asia warning allies of the impending announcement.
They described differences with Mr. Putin as amicable, and said they did not expect an explosive reaction from Moscow. At the same time, they insisted that Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, who had made little secret of his desire to reach a new accord with Moscow, agreed with the president's decision.
American officials said today that they anticipate that Mr. Putin will issue a statement of regret on Thursday but pledge to continue working with the United States to reduce strategic offensive weapons and fight terrorism. 
He may also announce, they said, the size of planned Russian reductions in the offensive strategic weapons, a sign that the two countries are still working together closely. 
If Mr. Putin's objections to Mr. Bush's action are muted, it will mark a pronounced shift. Last summer he warned that abandoning the treaty would trigger the collapse of other arms control agreements and the deployment of new Russian multiple-warhead missiles.
Administration officials said they do not expect either to occur. "I think the Russians will react," said a senior State Department official. "It is not going to be the end of the world, and it will not be the end of cooperation on strategic issues across the board."
However, they said, the reaction of China -- whose small nuclear arsenal would be more vulnerable to any antimissile system than Russia's huge missile stockpile -- was harder to predict. 
China was never a signatory to the treaty, and Mr. Bush and President Jiang Zemin of China have not discussed the issue in any detail. China had previously said it would increase the size of its nuclear arsenal, and Mr. Bush's announcement may well speed that process.
The question of the treaty's fate came up first in the presidential campaign, when Mr. Bush said he would deploy a much more ambitious missile defense system than President Bill Clinton had proposed -- and made it clear that he would not be constrained, as Mr. Clinton was, by the treaty.
Once in office, Mr. Bush's suggestion that, if necessary, the United States could withdraw from the treaty rattled many European and Asian allies. 
In June and July, Mr. Bush sought to reassure those allies during two trips to Europe and by meeting Mr. Putin and pledging to work with him in creating a new "strategic framework." He said he would consult broadly before making any decisions on the treaty.
By the time the two men met in Shanghai in October, the terrorist attack on Sept. 11 had drawn them closer than ever. Mr. Putin emerged from their meeting declaring that "we can reach agreements" on missile defense, and administration officials said that, for the first time, Mr. Putin no longer viewed American missile defense testing program as "a threat." Privately, Mr. Putin said he could "stretch" the treaty to accommodate a great deal of testing.
But it was not clear whether that meant he was willing to reach an agreement allowing tests that the treaty clearly prohibited, or if he would insist that Russia be briefed -- and perhaps approve -- each and every test.
That was the case until the administration sent a detailed list of questions to Moscow, and then sent Mr. Rumsfeld to get the answers on Nov. 3. Mr. Rumsfeld had been the administration's most outspoken critic of the treaty. 
It was Mr. Rumsfeld, who on that Saturday afternoon in Moscow described to President Putin a broad program of American missile defense testing in the air, space, at sea, and from a new base under construction in Alaska.
Mr. Putin objected, saying, "You want such flexibility that you are asking to effectively to gut the treaty," according to a senior administration official who participated. 
John R. Bolton, the undersecretary of state for arms control, who accompanied Mr. Rumsfeld, interjected that he agreed with the Russian interpretation. Mr. Bolton said the United States was "asking for the ability to test" in a manner that was completely "unrestrained by the treaty."
At that point, Mr. Putin asserted that as a lawyer, he viewed the American demand as overly broad with "too much latitude." He said such an interpretation was not acceptable to Moscow. 
"Well, then," Mr. Rumsfeld said, "we will be giving you notification of unilateral withdrawal from the treaty."
Still, there was another attempt to brief top Russian military officials, this time in New York a week later during a meeting of the United Nations General Assembly. American officials described in great detail the tests they had in mind. The Russian officials, according to American accounts, were somewhat stunned by the scale of the testing program, noting that they were completely out of the treaty's bounds.
"Basically what the Russians figured out was that this was a serious testing program to develop missile defenses and that wasn't going to work within an ABM treaty designed to prevent it," one senior State Department official said.
But White House officials held out a sliver of hope that, once they sat down together a few days later at the White House, Mr. Bush and Mr. Putin could work out an accord.
Their aides had left an open space in their draft joint statement that they hoped could be filled with a breakthrough reached by the two leaders. A breakthrough still seemed possible based on their public statements.
But it was a mirage. Neither Mr. Putin nor Mr. Bush offered any new ideas that morning, and during lunch, their senior staffs jammed into a cramped room in the basement of the White House to hastily draft a statement that conveyed a sense of progress on strategic talks when, in fact, none had occurred. 
"We had not reached an agreement," said one official in the room. Moments later, the two president stepped into the East Room with nothing to announce about missile defenses, and over the next two days at Mr. Bush's ranch in Crawford, Texas, they barely discussed the subject. 
Secretary Powell, last week in Romania, told his Russian counterpart that the time was "very close" when the president would make a decision to unilaterally withdraw. Still, there was no progress as Secretary Powell flew to Moscow for a final session with Igor S. Ivanov, the Russian foreign minister.
On Friday, Mr. Bush called Mr. Putin and told him the United States would withdraw this week. 
"It is absolutely the case that this would have been a lot harder to do eight months ago than today, because the president took the time to build the relationship with Russia," a senior administration official said. 
That will depend on the Russian reaction, which will have the greatest effect on how the rest of the world judges the wisdom of Mr. Bush's choice.

HEADLINE: American Express Will Cut Up to 6,500 From Payroll 

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The American Express Company, which has laid off 7,700 employees this year, said yesterday that it planned to eliminate an additional 5,500 to 6,500 jobs. To cover severance and related expenses, the company plans to take a pretax charge of $240 million to $280 million in the fourth quarter. 
 Michael O'Neill, an American Express spokesman, said that more than half of the job cuts would be in the company's travel business, which has slumped deeply since the Sept. 11 attacks. The remainder will be spread through the rest of the organization, he said. 
 "In October, travel sales were down about 46 percent from a year earlier," he said. "In November, sales were down about 38 percent."
At the start of the year, about one-third of the more than 88,000 people who worked for American Express were employed in its travel business. About one-third of the 7,700 positions that had already been eliminated were in the travel business, Mr. O'Neill said. 
With yesterday's cuts, American Express will have cut about 15 percent of its global work force. Pretax savings generated by the cuts are expected to be $230 million to $260 million next year and about $290 million to $315 million starting in 2003.
The American Express work force in the New York metropolitan area, which numbered about 4,000 employees at the start of the year, will be reduced proportionately to the overall cuts, Mr. O'Neill said. 
American Express said it expected some of the savings to bolster earnings in the form of improved operating-expense margins. The rest will be reinvested in high-growth businesses, the company said. 
Wall Street had been expecting additional cost cuts from American Express, and analysts said the company would lose little muscle by laying off people in the travel business. 
"There are still an awful lot of American Express travel offices," said Michael R. Hughes, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company. "The fixed costs have to be killing them, especially when they don't have all this travel revenue to hide behind. Younger, more Internet-oriented people have probably never been in an American Express travel agency." 
American Express has said it has shifted part of its travel business to the Internet, but will not specify how much. 
"The margins in the travel business have been under pressure for years," said Robert G. Hottensen, a specialty financial analyst at Goldman, Sachs. "The cuts that were announced today were expected and are in areas that are kind of logical."
Excluding the announced charge, American Express said it expected fourth-quarter earnings of 34 cents to 36 cents a share, less than the 40 cents a share expected by analysts. 
Credit card billings have also slumped since Sept. 11, American Express said, but the pace of the decline has slowed. 
Billed business volumes were down 14 percent in September, about 10 percent in October and about 6 percent last month, the company said. 
"These declines reflect continued weakness within the corporate travel and entertainment category," the company said in a statement, "offset in part by relatively stronger consumer spending. Credit trends are likely to show a modest deterioration, reflecting the increase in unemployment and the overall industry environment." 
Investors did not react harshly to the news. Shares of American Express, which have lost more than 38 percent of their value this year, fell 84 cents, to $33.42. 
With the expense cuts in place, most analysts said American Express was in good shape to deliver improved financial results next year, assuming the economic slump does not continue. 
"Through this restructuring and earlier ones, the company has lowered its cost base so that even if a recovery takes longer than people expect, they can deliver earnings growth in 2002," said Howard K. Mason, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.
