HEADLINE: Aetna Will Cut 6,000 Jobs, About a Sixth of the Work Force 

BYLINE:  By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Aetna Inc., the troubled health insurance giant, said yesterday that it would eliminate 6,000 jobs, or about one-sixth of its work force, and take a $125 million charge in the fourth quarter as it struggled to regain profitability.
 The job cuts -- including 360 in Hartford, Middletown and Windsor, Conn.; 444 in New Jersey; and 659 in Pennsylvania -- reflect Aetna's dwindling enrollment. It has lost 1.8 million health plan members this year, now at 17.5 million from 19.3 million in January, and it expects to lose more members as it raises rates and eliminates unprofitable Medicare and commercial health maintenance organizations. 
 Dr. John W. Rowe, Aetna's chairman and chief executive, said the cuts were needed to advance the company's turnaround plan, which he said was "emphasizing profitability over size." Health plan membership is expected "to decline materially" in 2002, he said, as Aetna raises prices to cover rising medical costs and as the withdrawals that it has already announced take effect.
As Aetna, based in Hartford, shrinks, it is expected to give up its position as the nation's largest health insurer to the UnitedHealth Group, based in Minnesota, which has 16.5 million members. 
James A. Lane, a health care analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, said the announcement implied that Aetna might lose as many as 2.1 million more members next year, dropping to 15.4 million.
Wall Street analysts expect Aetna to lose $1.65 to $1.93 a share this year, according to Thomson Financial/ First Call. Last month, Aetna reported an operating loss of $49.3 million, or 34 cents a share, in the third quarter as medical costs continued to increase faster than Aetna could pare expenses and raise premiums. The operating loss was $95.9 million, or 67 cents a share, in the second quarter. 
The cuts are "the right decision for the long term," said Lori Price, a health care analyst at J. P. Morgan Chase. But they are not likely to result in "visible signs of recovery" before the second half of next year, she said. 
Aetna has not made a financial forecast for 2002. A spokesman said it would probably make an earnings forecast in February when it reports its fourth-quarter results for 2001. Dr. Rowe has said that he expects the company to match the profitability of the industry leaders by the end of 2003.
Almost half the cuts, 2,700, are customer service workers, which may add to complaints from health plan members, Ms. Price said, despite a pledge by the company yesterday to maintain service levels. Aetna said it was also cutting 1,120 jobs from regional operations, including sales, and 580 jobs in other areas, including information technology and human resources. 
The company said that 4,400 jobs would be eliminated outright and that 1,600 others would be left unfilled as they become vacant. The 6,000 reduction comes on top of the elimination of 5,000 jobs, half through attrition, announced by Aetna last December. 
Todd Richter, an analyst at Banc of America Securities, said most managed care companies had slimmed down, usually through attrition, as the economy has slowed. "But the other companies did it while their business was growing, not while shrinking, like Aetna's business is," he said.
Shares of Aetna fell 30 cents, to $30.74.

HEADLINE: Rebuilding a Day at a Time; 
Law Firm Pushes 2 Steps Forward for Every Step Back

BYLINE:  By JOHN SCHWARTZ 

 BODY:
In the world before Sept. 11, John A. MacKinnon rated a spacious corner office -- not quite big enough for basketball, but enough to consider playing handball. That kind of luxury was not unusual for the partners at Sidley Austin Brown & Wood, a worldwide law firm that occupied most of floors 54 through 59 at 1 World Trade Center.
 His office today is as small and spare as a monk's cell. Gone are the artwork and family pictures, the bound "deal books" containing the papers from each project and the dozens of Lucite "deal cubes" commemorating them, all now part of the rubble being removed from ground zero. 
 Like the other 800 employees of the firm, he has been shoehorned into a building in Midtown Manhattan at 52nd Street and Third Avenue. Mr. MacKinnon says that a friend who knew the building well said: "I hope you got one of the nice corner offices." 
"I'm next door" to one, Mr. MacKinnon replied. The big corner office? Four lawyers work there.
The squeeze is only one of the changes that the people of Sidley Austin have been living with in the months since the terrorist attacks. They have resurrected work that had been scattered to the winds, striving to carry on for clients as if nothing had happened. To a remarkable degree, they have succeeded -- but with their exhilaration and dedication has come a toll in exhaustion and tension.
All the difficulties pale, though, beside the simple fact that all but one of them are still alive. With more than 600 people working at the World Trade Center, the firm lost a single employee, Rosemary Smith, a switchboard operator.
The Monday after the attack, nearly all 800 New York employees met in the ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Thomas R. Smith Jr., the vice chairman of the firm's management committee, opened the meeting with a simple statement: "I'm really glad to see all of you."
The burst of applause caught him by surprise. As the volume rose in a rolling crescendo, Mr. Smith, a steely lawyer and deal maker whose glare might just crack stone, bit his lip. Fighting tears, he, too, began to clap; the people of Sidley Austin rose to their feet, giving a standing ovation to survival itself.
The second-biggest wave of applause went to Charles W. Douglas, chairman of the firm's management committee. He told the crowd that Sidley Austin's insurance policies included tens of millions of dollars worth of coverage for damage to people and facilities, and $1.5 million for the art collection alone. On top of that, the insurance included a provision to recover the losses from interruption of business, even in case of terrorist attack. The policies, he told them, had been renewed on Sept. 1.
Most important, "the assets of the law firm are not the desks in the offices, the woodwork that's on the walls or the paintings that are hung in the corridors," he said. "The assets of the law firm are its people."
Sidley Austin's people say they return day after day to the struggle to rebuild their practice -- for many reasons. Because work itself can be therapeutic. Because that is what they do. And, ultimately, because they think they send a message with every contract and brief.
That's the way Michael L. Fitzgerald sees it. He was in charge of what would have been a garden-variety deal for the firm: a $300 million bond issue for the Mexican broadcaster Televisa. On Sept. 11, Mr. Fitzgerald had been on his way to work to wrap up the project when United Airlines Flight 175 hit some 20 floors above his office; a tire from the plane struck his cab. Shaken, he walked nine miles to his home on East 90th Street.
The next day, Mr. Fitzgerald sat at a conference table with representatives of the other law firms and companies working on the deal; he told them that what they were doing was bigger than an 8 percent senior bond issue due in 2011.
"I said it wasn't just our professional duty but our patriotic duty to get the job done," he recalled. Here, he explained, was a Mexican company coming to Wall Street to raise funds from investors around the world -- a prime example of the global economy at work. "This is something that the terrorists are trying to destroy," he told them. They worked frantically to recreate a foot-high stack of papers that had been drawn up over many weeks.
By the next day, they had pulled it all together: the paper, the lawyers on all sides, the bond underwriters at J. P. Morgan and Salomon Smith Barney, the executives at the bond rating agencies and the company to clear and record the transaction. Some people with offices in the shuttered financial district worked from home. Sidley Austin lawyers got help from colleagues in the firm's branches around the world.
And that afternoon they completed the deal -- on the day it had originally been scheduled to close. "A little bit later in the day than usual," Mr. Fitzgerald allowed.
"We had demonstrated," he added, "that the U.S. capital markets were still open for companies around the world."
That kind of drive astounded Byron Babbish, a senior staff lawyer for Chrysler, which had a deal of its own in the works that Sidley Austin helped to turn around within a week of the attack. He recalled asking Renwick D. Martin, a Sidley lawyer on the deal, whether he really wanted to go forward.
"I whispered to Ren, 'Are you guys up to this?' I didn't want to pressure them. We could probably put this off a day or two. Ren said: 'Let's do it. Anything is better than thinking about what happened.' "
Although the firm has continued to move forward, it has not been easy and the progress has not been steady. Those who returned are still dealing with trauma, and not just their own. Patricia Drake, the office services manager, could not return to work full time for a week because her 4-year-old son, John, could not bear to let her go. The family lives in Brooklyn, and Mrs. Drake's mother, who baby-sits during the day, often pointed across the East River to the World Trade Center towers and said: "Say hi to mommy! She's waving to you." With the towers gone, John asked, "Mommy, will your new building fall?"
Sidley Austin management has hired an outside counseling firm and is trying to be attune to the traumatic after-effects of the attack. "We're not looking for stiff upper lips here," Mr. Smith said.
John Feldkamp, executive director of the New York office, said that at the peak, 18 people found themselves unable to cope with going back to work. The number has dropped by half, he said, but he expects a few to opt eventually for disability payments.
Tensions remain high, and tempers occasionally flare. Dennis O'Donovan, who runs the firm's technical operations, said that when people snap at members of his staff, he tells his employees to "disappear for a half-hour -- take a breather." Still, he said: "It's good to see that our users are back to acting like the New York lawyers that they are. And, of course, I mean that in the nicest possible way."
The effects linger. John Connelly, the director of administration for the firm, spent precious time on Sept. 11 making sure that every Sidley Austin employee left the offices. He carried down emergency supplies with co-workers, getting out just a few minutes before the building collapsed. He is still haunted, he says, by the sight of firemen charging up the stairs as he was on the way down.
"I can go a week or two weeks," he said, "and be absolutely fine."
But on a recent outing with his wife to a street fair in Whippany, N.J., for instance, he saw T-shirts being sold to raise money for firefighters, police officers and emergency medical technicians. The back of the shirt bore this message: "The essence of America are its citizens who are willing to sacrifice their lives as guardians of this nation."
"I just read the T-shirt, and I broke down," he recalled. The shirt hangs in his closet now.
Can any good be wrestled from the horror of Sept. 11? Many at Sidley Austin think so. Sidney Rembert, who walked the floors of Sidley Austin the day of the attack with Mr. Connelly and a cafeteria worker, Kary Wippons, said that their experience had forged deep friendships. He and Mr. Wippons talk at least once a day, and his feelings toward Mr. Connelly -- who he believes saved his life -- are powerful.
"He's not a boss," said Mr. Rembert, 37, sitting in Mr. Connelly's office. "He's like a brother to me."
After getting others out, Mr. Connelly urged Mr. Rembert and Mr. Wippons down the stairs as the fire raged above. When the men reached the ground floor and began to sprint away from the building, they suddenly heard the unearthly roar of the tower's collapse. Still within the range of the falling debris, Mr. Rembert stopped and turned. "I had to see for myself," he said. "I just had to look." 
Mr. Connelly was already many yards ahead. He realized the others had not kept up, and turned. "Let's go!" he shouted. Mr. Rembert snapped out of his trance and ran to safety.
Mr. Connelly and Mr. Rembert treasure a group photo from a Yankees game in 2000. Mrs. Drake is on the far left of the photo, which sat on her desk for more than a year; she intended to make copies for the others. A recovery worker found it at ground zero and recognized a friend in the picture, which made its way back to Mrs. Drake. She has since made the copies.
For his part, Mr. Connelly, 35, has not sought therapy; he talks instead of the excitement he feels during the visits with his wife to the obstetrician to listen to the heartbeat of the child that he and his wife, Donna, are expecting in March. "The baby is therapy now," he said.
As he talked, Mr. Connelly fiddled with a paper clip, bending it slightly and bending it back perfectly into place, again and again. He showed far more concentration in the restoring than the bending.
The process of restoring Sidley Austin continues. The days since Sept. 11 have been filled with an intense hunt for new offices. Last week the firm announced it had finally found a new home, which it will move into next year: 11 floors in the Equitable building at 787 7th Avenue. "We are delighted and relieved and pleased all at once," said Thomas A. Cole, the chairman of the firm's executive committee.
Sidley Austin continues to plan for the future. Nancy L. Karen, chief information officer, said that while she was pleased with how well her network recovered, it could go more smoothly still. "We think we ought to be able to recover in less than a day next time," she said. Then she realized what she had said.
"God forbid!" she added quickly, and laughed nervously.

HEADLINE: Wrapped Tight for the Holidays; 
Shoppers Jam Stores and Form an Emotional Line

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
 "Stay on your right, you'll always be right," shouted L. E. Jones, the self-proclaimed mouthpiece of the security operation at F. A. O. Schwarz. He was trying to prevent pedestrian gridlock inside the toy store, at Fifth Avenue and 58th Street, where two gargantuan lines of shoppers converged. "Look at this traffic jam," he said. "It's a head-on collision." 
 Long lines, colder weather, shoulder-to-shoulder pedestrian traffic along Fifth Avenue and security guards turned foot-traffic monitors. Despite gloom's best efforts -- the still-healing scars from the terrorist attacks and the financial worries from the recession -- it finally feels like Christmas in New York City. 
And last Saturday in Midtown, the sidewalks and stores overflowed with potential customers, each with a personal philosophy about how to handle shopping in this oh-so-strange holiday after Sept. 11.
Many were determined to spend money. Erwin Baker, a retired publishing executive, calmly perched on a chair outside a dressing room at Bloomingdale's while his wife tried on clothes. 
"We're shopping, and we're keeping our life together," said Mr. Baker, 69, who lives on the Upper East Side. "The holidays just have more meaning."
His wife, Phyllis Fogelman, agreed.
"My office is 10 blocks north of the World Trade Center," she said. "We're not going overboard, but it hasn't stopped us."
Mark Testoni and his wife saved to make sure that their children would have a big Christmas bounty.
"We put a little bit more away than we did last year," said Mr. Testoni, 46, a state trooper from Connecticut. "These knuckleheads didn't stop us. They'll be a little bit more under the tree this year." 
Sophie Ciszewski, a registered nurse from Jersey City, brought her family to Manhattan for their yearly ritual of gazing at window displays. 
"I really haven't altered my Christmas," said Ms. Ciszewski, 42, said as she scoured the glass cases at Tiffany & Company for a silver bracelet. "I love New York. I wouldn't not come. The only bad thing is we can't take the PATH in." 
But there were those in the crowds who were thinking twice about lavish spending. Charles and Kathy Johnson, of Woodhaven, Queens, said they planned to buy most of their gifts from flea markets, vendors' stands and discount stores like Odd-Jobs Stores.
"You get more for your money," said Mr. Johnson, who had just bought several pieces of $5 boxed jewelry from a street vendor. "The prices are too inflated in department stores."
Although DeDe Guthartz and her husband, Matt Guthartz, were doing their last-minute Hanukkah shopping at retail stores, the couple said they were not buying as many gifts as they had in previous years.
"With the economy the way it is you have to be able to find things that don't break the bank, and you still want to find things that make everybody happy," said Mr. Guthartz, 33, a shoe designer.
Mrs. Guthartz said they were also putting more thought into the selection of gifts, instead of simply buying things, and making some presents by hand.
One difference in the stores this year, shoppers said, was that sales clerks were plentiful and seemed more perky and gracious.
At Crate and Barrel, a security guard greeted customers with holiday catalogs, while a line captain directed people to cashiers. An employee at Bloomingdale's invited shoppers to visit Santa Claus on the third floor.
At Tiffany's, employees turned the revolving door for patrons as they stepped inside. Customers noticed the extra effort.
"I think the retailers want you to spend money so they're being a lot nicer than they usually are," said Melissa Kelley, a secretary at American Airlines. "They're not taking anything for granted." 
Carolyn Conner, who owns an insurance agency in Hazlehurst, Ga., and comes to New York during the holidays every year, loved the new attitude.
"It's been wonderful," Mrs. Conner said, as she watched a gift wrapper at Saks Fifth Avenue tying neat bows around her packages. "From sales people on down, they're gracious and appreciative."
One sales clerk offered an explanation. "People are doing more window shopping, and if they're buying they're really looking at the price tag three times," said Kathleen Cecala, who works at Bloomingdale's. "I'm a makeup artist and we stay very busy. Now I have to work for business." She offered an onlooker a facial and free gifts with purchases.
Many of the tourists shopping on Saturday said they came to New York City because they thought it was one way they could help the city in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks. 
Robert and Eve Wall, of Greenville, S.C., came because Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's appeal for tourists impressed them. The couple's first stop after visiting ground zero was Saks.
"The only thing I asked her to do is not to try and save the whole city by herself," Mr. Wall said. 
Mrs. Wall smiled. "But you know," she said, "you only go around once."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Lucent Lowers Sales Forecast; Stocks Hit Hard

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
The stocks of Lucent Technologies and other big makers of communications equipment dived yesterday, as reports from Lucent and several other companies indicated that the telecommunications industry's long slump was continuing.
 Lucent, the largest maker of switches and other telecommunications gear, warned that its revenue for the current quarter would shrink by 35 percent, as low as $3.1 billion. 
 Lucent's continued decline is in many ways a result of the company's specific problems. And yet, the broader telecommunications industry has been in recession and Lucent's announcement was accompanied by grim statements yesterday from other companies. 
Qwest Communications, the big Denver-based phone company, said it would cut a further 7,000 jobs and reduce spending on equipment next year to $4.2 billion from an original goal of $5.5 billion. Ciena, a maker of fiber optic equipment and an important Lucent competitor, said revenue would decline by 30 to 40 percent this quarter.
But it was Lucent's warning that shook an industry that had mustered a rally of sorts in the last couple of months. Lucent said it expected a loss this quarter of 23 cents to 26 cents a share, substantially more than the 17 cent loss that had been expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. 
Lucent's stock fell 15 percent, to $6.52, yesterday, erasing more than a month of modest gains. Ciena's shares fell nearly 17 percent, to $14.94. Qwest was 2 percent lower, at $11.80. Other equipment makers caught in the downdraft included Nortel Networks, Lucent's largest competitor, which lost 11 percent, closing at $7.43. Juniper Networks fell 11 percent, to $21.18. 
Lucent's chief executive, Henry B. Schacht, said in an interview yesterday that his company's forecast, despite its bleakness, was a sign that the worst could be over for Lucent, which has already lost more than $16 billion this year.
"I think we have seen a bottom," Mr. Schacht said. "The best we can tell from our intelligence is that infrastructure spending around the world was very weak this quarter, but we expect our revenue to improve in the coming quarter."
Mr. Schacht declined to provide precise estimates, citing market uncertainties. But he reiterated previous predictions that Lucent would return to profitability in 2002. 
According to Mr. Schacht's earlier estimates, though, Lucent needs at least $4.75 billion in revenue each quarter to break even, which means it would have to increase sales by at least 50 percent from this quarter's level to reach his goal.
"It wouldn't be too herculean a task to grow revenue from this miserable quarter," said Ed Oppedisano, a telecommunications debt analyst at Deutsche Bank, "but meeting their previous goals will be tough. We think they're still burning through a lot of cash despite all the cost-cutting. There is a confluence of negative events that still hangs over Lucent."
The company's problems became evident last year when it disclosed that it could not meet ambitious sales targets. It became apparent that Lucent had offered generous loans to many of the start-ups that bought its products. When the financing for these companies dried up and larger customers grew increasingly cautious, Lucent's bad debts mounted and its sales went into decline. Around the same time, many of the investments it had made in dot-com start-ups went sour. 
Concern over Lucent's liquidity has eased with the recent completion of the sale of its fiber optics business to Furukawa Electric of Japan and CommScope for $2.3 billion. Lucent is thought to have used the proceeds to service debt financing provided by a group of banks earlier this year. Lucent declined to say exactly what it did with the cash.
Still, the unexpected revenue forecast for this quarter has renewed some analysts' concern about Lucent's ability to return to profitability even with a slimmed-down business structure. By the end of the first half of 2002, Lucent expects to have 57,000 to 62,000 employees, down from 150,000 in the middle of 2000. Mr. Schacht said he did not foresee further work force reductions.
It is not yet clear, though, how or when the global telecommunications market will recover, spurring a rise in Lucent's fortunes and those of other equipment makers and carriers. After the bursting of the technology bubble in the last year and a half, the big international phone companies that are Lucent's primary customers remain cautious in spending.
"The turbulence in the market right now points toward further consolidation and rationalization," Graham Wallace, chief executive of Cable and Wireless of Britain, said in an interview yesterday. "As far as we're concerned, our investment in infrastructure has peaked."
Salomon Smith Barney said in a report yesterday that it thought the main reasons for the decline in Lucent's revenue were the loss of market share in crucial products used in land line and wireless networks and in urban fiber optic systems. And Salomon predicted that spending by Lucent's customers would fall by an additional 30 percent in the coming quarter.
"We are not as convinced as Lucent that December should be the low point for sales," Alex Henderson, a Salomon analyst, said in the report. 
Mr. Schacht said the decline in sales was a result more of overall weakness in the market than erosion of market share.
Even as it seeks the comeback path, Lucent is also looking for a successor to Mr. Schacht, who came out of retirement more than a year ago to replace Richard A. McGinn.
One candidate who had been mentioned, Ben Verwaayen, accepted an offer on Wednesday to be chief executive of the BT Group, the renamed British Telecom. Mr. Verwaayen, who joined Lucent in 1997, had led Lucent's sales efforts in Europe and served as its vice chairman.
A Lucent spokeswoman said yesterday that the company was "still in the middle" of its search for Mr. Schacht's successor.

HEADLINE: '02 Forecast For Europe Is Darker 

BYLINE:  ByEDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Dec. 13 

 BODY:
The European Central Bank cut its forecast today for the European economy, predicting that growth in the 12-nation euro zone would be about 1 percent next year.
 The forecast provided more evidence that Europe was falling into a slump that is only slightly less pronounced than that in the United States. 
 It also comes less than three weeks before the arrival of euro notes and coins, which will begin replacing national currencies in 12 countries on Jan. 1. 
The euro changeover appears to be going fairly smoothly, with most banks already finished with the job of stocking up on euros. But consumers are extremely jittery about possible price increases, and overall consumer confidence has dropped sharply.
The European Central Bank said that growth in the 12-nation euro zone was likely to range from 0.7 percent to 1.7 percent next year and that the current stagnation was likely to persist at least several more months.
But the central bank also said that inflation was likely to drop well below 2 percent, which many economists say will allow the bank to reduce interest rates.
Jose Luis Alzola, an economist in London at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, said the forecast was roughly in line with forecasts by private banks.
The central bank's most surprising prediction, he said, was that the euro zone's economy would expand only 2.5 percent in 2003. That would be no more than the long-term average growth rate in Europe, despite the fact that growth is usually faster than normal as an economy bounces back from a slump or a recession.
Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank, provided its own bleak assessment today. Germany, which accounts for a third of the euro zone's economic output, is already technically in a recession, and many economists predict it will grow less than 1 percent next year.
"What we are missing the most right now is confidence and trust," said Ernst Welteke, the Bundesbank's president. German growth has been hurt by a slumping global demand for its exports, and domestic demand is too weak to pick up the slack, he said.
The only good news in today's assessments was the strong expectation that inflation would continue to decline. European inflation peaked at 3.4 percent in May, mostly because of rising oil and food prices, but it has now declined to about 2.4 percent.
"The message that I would draw from that is that we will are still going to see more rate cuts," said Mr. Alzola of Schroder Salomon Smith Barney.
Unemployment is rising again in Europe, with companies in manufacturing, telecommunications and technology reducing their work forces by thousands of people.
That poses big political problems for Germany's chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, who will face national elections next fall and who made unemployment the main issue in his political campaign last year.
But the bigger problem is that European budget deficits are rising sharply, and some countries are in danger of bumping against the limits set by the Stability and Growth Pact that governs all countries that adopted the euro.
Germany, which had pushed the hardest for rules limiting deficits to 3 percent of a country's gross domestic product, will see its own deficit more than double next year to 2.5 percent.
Though European leaders insist they still plan to adhere to goals for achieving balanced budgets the next several years, most private economists are extremely skeptical that they will succeed, given the growing pressure for fiscal stimulus to revive economic growth.

HEADLINE: A Boost for the Economy 

 BODY:
President Bush and Congressional leaders are finally getting serious about negotiating an agreement to stimulate the economy and provide help for those hit hardest by the recession. With only a few days left to reach an accord, Republicans have, little by little, acceded to Democratic demands to extend jobless payments and provide health benefits to those thrown out of work. The Democrats in turn have agreed to expand tax breaks for business. But the talks remain snagged on a few areas, the biggest of which is the Republicans' misguided insistence on income tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans. Dropping that demand could help produce a quick and welcome agreement. 
 In striving to reach a compromise, Republicans and Democrats need to remember a few key principles. The first is that the package, estimated to cost $100 billion in the next year, should not permanently widen the federal deficit. It should concentrate its benefits on the most needy Americans. It should provide a quick and real stimulus to the economy. Finally, and most important for New York, it should not only hold states harmless against tax code changes that reduce state tax revenues, it should provide financial relief to the states. 
 Unfortunately, the Republican strategy since Sept. 11 has been to lard the stimulus bill with unnecessary tax benefits to those least in need of help. Republicans are now trying to win over a handful of conservative Democrats who voted for Mr. Bush's tax cut earlier in the year. The administration should instead work for a package that wins broad bipartisan support.
Republicans do seem willing to drop their insistence on eliminating the corporate minimum tax, a step that would have awarded huge tax breaks to the nation's biggest businesses. But the G.O.P. still insists on accelerating the individual income tax cuts enacted earlier this year. That mostly helps families making $150,000 or more. It also widens the deficit, and is intended to lock in tax cuts for the rich. 
Though the Republicans have agreed to expand health benefits for the unemployed, their proposals favor young and healthy people at the expense of older and ill Americans. The health benefits plan needs to be restructured. Equally important, the tax breaks for expenses and depreciation, now endorsed by Democrats as well as Republicans, would cost the states $5 billion in lost revenue, because their taxes are based on federal law. The bill needs both to make up for that lost revenue and help New York and other states cope with their budget deficits. Otherwise, Congress would end up trying to stimulate the economy while forcing states to cut aid to schools, health care and social services. 
Congress members love to talk about their respect for state governments. They should back up their talk with money and include state aid, as George Pataki of New York and other governors are asking.

HEADLINE: Eleven And Counting 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Embarrassing but true: Just one month ago the James A. Baker III Institute presented Alan Greenspan with its Enron Prize. I'm not suggesting any impropriety; it was just another indication of how deeply the failed energy company was enmeshed with our ruling elite.
 And yet Mr. Greenspan also finds himself in Chapter 11. That is, the Fed has now cut interest rates 11 times this year, and has yet to see any results. What's going on? 
 One answer is that something has gone wrong with the monetary "transmission mechanism," the drive train that normally links the Fed's actions with the real economy. And one of the people who stripped the Fed's gears is Mr. Greenspan himself. 
The Fed's direct power over the economy is actually more limited than is widely appreciated. People often say that the Fed controls interest rates, but what it actually controls is only an interest rate, the rate in the overnight federal funds market. And this interest rate is, in itself, of very little economic importance. 
Normally, however, a fall in the federal funds rate indirectly affects financial variables that do matter; it leads to higher stock prices, a weaker dollar and -- above all -- lower long-term interest rates. Goldman Sachs economists have incorporated these variables into a "financial conditions index" that, they show, has historically done a very good job of predicting future economic performance. 
Based on past experience, you would have expected the Fed's dramatic rate cuts since January to lower the Goldman Sachs index by about five points -- enough to produce a roaring 2002. In fact, however, the index has fallen only about half a point, largely because long-term interest rates have not fallen at all. The Fed, in other words, is getting almost no bang for its bucks. Why?
Part of the explanation is self-defeating optimism. Bond traders continue to believe, despite mounting evidence to the contrary, that Mr. Greenspan is a magician -- that he will soon conjure up another dramatic boom, and will then raise interest rates to cool a red-hot economy. Ironically, this very belief helps keep long-term rates high, and thus ensures that no such boom seems imminent. 
And then there's the federal budget. Just months ago we were dazzled with projections of huge federal surpluses; there was enough money, the Bush administration insisted, to have a big tax cut, increase spending and still pay off the federal debt. But on Tuesday Paul O'Neill quietly asked Congress to raise the federal government's debt ceiling -- something he had previously said would not be necessary until 2008 at the earliest. 
Has the sudden return of federal deficits had an impact on long-term interest rates? Of course it has. Just a few months ago everyone expected the federal government to pay off its debt, drastically reducing the supply of bonds; now it turns out that it will actually be borrowing money. Inevitably this depresses bond prices, which is the same as raising long-term interest rates. So the rapid deterioration of federal finances is part of Mr. Greenspan's problem. (Has the negative impact of the tax cut on the economy via its effect on interest rates outweighed the positive effect on consumer spending? Yes, on any reasonable calculation.)
Mr. Greenspan, then, finds himself with much less ability to move the economy than anyone expected. And it's partly his own fault. After all, he did much to cultivate the mystique that now turns out to be a handicap. And let's not forget that he intervened decisively on behalf of large tax cuts back in January, when he urged Congress to prevent what he then saw as a great risk: that surpluses would be too large, and that the federal debt would be paid off too quickly.
It might be helpful if Mr. Greenspan would now say something to dampen self-defeating belief in a sudden economic turnaround. It would be even more helpful if he would concede, however indirectly, that he gave Congress bad advice last January; that might prepare the ground for an eventual return to fiscal responsibility. But the Fed chairman, who was quite willing to intervene in fiscal politics when that was helpful to the Bush administration, has gone oddly silent on the subject now that those surplus projections turn out to have been bad science fiction.
Maybe Mr. Greenspan deserved that Enron Prize after all.

HEADLINE: From Bush, 'Formal Notice' of End of Pact 

 BODY:
Following is an excerpt from the text of President Bush's remarks in the White House Rose Garden yesterday announcing that the United States would withdraw from the Antiballistic Missile Treaty, as provided by the White House:
 I've just concluded a meeting of my National Security Council. We reviewed what I discussed with my friend President Vladimir Putin over the course of many meetings, many months. And that is the need for America to move beyond the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty. 
 Today, I have given formal notice to Russia, in accordance with the treaty, that the United States of America is withdrawing from this almost 30-year-old treaty. I have concluded the ABM treaty hinders our government's ability to develop ways to protect our people from future terrorist or rogue-state missile attacks. 
The 1972 ABM treaty was signed by the United States and the Soviet Union at a much different time, in a vastly different world. One of the signatories, the Soviet Union, no longer exists. And neither does the hostility that once led both our countries to keep thousands of nuclear weapons on hair-trigger alert, pointed at each other. The grim theory was that neither side would launch a nuclear attack because it knew the other would respond, thereby destroying both.
Today, as the events of Sept. 11 made all too clear, the greatest threats to both our countries come not from each other, or other big powers in the world, but from terrorists who strike without warning, or rogue states who seek weapons of mass destruction.
We know that the terrorists, and some of those who support them, seek the ability to deliver death and destruction to our doorstep via missile. And we must have the freedom and the flexibility to develop effective defenses against those attacks. Defending the American people is my highest priority as commander in chief, and I cannot and will not allow the United States to remain in a treaty that prevents us from developing effective defenses.
At the same time, the United States and Russia have developed a new, much more hopeful and constructive relationship. We are moving to replace mutually assured destruction with mutual cooperation. Beginning in Ljubljana, and continuing in meetings in Genoa, Shanghai, Washington and Crawford, President Putin and I developed common ground for a new strategic relationship. Russia is in the midst of a transition to free markets and democracy. We are committed to forging strong economic ties between Russia and the United States, and new bonds between Russia and our partners in NATO. NATO has made clear its desire to identify and pursue opportunities for joint action at 20.
I look forward to visiting Moscow, to continue our discussions, as we seek a formal way to express a new strategic relationship that will last long beyond our individual administrations, providing a foundation for peace for the years to come.
We're already working closely together as the world rallies in the war against terrorism. I appreciate so much President Putin's important advice and cooperation as we fight to dismantle the Al Qaeda network in Afghanistan. I appreciate his commitment to reduce Russia's offensive nuclear weapons. I reiterate our pledge to reduce our own nuclear arsenal between 1,700 and 2,200 operationally deployed strategic nuclear weapons. President Putin and I have also agreed that my decision to withdraw from the treaty will not, in any way, undermine our new relationship or Russian security. As President Putin said in Crawford, we are on the path to a fundamentally different relationship. The cold war is long gone. Today we leave behind one of its last vestiges.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Oracle Hits Profit Goal, but Sales Are Far Off Estimates

BYLINE:  By CHRIS GAITHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 

 BODY:
The Oracle Corporation reported quarterly earnings today that matched Wall Street's expectations despite a sharp decline in its sales, especially in its software that runs enormous computer databases.
 Calling the quarter its toughest in a decade, Oracle said it never fully recovered from the Sept. 11 attacks, which happened two weeks into the company's second fiscal quarter. 
 The company, the world's second-largest software maker, said the terrorist attacks and the faltering economy caused sales for the quarter, which ended Nov. 30, to decline 11 percent from the comparable period last year.
Overall sales of software licenses, a crucial benchmark of the company's health, fell 27 percent, a much steeper decline than anticipated. Eighty percent of Oracle's license sales come from its database business. Oracle, based in Redwood Shores, Calif., said it did not expect business to grow rapidly again until the worldwide market recovers. 
"While we have lots of competitive challenges, it's more that we are all prisoners of the economy right now," Jeff Henley, the chief financial officer, said in an interview. But in a conference call with analysts, Mr. Henley said he expected a slight improvement in the coming months. For the current quarter, he predicted flat earnings and new license sales that would decline less sharply than during the last quarter. In the fourth quarter, he said, earnings should improve 2 or 3 cents a share from the year-earlier quarter, when Oracle reported a profit of 15 cents a share.
Oracle, more than competitors like I.B.M. and Microsoft, relied on booming business from dot-coms, which accounted for 15 percent of its North American sales last year. This year, Oracle is struggling to make up for the demise of those businesses.
For the second quarter, Oracle reported earnings of $549 million, or 10 cents a share, compared with $623 million, or 11 cents a share, during the second quarter last year, meeting estimates by the research firm Thomson Financial/First Call. Oracle's revenue declined 11 percent, to $2.36 billion from $2.66 billion. Analysts expected $2.5 billion.
Software licenses fell to $803 million, from $1.1 billion during the comparable period last year. The 27 percent plunge exceeded the warning from Lawrence J. Ellison, chief executive of Oracle, who said shortly after the Sept. 11 attacks that licenses could decline as much as 15 percent.
Oracle's core business, the database market, declined to $1.11 billion, from $1.25 billion in the period last year. In an interview, Mr. Henley conceded that Oracle might have taken its domination in the market for granted, but said customers had expressed satisfaction with its newest database software application, the 9i.
Mr. Ellison said many investors had asked him whether I.B.M. and Microsoft had taken market share from Oracle. "It's a resounding no," he said, adding that he thought the opposite was true.
James A. Moore, a managing director with Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown, said Oracle seemed to be holding its own against its competitors as the market slowed. His team of analysts recently surveyed Oracle customers and found that most were pleased with the 9i database. But while he praised the company for cutting costs to bolster profits, he warned that he saw little growth potential until budgets for information technology loosen.
Oracle is "basically a proxy for the health of I.T. spending," he said.
But Betsy Burton, an analyst with Gartner, a market research firm, said Oracle faces deeper challenges. She said major companies had told her that they refuse to let Oracle sales representatives in the door because of displeasure with their pricing and negotiating tactics. And Oracle has suffered some high-profile defections of top executives, including the recent resignation of a vice president, Jay Nussbaum.
Ms. Burton said Oracle had recently improved its pricing methods, but still had work to do to improve its credibility with customers.
"I don't purely see Oracle as a victim of the economy," Ms. Burton said. "They have their own housecleaning that they have to deal with."
The company reported its results after regular trading hours. In regular trading, Oracle fell 43 cents, or 3 percent, to $14.67. It fell as low as $14.30 in after-hours trading.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lawrence J. Ellison of Oracle at the Comdex show a month ago. (Bloomberg News)

HEADLINE: Beliefs; 
Tithing in a time of extra need. For a Manhattan couple, a 10th is a good round number.

BYLINE:  By Peter Steinfels

 BODY:
Among some devout religious believers, tithing -- giving 10 percent of one's income to charity -- is a duty commanded by God and strictly observed. But meet a Manhattan couple who do not tithe primarily out of religious obligation. They do it out of efficiency. 
 It is true that they chose that standard because they know that tithing is a practice rooted in the Bible. And they know that tithing has its parallels in other religious traditions, as well; in the zakat, for instance, the religious tax that is one of the five pillars of Islam, and in the alms-giving practices of Buddhism and Hinduism. 
 But for this couple, 10 percent is no more sacred a target than 9 or 11 percent, or 5 or 15 percent. Their point is simply that it is a venerable, reasonable target, and hewing to it gets the job done. 
Estimates of charitable giving vary depending on what methods are used, but the latest survey by the Independent Sector, a coalition of nonprofit and philanthropic organizations, reports that 89 percent of American households contributed to charity last year, giving an average of 3.2 percent of their income. Include the households that did not give at all, and the average drops to 2.6 percent. 
It is not surprising that the couple in question are unwilling to be named. Matters of personal finance are far more private these days than sex lives, it seems, especially for professional people like these, with careers (and modest reputations) in publishing, teaching, freelance writing, consulting and occasional public relations work. Ordinarily they would be deathly embarrassed to reveal anything about their tithing. They worry that appearing to boast of it could seriously complicate their work lives. 
Only the impression that this is a time of expanded need and a tightening economy, a time of unemployed shopkeepers in Lower Manhattan and children at death's door in Afghanistan, has loosened their tongues, in hopes of encouraging people to think about their giving habits. 
Both of them work. Their income varies from year to year; usually it is over $150,000 and under $200,000. They could probably earn more but have a weakness for jobs with various not-for-profit organizations. Their mortgage is paid off. Their children are through college. 
For years, they gave to charity on an ad hoc basis. They contributed regularly to their religious congregation. They responded to appeals after natural disasters. They supported several cultural activities with small sums and gave to human rights organizations and groups fighting hunger overseas. They wrote modest checks to help the disabled and those suffering from AIDS. 
But they never knew the total of each year's giving until income tax time. 
"And then I was usually embarrassed," the husband said. " 'Oh, we'll give more this year' -- that was my good intention -- but it always turned out to be pretty much the same."
"Naturally, I didn't think of us as rich," he continued, "but I was aware that from the perspective of the world's population or of all of human history, we were among the richest sliver of a fraction of people who ever lived.
"And then I knew the shocking data that shows that poor people are actually more generous in giving than the well-off," he said. 
A 1999 study by the Independent Sector did in fact suggest that low-income households tended to be significantly more generous than those wealthier, but other analysts disagree, contending that the organization's methodology misses large contributions from those in higher-income brackets.
The Manhattan couple have not stopped giving regularly to their congregation and writing checks to other charities as the spirit moves them. But about this time each year, they sit down, add up all these contributions and figure out how far short they have come to giving away 10 percent of their income. Usually it is at least several thousand dollars.
A few weeks ago, they began filling a manila folder with the appeals that flood the mail at this time of the year. Sometime in the next two weeks they will sit down again, pick and choose among those appeals and write checks until their tithing is done. 
"It's not terribly thoughtful," the husband admitted. "I have some ideas about which charities use their resources most effectively, and of course we have some causes that are closer to our hearts than others. But in the end a lot of this is guesswork." 
In the end, however, the checks do get written and the target sum is reached. The spouses share a discomfort with getting on anyone's list of big donors, so it's only $100 here, $200 there, maybe one or two $500 contributions. It adds up quickly, and if the couple need to delve a bit into their savings, they will do so, just as they would for any unavoidable financial obligation. 
The husband plays down the religious significance of this method. In fact, he suspects it could be spiritually deleterious. 
"At least I'm not using our tithing as a salve for, say, cutting corners ethically in my work," he said, "but I do worry about making it a substitute for more personal acts of helping." Self-described workaholics, the couple believe they give far too little of their time to hands-on service to those in need. 
"Tithing does not excuse this," the husband said. "I know that, but I still wonder whether at some level I take just enough satisfaction in our giving to let me off the hook." 
The process may be mechanical but it is also efficient. 
"I can't promise anybody that they'll be better because they do this," the husband said. "I doubt that I'm really a better person myself since we started. But becoming a better person is a lifetime job. Meanwhile, some people in need will have food in their bellies or medical aid at hand or counseling or an advocate to help them through their troubles. That should count for something."

HEADLINE: November Industrial Output Was Off but Beat Estimates 

BYLINE:  Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 

 BODY:
Industrial production dropped for the fourth consecutive month in November, the Federal Reserve said today, down 0.3 percent after a 0.9 percent October plunge.
 Analysts had expected a 0.7 percent decline. Industrial production has fallen 6.8 percent since its June 2000 peak -- the biggest decline since the 1981-82 recession. 
 The current recession's grip, meanwhile, kept consumer price inflation in check during November.
The Labor Department said today that falling food and energy costs kept the Consumer Price Index flat last month after a decline of 0.3 percent in October. Analysts had expected a 0.1 percent decline. Imported energy is cheaper primarily because the global economic slowdown has reduced demand.
Despite their overall grim tone, the reports from the government contained hints of the potential for recovery ahead. Analysts said that meant aggressive interest rate cuts by the Fed were probably near or at an end.
But costs for medical care and shelter as well as for 2002-model cars and tobacco all climbed, helping drive the core rate of inflation -- which excludes food and energy -- up 0.4 percent.
That was twice the 0.2 percent rise posted in October and the sharpest gain for any month since a matching 0.4 percent rise in January 1996.
Businesses ran at their slowest rate in 18 1/2 years, using only 74.7 percent of maximum operating capacity.
The automotive sector proved a bright spot, however, because auto production was ramped up to match sales driven by no-interest loans from automakers.
The Fed said vehicle assemblies rose to an 11.81 million annual rate from 10.70 million in October, the strongest clip since July.
A third report, from the Commerce Department, showed businesses were making solid progress at the start of the fourth quarter in paring down overstocked inventories -- a necessary condition before industrial output can reaccelerate.
Inventories dropped 1.4 percent in October, the biggest plunge since records were first kept in their current form in 1992, after a revised 0.6 percent decline in September. Overall business sales climbed a record 2.7 percent, with retailers posting strong gains on booming new-car sales.
"All of these reports can be taken as tentative signs that recession is at least slowing," said Robert Dederick, economic consultant to the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "These data also suggest that the need for, and desirability of, further monetary easing may be coming to an end."
Joel Naroff of Naroff Economic Advisors Inc. in Holland, Pa., said the C.P.I. report constituted a red flag for markets and for policy makers. Medical and other service costs will probably keep rising once the economic turnaround occurs, he added.
"Thus, while inflation remains tame for now, any indication that the economy is moving into an above-trend growth mode will almost certainly be met by aggressive Fed tightening," he said.

HEADLINE: Joblessness Is Fraying Istanbul's Social Fabric 

BYLINE:  By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Dec. 14 

 BODY:
Hands stuffed into empty pockets, Ali Adiguzel stood in the cold dusk, waiting for the muezzin's call and a free meal. 
 Like tens of thousands of urban Turks, he is unemployed. Mr. Adiguzel, a 32-year-old Ankara man, arrived here a month ago in search of work. Today he had come, along with about 2,000 other people, to a large tent in the city's main square, Taksim, to break his Ramadan fast. Private donations, customary during the holy month, paid for this evening's supper: soup, rice, vegetables, a four-inch hunk of bread. 
 "I don't feel happy about being here now," Mr. Adiguzel said. "I'm a young man. I'm healthy. I'm strong. I should be able to work." 
Every year during the Muslim holy month, which ends here on Sunday, the rich feed the poor at public tents like this one. But lines are twice as long at this tent this year, organizers say, echoing similar reports from other tents handing out the free meals. Demand for food packages has also risen.
The economic crisis that began in February has altered the social fabric of this city in many ways. Gasoline has become so unaffordable for many that traffic is noticeably lighter. Window bars have gone up to stave off thieves. A new brand of drive-by purse snatchings has shaken residents' sense of safety. 
Turkey, one of the United States' strongest allies in the Islamic world, is in the throes of what is widely regarded as the worst economic crisis in its modern history.
There is little confidence in the coalition government. Islamist political parties currently banned by the ruling elite in their striving to preserve modern Turkey's secular state are still important players because of the support they have traditionally enjoyed from the urban poor, whose ranks are now swelling.
Today, the International Monetary Fund announced that it had reached what it called an agreement in principle on a $10 billion package for Turkey, if the government carried out certain reforms. The new package would come on top of an existing $19 billion bailout from the fund.
On Wednesday, the Turkish Parliament passed a budget with tight spending limits designed to comply in advance with the fund's demands.
In some quarters, the I.M.F. aid is seen as a reward for support of the American-led war in Afghanistan. (Turkey was the first Muslim-majority nation to offer troops.)
"Sept. 11 was a blessing for Turkey," said Mensur Akgun, an international relations professor at Kultur University in Istanbul. "We were luckier than Argentina," he added, referring to that nation's efforts to stave off default on its much larger debt, and the fund's refusal so far to extend extra loans.
Others are less cynical, noting that Turkey, which fought armed insurgents of the Kurdish minority for 15 years until a cease-fire in 1999, has its own reasons to join the fight against terrorism.
"Of course we wanted support in the I.M.F. or wherever," said Cem Duna, a former diplomat who is now an investment consultant. "But our own efforts to combat terrorism were no less an element than anything else." 
For their part, I.M.F. officials have said the loan package had nothing to do with Turkey's new geopolitical role. 
Word of the I.M.F. loan has lifted the Turkish lira for the first time in months. Over the past year, the currency has lost approximately half its value against the dollar, and today stood at about 1,470,000 to the dollar. Inflation is in the high double digits, the economy is expected to shrink 8.5 percent this year, and per-capita annual income hovers around $2,200, the lowest since 1994.
The general aversion to air travel since the Sept. 11 attacks only sharpened the economic crunch by hitting tourism, one of few sectors that was still relatively flourishing.
In the working-class Istanbul district of Zeytinburnu the other day, Nevin Yakupoglu snaked through the narrow rain-soaked streets, trolling for the neediest of families.
As a volunteer with the municipal government's Ramadan charity program, Ms. Yakupoglu had in the trunk of her car sealed cardboard boxes of Ramadan aid: cans of tomato sauce, rice, a jar of marmalade, a big tin of olive oil.
In Hatice Cil's home, a two-room shanty built illegally years ago, Ms. Yakupoglu heard a familiar story. Mrs. Cil, 27, said her husband sold grilled liver on the street. Nowadays, business is so meager that the couple and their two small children barely survive. The landlord is owed a year's rent. They were behind on their bills. Yes, she said, they were all eating. But fruit was a luxury, and only for the children.
This year, what has surprised Ms. Yakupoglu most, she said, are the reluctant calls for help from ordinary working families -- people with jobs, education and ambition, unaccustomed to seeking charity. "It's a frightening thing to see," Ms. Yakupoglu said. 
Zeki Mergen, 27, a father of three who was standing in line at the tent in Taksim Square, waited with his TV-dinner tray in hand. He has a job, but the 250 million liras he earns each month as a construction worker -- roughly $180 -- is not nearly enough to cover basic expenses. "Each day is getting worse," Mr. Mergen said. "We miss yesterday."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In Taksim Square in Istanbul, the needy, whose ranks are growing, get free meals to break the Ramadan fast. (Staton R. Winter for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS; 
Shares Advance to End Week of Uneasiness for Investors

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks eked out gains after a late afternoon bounce yesterday, capping a week of losses amid increasing investor unease about the slipping economy and unrelenting bad news on corporate profits.
 "We've had a bit of profit taking after a pretty good couple of weeks, and the consensus had become that there would be a correction," said John Manley, chief equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney. "But now there's more upside to the market after all the selling." 
 Recent data have failed to offer a concrete picture of how and when the economy will emerge from recession. The market has also been buffeted by a steady procession of companies warning that their earnings have been deeply eroded by the economic slump, including blue-chip companies like Merck and American Express. 
"People are counting on a recovery very soon," said James Park, senior vice president of the brokerage firm of Brean Murray & Company. "Guidance and earnings are just telling you that it will take a little more time, but it's going to be a tough market."
The fourth-quarter confessional season -- when companies warn that results may miss forecasts -- heats up at the end of December. Analysts predict that profits for the Standard & Poor's 500 companies will sink by almost 19 percent, according to the research firm Thomson Financial/ First Call. That forecast could drop further as analysts cut their outlooks throughout the quarter.
After spending much of the session hovering near unchanged levels from Thursday's close, the blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average climbed 44.70 points, or 0.5 percent, to 9,811.15. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 3.69 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,123.07. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index advanced 6.66 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,953.17.
For the week, the Dow fell 2.4 percent, while the S.& P. 500 dropped 3 percent and the Nasdaq slid 3.4 percent.
The possibility that the war in Afghanistan could be drawing to a close gave traders reason to buy, analysts said. 
McDonald's helped support the blue-chip Dow and ignited a rally in restaurant shares by predicting growth next year, even as it said fourth-quarter U.S. sales would fall slightly. McDonald's climbed $1.16, to $26.80.
Amgen, the world's largest biotechnology company, fell $4.16, to $56.03, as investors seemingly gave a "thumbs down" to reports of a plan to buy the Immunex Corporation, an arthritis drug maker. Immunex lost $1.34, to $25.62.
Cisco Systems Inc. led technology issues higher and was the most actively traded stock on the Nasdaq. Shares of Cisco rose 38 cents, or 2 percent, to $19.39.
The software giant Oracle posted an earnings drop late Thursday, which helped curb gains in technology. Oracle shed 10 cents, to $14.57.
The company, the software vendor, posted earnings that were down from a year ago and called the last quarter "our toughest quarter in a decade." But Oracle said it expected profit growth to resume by the second quarter of next year.
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday after hints the economy might soon emerge from recession, with data showing a record drop in business inventories in October, while industrial production in November declined less than forecast.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 24/32 , to a price of 98 22/32 . The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.17 percent from 5.07 percent on Thursday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 31/32, to 97 2/32 . The bond's yield rose to 5.58 percent from 5.51 percent on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk; 
Congress Starts Looking for Plan to End Session

BYLINE:  By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 

 BODY:
The senators' cars were marshaled outside the Capitol on Thursday evening, looking like an officers' motor pool or perhaps the start of the Beltway 500. Senators had just finished saying how urgent it was to pass a farm bill or an insurance guarantee measure. Now it was time to take the last four-day weekend of the legislative year.
 The House had adjourned earlier and will return later on Tuesday than the Senate. 
 Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the majority leader, was asked whether he had a deadline for the end of this session of Congress, and the closest he would come to a commitment was, "Christmas Day, maybe." But to keep a quorum of senators in town past sundown on Friday, Dec. 21, would require the kind of magical powers that could be used instead to pass all the legislation that he wants.
The farm bill is the current business before the Senate. But Republicans have been stalling it. Democrats argue that it needs to be passed this year before a shaky economy overcomes the urge to spend billions on subsidies. For the same reason, the Bush administration would rather wait. This is one bill that could actually move faster after the four days off. Democrats hope farm state Republican senators will be pressured at home and vote to end the filibuster.
The only bill most of the public would consider urgent is the economic stimulus measure. Meetings, though not necessarily negotiations, will be held all weekend, with both sides continually weighing whether it is better to give in on an important issue or try to sell the public on the idea that it was the other guy's fault that nothing happened. 
House Republicans have already announced a plan to make Democrats look bad. If there is no deal, they will ram through a bill that has the backing of a few Senate Democrats and contend that they behaved in a bipartisan fashion, even though they know that it will not become law.
The insurance bill is an issue that almost everyone on Capitol Hill concedes is urgent. About 70 percent of business insurance policies expire on Dec. 31, and many insurers are refusing to provide coverage for future terrorist attacks. Banks and other lenders say they will not lend money for real estate or manufacturers without adequate insurance coverage. A credit crunch crippling a struggling economy is a serious forecast.
The stumbling block is Republican insistence that if insurers are to be protected, taxpayers should be, too, by limitations on lawyers' fees and liability payments. The insurance industry asked for no such provision, and most Democrats and trial lawyers regard it as an intolerable interference with the rights of plaintiffs. The House passed a bill with such provisions. But in the Senate, a filibuster would be guaranteed, unless Republicans promise not to raise the issue.
Three major appropriations bills remain to be voted on. The one that would cover the Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services and Education is pretty well wrapped up. The bill to cover foreign aid has one hurdle remaining, how to deal with family planning activities abroad. The military appropriations bill has a major fight over how much of a $20 billion add-on should go for the Pentagon, because the House and the administration want more than the Senate does.
Probably the only other must-pass legislation is a bill dealing with removing tax liabilities for this year and last year for victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and providing some tax relief for businesses in Lower Manhattan.
Mr. Daschle talked bravely today of merely recessing the Senate, subject to the call of the chair, and calling it back to work in mid-January to finish up things left undone this year. But January vacations have already been planned.
He may have better luck relying on history. Sometimes a remarkable amount of legislation -- some of it remarkable for its eventually discovered contents -- is passed in the last few days of a session. If a problem is really crucial, sometimes lawmakers drop their objections or look for a compromise.

HEADLINE: Fannie Mae Sets Mortgage Record 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 

 BODY:
Fannie Mae, the nation's leading buyer of home loans, said it had committed itself to buying a record $49 billion in mortgage loans in November as homeowners flocked to refinance and take out new loans. 
 The figure surpassed the previous high of $33.6 billion, which Fannie Mae agreed to buy in October. 
It bought $25 billion in loans last month. Its portfolio of loans and bonds grew by $3 billion, to $696 billion, for a 4.8 percent annualized growth rate, the slowest this year as refinancing spurred the liquidation of $21 billion in loans. 
 Fannie Mae is benefiting from a lending boom that has taken place as the Federal Reserve repeatedly cut interest rates this year and the 30-year mortgage rate slipped to a record low of 6.45 percent during the week of Nov. 9. Some analysts expect lending to top $2 trillion this year, beating 1998's record of $ l.5 trillion. 
"The mortgage purchase volume is going to stay high a couple of months after refinancing slows down," said Makiko Coakley, an analyst at Lehman Brothers. 
The lending boom has created a backlog of mortgage applications and the industry is "pushing the big volume into next year," said Mr. Coakley.
"I'm trying to get a mortgage myself," he said, "and it's really, really slow."
Earlier this week, the Fed cut its overnight lending rate between banks for the 11th time this year, to a 40-year low of 1.75 percent.

HEADLINE: Delivering Hope By Another Route; 
H.I.V. Activists Collect Drugs For the Needy Outside the U.S.

BYLINE:  By JENNY HOLLAND

 BODY:
It started when a stranger asked for help. 
 A woman walked into Jesus Aguais's office at St. Vincent's Manhattan Hospital in the fall of 1996. She had traveled from Venezuela because her son and daughter-in-law had tested positive for H.I.V., she said, and she had sold everything, including her burial plot, to come to the United States for medicine. The drugs they needed for survival cost $1,000 per month. 
 Her story gave him an idea. Mr. Aguais, an AIDS educator at St. Vincent's and an H.I.V. activist, had been collecting surplus medication from friends and storing it, but until then, he said, he was unsure what to do with it. 
"Who makes $1,000 a month in South America?" he asked in an interview. "I had to get organized."
He started Aid for AIDS, which collects donated medication from across the United States and Canada, from various sources, including from people with H.I.V. who change prescriptions, stop taking a certain medication, or die. The drugs are inspected and then sent overseas to needy people with H.I.V. who would not otherwise have access to medications.
The medicine collected by Aid for AIDS comes from patients, social workers and doctors. The organization says it is now helping to keep alive 300 people from Ecuador to Ethiopia, through its shipments and efforts to find local health care. 
Aid for AIDS is small -- just three employees -- and most of its money comes from private donors. (It is a federally registered charitable group.) The group, whose office is on Greenwich Street in Manhattan, hopes to raise $100,000 at a fund-raiser on Monday at Latincollector, a gallery at 153 Hudson Street between Hubert and Laight Streets.
"With an overhead of just $150,000, we sent over $3.5 million worth of AIDS medication last year," Mr. Aguais said. "Now a lot of people have their eye on us." Although the program has been praised by the United Nations' AIDS organization and the World Bank, it has been operating in a legal gray area. According to the Food and Drug Administration, the program violates the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act, which forbids the delivery or receipt of drugs from any source other than the manufacturer, processor, packer or distributor. 
"There is no quality assurance once the medication has left the pharmacy," said Richard Klein, the H.I.V./AIDS program director at the F.D.A. "It's a humanitarian program, but there is no guarantee of the drugs' integrity."
While the F.D.A. questions the legality of drug recycling, it has not received any reports of tainted drugs or drugs that have lost their potency being processed through Aid for AIDS and has not tried to stop its work. But Mr. Klein said that it was unlikely that the agency would hear complaints since the recipients are outside its jurisdiction.
Aid for AIDS says the group is not breaking any laws. "This absolutely does not violate the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act," said Paul O'Dwyer, the lawyer representing Aid for AIDS. "They are not going to touch any medication if there is the possibility that it was adulterated." 
Aid for AIDS does not accept unsealed bottles of liquid medicine, organizers say, and each tablet and capsule is checked to ensure it has the pharmaceutical imprint. "These are very unique drugs," Mr. Aguais said. "If someone is going to do damage to them, they are going to have to own a lab."
While the group is aware that its drugs can end up on the black market, it is adamant that what it is doing is better than doing nothing. "You can never be totally sure, but this is about surviving," Mr. Aguais said. "We did what we needed to do in order to save lives." The organization keeps a three-month supply in stock for each person. There is a long waiting list to enroll, the group says, because it still has limited drug supplies.
Organizers say that they send medicine only to people whose T-cells -- a type of white blood cell -- are down to a count of 250. Aid for AIDS requires (and pays for) blood tests done in the recipients' home countries every six months to ensure that they are adhering to the treatment. Jaime Valencia, the clinical coordinator for Aid for AIDS, says that some packages of drugs are sent directly to patients and some to doctors, and that the group keeps in regular contact with both.
"These kinds of programs have to have really strict guidelines," Mr. Aguais said, because some of the drugs are toxic and the virus can become resistant to treatment if a person does not adhere to the regimen.
Even with the strict requirements, the medication from Aid for AIDS was a godsend for a Venezuelan family: Sandra Varela, 32; her husband, Americo Teijeiro, 39; and their 6-year-old son, Alejandro. They received drugs from Aid for AIDS in 1996, shortly after finding out that they were all H.I.V.-positive. Although the family is now receiving free medicines through a health insurance program administered by the Venezuelan government, Mr. Teijeiro said that the year they were helped by Aid for AIDS was critical.
"It meant life, basically," Mr. Teijeiro, a taxi driver, said in a phone call from Caracas. "We wouldn't be here today if it hadn't been for their help. I know our son wouldn't. He was born with the virus and he is doing great, going to school and leading a normal life."
The work done by Aid for AIDS has been called "a very important initiative" by Bertil Lindblad, deputy director at the New York office of the Joint United Nations Program on H.I.V./AIDS, known as Unaids. And the AIDS Education and Treatment Initiative has sent people to Aid for AIDS. The initiative is run by Hans Binswanger, an AIDS activist and director of the rural, social and environmental development program for Africa at the World Bank.
"In the U.S. and Canada there are six or seven groups that collect medication and send them to developing countries," Mr. Binswanger said. "Aid for AIDS is the biggest and the best."
Aid for AIDS just absorbed another group based in New York, Hope's Alive, that sends medication to an orphanage in Trinidad. To Nicole Guide, the founder of Hope's Alive, discarding or not using the surplus of medication in this country is part of a "culture of waste." 
"People would rather throw away food than send it to somebody who's starving," she said. "It's the same with medicine."
The concept of recycling and even sharing AIDS drugs is not new. Michael, an H.I.V.-positive man who has donated medication to Aid for AIDS and who asked that his last name not be used, said that it is not uncommon for friends to share pills informally with someone who does not have medication handy. 
Another man who has donated drugs to Aid for AIDS said he was motivated by gratitude. "I've been very fortunate in receiving the care that I need," said Bill, who also asked that his last name not be used. "This is a good way to help others and pay back the good fortune I've had."
Aid for AIDS's work has not attracted a lot of attention from the pharmaceutical and insurance industries. Paul Macielak, president of the New York Health Plan Association, a trade organization representing managed care companies, said that drug recycling seemed to be unknown from the group's standpoint. "Health plans are not able to recoup pills or medication from members," he said. "We have no significant involvement with the issue."
One doctor who volunteers for Hope's Alive said he understands that drug regulations are vital to protect people in the United States, but he said that the situation in poor countries is so dire that the same rules should not apply.
The doctor, Dr. Edward L. Handelsman, an assistant professor of pediatrics at State University of New York Downstate Medical Center and Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn, travels to Trinidad for Hope's Alive to monitor children's progress. "The F.D.A.'s opinion notwithstanding, the simple fact is without the medicine, the children will die -- some right now, some later," Dr. Handelsman said. "Either you do it in a roundabout way, or you don't do it."
