HEADLINE: Top Official, But No Others, To Get Raise At Port Agency 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS

 BODY:
At a time when the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is projecting a 23 percent drop in operating revenue, the governors of the two states have approved a 22 percent salary increase for the executive director's post. 
 But Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday rejected a Port Authority consultant's suggestion that salaries be raised anywhere from 10 percent to 40 percent for some of the agency's senior management staff and department heads. 
 "We are facing very difficult economic times," Mr. Pataki said in a statement. "We are facing the need for all of us to tighten our belts, and to consider massive pay raises like this at the Port Authority now is wrong. It's not going to happen." 
Joseph J. Seymour, who was approved as the agency's executive director on Thursday, will make 22 percent more than his predecessor, agency officials said yesterday. Mr. Seymour will receive $225,000 a year, as opposed to the $185,000 starting salary paid since March to Neil D. Levin, who died in the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.
Unlike other salaries at the authority, which are set by the agency's 12-member board, the executive director's pay level is the prerogative of New York's governor, who by tradition gets to name the bistate agency's top staff member, said the board's vice chairman, Charles A. Gargano. The salary must then be approved by the New Jersey governor, who by tradition defers to his New York counterpart, Mr. Gargano said. "That was the level of salary that Joe Seymour wanted, and the governor agreed to it because he needed him for this position at this critical time for the Port Authority after Sept. 11," Mr. Gargano said.
The terror attack struck a financial and physical blow to the authority, whose headquarters were in the trade center. The board is considering deferring about $250 million worth of projects in a $9.5 billion, five-year capital plan adopted a year ago.
Even as the two governors were approving a raise for the executive director, Governor Pataki put the brakes on a consultant's report suggesting raises for members of the senior management staff and department heads. A board committee had commissioned the report, which listed comparable salaries in the private sector for many of the authority's senior management posts. 
Mr. Gargano said that however much those raises might be deserved, Governor Pataki -- and, he believed, Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco of New Jersey -- would not allow such increases at this time.
Tom Wilson, a spokesman for the acting governor, said he thought that Mr. DiFrancesco would favor the staff increases. 
Sean Walsh, a spokesman for New Jersey's governor-elect, James E. McGreevey, said he had not reviewed any of the salary studies for the top officials among the agency's 7,200 employees.
Still, Mr. Gargano and Lewis M. Eisenberg -- who stepped down this week as authority chairman but remains as a board member -- said that raises for top staff members were overdue, and would have to be granted at some point to keep the agency competitive in attracting and keeping qualified people. Mr. Eisenberg said that most of the agency's managers, even in this economy, could probably make "a whole lot more" if they took comparable private-sector jobs. 
Any raises for staff members must be recommended by the executive director to the board. They must then be approved by the board in a public session, and ultimately by both governors, who traditionally signal approval or disapproval by signing or not signing the minutes of board meetings at which particular actions are taken.
Mr. Seymour's salary, however, received no such public vote or discussion because it was set by Governor Pataki, Mr. Gargano said. It was impossible to determine the salary figure from the various resolutions, motions and calendar items that the board voted on Thursday.
Mr. Gargano said that the same salary study authorized by the board for senior management salaries recommended a salary of $225,000 to $250,000 for the executive director. "And the governor chose the lower end of that range," he said.
The other study recommendations that were put on hold included new salaries of $175,000 to $200,000 for those now earning between $140,000 and $160,000, and $150,000 to $175,000 for those now earning $135,000 to $145,000.
Mr. Eisenberg said the salary studies had been authorized months ago but had lain dormant as the agency coped with other, more pressing matters and was then enveloped by the Sept. 11 crisis.

HEADLINE: The Familiar and the Cozy Are Much in Favor This Year 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

DATELINE: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 8 

 BODY:
Just an hour after the gargantuan Mall of America opened here on this cold Saturday morning, customers were already bumping into each other amid the retro-print chenille robes and pajamas in Francoise Shirley's shop here.
 Ever since the Sept. 11 attacks, shoppers have been clamoring for comforting apparel, said Ms. Shirley, the owner of the store, Sleepyheads.com. She has been taking in $5,000 to $6,000 a day, several times what she needs to break even, and has already surpassed her fourth-quarter sales target. 
 And the same yearning for old-fashioned things, including toys from the past, is providing one of the few comforts for retailers during this recession-bound holiday season.
Indeed, while Ms. Shirley's store here was bustling, shops with familiar names like Ann Taylor and Casual Corner were practically empty inside the sprawling mall, the largest in the country. Even the big anchor department stores, including Nordstrom and Macy's, could be easily traversed during what is normally one of the busiest shopping days of the year, reflecting a trend toward specialty shopping that mall officials have seen develop all year -- and which is being echoed in retail sales nationwide.
In a typical year, the Mall of America has 35 million visitors, or as many as 900,000 a week during heavy shopping times like Christmas. Figures for the current shopping season are not yet available.
"I don't think it's crowded at all," said Mary Windmiller, a frequent visitor to the Mall of America who drove two and a half hours from Wausau, Wis., and was pleased that she did not have to fight for a parking spot and could simply stand quietly for a while, listening to folk music from a balcony above a stage. Even the line for Santa was manageable, with space available in the area cordoned off for visits.
Among the mall's 520 stores, those that sell the unique or offer tradition and patriotism are thriving this season, according to Maureen Cahill, the mall's spokeswoman. But business appears to be off at places where merchandise is similar to what customers can already find in their homes.
The 78-acre mall typically draws 40 percent of its customers from around the country, but its reach extended even further than usual last Saturday, thanks to deeply discounted fares offered by Northwest Airlines for its annual "Shop 'Til You Drop" promotion. This is the 10th holiday season that Northwest has offered the fares, which start as low as $99 for a round-trip ticket from places like Grand Rapids, Mich., and Philadelphia.
In past years, between 1,000 and 2,000 people have taken part, a Northwest spokesman said. He did not provide figures for current flights. This was the first time Northwest had offered the deal since Sept. 11.
Security measures added since airports reopened after the attacks meant a pre-dawn journey for Tricia Anne Alexander of Temperance, Mich., who joined her mother and her aunt, Linda McMahon of Toledo, Ohio, on a flight from Detroit. They arrived at 4:45 a.m., before the security checkpoints opened, for their 7:05 a.m. takeoff.
Mrs. McMahon, making her first plane trip since Sept. 11, said she felt "apprehensive." But Ms. Alexander, armed with a list of 21 stores she hoped to visit, was ready to go. "I have six hours," Ms. Alexander said. "I have this down to a science."
The flight was uneventful, and by midday, the women were taking a break at a coffee bar. Mrs. McMahon and Sharon Alexander showed off bracelets featuring the American flag in rhinestones. Then, all three headed off for more shopping before their 8 p.m. return flight.
To draw more shoppers, the mall's operators are trying to expand offerings that seem particularly popular this year. They cleared out a store they had operated in a prime location to sell Mall of America souvenirs and offered the space, including the lights and fixtures, to Ms. Shirley so she could open a second shop. The new store is called Hollywood Legends and features an entire section inspired by Lucille Ball. 
Just one floor above, another new shop, the 911 Marketplace, was doing a brisk business selling New York Fire Department T-shirts and baseball caps, as well as coffee mugs, key chains, toys and other related gifts.
Sean Moriarty and Tom McDonough, two local firefighters, opened 911 Marketplace -- originally meant to refer only to the emergency phone number -- for business last summer before the terrorist attacks. The store was already deluged with customers when Sept. 11 turned police, fire and emergency workers into national heroes. Now, customers wait in the hallway outside until there is room to browse.
"It's really something," Mr. Moriarty said.
At the mall's Nordstrom store, however, the atmosphere was more subdued. The main floor at Nordstrom at first appeared jam packed, but the traffic was helped by a dozen black-clad Estee Lauder makeup artists offering free makeovers, and by other cosmeticians giving out mini-manicures.
Upstairs on the apparel floors, the aisles were lightly traveled. Entire departments, including gifts, were empty, and even at the height of the lunch hour, it was easy to get a seat in the cafe. Sales clerks rushed to help customers, and markdowns abounded -- 25 percent, 40 percent and even 50 percent off on names like Ellen Tracy, Ralph Lauren and Nordstrom's own Caslon line.
Nordstrom would not comment on sales of any individual store.
Tracee Aube, the owner of the Afternoon, a gift shop that has been open since 1994, recalls the entire mall being that quiet during the fall. The mall was evacuated on Sept. 11. Business remained tepid through October, particularly on Halloween, when an Internet rumor cited the mall for an attack. All this caused Ms. Aube to fear for the Christmas season.
But in recent weeks, her shop has been bustling once again, with customers spending, on average, about $50 apiece. Pointing to a wall of blown-glass ornaments, Ms. Aube said: "We can move faster than Target or Dayton's. That's the only thing that saves us."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Finance Minister Of Argentina Resigns Post

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
The uncertainty of Argentina's precarious financial situation deepened yesterday when Daniel Marx, the finance secretary, resigned.
 Mr. Marx stepped down as Argentina paid $700 million in short-term debt owed to local banks by forcing pension funds to buy government bonds. The payment was the first of two in December that would hold off a default on its public debt.. Argentina has been struggling to contain its public debt, now totaling about $132 billion, after four years of recession. 
 In discussing his decision, Mr. Marx suggested that it was time for someone else to oversee the government's negotiations with its creditors. "It's a cycle," he said. "I had also some personal things to deal with."
Mr. Marx added that he would still work with the government, in a capacity that had not yet been formalized. "I agreed to continue to work on the national debt issues for Argentina," he said.
In the last few weeks, working with the economy minister, Domingo Cavallo, Mr. Marx had been trying to persuade Argentina's foreign creditors to accept lower interest rates on existing debts. Domestic creditors already agreed, under some duress, to swap roughly $40 billion in obligations for new loans. Mr. Marx said that his foreign consultations had been proceeding "according to schedule."
There was no doubt, however, that Mr. Marx's job had recently become tougher. The International Monetary Fund decided last week to delay the release of $1.3 billion in aid, which is needed to cover a budget shortfall. During the last few months, political infighting has eroded the government's ability to adhere to the zero-deficit rule favored by the I.M.F. and promised by Mr. Cavallo.
Mr. Marx's resignation also followed a national strike on Thursday by union members, shopkeepers and unemployed workers, which brought the country close to a standstill. The strikers were protesting federal budget cuts and restrictions on withdrawals from bank accounts.
Mr. Cavallo instituted the banking controls on Dec. 1 to stave off a run on Argentina's banks. Depositors who worried that the peso's fixed one-to-one exchange rate with the dollar was about to be broken by a devaluation, despite Mr. Cavallo's insistence to the contrary, were withdrawing dollars from bank accounts. A sudden, widespread drop in deposits threatened to choke economic activity and worsen the country's financial troubles.
The controls were a sign of the financial pressures on Argentina, according to Vincent Truglia, an analyst at Moody's. "They were indicative of the very difficult situation that the country was in and continues to be in," he said.
Mr. Marx declined to say in an interview whether he had favored imposing the restrictions.
Mr. Marx became finance secretary in December 1999 after a career in private finance and a stint on the board of Argentina's central bank. The finance secretary is effectively the economy minister's deputy, with specific responsibility for the public debt.
Mr. Marx kept his job through the resignation and replacement of two economy ministers, Jose Luis Machinea and Ricardo Lopez-Murphy, and the return of Mr. Cavallo to government. His technical knowledge and strong relations with Argentina's foreign creditors won him considerable respect at home and abroad.
Mr. Marx is known for favoring market-based rather than regulatory solutions to economic problems, a reputation shared by Julio Dreizzen, who resigned as finance undersecretary on Oct. 29, citing personal reasons.
Mr. Marx's departure may pave the way for Miguel Kiguel, an economist from the Justicialist opposition party, to join Mr. Cavallo's team. On Thursday, Argentina's president, Fernando de la Rua, met with Carlos Saul Menem, a former president and leader of the Justicialists, to discuss economic strategy. The appointment of Mr. Kiguel to succeed Mr. Marx may be seen as a way to bring the Justicialists into Mr. De La Rua's ruling coalition, forming a sort of national unity government to address the economy.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 19, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A headline in Business Day on Saturday about the resignation of Daniel Marx, a senior Argentine government official, misstated his title. Mr. Marx holds the post of finance secretary, which is below cabinet level. He is not finance minister; Argentina does not have a finance ministry.
Because of editing errors, a biographical sketch on Saturday about two family members who worked together at Cantor Fitzgerald and died at the World Trade Center misspelled their surname in some copies and at one point misstated their relationship. They were Frederick J. and Michele L. Hoffmann, not Hoffman -- father and daughter, not uncle and niece.

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Europe: Sweden: Electrolux Cuts More Jobs 

BYLINE:  By Suzanne Kapner (NYT) 

 BODY:
 Electrolux, the Swedish appliance maker, said it would eliminate a further 2,800 jobs, making the total number of staff reductions this year 6,900, or 8 percent of its work force. Electrolux, the maker of Frigidaire refrigerators and Eureka vacuum cleaners, said it might cut more jobs next year if the economy did not improve. Electrolux shares fell 96 cents and closed at $28.89. The company said it would take a 1.5 billion kronor ($142 million) charge to account for the job reductions. The company said it expected to save 1.4 billion kronor by the end of 2003, after which it would save 940 million kronor a year by operating with less staff. Other appliance makers have struggled as consumers delay large purchases in the face of rising unemployment and an economic slowdown. Moulinex S.A. of France was liquidated in October, and Maytag of the United States said last week that it would eliminate 200 jobs.
 Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

HEADLINE: Grounded by an Income Gap 

BYLINE:  By ALEXANDER STILLE 

 BODY:
For 30 years the gap between the richest Americans and everyone else has been growing so much that the level of inequality is higher than in any other industrialized nation.
 What no one can quite figure out, though, is why, or even whether anything should be done about it. 
 "Why there has been increasing inequality in this country has been one of the big puzzles in our field and has absorbed a lot of intellectual effort," said Martin Feldstein, a professor of economics at Harvard University and the chairman of President Ronald Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers. "But if you ask me whether we should worry about the fact that some people on Wall Street and basketball players are making a lot of money, I say no."
With inequality growing through out the industrialized world, Mr. Feldstein, like many economists, has come to see inequality as a basic feature of the new high-tech economic scene, the natural consequence of an economy that has begun to reward talent, skills, education and entrepreneurial risk with increasing efficiency. 
"There is no doubt that market forces have spoken in favor of more inequality," said Richard Freeman, a professor of economics at Harvard. Just look at the figures. Most of the incredible wealth generated during the 1990's boom went to the richest of the rich. "Forty-seven percent of the total real income gain between 1983 and 1998 accrued to the top 1 percent of income recipients, 42 percent went to the next 19 percent, and 12 percent accrued to the bottom 80 percent," writes Edward Wolff, an economics professor at New York University in a new edition of his book "Top Heavy" (New Press), about growing economic inequality.
In the 90's only the people at the very top and very bottom made any real improvement. Wages for full-time male workers, for example, have grown only 1.3 percent since 1989. The richest 10 percent of American households, economists point out, have 34.5 percent more financial wealth than the average family. These changes have persisted through Democratic and Republican administrations and began at the same time in Britain, even before Margaret Thatcher's market-oriented policies, Mr. Wolff said, indicating that they are not simply the product of economic policy but reflect deep structural changes in the economy. The leading hypotheses are technological advances, increases in trade and imports, growing immigration and declining union membership.
But where economists split is whether anything should be done about the divide. "The question is whether you lean against the wind of the market to try to preserve decent living standards for working and poor people," Mr. Freeman said. "Europe and Japan are leaning against the wind."
Many liberal economists say the United States should, too. 
Levels of equality and inequality play a large role in people's sense of satisfaction or dissatisfaction with their lot in life, said Ronald Inglehart, a sociology professor at the University of Michigan, who for 30 years has been conducting something called the World Values Survey. "Interestingly the levels of dissatisfaction are highest in both the most equal countries in the world, the Communist countries or those that have just emerged from Communism, and also those with very high levels of inequality," he said. 
The only way you can achieve total equality is through coercion, he said, which makes people feel they have no control over their lives and no way to benefit from their labor. But highly unequal, extremely stratified societies, where people feel crushed by the economic power of others, breed similar dissatisfaction.
Conservative economists insist that the problem with the new economy is not that some people make a lot of money but a series of noneconomic factors that are holding others back. "The problem is not inequality but poverty," Mr. Feldstein said. Poor education, the breakdown of the family and what he terms "low cognitive ability," together, may be responsible for holding back many of those mired in persistent poverty. He added that some poor people may choose not to work as hard as investment bankers working 70 hours a week, or to skip school, and so earn less.
James Heckman, a professor of economics at the University of Chicago, argued: "We have to look at some of the basic structural reasons why we have so many unskilled, poorly educated, poorly motivated people in our society. One of the most amazing phenomena of recent years is why so many people, especially minorities, have not responded to the opportunities out there. There has been a big increase in demand for skills, educated blacks have done very well, but college completion rates have leveled off."
Perhaps never before, economists say, has education been such an important factor in predicting future earnings. Marvin Kosters, a senior economist with the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative think tank in Washington, said the earning advantage for those who attend college over those who do not has doubled to about 60 percent from 30 percent in the early 1970's. 
"Even finishing high school improves your income by about 30 percent," Mr. Heckman said. 
One of the biggest reasons people fail to finish school is teenage pregnancy and the strains of running a household as a single parent. "More than 40 percent of all female-headed families with children had incomes below the poverty line," Prof. Marc L. Miringoff of Fordham University writes in his recent book, "The Social Health of the Nation" (Oxford University Press).
Meanwhile the high school dropout rate for Hispanics -- the fastest-growing ethnic group in the country -- remains more than 30 percent, more than twice that of blacks and nearly three times that of non-Latino whites. 
David Ellwood, a liberal economist who does worry about inequality, said this may be just the beginning of a trend toward greater inequality. "We are in the midst of two huge demographic changes," he said. "In the last 20 years our prime labor force -- people between 25 and 54 -- grew by 20 million people, 16 million of them native born. In the next 20 years the growth of that labor force will be zero, all growth will be by immigrants and by older workers." Immigrants generally do not have the same education and language skills as native-born workers, he said, meaning that there will be fewer skilled laborers and more unskilled, accentuating the income gap.
"The other thing that is happening is a slowdown in the upgrading of the work force," Mr. Ellwood added. "Baby boomers got a lot more education than their parents. There was a lot of upgrading in skills. But the children of baby boomers are not more educated than their parents. This would mean that wage inequality could increase rapidly." 
Economists like Mr. Feldstein consider the level of inequality -- measured by something economists call the Gini quotient -- irrelevant. "If the stock market goes up, which we generally regard as a good thing, the Gini quotient may well go up, too, as stockholders get richer," he said. "If the stock market collapses and everyone gets poorer, the Gini quotient would go down. So I think that's the wrong way to focus the question." If one person's good fortune does not harm others, why should we worry? 
The problem, said Alan Krueger, an economist at Princeton University, is that Mr. Feldstein's analysis looks at money in the abstract. "There is a relationship between economic power and political power," he said, noting that as the income gap has increased, political participation among those at the bottom of the economic ladder has dropped precipitously. Poorer people may be dropping out of the process because they feel they have no voice.
To Mr. Ellwood a host of social ills come with growing inequality. Problems like drug use, teenage pregnancy, crime and lowered life expectancy all have gotten worse with widening income inequality, while these improved somewhat when the poverty rate went down and real wages went up in the late 90's. 
"If you are born to a woman in the bottom quarter of the income scale or grow up in the a single-parent household, the odds that you will go on to college, even if you have the same grades and the same test scores, are much lower," Mr. Ellwood said. 
Curiously, this is a point on which the views of conservatives like Mr. Heckman converge with those of liberal economists. 
"Never has the accident of birth mattered more," Mr. Heckman said. "If I am born to educated, supportive parents, my chances of doing well are totally different than if I were born to a single parent or abusive parents. I am a University of Chicago libertarian, but this is a case of market failure: children don't get to 'buy' their parents, and so there has to be some kind of intervention to make up for these environmental differences."
Even Adam Smith, the prophet of laissez-faire economics, had a strong concern for equity if not equality. "No society can surely be flourishing and happy, of which the far greater part of the members are poor and miserable," he wrote. "It is but equity, besides, that they who feed, clothe and lodge the whole body of the people should have such a share of the produce of their own labor as to be themselves tolerably well fed, clothed and lodged."

HEADLINE: As the War Shifts Alliances, Oil Deals Follow 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE with SABRINA TAVERNISE 

 BODY:
There is no oil in Afghanistan, but there are oil politics, and Washington is subtly tending to them, using the promise of energy investments in Central Asia to nurture a budding set of political alliances in the region with Russia, Kazakhstan and, to some extent, Uzbekistan. 
 Since the Sept. 11 attacks, the United States has lauded the region as a stable oil supplier, in a tacit comparison with the Persian Gulf states that have been viewed lately as less cooperative. The State Department is exploring the potential for post-Taliban energy projects in the region, which has more than 6 percent of the world's proven oil reserves and almost 40 percent of its gas reserves. 
 The United States government cannot compel investment, but it can clear away diplomatic and bureaucratic obstacles. Western oil companies say warming relations with regional powers could yield small openings. Better ties between Russia and the United States, for example, have accelerated a thaw that began more than a year ago over pipeline routes from the Caspian Sea to the West. 
"The sharp edges are off that discussion, and things are seen as less of a threat," said Martijn Minderhoud, a senior regional vice president for Royal Dutch/Shell. 
But any payoff remains distant. The entrenched problems that hobbled oil investment in Russia and Central Asia before September still exist. Oil companies and regional experts wonder whether significant new oil and gas reservoirs will be opened to foreign investment, whether onerous laws and tax codes will be reworked and whether persistent corruption can be reduced.
"This is a period of reassessments among oil companies, and a time of cautious optimism," said Scott Horton, a partner at the law firm of Patterson, Belknap Webb & Tyler in Manhattan. "But all have been badly burned in the former Soviet Union before." 
Skeptics, especially in the Islamic world, contend that oil interests lie at the heart of the West's war in Afghanistan. "The Pipeline of Greed," read the headline on a recent article in the Pakistani newspaper Dawn about the American-led attacks on the Taliban and Al Qaeda. "The war on terrorism may well be a war for resources," it said.
The Bush administration says that its war goals have been clear -- and do not involve oil. "There is no such hidden agenda," said an administration official. "Operation Enduring Freedom is meant to get rid of terrorism in Afghanistan, Central Asia and the surrounding areas."
Still, the administration lately has discreetly overlooked the pitfalls of doing business in the former Soviet Union. During a visit a week ago to Kazakhstan, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said he was "particularly impressed" with the money that American oil companies were investing there. He estimated that $200 billion could flow into Kazakhstan during the next 5 to 10 years.
Two weeks earlier, on a visit to Russia, Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham championed the cause of increased foreign investment in Russia's oil industry. On the same trip, David J. O'Reilly, the chairman of ChevronTexaco, said his company was reviewing possible projects in the Russian Far East. 
Pipelines are the clearest realm of progress. For years the United States and Russia clashed over routes to transport oil and gas from the Caspian Sea region to lucrative Western markets -- and the political and economic power that control of those networks conferred.
Russia wanted pipelines built on its territory, and some were. The United States backed a pipeline from Baku, Azerbaijan, to the Turkish Mediterranean port of Ceyhan, bypassing Russia entirely. The pipeline consortium is led by BP and represented by Baker & Botts, the law firm of James A. Baker III, a Bush family confidant and former secretary of state.
Over the last year, Russia's opposition to that route has subsided, and in October, the oil ministry invited BP to make a presentation about it to domestic oil companies. Industry analysts said that meeting would have been unthinkable if ties between the United States and Russia had not improved. Russia's largest oil company, Lukoil, confirmed that it was seriously looking into investing in the project.
The arc of countries in Central Asia where Western oil companies work grazes Afghanistan. But the value of Afghanistan itself, if any, might be as a pipeline route. 
Four years ago, the Unocal Corp. -- with the State Department's backing -- negotiated with the Taliban to build a pipeline through Afghanistan linking Turkmenistan, which is rich in natural gas but landlocked, to Pakistan. Although Pakistan has called for reviving the pipeline, industry experts say oil companies are so far not interested. 
But the plan could be dusted off.
"Once we bomb the hell out of Afghanistan, we will have to cough up some projects there, and this pipeline is one of them," said Matthew J. Sagers of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a research and consulting group. "Can oil companies be persuaded by the United States? It has happened before. Look at Baku-Ceyhan."
That project exemplifies how Washington fosters oil investment. The White House began advocating the Baku-Ceyhan route about five years ago, but oil companies in the Caspian argued that it made little economic sense. At that time, there was little oil from the Caspian Sea. But there was plenty of natural gas, and companies needed a pipeline for it.
They agreed to develop the Baku-Ceyhan oil pipeline if they could get the American government's help to build a parallel gas pipeline, a person close to the Baku-Ceyhan consortium said. The presence of an Iranian company, OIEC, as a 10 percent shareholder in the gas pipeline consortium might have prompted the United States to block the project. But it did not, and both pipelines are now proceeding.
This fall, the antiterrorism campaign raised oil companies' hopes that relations between Iran and the United States might improve. The industry's favored export route for Caspian oil is through Iran. But while the Bush administration confirms that Iran is sharing intelligence about Afghanistan with the United States, the president is maintaining Washington's longstanding policy against doing business with Tehran.
Western oil companies, showing a bit more faith than before in Central Asia and Russia, are gingerly looking for investment opportunities, industry consultants said. But the barriers are significant. 
Through the 1990's, the United States fostered good relations with Kazakhstan to circumvent Moscow. But the relationship cooled when the Justice Department last year began investigating accusations of high-level corruption in oil projects there. 
That investigation continues, but Kazakhstan -- which holds about 88 percent of Central Asia's oil wealth -- has offered the United States use of its airspace and military bases for the war. Its president, Nursultan Nazarbayev, is due in Washington next Friday to meet with President Bush and then will travel to Texas to mingle with oil executives.
Russia would seem the most attractive candidate for investment, given its warming relations with the United States -- missile defense aside -- and its relatively extensive economic changes.
But Russia is hard to figure. Its recent decision to acquiesce to OPEC's demand to cut exports has been interpreted in differing ways. Moscow might have come under American pressure to go along with the Middle East to protect oil prices, and so ensure political stability among the United States' Arab allies. Or the cut, which went against the official position of the United States, might have defied Washington.
Either way, Western oil companies understand, Russia's underlying motivation is the same: the Russians pursue their interests, which occasionally coincide with America's. 
Those Russian interests still preclude serious involvement by Western oil companies in developing most Russian fields, except for complex offshore projects. Russia has tarried in developing tax laws and a production-sharing agreement for foreign oil concerns. Russian politicians fear surrendering oil to foreigners. After years of courting their wealthier and more-experienced Western counterparts, Russian oil companies, made richer by high oil prices, mostly want to go it alone. 
"In the last year, the attitude of Russian oil companies to Western ones has changed," said Yevgeny Khartukov, general director of the International Center for Petroleum Business Studies, a nonprofit research and consulting group in Moscow. "Now they don't need them."

HEADLINE: Verizon Seeks Advantage Over Smaller Competitors 

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR

 BODY:
Verizon Communications, New York's local phone carrier, has begun a lobbying effort in the wake of the terrorist attack on Sept. 11 that would give the company a competitive advantage, and its rivals are criticizing it for trying to profit from the disaster. 
 Since Sept. 11, Verizon executives and lobbyists have argued in Albany that the rates competitors pay to lease space on its networks should be increased to pay for new security and backup systems necessary in light of the attack. 
 In Washington, Verizon lobbyists have asked federal regulators to make it more difficult for competitors to lease space on its network, arguing that its success in restoring phone service in Lower Manhattan proves that only a big company could handle maintenance, recovery and security in the wake of such a disaster.
The trade center collapse knocked out nearly 300,000 telephone lines and damaged a central office that ran much of Verizon's network in Lower Manhattan, one of the most congested telecommunications hubs in the world. Verizon has been praised by many for its efforts to quickly restore phone service after the attack. But the company has also been criticized for not restoring service to some customers, particularly in Chinatown and other parts of Lower Manhattan, where Verizon says about 10,000 of its lines still do not work. 
"Think about what happened at ground zero and ask yourself who else could do what we did," Ivan Seidenberg, the co-chief executive of Verizon, said during a speech at the National Press Club in Washington last week. 
Mr. Seidenberg and other Verizon executives have advocated ending the practice of encouraging smaller competitors to lease lines on its local telephone networks and then resell them to consumers. Verizon has long argued that this competitive business model was flawed.
The new twist is that Verizon's leaders and advocates have been arguing since Sept. 11 that all competitors should eventually be forced to build their own networks, in part because of the security and logistical challenges that became clear after the attack and during the recovery efforts.
"Verizon has really kicked up its public policy and lobbying presence since Sept. 11," said Michael Morrissey, vice president for law and government affairs at AT&T. "They did a good P.R. job in terms of the recovery efforts; frankly, they did a good job with recovery, although others did just as well."
But he added, "It comes as no surprise that their kind of solution is that if you want to take care of the problems of Sept. 11 and wipe out the threat of terrorism, 'wipe out my competitors.' "
Verizon, an offspring of the old Bell network formed when Bell Atlantic and GTE merged last year, operates more than 128.5 million phone lines in 31 states and the District of Columbia. The company is New York's main local telephone company. 
Mr. Seidenberg said that he would welcome competition from companies with the same scale as Verizon, but that smaller ones that lease lines on a local carrier's network would not be able to ensure security, build backup systems and pull off a recovery of the scale of what was needed after Sept. 11.
Verizon has made no public estimate of the total cost of the disaster. But company officials have told Wall Street analysts that they believe most of the cost will be covered by insurance. 
In a speech last month at the Chief Executive Club in Boston, Chuck Lee, Verizon's chairman and other co-chief executive, made remarks similar to Mr. Seidenberg's. "For all the focus on the viability of small niche competitors in the communications industry, this was one instance where, when push came to shove, scale mattered," Mr. Lee said of the recovery efforts. 
The Telecommunications Act of 1996 allowed local carriers to enter the long distance business as they allowed other companies to compete with them in the local arena. The equation has turned out better for the local carriers, the Baby Bells, which have been able to make significant inroads into long distance service as other competitors have had a hard time piercing into their local customer base.
The telecommunications act forces Verizon to sell access to its network to competitors at a price that is capped by the New York State Public Service Commission. Verizon officials have long said those prices are too low, and they have repeated that with increasing insistency since Sept. 11. 
All of Verizon's local competitors contend that they are not profitable in New York.
In response to a question from the Public Service Commission about the impact of the terrorist attacks, Verizon's regulatory counsel, Joseph A. Post, wrote a letter on Oct. 9 asking that the commission take into consideration the extra security costs when it reviews the amount that Verizon could charge for leasing the lines.
He also said that the small competitors that lease lines "did not and could not contribute in a meaningful way to the restoration of vital telecommunications services in Manhattan."
The Verizon lobbying efforts led three industry groups that are financed by Verizon's small competitors -- the Competitive Telecommunications Association, the Association of Communications Enterprises and the Association for Local Telecommunications -- to sharply rebuke the company in a letter to the Federal Communications Commission.
"Verizon's management is attempting to gain commercial advantage from these sad events," the letter read. "Verizon is attempting to use this tragedy to gain nothing less than a de facto repeal of the Federal Telecommunications Act of 1996, and a return to an integrated monopoly." 
The letter went on to say, "The scale and scope of the Verizon network is the cumulative byproduct of nearly 100 years of monopoly service and government protection. The core vision of the Federal Telecommunications Act of 1996 -- that these inherited scale and scope economies are to be shared with competitors -- is as important today, in the wake of Sept. 11, as it was on the day the act was passed."
Verizon executives and lobbyists have said that there are concerns about security when it comes to allowing technicians from competitors into its offices. More important, the Verizon officials have said that the size of their company allowed them to pull in resources from all over the region for repair efforts, and that the size of Verizon's network allowed them to more easily reroute service.
In the days and weeks after the attack, as they scrambled to get the New York Stock Exchange and other Lower Manhattan customers back online, Verizon officials warned that they would have to invest untold amounts of money into improving security and making a backup system for telephone service. The moves would include increasing physical security, like making its offices less vulnerable to blasts and fires, as well as network security, like adding computerized switches that could be easily replaced.

HEADLINE: Moody's Cuts Calpine's Credit Rating to Junk 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif. Dec. 14 

 BODY:
Moody's Investors Service cut the credit rating of Calpine today to junk, causing its shares to fall to a two-year low and its bonds to drop to 78 cents on the dollar.
 A lower credit rating could hamper Calpine's effort to secure as much as $1.5 billion to finance power plants under construction. Moody's lowered the rating to Ba1, the highest junk level, from Baa3, the lowest investment grade. Further cuts are possible, affecting $11.6 billion in debt, the ratings company said. 
 Moody's review and subsequent ratings reduction unnerved investors because after Enron, the energy trader, had its rating reduced, it filed for bankruptcy.
Calpine's shares, down 40 percent the last month, fell $2.85, or nearly 18 percent, to $13.20, the lowest closing price since Oct. 28. Its 8.5 percent notes maturing in 2011 traded at 78 cents on the dollar, to yield 12.6 percent, from more than 84 cents on Thursday. The bonds traded above 100 as recently as November.
Also today, Moody's cut the credit ratings of Dynegy Holdings, a unit of Dynegy Inc., to Baa3. Moody's said said further cuts are possible. It cut Dynegy Holdings' senior unsecured rating by one level, to the lowest on its investment-grade scale, and it lowered the commercial paper rating to P3 from P2. Dynegy shares, which dropped $1.64, to $24.94, fell to $23 in after-hours trading.
Moody's said it was concerned about Dynegy's high debt levels relative to other similarly rated companies. Dynegy, which abandoned its bid to acquire Enron, has about $5 billion in debt securities that are affected by the downgrade, Moody's said. That compares with the company's $8 billion stock market value.
On Thursday, a top Dynegy official told Dow Jones that it has put long-term building plans on hold indefinitely as power companies' ability to obtain financing for new projects had been damaged by the collapse of Enron. Dynegy is still on target to bring four plants producing 2,300 megawatts of new power on line by the summer of 2003, the official said.
Moody's said it lowered its rating on Calpine because the company must manage the "significant debt burden" it incurred for its expansion plan "in the face of modest operating profits."
Standard & Poor's affirmed its BB+ rating, the highest junk grade, on Dec. 12 and is not considering changing the rating.
Fitch Inc., another ratings company, also placed Calpine on watch for a downgrade, saying that "while the company's operating fundamentals are sound, the financial profile is aggressive."
Stoking the concern is the comparisons some investors are drawing between Calpine and Enron. Both companies financed some of their business with off-balance-sheet debt and both trade power, which requires a credit rating high enough to finance positions. Calpine and Enron also used the same auditor, Andersen.
Calpine is relying on loans to pay for power plant construction. Calpine plans to almost double its generating capacity in coming years, building and expanding enough plants to light 18.4 million average homes.
The company, based in San Jose, has about $190 million in debt that does not appear on the balance sheet, spread over seven power-plant projects, a spokeswoman, Katherine Potter, said. The company has bought the interests of some partners, reducing off-books debt from about $300 million on Sept. 30, Ms. Potter said.
"In the wake of Enron, the mild weather and the economic downturn, these are short-term difficulties, but our long-term strategy remains in place," Ms. Potter said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Vivendi Universal Plans To Challenge Media Giants
Vivendi Universal of France has lined up a set of deals intended to challenge the American entertainment giants in their struggle to dominate the production and distribution of movies and television programs.
 The company will place its programming on five satellite television channels, giving Vivendi its own distribution capabilities for the first time. As soon as Monday, Vivendi hopes to announce an agreement giving it control of USA Networks. At the same time, Vivendi may announce that it is putting its American movie and television holdings under the control of one of the entertainment industry's most experienced executives, Barry Diller. Page A1. 

Ratings of Calpine and Dynegy Cut
Moody's Investors Service cut the credit rating of Calpine to junk, causing its shares to fall to a two-year low and its bonds to drop to 78 cents on the dollar. Its shares fell $2.85, or nearly 18 percent, to $13.20, the lowest closing price since Oct. 28. Moody's also lowered the credit ratings of Dynegy Holdings, a unit of Dynegy, to the lowest investment grade. C2.

NBC Is Said to Lose N.B.A. Contract
Starting next season, ESPN and ABC Sports will pay nearly $1.6 billion over four years to televise National Basketball Association games, two industry executives said. The new contracts, which are to be announced soon, will usher NBC Sports out and give cable TV its largest role in a major league sport. S1.

Factory Production Drops Slightly
Industrial production dropped for the fourth consecutive month in November, the Federal Reserve said, down 0.3 percent after a 0.9 percent drop in October. Separately, the government reported that falling food and energy costs kept the Consumer Price Index gauge of inflation flat last month after a 0.3 percent decline in October and that business inventories dropped 1.4 percent in October. C2.

Kirin Brewery Stake in San Miguel
Kirin Brewery said it would pay 27.9 billion Philippine pesos ($536 million) for a 15 percent stake in the beer and beverage conglomerate San Miguel, tapping into Asia's fast-growing thirst for beer and providing what may be crucial boardroom support for San Miguel's embattled chairman, Eduardo M. Cojuangco Jr., above. Despite high marks from investors, Mr. Cojuangco is tainted by his friendships with the former dictator Ferdinand E. Marcos and with Joseph E. Estrada, who was discredited and ousted from the Philippine presidency in January. C3.

Small Uptick After a Week of Losses
Stocks eked out gains after a late afternoon bounce, capping a week of losses amid increasing investor unease. The blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average climbed 44.70 points, or 0.5 percent, to 9,811.15. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 3.69 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,123.07. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index advanced 6.66 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,953.17. For the week, the Dow fell 2.4 percent, while the S.& P. 500 dropped 3 percent and the Nasdaq slid 3.4 percent. C5.

BellSouth to Eliminate 1,200 Jobs
BellSouth said that it would eliminate 1,200 more technical and clerical jobs. It also switched advertising agencies, naming Grey Worldwide in New York as its agency of record. Billings are estimated at $120 million to $150 million. C5.

ITT Industries is eliminating 3,400 jobs and closing five plants. C3.

Delta Pilots Agree to Take Leave
In an effort to cut costs, Delta Air Lines said it had reached a tentative deal with its pilots that allows them to schedule a monthlong leave while receiving partial payment equivalent to 55 hours of flying time, less than they would receive for a full month of work. C2.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED -- AN OVERVIEW: DEC. 14, 2001; 
Containing Al Qaeda, Reviewing Bin Laden, Seeking Aid at Home

BYLINE:  By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
Two months ago, the war in Afghanistan seemed dauntingly open-ended. Taliban and Al Qaeda forces controlled 90 percent of the land. The local opposition was in disarray. Mullah Muhammad Omar reigned in Kabul and blustered in Kandahar. Finding Osama bin Laden seemed hopeless.
 By yesterday, the Taliban had been beaten, Mullah Omar was in hiding, a new government was preparing to take power in Kabul, and the last remnants of Al Qaeda were under heavy attack in the eastern mountains of Tora Bora, which may be Mr. bin Laden's final refuge. 

A CAVE IN SIGHT -- "Al Qaeda is finished," Commander Hazarat Ali, the ranking Afghan military officer, proclaimed. "They are surrounded." After a week of heavy American bombing, sporadic ground fighting and walkie-talkie attempts to negotiate a surrender, the war's last big battle appeared to be nearing a climax, and what could be Mr. bin Laden's last redoubt seemed in sight. "There is one specific cave," Commander Ali declared. "We can see it. We are trying to reach it."
American officials were more cautious. Pentagon spokesmen said they believed Mr. bin Laden was still somewhere in the Agam and Wazir Valleys of Tora Bora, but the Pakistan-based Afghan Islamic Press, quoting unnamed sources, said the world's most wanted man slipped into Pakistan in late November. President Bush said it hardly mattered, that Mr. bin Laden would be captured, sooner or later, dead or alive.

VIDEOTAPE FALLOUT -- Reaction to the videotape of Mr. bin Laden gloating over the terrorist attacks that killed more than 3,000 people continued to pour in. The United States and its allies see the tape as damning evidence: on it, Mr. bin Laden admits to knowing about the attacks in advance and even speaks of calculating casualties. Prosecutors said it could be decisive in court, if Mr. bin Laden were brought to trial. But defense lawyers said there were ways to undercut its value.
Having seen the tape, some prominent Muslims in the United States who had been skeptical of the accusations against Mr. bin Laden are now persuaded of his guilt. But many ordinary Muslims in America and around the world dismissed the tape as a fake, and many Muslim states reacted cautiously, or not at all, mindful of restive Islamic public opinion. Investigators, meantime, note that Mr. bin Laden did not mention anthrax, and are mulling over what that means.

MARINES SECURE AIRPORT -- Hundreds of United States marines occupied the Kandahar airport in southern Afghanistan, some landing by helicopter and others arriving in a convoy. They met no armed resistance, but moved cautiously, checking for booby traps, land mines and unexploded bombs. The airport, fixed up, is to become a major arrival point for humanitarian aid that will be desperately needed this winter.
The marines had come from Camp Rhino, their base southwest of Kandahar, and were expected to move many operations to the airport. But the rear-guard camp may serve another purpose soon. A prison being constructed there is expected to hold many Taliban and Al Qaeda prisoners. Two weeks ago, the Bush administration appeared to be interested only in the enemy's top leaders, but officials now see intelligence possibilities in the captured rank-and-file fighters.
In Kandahar, new details emerged of the fighting that led to the Taliban's defeat there a week ago. They suggest a strange picture of incongruous allies -- Afghan warlords whose hatreds turned some encounters with the enemy into summary executions, and the American commandos who contributed lavish technology and awesome ordinance.
Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld flew off to Azerbaijan, Armenia and Georgia for talks on the war. Those former Soviet republics have offered the use of their airspace for American military action. Attorney General John Ashcroft was in Rome on his European tour seeking support for the extradition of terrorist suspects facing the death penalty. He had no success in Britain, Spain or Germany. Italy, which outlawed capital punishment in 1948, is not likely to go along either.
In Washington, where Congressional negotiators were trying to reconcile differences over an economic stimulus plan, New York lawmakers were mounting a bipartisan effort to get the $9.5 billion the Senate approved last week to help New York City recover from the Sept. 11 attacks. House Republicans put in only $7 billion, despite New York jeers that it was too little.
 ROBERT D. McFADDEN

HEADLINE: HOLLYWOOD'S NEW FORCE: THE REGULATORS; 
State Attorneys General Taking Steps to Block Satellite TV Acquisition

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER 8. LEE 

 BODY:
Even as Vivendi announced its plans to take a stake in EchoStar, some state attorneys general said yesterday that they were preparing efforts to block EchoStar's purchase of a rival and take control of 90 percent of the satellite TV industry. 
 Their concerns reflected those of some members of Congress, particularly from rural areas, who have warned that EchoStar's plan to buy Hughes Electronics could result in a monopoly in many areas of the country. Together EchoStar and Hughes's DirecTV satellite unit control more than 90 percent of the satellite TV market. 
 "We're very close to taking action," said Richard Blumenthal, the attorney general of Connecticut. "There are strong and serious grounds for opposing this deal because very clearly it will have anticompetitive and anti-consumer effects." He estimated that "5 to 10 states at a minimum" would participate in any legal effort. 
Charles Ergen, the chief executive of EchoStar, has said that the merger is necessary to allow satellite television to compete with cable TV. He has also argued that a merged company would make more local channels available to consumers, eliminating redundant broadcasting on the limited satellite bandwidth. He has also promised a national price plan, so that rural residents would benefit from prices that result from urban competition with cable.
Vivendi's chairman, Jean-Marie Messier, has said that the investment is worthwhile regardless of the outcome of the merger. But if the merger is approved, Vivendi would obtain a distribution network reaching more than 16.7 million subscribers, the largest pay TV service in the nation. 
Shortly after EchoStar agreed to buy Hughes for $26 billion in late October, offices of state attorneys generals began regular conference calls to discuss it, with about 20 states regularly participating and sometimes more than 30 states calling in, participants said.
The attorneys general have formed a working group to interview experts, read documents and explore legal theories.
Most of the public attention on the debate has focused on Washington, where the Justice Department and the Federal Communications Commission have regulatory authority over the merger. Last Tuesday, the House of Representatives held two hearings on the merger. 
But the states may prove to be a more difficult battleground, and opponents are already working to be heard. Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, which had also bid for DirecTV, has distributed an "Essential Guide" to the merger, an inch-thick book that details the economic and legal issues. News Corporation has also retained Robert Abrams, the former attorney general of New York, to lobby against the deal on the state level, while the National Rural Telecommunications Cooperative has reportedly retained Jeffrey A. Modisett, the former attorney general of Indiana. 
While a number of state attorneys general express concern privately over the merger, they take care to to note that the review process is still in its early stages. The approval process could take up to a year, and many states have just begun to examine the issue.
A few states, however, have been outspoken from the beginning. In late November, the attorney general of Missouri, Jay Nixon, sent a three-page letter to the Department of Justice outlining his opposition. The merger would leave Missouri residents who are not wired for cable, about one-third of the state, under a satellite television monopoly, he said. "I disagree that this monopoly would increase competition," Mr. Nixon said. "I think it would obviously end the competition between these two companies."
In Washington, members of the House of Representatives are also circulating a letter asking the Department of Justice and the F.C.C. to "rigorously scrutinize this proposed merger to ensure that rural consumers do not suffer the consequences of higher prices, fewer choices and reduced services." The letter has gained bipartisan support, with more than 60 representatives from rural and urban areas signing it. The leaders of the rural caucus expect to have at least 80 signatures before they send it next week. Representatives from EchoStar and Hughes have requested a meeting before the letter is sent. 
Congress has no direct role in the regulatory approval process. But state attorneys general do have the power to block mergers by filing lawsuits grounded in both state and federal antitrust laws.
The state attorneys general have become a feisty political force in the last few years, taking legal action against tobacco companies and Microsoft. Many of the attorneys general seem willing to march down their own path, independent of the new Justice Department administration.
"This is ramping up as if it will be a significant and serious effort on behalf of a number of states," Mr. Nixon said.
For all the opponents of the EchoStar deal, there have been some politicians who have enthusiastically endorsed it. Representative Rick Boucher, a Virginia Democrat who represents a mostly rural district, says that his constituents would benefit from a single satellite television company.
A combined entity would be more efficient, allowing his constituents to receive their local television channels, which are currently not available on satellite. In addition, it could bring high-speed satellite Internet access at a lower price. "It would be an enormous benefit," Mr. Boucher said.
EchoStar has a service center in his district, but Boucher said he did not know whether it would benefit from the merger.

HEADLINE: Lawmakers Slip Farther Apart On Economic Recovery Deal 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 

 BODY:
Talks in Congress over an economic recovery package stalled today after the chief Republican negotiator asked for more sweeping income tax cuts than the Bush administration is seeking.
 Participants in the talks said the negotiator, Representative Bill Thomas of California, who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, sought to persuade Democrats to speed up planned reductions in income tax rates for upper-income brackets as well as for middle-income people. 
 President Bush had proposed this week that the income tax cuts be limited to accelerating a planned reduction in the current 27 percent rate to 25 percent, a change that would apply to individuals with taxable income starting at $27,950 and couples starting at $46,700. 
Mr. Thomas also continued to press for a full repeal of the corporate alternative minimum tax, participants in the meeting said, even though the White House and Senate Republicans have already signaled they are willing to compromise on the issue.
Senator Max Baucus, the Montana Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said Mr. Thomas's proposals moved the talks backward.
"They're asking for full A.M.T. repeal and significant acceleration of the rate cuts, which I think is too much," Mr. Baucus said in an interview, referring to the alternative minimum tax. He added that the two parties remained far apart over how to provide laid-off workers with help buying health insurance coverage.
"There's been a lot of talk but no real movement," Mr. Baucus said.
After optimism on both sides this week that an agreement was in sight, the negotiations have made almost no progress in the last few days. If there is no deal by the middle of next week, Congress will most likely go home for Christmas without taking action to help bring about a recovery from the first recession in a decade.
To try to break the logjam, Mr. Baucus, who is his party's main negotiator, and Mr. Thomas scheduled a one-on-one meeting for Saturday morning. 
In an effort to put pressure on the negotiations, House Republican leaders have scheduled a vote for Tuesday on a compromise proposal that is also supported by a handful of moderate and conservative Democrats in the Senate. Democrats said the strategy was nothing more than an effort by Republicans to give themselves political cover should the negotiations fail.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative Bill Thomas, Republican of California. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE FEDERAL AID; 
State's Leaders Are Together In Fight for $9.5 Billion Deal

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 

 BODY:
New York lawmakers are mounting a bipartisan effort to ensure that New York gets at least the $9.5 billion that the Senate approved last week to help the city recover from the Sept. 11 attack, an amount that is by no means assured.
 Democrats included that money in a $317.5 billion defense appropriation bill that the Senate approved last week. But House Republicans provided only $7 billion for New York in a similar defense appropriations bill they approved, despite complaints from New York lawmakers that that was not nearly enough. 
 Now, negotiators for the House and the Senate are trying to reconcile that and other differences between the competing defense bills. That, in turn, has prompted a vigorous lobbying campaign by New York lawmakers, who say they face a tough fight. 
This week, Representative John E. Sweeney, a Republican from upstate New York, sent a letter to his House colleagues urging them to provide the entire $9.5 billion for New York. But in an interview, he conceded that New York might not get that much. Even Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican who has kept a low profile in the battle, is urging Congress to accept the $9.5 billion figure.
In a letter he sent to Capitol Hill lawmakers Thursday, Mr. Pataki recalled the people who died in the attack on the World Trade Center, as well as the damage it did to the city and state economies.
The fight for New York money is being waged on yet another front. Democratic leaders in the Senate advanced a national economic stimulus plan that included $5 billion worth of tax credits and other incentives to encourage businesses to stay in Lower Manhattan. The package was sponsored by New York's two Democratic senators, Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton.
House Republicans did not include such a package for New York in the national economic stimulus plan approved by that chamber. But Thursday, the House did approve $6.1 billion in tax breaks to help New York City recover from the attacks, along with a measure that would free the estates of victims from any income tax liability for this year and last year.
The House measure -- which would create a new economic development zone, called a Liberty Zone, in Lower Manhattan -- had been strongly supported by a bipartisan group of New Yorkers in the House, as well as by Mr. Pataki.
Now, New York lawmakers are trying to convince House and Senate negotiators to include some sort of economic recovery package for Lower Manhattan in whatever compromise they reach on a stimulus plan for the national economy.
The lobbying comes just days after Republicans defeated a Democratic effort to add $17 billion for New York to the defense appropriations bill. The additional money was added at the request of Mr. Schumer and Mrs. Clinton.
In the end, Democrats accepted a smaller figure for New York -- the $9.5 billion. That was seen as a victory for Mr. Bush, who had opposed the $17 billion proposal. Mrs. Clinton conceded that she and her New York colleagues faced an uphill battle in getting the entire $9.5 billion for New York as the House and the Senate head into negotiations. Mr. Schumer echoed that sentiment. But he noted that at the very least, the showdown over the $17 billion prompted Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska, the ranking Republican on the Appropriations Committee, to promise to seek more money for New York as early as January.
Many New York lawmakers are worried that Republicans will put off the question of giving New York additional aid until the shock of Sept. 11 might have faded and, along with it, national sympathy for New York. "There is still a great deal of good will toward New York," Mr. Schumer said, in arguing for getting additional money sooner rather than later.

HEADLINE: South Korea Sees Prospects Of Its Leader Steadily Ebb 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 12 

 BODY:
One by one in recent weeks presidential candidates have been emerging like hibernating bugs from Korea's political woodwork, first in the opposition parties, and then in the ruling party of President Kim Dae Jung himself.
 Few democratic countries have had more imperial presidencies than this one. So across the spectrum, with elections still a full year away, the sudden crowd of hopefuls is inevitably being seen as a signal of the end of Mr. Kim's once formidable powers. 
 "The president's popularity is way down and his party has lost major elections three times in a row," said Park Shin Il, an official of the opposition Grand National Party, who was fairly clucking. "Most importantly, his favorite dream of all, his sunshine policy toward North Korea, is totally stalemated. Even people in his own party are calling Kim Dae Jung a lame duck."
Even if the 77-year-old Mr. Kim's political allies are not willing to completely write him off yet, for many who follow this country's rough and tumble politics, the president's stunning descent, to 25 percent approval ratings and scarcely veiled challenges within his own party, has been a breathtaking thing to watch. 
Just one year ago this week, Mr. Kim was being toasted by the Nobel Committee in Sweden as its latest peace prize laureate.
At home and abroad, having unexpectedly pulled off a reconciliation with his country's cold war enemy, North Korea, Mr. Kim had the aura of a political miracle worker.
Critics and admirers alike say, though, that what has happened in the last year is an object lesson for future leaders of this nation of 46 million about the limits of influence in a region where far larger and more powerful nations have always called the tunes. 
For many indeed, Mr. Kim's successes with North Korea, including the historic summit in Pyongyang in June 2000, represent the beginning of the end for the South Korean leader. Critics say that Mr. Kim seemed so determined to reconcile with his Communist neighbor that he neglected other vital aspects of governance like mushrooming official corruption and a sputtering economy.
Then, even his diplomacy ran aground, falling badly out of synch with the new Bush administration, whose suspicion of the North went undisguised during a visit by Mr. Kim to Washington in March and effectively knocked the supports out from under his policy.
Resurgent hostility from the North was soon to follow, leaving Mr. Kim suddenly with few laurels to lean on.
"When President Kim went to the United States -- standing right next to him at a press conference -- George Bush said he was skeptical toward North Korea," said Yong Soon Yim, a political scientist who is dean of the Sungkyunkwan University graduate school in Seoul. 
"It almost sounded like a rebuke. Already with the economy going bad here, people had begun to ask, 'Why should we be helping North Korea so much when we are suffering?' " The reception gave fuel to Mr. Kim's political enemies at home. 
The Sept. 11 terror attacks managed to strip Mr. Kim of any remaining momentum for his policy once provided. The Bush administration's posture toward the North grew even tougher as it warned that the United States would not only go after terrorists but also the states that sponsored them, something Washington has long accused North Korea of doing. 
Rather than assisting Mr. Kim as he began to experience troubles at home, North Korea has exhibited the kind of bad timing and political tone-deafness for which it is famous. Pyongyang has recently stepped up the volume of its criticisms of the South, launching into vituperative attacks on the United States as well.
The low point came late last month when the two countries exchanged automatic weapons fire across the border for the first time since 1998. 
Another ace in the hole for Mr. Kim has been the country's burgeoning civic groups, which once strongly supported the president because of his credentials in the democracy and human rights movement that date to his long years as a persecuted dissident. 
The civic movement has turned decidedly lukewarm, however, blaming the president for not pushing his economic reforms vigorously enough. 
"Ordinary people can't feel any benefits from his economic programs," said Lee Tae Ho, chief coordinator of People's Solidarity for Participatory Democracy, a leading civic group. "Support for Kim has waned because it seemed like he wasn't interested in reform anymore." 
Mr. Kim had set out to break up many of Korea's giagantic industrial conglomerates and to open the economy to independent entrepreneurs. But since the middle of his term, after an economic crisis swept through Asia, he backed off many of his promises. In recent weeks, however, the ecnonomy has begun to pick up again, and so have grass-roots calls for reform.
Yet for all of the gloom surrounding the remainder of Mr. Kim's term, there are still those who warn that writing off a man who has survived for so long, combining extraordinary willpower, wile and courage would be foolish. For one thing, they say, the engagement with North Korea remains a major historical achievement.
"The North has destroyed Kim Dae Jung's diplomatic credibility by failing to show him even a minimum of respect lately, but it would be quite inaccurate still to call the sunshine policy a failure," said Ralph A. Cossa, the president of Pacific Forum, a Hawaii-based Asian affairs research group. "People will look back at this as a tremendous accomplishment, even if it didn't live up to expectations."
Associates of the president say, however, that while he is not giving up completely on North Korean diplomacy, his eyes are already focused on a more immediate goal: defying his critics by helping his Millennium Democratic Party pull off a surprise victory in next December's presidential election.
"It no longer matters whether Kim Jong Il comes here to visit at this point,"one presidential aide said, referring to the North Korean leader. "The focus is one thing now -- the elections. And if the economy keeps improving the way it has been, our president believes his party can win."

HEADLINE: HOLLYWOOD'S NEW FORCE: THE PLAYER; 
If Diller Did Comment on This, He Might Say, 'Rosebud'

BYLINE:  By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14 

 BODY:
Barry Diller's favorite movie is "Citizen Kane," in which Orson Welles plays a brilliant, restless and enigmatic media mogul.
 The same adjectives describe Mr. Diller, who is now in final negotiations to achieve his longstanding goal of becoming one of the handful of powers -- like Rupert Murdoch, his former boss, and Michael D. Eisner, his former employee -- who dominate the entertainment landscape. 
 Although Mr. Diller and Vivendi Universal are still dickering over the details, the 60-year-old multimillionaire is expected to become chief of the company's Hollywood businesses, running Universal's film and television operations. 
In the process, he would cement his control over USA Networks Inc., the company he cobbled together while waiting in Hollywood's wings. USA Networks would contribute its cable channels and television studio to Universal, leaving USA with a variety of Internet properties, Ticketmaster and the biggest home shopping networks.
The deal is expected to be announced as soon as Monday.
Mr. Diller quit the chairmanship of Fox Inc. nearly 10 years ago because he no longer wanted to work for Mr. Murdoch, the owner -- or anyone else, for that matter. So his willingness to consider working for Jean-Marie Messier, Vivendi's ambitious chief executive, puzzled even Mr. Diller's friends, especially given his insistence to more than one in recent days that "I would never give up my independence for anything."
The explanation, perhaps reflecting the ambiguity in which Mr. Diller thrives, is that the deal he is on the verge of reaching with Mr. Messier lets him have it both ways. 
He will continue to be his own boss at whatever USA Networks' rump properties are renamed -- and, in fact, will give that business the majority of his time, according to friends who have discussed this with him. In addition, he will be firmly in control of Mr. Messier's much larger Universal operations.
"It's a win-win for Barry," said a longtime friend. "He'll have his own assets, he'll do things in his own way. And he'll have this arrangement where he runs Universal as long as he's comfortable. And if he's not comfortable, he'll pick up his marbles and leave anytime."
That Mr. Messier would even consider such an arrangement appears to show the trust he has developed working with Mr. Diller over the last year. As the 43 percent owner of USA Networks, Vivendi s already in business with Mr. Diller -- a result of an earlier deal that reflects Mr. Diller's financial shrewdness (some say cunning).
Mr. Diller may now sell to Mr. Messier the same television assets that USA Networks bought four years ago, for $4.1 billion, from Seagram, the company that Mr. Messier bought last year to get Vivendi into the media business. 
In exchange, Edgar Bronfman Jr., who was running Seagram, got the 43 percent stake in USA. And Mr. Bronfman got Mr. Diller to run his television business, as Mr. Messier hopes to now.
The deal would add to Mr. Diller's already substantial wealth; if Vivendi, as expected, pays $10 billion or so for the USA holdings -- more than twice what they cost Mr. Diller -- his 7 percent stake in the company would reap him $700 million. 
And he would be reaping it during an economic slump in the television business.
"The business of owning a general-entertainment cable network has gotten worse and worse," one top television network executive said. "He's walking into a price that's good for him."
Besides money, Mr. Diller -- who has never lost his cachet on Wall Street or the New York and Los Angeles social scenes -- would be assuming the kind of prominent job that would again make him a dominant figure in show business. He would at least regain the stature he had when he ran Paramount and then Fox, if not the standing he sought in making failed bids in the 1990's for control of Paramount, CBS and NBC.
"Barry's been marginalized," said a longtime friend in the film business. His USA holdings "all seemed so amorphous, like odds and ends," the friend said. "This gives him a clear focus. It's movies, television, theme parks, the Internet." Running Universal, this person said, "he's now one of the five or so most powerful guys in this world here -- that hasn't escaped him."
Diane Von Furstenberg, who married Mr. Diller in February after 27 years of friendship, said today: "What drives Barry is to realize his vision. I don't think it was ever just about money. Money was the consequence. Barry has a vision, and he likes to make things happen. That's what he does. That's what drives him."
But Mr. Diller has always seemed to have a problem with authority. When he joined Fox in 1984, he had a clause in his contract that he would speak to the owner, then Marvin Davis, twice a year, according to Mr. Diller's former associates.
On a personal level, Mr. Diller can be at turns charming and abrasive. He has a temper.
One of the most famous stories about him -- one he has never denied -- is that in the mid-1980's, in a fit of rage, he hurled a videocassette at an associate, Stephen Chao. It went right through the wall. Mr. Chao, who until recently remained a Diller deputy at USA Networks, had that section of the wall framed.
"Barry nails you if you don't know your stuff," said a film producer who has worked with Mr. Diller at Paramount and Fox. "He goes after weak spots; he doesn't let you get away with anything." Still, this person said: "He actually prefers when you don't agree with him. And he's only intimidating if you're intimidated by him."
A college drop-out, Mr. Diller, at 25, became the youngest vice president of programming ever at ABC. He invented the "Movie of the Week" and the "novel for television," the latter of which turned into the mini-series.
In 1974, at the age of 32, he was the head of Paramount, where he employed a group of young executives like Mr. Eisner, now the chairman of the Walt Disney Company, and Jeffrey Katzenberg, now a partner at DreamWorks. Under his lead, the lackluster Paramount studio was revived with hits like "Raiders of the Lost Ark" and "Saturday Night Fever."
Ten years later, Mr. Diller jumped to Fox, where he started the Fox television network and programmed shows like "The Simpsons," "Married . . . With Children" and "Beverly Hills, 90210."
After leaving Fox in 1992, because he wanted to control his own company rather than work for Mr. Murdoch, Mr. Diller bought a 13-seat Gulfstream jet and an Apple PowerBook laptop computer, and traveled around the country considering his next move. 
In 1995, he took control of the Home Shopping Network. In 1998, he bought USA Networks, whose USA and Sci-Fi cable channels became the centerpieces of his company. 
Over the next five years, he added a grab bag of assets including Ticketmaster, a number of UHF television stations, Web ventures like the Internet Shopping Network, a production company called Studios USA and the Hotel Reservations Network.
In the process, Mr. Diller built his company's market capitalization from $250 million to $17.58 billion.
