HEADLINE: HOLLYWOOD'S NEW FORCE: THE STRATEGY; 
'01 Media Model: Content and Distribution Go Together

BYLINE:  By AMY HARMON 

 BODY:
Ever since Jean-Marie Messier began aspiring to turn Vivendi Universal from a French water company into a global media conglomerate, critics have said its weakness was a lack of control over the distribution of its entertainment products. 
 After all, Vivendi's main competitors -- AOL Time Warner and Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation -- combined content and distribution, and experts said they represented the smart paradigm. Mr. Messier's deal-making this week finally gives him distribution, through the EchoStar Communications and DirecTV satellite systems, and lets him poke Mr. Murdoch in the eye as well, since the News Corporation had hoped to win control of DirecTV itself. DirecTV is owned by General Motors. 
 There are fewer and fewer dissenters from this business model, despite some failures in the last decade when media companies sought to merge with phone companies and then became infatuated with the Internet as a new means of delivery. 
Now media analysts and executives are convinced that the most efficient business plan is to own as many outlets as possible to deliver the movies, television, music and books that they themselves produce. 
The pursuit of that goal has been hindered in the past not only by misguided visions of the future but also by government action that sought to limit the control entertainment producers could have over the distribution of their material. But government regulators in recent years have been far more lenient on that front.
As a result, the media winners of the coming decade will be the ones that best combine multiple means of distribution with many forms of entertainment production.
"There's always that potential threat that your own productions will not see the best positioning on a competitor's distribution system," said Harold Vogel, a media analyst and author of Entertainment Industry Economics. "If you have your own distribution assured then you can use that as leverage against anybody that would dare to deny you access."
It is a model that traces its roots to the dawn of the movie industry in the 1920's and 1930's, when the studios consolidated control over the theaters where their films would be shown. Those combinations were dissolved by a 1948 consent decree by the government. 
Similarly, in the late 1960's, the Federal Communications Commission inaugurated rules that prevented television networks from owning the programs they broadcast. Those rules were dropped in 1995, paving the way for deals that included the mergers of Disney and ABC; Viacom and Paramount Studios; and later, Viacom and CBS.
AOL's merger last year with Time Warner was also based on the logic of combining content with distribution -- albeit a different kind of distribution called the Internet. For its part, the News Corporation has purchased satellite companies in Europe and Asia in pursuit of a global system to deliver its own products. 
Still, the question remains whether the marriage of content with ownership of cable or satellite systems is the best mix. At least one media giant, Disney, contends that content is most valuable when it can be shopped to a variety of distributors. 
"For us, the main product is intellectual product, or content," Disney's chairman, Michael D. Eisner, said in an interview last summer. "And it is our single driver."
And some media paradigms seem to have a half-life of only a few years. After cable distribution companies like Viacom and Time Warner scooped up programmers like MTV and Turner Broadcasting, conventional wisdom held that the next step was for the cable companies to merge with phone companies. That way, they could deliver interactive services to consumers over whichever wire into their home best suited their needs.
But those deals fell apart, largely over an inability to merge technologies and corporate cultures. Similar issues may plague the media giants as they seek to merge more production and distribution today.
"For every business there is a natural size and the natural-size unit in movie and television production is fairly small," Mr. Vogel said. "But distribution requires much larger-size units to be effective. If there's too much bureaucracy injected into the whole structure, whether distribution or content production, then it becomes less efficient and you start to lose creative people."
Still, for the moment, the argument is not over whether bigger is better but which kind of bigger is best. AOL Time Warner, for instance, clearly has an edge in Internet distribution, while Viacom has solid cable holdings. The News Corporation is seen as needing to plug a gap in its satellite distribution network in the United States. Disney's Internet ventures foundered, but the firm has strong properties in ESPN and its film library.
Vivendi, everyone agrees, needs a television network partner, and may get one soon if its negotiations with USA Networks bear fruit.
"Vivendi simply wants to be more like AOL Time Warner and Viacom CBS and Disney ABC," said Paul Sagan, a media analyst with Paul Kagan Associates. "That's the model, and that model is working."

HEADLINE: THE CLOSE READER; 
Expecting the Worst

BYLINE:  By Judith Shulevitz 

 BODY:
EVER since Americans began fighting wars, they have mostly done so in the name of ideals -- freedom, democracy, human rights. The war in Afghanistan is no exception. Once the press conferences are over, however, relatively few of the people who decide when and where to wage war actually think of themselves as idealists. The term preferred by members of the American foreign policy establishment is "realism," which in this context has a very precise meaning.
 Realists, who hold many of the best jobs in our graduate departments of international relations, foreign policy think tanks and world-affairs commentariat, are a knit-browed bunch. They see reality as a condition of uncorrectable anarchy, particularly the reality of international politics, and one to which the proper response is sternness. Hence the expression Realpolitik, used to describe the kind of statecraft Henry Kissinger made famous, in which considerations of power and security take precedence over moral concerns. 
 To quote Hobbes (and everyone who starts talking about realism does), life for people in the state of nature is "solitary, poor, nasty, brutish and short," and life for states is similarly dubious, spent in the throes of "continuall jealousies, and in the state and posture of Gladiators; having their weapons pointing, and their eyes fixed on one another; that is, their Forts, Garrisons and Guns upon the Frontiers of their Kingdomes; and continuall Spyes upon their neighbours; which is a posture of War."
If Hobbes's imagery suggests the landscape of an Elizabethan tragedy, you've grasped the guiding spirit of political realism. An aura of doom hangs over realist policy analysis, though few academic realists call themselves "tragic realists." That popular formulation is journalistic, used notably by the foreign correspondent Robert D. Kaplan, whose account of the Bosnian conflict as rooted in ancient tribal hatreds was said to have caused Bill Clinton to stall for years before getting involved in the Balkans.
Though Hobbes gives tragic realism its tone and Kaplan its epithet, foreign policy pessimism goes back to Thucydides, the great Greek historian of the Peloponnesian War. In one often quoted sentence, he implied an origin of that war that realists have expanded into a universal theory of belligerence. "What made war inevitable," he wrote, "was the growth of Athenian power and the fear which this caused in Sparta." In other words, an imbalance of power between states triggered the struggle of all against all that lurks beneath the surface of seemingly civilized relations.
Realists agree on their disdain for woolly-headed idealism (which they also call "moralism" and "utopianism") but not on much else. In the millenniums since Thucydides, writers as diverse as Machiavelli and Rousseau have contributed to the canon, but realism has finally thickened into two main flavors, historical and scientific. Historical-minded realists generally come from outside the discipline of political science; their conservatism stems at least as much from temperament as from a systematic assessment of the data. They are historians like Thucydides or Gibbon, worldly diplomats like George F. Kennan or, in one notable case, a theologian. Reinhold Niebuhr, the American Protestant thinker, believed that even the religious outlook required a certain -- though not excessive -- amount of cautionary pessimism. Realists of this sort see multiple reasons for hostilities: the distribution of power, domestic politics, ideology, national traits, leaders' personalities. They think wars are inevitable, but they tend to hold out some hope that by promoting democracy or wiping out poverty abroad, international violence can be averted.
Scientific realists, on the other hand, emphasize a single cause: the zero-sum game that is international politics. They think in terms of systems and structures, rather than personalities, and they downplay internal politics in favor of a vision of the world as a chess game in which the question of whether one's knight is made of marble or wood is irrelevant. They doubt that governments can do much to cure the social diseases said to lead to war, and have a strong predisposition to stay out of foreign conflicts.
Eight years ago, Samuel P. Huntington, a scholar of international relations, advanced a theory that falls somewhere between scientific and historical realism. Huntington's ideas have gained enormous currency in the past few months, if only because they appear to have come true. Huntington is monocausal, but his prime mover is not politics but culture. In "The Clash of Civilizations and the Remaking of World Order," he identified several great cultures (he calls them civilizations) bound to compete for power now that Communism and fascism -- the great ideologies -- have come to an end. (He doesn't see much future for liberalism, either.) Among those civilizations are the Chinese, the Hindu or Indian, Islam and the West. The most volatile, he predicted, would be Islam. His prescription: to renew a strong and proud Western identity at home and eschew a false universalism abroad.
In some ways his advice is unexceptionable. Indeed, it even has a strong moral appeal, since in making our characters our destinies Huntington appears to avoid the paralyzing effects of thinking in terms of vast, impersonal constellations of power. Yet like many of his fellow realists, Huntington reveals a strong strain of fatalism. He turns culture -- the record and embodiment of human innovativeness -- into something surprisingly fixed and eternal. Theorists of interconnectedness, who rank high among the realists' intellectual opponents, think Huntington and others gravely underestimate the ability of the global economy to reshape cultures and nations from within.
It's salutary to grapple with realism, since it forces us to think in hardheaded ways about how far we'd go to keep ourselves safe. But at the same time we run the risk of slighting our own knack -- and that of our adversaries -- for trust, cooperation and growth. Like Greek tragic drama, in which it is partly grounded, realism has a way of seeing the world as so intractable and human options as so narrow that we can no longer be held responsible for our own fates.
Half a century ago, the philosopher Isaiah Berlin dismissed theories of what he called "historical inevitability" for that reason. He believed that their disregard for human freedom gave them the power to wreak a great deal of havoc. Deterministic models of behavior, he said, were like "djinns," which "once set free from the jars in which they have been confined for centuries, become uncontrollable, and capriciously play with the lives of men and nations." His warning seems as apt as ever. We wouldn't want Hobbes's gloomy, garrisoned frontier to become the farthest reach of our aspirations.

HEADLINE: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: BOOKSHELF 

 BODY:
 THE CHRISTMAS PROMISE. By Susan Bartoletti. Illustrated by David Christiana. Blue Sky/Scholastic. $15.95. (Ages 5 to 9) This wistful story tells of a young girl and her unemployed father, who are on the road as hobos during the Great Depression. They do find a warm, safe place for the child to stay at Christmas. The endpapers include the hobo signage indicating places where there is danger or a jail, a place to camp or a kind lady.

CHRISTMAS SOUL: African American Holiday Stories. As told to Allison Samuels. Illustrated by Michele Wood. Jump at the Sun/Hyperion. $17.99. (All ages) A charmingly illustrated collection of holiday memories of popular celebrities ranging from Debbie Allen and Halle Berry to Aretha Franklin, LL Cool J and Patti LaBelle. Shaquille O'Neal tells about receiving the Stretch Armstrong doll he loved, and spending the whole special day with his father.

PINOCCHIO: A Classic Illustrated Edition. By Carlo Collodi. Compiled by Cooper Edens. Chronicle. $19.95. (Ages 5 and up) This publication of the familiar, and always startling, story of Geppetto the carpenter and the adventures of the wooden boy he carved uses most of the original 1892 English-language translation. As with other titles in this series, including "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland" and "Peter Pan," the illustrations come from more than two dozen other editions -- including here the splendid familiar one by Attilio Mussino. As great as the movie version is, Jiminy Cricket and all, it is well worth reading these short, surprising chapters aloud.

A CHRISTMAS TREASURY: Very Merry Stories and Poems. Illustrated by Kevin Hawkes. HarperCollins. $16.95. (All ages) Here's a basic collection for fireside reading, which includes excerpts from "The Wind in the Willows," "A Visit From St. Nicholas," "Christmas at the Hollow Tree Inn," by Albert Bigelow Paine, and two carols, "Jolly Old St. Nicholas" and "The Friendly Beasts," all exuberantly illustrated.

ROVER SAVES CHRISTMAS. By Roddy Doyle. Illustrated by Brian Ajhar. Arthur A. Levine/Scholastic. $14.95. (Ages 5 and up) Remember Rover from "The Giggler Treatment"? Well, he's back, because one Christmas Eve up in Lapland, Rudolph got the flu and Santa realized that Rover, back in Dublin, is the one to help. It's another loopy, very Irish, adventure set in Lapland, Dublin and Lagos (by the author of "Paddy Clarke Ha Ha Ha"), with wordplay, bad jokes and even commercials for toothpaste.

THE PAPER DOORWAY: Funny Verse and Nothing Worse. By Dean Koontz. Illustrated by Phil Parks. HarperCollins. $17.95. (Ages 8 to 12) A cheerful collection of light verse from a writer more associated with scary adult fiction. The topics range from "The Monstrous Broccoli Excuse" to "An Interesting Fact About Dogs." The black-and-white illustrations are extremely funny, and each one, the author and illustrator claim, contains a mouse somewhere.

TABLE MANNERS: The Edifying Story of Two Friends Whose Discovery of Good Manners Promises Them a Glorious Future. By Vladimir Radunsky. Illustrated by Chris Raschka. Candlewick. $16.99. (Ages 5 and up) A hilarious illustrated conversation on the topic, between the author, known as Dudunya, and the illustrator, called Chester. It is perhaps better suited to teenagers or college students than to children, who really haven't got a grasp of table manners.

SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Pg. 72

LENGTH: 4528 words

HEADLINE: Whatever It Takes 

BYLINE:  By Matthew Brzezinski; Matthew Brzezinski last wrote for the magazine about John Tobin, the American student falsely accused of espionage by Russia.

 BODY:
One by one, the defendants file into the large steel cage. There are 10 of them, young men in their mid-20's. Some wear jeans and sweatshirts -- and defiant expressions. Others appear bruised and frightened.
 Soldiers in desert camouflage fatigues and black jackboots ring the cage, which runs along one wall of the Akmal Ikramov District Court. Outside, sheep graze next to Tashkent Police Station No. 2, and anxious relatives mill around a fountain, waiting for the courthouse to open its doors. 
 Today is the last day of hearings, and the verdicts will be handed down. The mothers, grandmothers, sisters and wives of the accused murmur prayers and recite verses from the Koran, though many of them know that praying won't save their sons and husbands. 
Judge Rustamov Nizam is presiding, and in these parts of Central Asia he has a reputation for dispensing swift justice. He sits at a raised plastic-laminate table, beneath the blue, white and green seal of Uzbekistan with its crescent and stars, looking supremely self-confident -- as if he has the power over life and death, which he does. 
"Silence," he commands, and a hush falls over the courtroom. This afternoon, the 10 defendants will get their only chance to say their piece, to beg the court's forgiveness and to ask for clemency -- not that it's likely to be forthcoming. They all stand accused under Article 159 of the criminal code of undermining the constitution. But their real crime is religious fanaticism, of wanting an Islamic state. It's a serious offense in this former Soviet cotton colony, where the government of the onetime Communist Party boss, Islam Karimov, has ruled with an iron fist since the days when the Red Army used Uzbek bases to occupy neighboring Afghanistan. Today, thanks to a three-year crackdown following a terror attack, leaders of the Islamic opposition are all either in jail or in exile.
In many respects, President Karimov is no different from the region's other strongmen, whose abysmal human rights records and bizarre notions of democracy appear to have been inspired more by Genghis Khan than by George Washington. But Uzbekistan is America's newest ally in the war against terror, and any rumblings in the State Department over Karimov's heavy-handed ways have been silenced since the Uzbek leader allowed American troops to use his desert nation as a beachhead for their assault on Afghanistan. The trade-off -- for a regime that was frequently snubbed by the Clinton administration -- is political legitimacy. In exchange for that precious commodity, Karimov granted access to a key air base in Khanabad, a few hundred miles north of the Afghan border, where more than 1,000 special light infantry rangers were immediately deployed. Until last week, his generosity had not extended to the "Bridge of Friendship," the main link with Afghanistan, which had remained closed to all traffic -- including essential food shipments. 
But Uzbekistan, meanwhile, is free to continue its decadelong policy of persecuting anyone perceived as a threat to Karimov's authority. It just so happens that with all political dissent crushed, the targets of the current crackdown are about the only people left in the country who don't see eye to eye with the president: militant Muslims. That, of course, makes it a whole lot easier for Washington to look the other way. 
"The accused Aliev will rise," Judge Nizam says. Mohamed Aliev stands in the steel cage. He is a slim young man, with shorn dark hair and a blue Adidas T-shirt. "We are charged because of our beliefs," he begins. "Because we are part of Hizb-ut-Tahrir. But we are not against the constitutional order."
The judge interrupts him impatiently: "You are confessing guilt but saying you're not guilty." Aliev doesn't know it, because like most of the other defendants he is not represented by legal counsel, but simply admitting membership in Hizb-ut-Tahrir is tantamount to treason in Uzbekistan, as the fundamentalist Islamic movement seeks to replace the secular state with the Caliphate, or religious rule.
"I demand that medical experts examine us to prove that we were beaten and tortured," says another defendant, Sayeed Ahbat, when it is his turn to address the court. Nizam cuts him off brusquely. "If he was beaten, then he needs to write a statement of complaint -- I will not allow you to speak anymore," Nizam says, raising a pudgy hand. "Next." 
Mohamed Sharatin rises unsteadily to make his statement. He is tall, handsome and athletically built. Tears stream down his broad face, which is purple and red in parts and badly swollen. "I beg forgiveness," he begins, to which the judge nods approvingly. "I confess to reading Hizb-ut-Tahrir literature." Sharatin's crime was to be caught in possession of a leaflet from the radical organization, which labels Bush a "war criminal" and calls on the faithful to rise up against the great "Satan" that is America. "But I was simply curious and did not force anyone else to read it."
Sharatin's curiosity could cost him 19 years in Jaslyk, the notorious penal colony opened two years ago in the salt beds and sand flats south of the shrunken Aral Sea. Specifically constructed to house the growing influx of religious prisoners, the new desert gulag has developed such a reputation for torture and tuberculosis that dissidents say the only way out of Jaslyk is in a body bag -- if the pretrial interrogation, or a firing squad, doesn't kill you first. 
Uzbekistan's jails aren't confined to suspected religious fanatics. In 1995, for instance, when one of the country's former ambassadors to Washington fell out of favor with Karimov, his pregnant niece was hauled in on smuggling charges. Rather than release her on bail pending trial, as Uzbek law requires for expectant mothers, authorities aborted the fetus in a prison hospital. 
The rest of the Hizb-ut-Tahrir defendants make their statements. Finally, a defense attorney, Rustam Rakhmatulaev, addresses the court. He speaks for barely two minutes, since the outcome of most trials here is a foregone conclusion. "All the defendants have requested forgiveness under interrogation," he begins. "None of them said anything bad about the president," he adds hopefully. Insulting Karimov, whose photograph hangs in the courthouse, as it does in hotel lobbies, storefronts and schools, and whose specter seems to hover everywhere in Uzbekistan like an unseen presence, is punishable by up to five years in prison. 
"I request that the court be lenient," Rakhmatulaev says, concluding his summation. Uzbekistan's courts, however, are not inclined to mercy; not, at least, in instances in which religion threatens to impinge on affairs of state. Since the government declared its war on militant Islam in 1998, some 7,000 people, according to Human Rights Watch, have been imprisoned. Many of those were tortured and, in some cases, even killed for their religious beliefs. The campaign had drawn worldwide criticism for its arbitrariness and brutality; that is, until Sept. 11 changed the way most Americans look at the world.
And as Nizam calls for a recess before handing out a passel of 19-year sentences, it suddenly dawns on the relatives of the accused that they may not be seeing their sons or husbands for a long, long time. The families press forward, crying out, trying to reach through the steel bars for one last hug. The soldiers spring into action, linking arms and forming a human chain between the defendants and their loved ones. Slowly they push the wailing mothers, sisters and wives out of the courtroom.
Outside, Savara Umarova stands stunned by the fountain. "My brother will be an old man when he gets out," she says, her voice shaky and barely audible. "He's not a terrorist. He's just a believer."
The toppling of the twin towers has indeed muddied the waters for critics of Uzbekistan's human rights record. They strongly suspect that the Bush administration's embrace of Karimov could backfire, as have past marriages of convenience to dictators like Manuel Noriega of Panama or the shah of Iran. It's hard to tell if the new relationship will prove quite that disastrous. But for the first time since the fall of the Soviet Union, Washington is pursuing a strong, overarching foreign policy goal; in this case, fighting world terrorism (and, of course, getting rid of Osama bin Laden and his Taliban cohort). And as we saw repeatedly during the cold war, such single-mindedness often leads to moral compromises, which often end up doing more harm than whatever is gained in the original pact.
"If Uzbekistan is going to be a strategic partner," Rachel Denber of Human Rights Watch says, "then the burden is greater than ever for the Bush administration to use the leverage that it has to clean up the appalling human rights record. Otherwise, the people of Uzbekistan will draw the conclusion that the United States condones torture, unlawful arrests and other abuses." 
Nevertheless, Washington is likely to be very circumspect in criticizing its new partner in Central Asia. "We have serious disagreements with the Uzbek government on human rights and an absence of democracy as we define it," says Joseph Presel, a career diplomat who served as American ambassador in Tashkent. "On the other hand, Uzbekistan has been very helpful to us in the present circumstances, and it is my belief that the best way to foster the developments that we all want is through close and continuous engagement." 
It is unclear what engagement will accomplish in a country where the K.G.B.-schooled secret police have a hard time distinguishing pro-democracy demonstrators from hard-core Muslim militants. But nothing is simple in Central Asia. The fact is that the police-state tactics so criticized by the human rights establishment have allowed this isolated nation of 24 million to remain an oasis of relative stability in one of the most troubled corners of the globe. And Karimov's zero tolerance policy for Muslim extremism is not without its supporters both here and, increasingly, in Washington.
"I, too, am a believer," Feruza Insavaileov informs me when I call to tell her about the trial and ask if she can recommend someone to interpret from Uzbek, a Turkic tongue, into Russian, the lingua franca in post-Soviet Central Asia. "But I support what the government is doing," she adds. "I'll explain over lunch, if you want."
We meet at the Aladdin restaurant in Independence Square, one site of a bloody 1999 bombing spree by the Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan -- the Afghan-based terrorist group that first announced itself a year or so earlier by decapitating a police chief and sticking his head on a stake. Security is tight around the grimy government buildings that surround the square, and Feruza, when she turns up, is pretty enough to turn many of the militiamen's heads. Twenty-three, and an administrative assistant two years out of college, Feruza says she has a story to tell that might better help me understand the "complicated" human rights situation in Uzbekistan. It's about her kid brother, she explains, and how he narrowly escaped a fate similar to the 10 convicted Hizb-ut-Tahrir members.
The story begins shortly after the collapse of Communism, when, after decades of imposed atheism, Uzbeks were suddenly free to explore their Muslim roots. At the time, missionaries were pouring into Uzbekistan from places like Pakistan, Egypt and, especially, Saudi Arabia, which flooded the country with Korans and started building hundreds of mosques.
In the Insavaileovs' neighborhood in one of the leafier suburbs of Tashkent, an abandoned mosque had reopened next to the cemetery, and one day a mysterious stranger showed up there. "Some said he was from Pakistan or Tajikistan, and others were sure he was from right here in Tashkent," Feruza recalls. "In any event, he had a long beard and torn robes, like the prophet."
This stranger aroused the curiosity of many of the neighborhood kids and was apparently very charismatic. Soon, Feruza's 12-year-old brother, Eldor, and his friends were bringing the holy man food and spending more and more time at the old mosque.
"At first, I thought it was cute," she says, "but then Eldor started acting strange." There was the constant praying and sermons about the evils of alcohol and tobacco. That Feruza's family could live with. But suddenly television and radio were also treacherous foreign inventions, and young Eldor wanted to throw the new color TV out of the house. Things just got weirder from there. "It was like he was being brainwashed," she recalls.
Feruza invites me over to her house to meet Eldor and the rest of her family to get the full story. The Insavaileovs live in Kibray, about a 25-minute drive from the capital, just past the new presidential palace Karimov is building for himself. Their home is built around a large courtyard, with an ornate gazebo in the center, cherry trees, grapevines and a hand-cranked well. There is also a barn, where the family keeps its cows -- Zoya and Milka -- and 14 chickens. A satellite dish the size of a small automobile sits on the flat tile roof. 
Feruza's father, Malik, greets us with a traditional Muslim prayer of welcome, followed by Russian-style vodka toasts. He is an onboard mechanic and navigator with Uzbekistan's cargo air carrier, and his job has taken him around the world: delivering food for the United Nations to sub-Saharan Africa, gold to Switzerland, sacrificial lambs to Saudi Arabia, generators to China. 
Feruza's mother, Zera, an economist, joins us at the table, which is laden with fruit and traditional Tatar and Uzbek dishes. Soon the conversation turns to Eldor's flirtation with fundamentalism. "Since we didn't know much about being Muslim, we initially approved of Eldor's interest in religion," Zera says. "At first, he was teaching us what the proper prayers were, about Ramadan, things like that."
After a few months of this, though, his behavior changed. "Eldor became very aggressive toward women," Feruza recalls. "He started insulting us and calling us immodest." Eldor began insisting that his sister wear a hijab, or scarf, and a robe to cover her limbs. "He complained about the way Mom and I wore our hair, said it was sacrilege."
It wasn't just at home that Feruza encountered this type of animosity. At the university, some boys who had gone abroad to study in madrasas returned with very different notions about how women should behave. It was becoming a national problem in Uzbekistan in the mid- to late 1990's, agrees Frederick Starr, a leading Central Asia scholar in Washington. "Saudi foundations were paying for young Uzbeks to study in Pakistan or Medina, and these kids were coming back with their heads filled with crazy ideas," he says. 
For Eldor, of course, the crazy ideas were available right in his own neighborhood. "We started worrying about losing our boy to a cult," Malik recalls. "It was as if he was becoming a different person." The family didn't know what to do at first. They consulted with the leaders of their mahallah, the powerful neighborhood organization in Uzbekistan that governs everything from family disputes to real-estate transactions. The neighborhood elders were equally stumped.
Around this time, the Karimov government was also grappling to find a solution to the growing problem of extremism. "Obviously, it would be political suicide for us to be against Islam, because we couldn't oppose 90 percent of the population," says the deputy foreign minister, Sodyq Safaev. "But we couldn't allow the Islamization of politics or the politicization of Islam. That would lead to chaos. We had to fight these foreign imports." 
Fortunately for Eldor, the family struck upon a solution well before the big government crackdown. By mutual agreement, it was decided that he would no longer visit the holy man and would avoid the mosque altogether. This proved to be the right choice. "Where is Eldor now?" I ask Feruza.
"He's probably tinkering with the car again," her mother suggests. "Try him on his cellphone." 
Sure enough, he shows up a few minutes later in a dirty U.S.A. T-shirt, hands covered in motor oil. Cars, apparently, are one of his new passions, now that he's 19 and earning good money in sales for a textile mill. "The new Mercedes C-Class Kompressor is my favorite," he says with the salesman's ready smile. "But it's hard to get in Uzbekistan."
He is also into Hollywood movies and pronounces Angelina Jolie's latest action thriller "excellent." Looking at him, it's hard even to imagine the Eldor of old. He doesn't really want to discuss those confused times -- though he will talk your ear off about Pentium III chips -- but concedes that "many of the things the imam told us at the mosque were wrong."
The Insavaileovs, not surprisingly, are much relieved that their son saw the light. "I'm glad Karimov is locking these Wahhabis up," Malik says. "They are a menace to society."
"Don't get me wrong," Zera says. "I'm not against religion. I'm a believer. I just don't think I need to be covered from head to toe in a burka to prove it. It's like anything in life, moderation is best."
That message, thanks in part to heavy doses of propaganda in the state-controlled media, appears to have gotten through in most parts of Tashkent, including some very unlikely places, as I discover the next day at the cockfights. The bouts are held every Sunday in an abandoned warehouse in the Kuluk industrial sector of town. It's not far from the women's prison and a psychiatric institute where a political activist was recently sent for protesting, among other things, the government's decision to bulldoze some homes to make room for a road.
The atmosphere around the ring is spirited, drawing hundreds of vocal gamblers, many of whom, with their black leather jackets, scars and tattoos, look downright scary. Several of these toughs take an unusual interest in the photographer I am traveling with, viewing his presence with clear suspicion. Finally one man jabs an accusing finger at the photographer's black beard. "Wahhabi?" he demands in a decidedly unfriendly tone. "Yevrey," the photographer shoots back -- Jewish." The tension lifts immediately, and relieved grins crease the men's faces. "Ah," one says, smiling. "I'm a Muslim. Welcome."
It's an odd but telling exchange, one that you would be hard pressed to witness in most other corners of the Muslim world. But Uzbekistan, because of its Soviet past, is a strange cultural crossroads: part Europeanized Politburo puppet, part proud inheritor of Tamerlane's 14th-century Golden Horde.
All this makes Islam an important part of the country's identity, especially since the break from Moscow in 1991. Devotion, far from being banned, is actively encouraged. Men openly walk around in dopas, the colorful Muslim caps. At Tashkent's tiny airport, hundreds of ghostly figures move about the predawn gloom: pilgrims in white robes making the hajj to Mecca. The city's huge central mosque -- erected by the Sheik Zainudin Foundation of Saudia Arabia in 1993 -- is nearly full to its 10,000-space capacity for Friday prayers. And on Saturday mornings you will find all 139 modestly veiled pupils from the Khadichi Kubra madrasa for girls studiously poring over their lessons. What you won't find there is any of the revolutionary rhetoric that has given madrasas in places like Pakistan the nickname "Jihad U." 
"There is freedom of religion in Uzbekistan," Presel, the former ambassador, says. "As long as you practice mainstream Islam." It's when you cross the line, he adds, that things can get a little dicey.
"His feet are still swollen, but he's put on a little weight and looks better," Irina Mikulina, a defense attorney, is reassuring the wife of a client she has just visited in jail. "I brought him your letter, and the food."
Her client, Imam Abduvahid Yuldashev, is serving a 19-year sentence under Article 159, which is something of a catchall provision in Uzbekistan's harsh criminal justice system. The Muslim cleric recently received 20 lashes with a bamboo baton on the sole of each foot for committing some minor prison infraction. He couldn't walk for a week, Mikulina says, but that was nothing compared with what he suffered during pretrial interrogation. "The police put a lighter to his genitals," she says matter-of-factly, as if this sort of thing happened all the time. "At first, he wouldn't tell me about it. He was too modest." 
The imam was luckier than some victims of police interrogations here, who, according to Human Rights Watch, are sent home wrapped in sheets soaked with blood, along with dubious explanations from the coroner's office attributing the cause of death to heart or kidney failure. Electric shock, beating and burning are routine tools of Uzbekistan's anti-Islamic inquisition, says Acacia Shields, a Human Rights Watch researcher who recently returned from a two-year posting in Uzbekistan. She adds that another tactic to elicit confessions involves stripping the accused's female relatives and threatening to gang-rape them in front of their loved ones.
Even some senior Uzbek officials acknowledge privately that the methods are at times excessive. "We treat Muslim extremism as a cancer that has to be cut out," one says. "But sometimes we act more like butchers than surgeons. It's, how would your Pentagon put it?" he adds slyly, "the collateral damage of dealing with such a large-scale problem." 
That's small consolation to Mikulina's clients, like Yuldashev. The 34-year-old cleric first ran afoul of the law in 1999, during the big roundup that followed the Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan's bombing spree in Tashkent, which hospitalized hundreds and killed 16. Ten thousand people were detained in one week alone, Mikulina says, and the arrests were often arbitrary. Yuldashev was accused of Wahhabism, but his real crime, the attorney says, was preaching at a mosque where another outspoken imam had fallen out of favor with the authorities. Everyone associated with that imam and a dozen of Yuldashev's pupils were charged and promptly convicted, so that in the close-knit community where the Yuldashevs live you now see only very old men and very young boys -- as in wartime.
Several female relatives of the imam's imprisoned followers have gathered at his damp apartment to hear news from Mikulina about their loved ones. Mikulina does her best to reassure the veiled women, and her tough, no-nonsense manner seems to give them some strength. Away from her clients, however, she is not so upbeat. "I'm losing hope," she told me on the way to the Yuldashevs'. "Especially since the events of Sept. 11. Who is going to come to the defense of orthodox Muslims now? The government can do whatever it wants to them, and most people in the West will probably just cheer."
She has a point. Watching Yuldashev's young wife, Omina, shyly prepare pomegranates and rice pilaf, or plov, as it is known here, I find myself not worrying about how much of a sacrifice this costly display of hospitality is for a family with no income but about the dirt on the unwashed fruit and the flies on the greasy plov. Casting an eye around the barren apartment, I wonder how anyone can choose to live without furniture, television or radio, as this family's adherence to the strict Wahhabi sect requires. And looking at Omina struggle with her four disheveled children, I feel more baffled than sympathetic. 
Under her hijab, she is a very pretty young woman, blemished perhaps by her rare smile, which reveals a dowry of a dozen gold teeth. We don't speak much. Omina is too modest to talk to men, and I am the first male to set foot in the apartment since her husband's arrest. Only when she shows me photos of her husband do her dark eyes light up with real emotion. The photos themselves tell the story of a life transformed. The first shows a burly paratrooper with sergeant's stripes striking a virile pose in Red Square: Yuldashev as an 18-year-old conscript. Another, around 1991, captures a mustachioed young man on the make, in flared jeans, a suede jacket and an open-collar shirt. All that's missing is a few gold chains, and it could be an outtake from "Saturday Night Fever." The third, most recent, photograph is a mosque ID in which Yuldashev appears intense beneath a long, pointed beard, a black robe and a dopa on his head. "My husband is not a threat to anyone," Omina says. "He is a good Muslim."
It is hard to say for certain who here harbors revolutionary intentions and who is simply a victim of circumstance in the state's struggle to control people's minds. "Karimov is far less concerned with keeping the world safe from Islamic terrorists than keeping himself in power," says Shields of Human Rights Watch, adding that the crackdown on religion is a thinly veiled attempt to stamp out dissent. Opposition parties are banned in Uzbekistan, and Karimov, when he does bother to run for re-election (he side-stepped a competitive ballot in 1995), hand-picks his challengers. (The last, in 2000, proclaimed loudly that he was voting for Karimov.) 
In Washington, however, many are willing to give the Uzbek president the benefit of the doubt. "Karimov would probably win a free and fair election," Presel says. "The sad part is that he is unwilling to take the chance."
As for the crackdown on religion, that, too, has some justification, say people who follow the region. "Left unchecked, extremism could become a serious problem in Uzbekistan," says Glen Howard, a security expert on Central Asia. "Civil war, maybe, like in Tajikistan," speculates Abdumannob Polat, an exiled opposition leader, when I ask him what the ultimate result would be if the government halted its campaign against fundamentalism. 
While it remains to be seen if Washington will live to regret its alliance with the Karimov government, for now relations are rosy, and the Uzbek leader is basking in the glow of frequent photo ops with top White House officials. Indeed, cashing in on his enhanced prestige, Karimov just proposed a referendum to extend his current five-year term by two years.
Even Mikulina concedes that a majority of Uzbeks support Karimov's hard-line stand, though many get only a skewed picture of what is really going on because of the state's tight grip on the media. Omina Yuldashev found that out the hard way when she turned to her mahallah for financial assistance after her husband's arrest. Not only did community leaders turn her down, but they also subjected her to a humiliating mock trial and hate rally, in which neighbors denounced her and hurled insults at her jailed husband. "They said I was an enemy of the people," she recalls.
Not so the Insavaileovs, whose mahallah just named them "family of the year," an honor Feruza's parents cherish, prominently displaying the award photograph in their dining room. And as for Eldor, he has found a new idol to worship: Bill Gates. He even mailed the Microsoft founder a fan letter some months ago, telling him how much he admires the way he runs his company and crushes the competition. He is still waiting for Gates to write back.

HEADLINE: The Web Is In for the Short Haul, Too 

BYLINE:  By BOB TEDESCHI 

 BODY:
Like millions of other travelers this fall, Christina Washington has stayed close to home since Sept. 11. But she hasn't stopped traveling. 
 For a variety of reasons -- chiefly the terrorist attacks, but also the slowing economy and lower gasoline prices -- many Americans are shelving extended vacations in favor of weekend getaways by car, often planned at the last minute. The Internet, where last-minute travel deals abound, dovetails nicely with this trend. 
 Take the case of Ms. Washington, an administrative secretary for the City of Rockford, Ill. Before the attacks, she and her husband, Jack, a salesman, had planned to fly to Las Vegas in October. "But after what happened, I was not going to fly," she said, "so we decided to do a short trip to Chicago," which is about two hours' drive southeast of Rockford. 
Having never used the Web to explore travel options before, Ms. Washington logged onto some of the more well-known search engines, like Google.com, and found a listing for Site59.com, which specializes in discount weekend vacation packages by air or car. There, she booked a three-night Hotel Plus package at the Sheraton Gateway Suites O'Hare, a mile from the airport. 
The package, including a walking tour of Chicago, cost just under $200 for both of them. (Site59.com had the same package for early December priced at $202 for two.) Rates at the Sheraton typically are $160 to $284 a night. 
Internet travel executives say they have generally been able to withstand the travel industry's autumn slump, in part because airlines and hotels see the Web as a way to get rid of unsold seats and rooms at the last minute, quickly and cheaply. While that's a boon to discount-minded travelers, the deals are not necessarily easy to find if, like many road-trip travelers, you have a short list of destinations. 
Ms. Washington was fortunate in that Chicago is one of the roughly 30 cities Site59 includes in its Hotel Plus packages. If she were looking for a deal near, say, Albuquerque, she would have been out of luck. 
To be fair, such capriciousness is almost always the case with Internet sites that cater to the weekend traveler. Some sites are strong on destination information, but give no help in finding a room. Others offer deals on hotels but give scant details on why you'd want to visit that city. Still others offer a smattering of both, but not any great depth. 
In short, the Web is still a big help for those embarking on weekend jaunts, but it can also mean a lot of work. 
The genesis of many weekend road trips -- the "Honey, let's just get away somewhere" scenario -- often results in travelers' drawing a circle with a radius of 300 miles or so from their hometown, and nominating a few possibilities based on what they have heard about a given destination. The Web makes this process much more efficient, since virtually every town lists its tourist attractions and weekend events on the Internet. 
For suggestions from a source that's presumably more objective than the local chamber of commerce, though, the American Express site offers a useful feature, Destination at a Glance. From the home page of AmericanExpress.com, click on the Research Your Vacation link. There, click on the Choose Your Resource menu, to find Destination at a Glance. 
This has a pull-down menu, so you can quickly peruse different regional stops. There are 30 destinations in the Northeast, for instance, each with a thumbnail description of the area and links for special offers, so you can start some budget-minded brainstorming. 
You can also get a look at the four-day forecast for an area, a map of A.T.M.'s and a short list of activities, restaurants, shops and accommodations (with a link to a more comprehensive list for each). One caveat: not every destination may be completely up to date. Late last month, the Lake Placid, N.Y., section still listed Fort Ticonderoga among activities, even though it's open only from May to October. 
Once you've narrowed down the possibilities, sites like RandMcNally.com and MapQuest.com are particularly useful in filling in the details. Rand McNally, for instance, lets users type in a particular destination and choose from six types of attractions; then it lists everything that fits the bill. That these sites will also help you get to the destination, of course, is a bonus.
Assuming the aforementioned sites help you decide on a destination, finding a hotel room is the logical next step. Here, the most useful Web sites are Quikbook.com and HotelDiscounts.com. 
According to Bob Diener, president of the Hotel Reservations Network, which operates HotelDiscounts.com, the rates on his site have dropped significantly this fall. Late last month, for instance, his site listed the Caesars Tahoe for $75, "whereas we'd normally have it for between $129 and $149," Mr. Diener said. 
The all-purpose online travel agencies, Expedia, Travelocity and Orbitz, depending on their relationships with certain hotels, can sometimes offer rates that are comparable to those found at Quikbook and HotelDiscounts. 
Site59 is also worth a look. Unlike many other hotel sites, Site59 bundles something of value with its discounted hotel rooms -- in the case of Ms. Washington, the walking tour of Chicago. For some Vermont hotels, the bonus is a cheese sampler. According to Michele Peluso, Site59's chief executive, this bundling approach is intended to prevent customers from knowing which product is actually being discounted -- is it the cheese or the room -- so consumers don't think the hotel in question has gone lowbrow. 
Whatever the motivation, Site59 is fast, simple to navigate and easy on the eye. The descriptions and suggested activities for each destination are far from exhaustive, but they are helpful. And, as Ms. Washington can attest, the prices have been good of late. 
Given that it can cost more for a dinner for two at a good hotel than for a room upstairs, weekend travelers may want to use the Web to research restaurants. On this front, the online city guide services from DigitalCity.com and CitySearch.com offer some good suggestions. If the city you're interested in is covered by either Digital City or CitySearch -- and in many cases, it will be -- users can expect a decent number of reviews and, often, boxes that allow users to search for cuisines. 
Zagat.com is also worth a look. The purveyors of word-of-mouth restaurant reviews pack the site with great, and not-so-great, restaurants. The search function, however, can be moody: one recent day, the site refused to show me restaurants in the Berkshires, even though that was one of the selections on a pull-down menu. (You'd think a restaurant site would have the menu thing figured out.) 
And the list of restaurants, while long, is not as comprehensive as it could be. I tried to research restaurants in Vermont to see how to round out the Site59 weekend packages there, but Zagat apparently had nothing worth listing there. So for the Vermont tourists looking for good food, a little more surfing would be in order. While you're looking, if you've booked the right Site59 package, you can snack on that cheese sampler.

HEADLINE: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 12-16-01: CONSUMER AFFAIRS; 
Duty-Free Shopping

BYLINE:  By Amy Goldwasser; Amy Goldwasser is a frequent contributor to the House & Home section of The Times.

 BODY:
I have bought three pairs of jeans since Sept. 11 in Lower Manhattan. I don't mean to sound unpatriotic, but I bought them because they make my bottom look good. Not because they're all-American or utilitarian or because "boot cut" and "rivet" sound kind of butch-military appropriate. Certain acts -- for starters, shopping, sex, leaving work early to see a dumb movie, ordering mashed potatoes -- are most enjoyable when not premeditated or endorsed by anyone else, when you can believe that the only economy you're affecting is yours and when neither the mayor nor the president is involved.
 But that kind of selfish indulgence just isn't an option anymore. Wherever you look these days, there's a public official telling you that these petty little pleasures are brave acts of patriotism. That may make them more noble, but it sure doesn't make them more fun. Encouragement from the public sector to go on with private delights feels like an announcement from the waiter that it's just the right time to kiss your date. Even worse if you know it's happening simultaneously in restaurants all over town. 
 My dad died suddenly last holiday season. I have probably never spent more (or earned less) money in my life than in the few months that followed. In deep grieving, I developed tastes for an odd collection of things that never interested me enough to buy before and wouldn't now: chai latte, the Palm V, an expensive, ridiculous knee-length turquoise silk tunic or whatever-you'd-call-it that has never left my closet. At the time of purchase, though, its shiny blueness made me touch it and smile, and that was no small thing. Discovering it and taking it home felt pretty organic and all mine. Had the impetus come from anyone else, however -- the shop owner offering a Now More Than Ever discount or the commissioner of public grief telling me I owed it to my father -- the sale would have never gone through. It was no more a tribute to my father than a $10,000 Prada splurge is a bulwark against terrorism. 
I have a friend who goes to Barneys in times of trouble because he's convinced nothing bad can happen there; he called me from the store's pay phone on Saturday, Sept. 15, as he had a few days after his mother died in January 1999. If it works for him, it's only because his strategy for solace is an original one, the retail involvement unsolicited.
This holiday season, the enduring denim and irony-free pop music and scented candles and Omaha Steaks and 400-page novels and puppies that we were told we wanted last year and the year before and every year in recent memory are being offered to us under a new rubric. For 2001, "inspired by events," we are targeted to want them not just now, but especially now -- now more than ever. The gravity-lending phrases can be tacked onto the end of any current slogan as seamlessly as an "in bed" to a fortune from a cookie.
There's an especially-now pitch for almost any product, with varying degrees of legitimacy. People are afraid of malls (a boon for online shopping). People are cocooning (a boon for DVD systems, pashmina blankets, leather sofas, Tickle Me Elmos, PlayStations). People are seeking answers in faith and family (sales of crosses, Bibles and Korans, self-help titles and diamond engagement rings all rose in the months following the attacks). And people are feeling patriotic, leading to more flags in more ads than anyone can ever salute.
When something like shopping becomes so serious -- a part of the war effort rather than an escape from it -- we lose our ability to act unburdened locally at a time when we're feeling helpless globally. This frustrated nation has an awful lot of decompressing to do, in movie theaters, shops and restaurants, at home. In bed. Time Out New York's annual sex issue came out in mid-October this year. Its cover exclaims, "SEX: NOW MORE THAN EVER!" If ever there was a cause that needs no patriotic rallying, this is it. I imagine that citizens of New York and Kabul alike were doing it on Sept. 10, 2001, as much as they are tonight. And as little of it for God and Country. The 2002 Zagat Survey of New York City Restaurants, published after the attacks, has a drawing of Lady Liberty's raised, torch-holding arm on the cover above the words "Stronger Than Ever." 
But what's stronger than ever? We know it's not the city's restaurant industry, which is reeling. Is the guide itself stronger than ever? Or is it that we the people who courageously patronize restaurants are stronger than ever? A preface by Nina and Tim Zagat reasons: "None of us can reverse the horrific events that caused the destruction of buildings and lives. But we can fight back by dining out." There's not a regular follower of Zagat's 2002 who's in danger of forgetting what happened to New York restaurants in 2001. 
It has become difficult to do anything in this town that isn't of national significance. I wore my new jeans to a benefit reading for a firehouse that lost 12 men in the World Trade Center attack. I saw "Zoolander" and watched the Yankees win and then lose in them. I dribbled some mango drink on them while overdoing my part in fighting back at a favorite downtown restaurant. Sometimes I wear them on the subway while reading a magazine I just bought at a local newsstand. All, it turns out, acts of accidental patriotism. New Yorkers are just trying to get on with our lives, as sometimes self-indulgent and silly and vain as they are. I feel taller than I am in my jeans. This is not to be mistaken for philanthropy, even -- especially -- now.

HEADLINE: Housing Problems The City Faces 

 BODY:
Regarding your article "Cracks in Pillar of Affordable Housing" Nov. 18 : 
 Reduction in the number of homes covered by Section 8 contracts is but one of several housing problems facing the city. 
A similar prospect faces owners and tenants in buildings built with federal low income housing tax credits and those constructed under the state's Mitchell-Lama program. At the same time we still face demographic pressures, as our city's housing stock has not kept pace with the growth in our population. We must remember that each day roughly 27,000 New Yorkers still spend the night in homeless shelters. 
 New York City faces a host of great challenges in overcoming disaster, a slowing economy and budget shortfalls. We cannot however defer our commitment to affordable housing. The social and economic costs of increased homelessness and displaced families will be significantly greater than any near-term investments. Government at all levels and the private sector must work creatively to preserve the precious affordable housing resources that have been created under Section 8 and other programs.

ROLAND LEWIS
Executive Director
Habitat for Humanity-N.Y.C.

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL; 
On Dance Floor, Jobless Meet Employers

BYLINE:  By MARCELLE S. FISCHLER; E-mail: lijournal@nytimes.com

 BODY:
STANDING on the dance floor at Chelsea Street, a nightclub in East Meadow, Kellie Ullah ignored the thumping music, moving not to the beat but from table to table, spotting prospective employers by the glowing green plastic bracelets on their wrists. 
 "I need a job," said Ms. Ullah, wearing a bright pink wristband to distinguish herself as a job hunter. She was laid off from her midtown Manhattan position as a learning and development specialist after her company's data center in the World Trade Center was lost on Sept. 11. 
 "I have two children to take care of," she said. "It's not easy. The bills don't stop coming. Everything still has to be paid even though I don't have a job." 
At Long Island's first pink slip party on a recent Wednesday evening, the mixing, networking and mingling was not about relaxing after a day at work. The crowd at the bar may have been imbibing as if it were any other happy hour, but the beer was consolation and the buzz commiseration. Among the nearly 250 laid-off men and women the talk was of changing career paths, acquiring new skills and the paucity of prospects for information-technology and middle- and upper-level management jobs.
But if anything could make Ms. Ullah, 33, feel like dancing, it was being able to hand out resumes and meet face to face with 24 headhunters and recruiters.
"This makes it more comfortable," said Ms. Ullah, referring to the informal disco setting for a job fair. "I still might not get a job, but I feel better about it. You feel like people are paying attention to you. Maybe they're not. They're making you feel better and at times like these, we need to feel better."
Lisa Cotoggio, the event planner for Chelsea Street, said the club has always done a Wednesday corporate happy hour. After holding a slew of corporate farewell parties for the newly jobless in the last six months and reading about other layoffs on the Island and job-search parties for unemployed dot-commers in Manhattan, she decided to hold one. She plastered job notices on a board by the entryway and put out blue wristbands for sympathizers and nervous employees who think a layoff might be in their near future. 
Deborah Brown, a career coach from Long Beach, runs a group called Life After the Layoff. She set up shop at a table by the upper level bar, dispensing advice and touting the benefits of networking and job hunting in a dim nightclub over a bright exhibition hall or sending a resume via the Internet.
"It's a little more laid back," Ms. Brown said. "It's not as much pressure. The atmosphere is a little less threatening."
The free buffet and the liquor, she said, calmed the aspirants down, though she recommended having a drink before seeing, but not in front of, a potential employer.
"When you send a resume to a company and the company doesn't get back to you, you feel rejected," Ms. Brown said. "At least here you feel like you can touch somebody. You are touching a recruiter. You are touching a company. You are making contact versus just this resume that just goes into the air."
When Baglan Altuntug, 31, moved to the Island from Turkey when she got married last January, she declined job offers that would have continued her career as a bank department manager. Instead, she enrolled in a computer school in Westbury to enhance her skills. Then the economy fizzled.
"Money is not important," Ms. Altuntug told Bob Schneider, a staffing specialist from Lloyd Staffing in Melville. "We just want to get our foot in the door. We want experience now."
But Mr. Schneider did not have a job to offer. Like many of the recruiters, he was pooling resumes for future opportunities.
"It's great to meet candidates right now," he said. "Hopefully when the market opens up a month or two from now, we have a candidate."
Dominick Bianco, an executive vice president with Continental Broker-Dealer Corporation in Carle Place, took a swig from a bottle of Bud Light, confident that the ball was in the employers' court.
"If we find a few quality people, we can ask them to stick around and have a drink later," he said. 
Mr. Bianco was surprised by the quality, and age, of the job seekers. Many were in their late 40's, refugees from mid- to senior-level management posts, not just 20-something casualties from the dot-coms. Several people he spoke to had been making $100,000 to $150,000 a year.
"We might be able to find a diamond in the rough at a great price," Mr. Bianco said.
In August, Ivan Leon, 40, of Manhattan went to a pink slip party in the city as a sympathizer and landed a date. Then he got laid off. At Chelsea's, he made the rounds of the employer booths, displaying the four employer business cards he collected in his hand like a royal flush. Seaman's Furniture, he said, needed accounting people and the recruiter took his resume. His background as an auditor might fit.
Besides, there were other prospects at the disco. "A woman approached me and gave me her card and put her number on the back," he said, munching on peanuts. "Now I might find a job and a date."
Tom Holmes, 25, the chief executive partner of Live Free Inc., a five-week-old Connecticut start-up, surveyed the club. He was looking for salespeople to start at $60,000.
"A bar is where people can be themselves," Mr. Holmes said. "You can see the other intangibles. You can check out their social skills. This is a great place to interview somebody." 
It's also a way for Chelsea Street to attract customers. Greg Buttle, the owner, said about 35 percent of the pink-slip party people stayed at the club after the event ended.
Sitting at the bar, Myron Kamil, 47, of Bellmore, a former vice president of finance and controller at a telecommunications company who was laid off in August, and Ron Ferraro, 51, laid off from a mid-level position at J. P. Morgan Chase last month after 23 years and four mergers, sipped Zinfandel and wondered where their next jobs would come from. Both men had children in college, were out of work for the first time in their lives and were disappointed in the level of jobs the recruiters at the event had to offer. They hoped other companies would show up at future pink slip parties, scheduled for the first Wednesday of every month beginning Feb. 6, but hoped even more fervently that they would be employed by the time the next job fair rolled around.
"It's a frustrating experience, the job search," Mr. Ferraro said. "The camaraderie of networking is extremely important."
Mr. Kamil's attention was already on other things. "Having it in a bar, even if it's not good, could be a good pickup place," he said.
As they were talking, the disc jockey announced a raffle. Mr. Ferraro and Mr. Kamil pulled out their ticket stubs and peered at the numbers. The prize was a camera bag. 
Mr. Kamil crumbled his ticket, disappointed. "I thought they were giving away a job," he said.

Chance for a Mitzvah
Santa Claus is not the only holiday spirit with a beard, spectacles and a broad appeal. There's Anchelle Perl, 47, an ultra-Orthodox Lubavitch rabbi and executive director of the National Committee for the Furtherance of Jewish Education of Nassau County.
"It's a holiday of light and we want to bring our light to you," said Rabbi Perl, presiding over his 10th annual Hanukkah telethon, broadcast to the tristate area last Sunday from Pro Image Studios in Islandia, accompanied by a bevy of dark-suited, cheerleading Hasidim, their ritual fringes flying like pompoms as they danced.
With his black hat, frail frame and pious manner, Rabbi Perl is an unlikely Jerry Lewis stand-in, pitching for dollars to launch a Center for Performing Arts for Jewish singles at his Congregation Beth Sholom Chabad in Mineola.
"I am trying to bring across traditional ideas in a nontraditional way," the rabbi said. He tap danced, pulled on an Uncle Sam hat and auctioned off a Harley-Davidson motorcycle. Among his guests were the owner of the Long Island Ducks, Bud Harrelson; the chairman of the Long Island Power Authority, Richard Kessel; and the Town of Oyster Bay supervisor, John Venditto.
In Rabbi Perl's honor, "I got this little beard started," said Mr. Harrelson, stroking a gray goatee.
"Buddy, as soon as you have a full beard grown, give me a call," the rabbi replied. "I'll give you a black hat." 
Marilyn Michaels, the singer and impressionist, was a co-host. She did her rendition of Ivana Trump and Joan Rivers, but was not allowed to sing because of Orthodox laws prohibiting women from singing in front of men. She wished her non-Jewish friends a merry Christmas.
"This is about humanity," Ms. Michaels said. "This is for people of all religious denominations. Send in a donation. It's called a mitzvah."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property; 
Pennsylvania Power Plant to Get New Life as Offices

BYLINE:  By MAUREEN MILFORD 

DATELINE: CHESTER, Pa. 

 BODY:
SOME people who grew up near the electrical power plant on the Delaware River here remember it as an ogre at the foot of Ward Street that puffed plumes of dark smoke from its head. 
 "We called it the Monster and the Monstrosity," said Bishop Dickie L. Robbins, 45, recalling the coal-fired Chester generating station, formerly owned by the PECO Energy Company. "It was huge and dismal and just had an eerie look about it." As a child, Bishop Robbins, pastor of the Life in Christ Cathedral of Faith, lived near the station, but he never set foot on the property. 
 Now, neighbors like Bishop Robbins are touring the imposing 1918 Neo-Classical building as it undergoes a $55 million conversion into offices. 
The onetime power plant is the centerpiece of a $300 million redevelopment being done by a private developer along a half mile of riverfront. Called the Wharf at Rivertown, the project is southwest of the Commodore Barry Bridge, which connects Interstate 95 in Pennsylvania with Interstate 295 in southern New Jersey.
Once inside the power plant, Bishop Robbins could not help but be impressed by the majestic turbine hall, with its 115-foot vaulted ceiling, ornamental skylights, Corinthian pilasters and bronze wall sconces. "My view of it has changed -- I see it now as a symbol of hope," he said.
For many, the commitment by Preferred Real Estate Investments Inc. of Conshohocken, Pa., to redevelop the vacant Chester Station is confirmation that the city of 36,854 is inching up from the bottom.
An industrial town southwest of Philadelphia International Airport, Chester has been battered in recent decades by poverty, drugs, crime and AIDS. Founded by Swedish settlers as Upland in 1643, it is now one of the nation's most distressed cities, according to Keith W. Reeves, who grew up in Chester and now heads the Center for Social and Policy Studies at Swarthmore College.
The violent crime rate in 1999 was 14 times higher than the rate for surrounding Delaware County, according to the center's data. Though Chester is encircled by comfortable suburbs, at least 75 percent of students at its middle and high schools are eligible for free or reduced-priced lunches. The school district, taken over by the state in 1994, has ranked dead last for academic performance among Pennsylvania's 501 districts, the center reports.
Since 1990, the population has declined by 12 percent, with burdensome property taxes helping to drive out middle-class families. Jobs dwindled to about 5,000, a far cry from the 1940's, when the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company alone employed 30,000. In the oldest section of the city, where William Penn landed in 1682, a smattering of derelict Colonial houses provide the only evidence of a place described in an area history just 60 years ago as resembling an old English city.
But residents are proud of Chester's cultural, industrial and social heritage. Penn spent his first winter in America there. Martin Luther King Jr. preached in local churches while attending nearby Crozer Theological Seminary in 1948 to 1951. The legendary singer Ethel Waters was born here at the beginning of the 20th century. And a regional artist, Andrew Turner, uses the city as a setting for colorful paintings.
"Older folks remember a vibrant, hard-working city," Mr. Reeves said. "Despite its problems, we love it."
For most of the second half of the 20th century, there was little outside investment in Chester. But since 1996, more than $500 million has been committed by the private, public and institutional sectors, according to David N. Sciocchetti, executive director of the Chester Economic Development Authority. Projects include three new housing developments for low- to moderate-income families and a new technology park near Widener University.
When the converted power plant's lead tenant, Synygy Inc., relocates from Conshohocken at the end of 2002, it will bring the largest number of jobs to the city since World War II, said Mayor Dominic F. Pileggi. Synygy, the country's largest provider of software to manage comporate incentive compensation plans, will employ 700. 
Along with other tenants -- a financial consulting firm has already agreed to take 10,000 square feet -- Synygy will receive tax relief for 10 years under a state program to stimulate job creation in deteriorated areas.
Tax benefits were important to Synygy's founder, Mark Stiffler. But Mr. Stiffler, 39, also has a love of architecture, which he studied at Massachusetts Institute of Technology before getting a degree in civil engineering and management information systems. He was struck by what the plant's architecture was meant to convey.
"At the time, electricity was not trusted," he said. "The building was built in a grand style as a marketing tool. It portrays a combination of creativity and reliability."
THE architect John T. Windrim of Philadelphia, who was on the board of the Philadelphia Electric Company, designed the plant as the utility geared up to provide power to industries that supplied the Allies during World War I. When it opened, it was considered an architectural showplace, according to Nicholas B. Wainwright in his book "History of the Philadelphia Electric Company 1881-1961." 
"If one could see over the coal piles on the landward side," Mr. Wainwright wrote, "one might mistake it for an enormous public library!" 
From its earliest days, Chester was part of the "arsenal of democracy," Mr. Sciocchetti said. Shipbuilding began in 1778, and the industry continued until the late 20th century.
Sun Shipbuilding constructed tankers and cargo ships during World War II. The Ford Motor Company had an assembly plant in Chester and made small tanks and jeeps. The Scott Paper Company occupied a full block on the river. The city's population was about 70,000 during the war years.
Today, of the major manufacturing companies of 50 years ago, only the Kimberly-Clark Corporation, which acquired Scott Paper, remains. PECO stopped generating at the Chester Station in 1982, when it moved to nuclear plants.
Despite being vacant for two decades, the Chester Station building is still magnificent, according to Michael G. O'Neill, chief executive of Preferred Real Estate. "They always tell you, 'Don't fall in love with the real estate,' " he said. "But with this building I couldn't help it." 
On the southeast side of the building facing the river are huge concrete Tuscan columns and cornices designed to look like stone. Interior details are equally striking. "It was a temple to electricity," said James B. Garrison, senior associate of historic preservation at Hillier, the Philadelphia architectural firm handling interior design for Synygy. "It was a highly symbolic structure."
PECO considered demolishing the building but sold it with 60 acres for $1 with the provision that the new owner tackle interior environmental clean-up. The remediation mostly involves removing materials in the building, which Mr. O'Neill estimates will cost $10 million.
Synygy will occupy 178,000 square feet, or nearly half the building. The turbine hall, two floors of the attached switch house and two floors in the boiler house section will be converted to offices once power equipment is removed. The company will also have a corporate apartment, fitness center and meeting rooms in one of two coal towers.
Smokestacks will be removed, and a glass penthouse floor will be added. Other elements, like the coal tower cranes, will be maintained for historic reasons. The building is expected to total about 380,000 square feet on six floors.
Once the renovation is completed, Preferred intends to build a 500,000-square-foot office building on the property. There will also be two marinas and several restaurants. 
The project, which is to be completed by the end of 2003, is expected to benefit from road improvements, including construction of a ramp to Interstate 95 near the property.
A river walk running from the Commodore Barry Bridge to Highland Avenue is to be open to the public. Initially, the developer considered putting the complex behind gates but decided that would send the wrong message, said Michael P. Balitsaris, marketing manager with Preferred Real Estate. "We realized nobody wants to be isolated like that," Mr. Balitsaris said.
