HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
Used-Car Sales Hitch a Ride With the New Cars

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
THE advertisements promoting "zero percent financing" have been all over the papers and airwaves this fall, but what brought Michael and Susan Cespites of Port Jefferson Station to Ramp Chevrolet were the bleak prospects for the 10-year-old sedan Mrs. Cespites has been driving to work at the allergist's office where she is a nurse. 
 With 140,000 miles on the odometer, the car often requires a mechanic's ministrations. "The guy in the garage sees me and says, 'If I were you, I'd bail on this car,' " said Mr. Cespites (pronounced cess-PEED-us). "So we're looking to replace it. We want to make sure it comes with a warranty. And it definitely has to be an American-made car." 
 Late one afternoon last month, Mr. and Mrs. Cespites and their three children came to Ramp Chevrolet in Port Jefferson Station, the biggest Chevrolet dealership in New York State. Even with no-interest financing, they found that their $15,000 budget would not stretch to cover the cost of a new model, so they headed toward the used cars. Like many dealers, Ramp is selling more used cars these days, and the couple looked carefully at an Impala and a Malibu before heading inside the showroom. 
Sales of used cars constituted about 25 percent of Ramp's total sales in October, about double the usual number, said John Rampone, an owner. While the glamour in auto sales is clearly in moving new metal, profits are usually higher on what the industry likes to call "previously owned."
Mark Schienberg, the president of the Greater New York Automobile Association in Whitestone, Queens, said: "A General Motors dealer might make as little as $300 profit on a new vehicle. The manufacturer controls the wholesale price, and the sticker price is pretty much frozen. The dealership tends to make its money on used cars, as well as from the service and parts departments."
When automakers began introducing "zero percent financing" and other promotions for new cars and trucks this fall, they jump-started a year that had begun dismally. Nationally, sales for cars and light trucks have passed 17 million and are expected to finish the year a shade under last year's all-time sales record of 17.4 million, said Paul Taylor, the chief economist at the National Automobile Dealers Association in McLean, Va. "Clearly, the promotions helped boost new-car sales in the fourth quarter." 
At the same time, he said, the promotions have indirectly driven up the sales of used cars and light trucks, projected at 12.6 million this year, up from 12.5 million the year before. In October, when the sale of new vehicles spiked at 1.7 million, more than half of the buyers brought along an old vehicle to trade in, flooding dealership inventories with an additional 212,000 used cars and trucks. Other factors, including fleet-culling by rental companies and the return of leased vehicles, have helped to create what some people in the industry openly call a used-car glut.
Despite the large inventories, used-car prices at dealerships have not fallen but have increased nearly 2 percent, Mr. Taylor said. He attributed the uptick to the fact that dealers have a larger number of newer cars with more options than in the prior year. In the first eight months of this year, the average used-car price was $13,858, he said, compared with $13,594 for the same period the year before.
The auto dealers' association expects the trend to continue, a reflection of the sluggish economy. "The myth is that people tend to buy used cars in a recession rather than new ones," Mr. Taylor said. "The reality is that car sales drop, but used cars drop slower than new ones."
The growth of the used-car market also reflects a push-me-pull-you dynamic. "There has been the emergence of a near-new market, of cars three years or less in age, because of the strong volume in leasing over the last five years and the relative popularity of luxury brands," Mr. Taylor said. "It's now possible to buy a relatively young used car that is still certified by factory warranty and to purchase an extended warranty that takes the uncertainty out of the transaction." All this for a third to a half the price of a new car.
Back at the Ramp Chevrolet showroom, Steve Brian, a salesman, found that Mr. and Mrs Cespides were in no hurry to buy any of the cars they inspected. Mr. Brian tapped some information into the computer sitting on his desk, and in a moment he said he had good news. There was, he said, a blue Malibu available that fit their needs. It had 39,000 miles on the odometer, and in fact, it was one of the vehicles the couple had seen on the lot before they came into the showroom.
Mr. Cespites nodded but said nothing. Mr. Brian asked if the color was an issue. As he asked the question, he tapped away at the computer, which provided him with information on the dealership's inventory. "We have a white one," Mr. Brian said after a moment, and the price was the same, just under $10,000. "However," he added, "it has another 2,000 miles on it. And it's still being prepped, so I can't show it to you."
Mr. Brian chatted on, suggesting that the process of buying a used car was similar to buying an antique. "You see something you like -- it's one of a kind, so you buy it," he said. Neither Mr. nor Mrs. Cespites responded. "You never know," he continued, "if it will be there the next time."
The couple seemed untroubled by that possibility and left without buying. Later, Mrs. Cespites said her husband's employer, a paint shop in Sayville, had offered him great terms on a Ford Contour it owned, and the couple bought it. "They were terms we couldn't pass up," she said.
While Mr. Rampone didn't get the Cespiteses' business, he has been closing other deals and expanding his family-owned dealership, now in its third generation. Mr. Rampone is turning the eight-acre lot across Route 112 from his dealership into a Corvette showroom, which is to open next spring. He also has secured the rights to sell Hummers, now made by General Motors, and Indian motorcycles. Indian, founded in 1901, went out of business in the early 1950's but was revived two years ago by the Indian Motorcycle Company of Springfield, Ill.
Mr. Rampone said that he likes the bikes and went out of his way to become a licensed dealer. He plans to sell the motorcycles at the former Daewoo dealership he bought in Smithtown, and the Hummers from his flagship dealership in Port Jefferson Station. 
Mr. Rampone, who is a grandson of the dealership's founder, Alfred Rampone, began his career in retailing, moving to Manhattan and rising to a merchandising executive at Giorgio Armani and Bergdorf Goodman. He returned to take over the family business in 1988, he said, at a time when he felt disillusioned with the fashion industry. But he has used some of the merchandising lessons he learned to transform the hidebound world of auto sales.
"When I took over in 1988, this was the smallest Chevrolet dealership on Long Island, and now it's the biggest," Mr. Rampone said with pride. "If you want to buy a Chevrolet on Long Island, you are going to end up with us."

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Glen Cove; 
An Unusually Inclusive Gold Coast City

BYLINE:  By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
A FORMER Gold Coast stronghold on a North Shore peninsula of Long Island's Nassau County, Glen Cove is now home to people whose means range from very great to extremely modest. Dwellings range from gated estates to subsidized apartments and rooming houses, with a variety of residential-neighborhood choices in between.
 One of two cities on Long Island (the other is Long Beach), Glen Cove is low-rise and generally suburban, with industrial patches and a center for Hispanic laborers who shape up here looking for work and often find places to live in the Orchard section. 
 In size and layout, the city looks more like a moderately sized town loosely organized around a commercial district. 
Reflecting the Gold Coast era that peaked about 1910 and ended after World War II, most of the greatest wealth is in the city's north and near the water. But public beachheads long ago opened up the grand views over Hempstead Harbor and Long Island Sound, where the financier J. Pierpont Morgan's black yacht, Corsair, once carried Morgan from Manhattan to his estate on what is now called East Island, a waterfront community of expensive to moderately expensive single-family homes. 
There are marvelous vantage points at the 62-acre Garvies Point Museum and Preserve, a county-owned Indian archaeology and regional geology museum, where five miles of nature trails weave through primordial woodland containing dozens of species of trees, shrubs, vines and other flora. 
Most of the old estates have been diced into housing lots since Morgan, F. W. Woolworth and the Standard Oil magnate Charles Pratt and his numerous sons built extravagant and ultraprivate mansions. 
The city is known now less for exclusiveness than inclusiveness. Real estate professionals and others familiar with Glen Cove say its ethnic and economic variousness sets it apart from other North Shore areas. 
"This is the real world -- yes, it is," said Carol A. Caggiano, a sales associate at Daniel Gale MacCrate Real Estate and a former city councilwoman. "It's what the world is about now, the diversity."
In a pattern common throughout Nassau, housing prices have risen substantially in the last five years. But some market segments remain low to moderate when compared with many other North Shore communities. "It's the North Shore, but it's got middle-income areas between the extravagances," said Bob Carlson of Century 21 Jimco Realty. 
Since the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, sales have slowed and prices have stabilized here, as elsewhere. 
Single-family houses predominate, but Glen Cove also has a substantial number of two-family houses whose owners sometimes occupy one unit and rent the other. 
The Legend Yacht and Beach Club, a newly constructed waterfront enclave of about 40 homes on a former Gold Coast estate overlooking Hempstead Harbor, fits within the upper end of the city's real estate market, if $5 million estates are excluded. The prices range from about $750,000 to $2 million for the quasi colonials, most of them on half-acre lots. The gated and guarded entrance recalls an old Gold Coast habit. 
In midrange Roxbury, a neighborhood with many single-family ranches and Capes mostly built in the 1950's, prices range from about $325,000 to $425,000. Single-family homes in Strathmore Glen, most built about 30 years ago, go up to $500,000.
More affordable homes, many built in the 1920's, are in the Landing, an area named for its proximity to a former steamboat and ferry landing. One-family houses range from about $225,000 to $265,000. There are also some two-family houses.
Three condominium complexes -- Cove Landing, Lattingtown Ponds and Long Meadow -- were built within the last 15 years. Co-ops include the Glen Pearsall with three separate five-story buildings and Trousdale Village, a former rental complex.
The Glen Cove Housing Authority maintains 250 units, including 70 units for people 62 and older, in apartment buildings, town houses and row houses at various locations. Tenants pay no more than 30 percent of adjusted gross income in rent. 
Like the city as a whole, the Glen Cove public schools are ethnically and economically diverse. There are two primary schools for kindergarten through second grade, one of which offers half-day pre-K classes: two elementary schools for Grades 3 and 4; and a middle school for Grades 5 through 8.
At the Glen Cove High School, 59 percent of the 170 graduates in the class of 2001 went to four-year colleges and universities, while 34 percent continued at two-year colleges or technical schools and 7 percent enlisted in the military or went to work. More than half the graduates received Regents' diplomas.
College Board averages for the class were 481 in verbal and 496 in math, below the state averages for college-bound students of 495 in verbal and 505 in math.
THE high school, built in 1962 on a 50-acre campus, offers 12 advanced placement courses and a special robotics program in which students build a robot and enter it in a regional competition. The district superintendent, Mary Ellen Freeley, said another program popular with students teaches the fundamentals of business and personal financial management. 
In an academic leap forward, 60 percent of eighth grade students met the state standard in English language testing this year, up from 35 percent last year. Dr. Freeley said the increase resulted from "focus, focus, focus" on test preparation. Improvements were less striking in math, where students meeting the state standard rose from 24 percent to 40 percent. "We still have a long way to go, but we're getting there," Dr. Freeley said. 
Beginning in 1997, when the state first permitted residents of Glen Cove and more than 50 other small cities to vote on the local school budget, two budgets have gone down to defeat. But in 1997, voters approved a $2.5 million technology bond that Dr. Freeley said put Glen Cove among the technological elite districts on Long Island. At least three computers are in every classroom in addition to computer laboratories in school buildings.
Private and parochial schools in and near Glen Cove include Friends Academy and St. Patrick's elementary school.
There are three Long Island Rail Road stations within the city boundaries -- Glen Cove, Glen Street and Sea Cliff -- but the line, on the railroad's Oyster Bay division is not electrified and service is by diesel.
Some residents make private arrangements to secure parking spaces in Manhasset to ride on the Port Washington branch, whose frequently scheduled electric trains whoosh to the city in little more than half an hour. It takes about 20 minutes to drive to Manhasset.
Fox Navigation runs a weekday ferry service to Wall Street for $26 round-trip. Fares are lower for purchasers of weekly, monthly or annual tickets. The ferry leaves from the mouth of Glen Cove Creek at 6:30 a.m. and leaves Pier 11 in lower Manhattan at 5 p.m. The trip takes about 50 minutes each way aboard a high-speed catamaran with room for nearly 400 passengers.
Glen Cove has its own police force and city courts, a large public library, an array of municipal services and plenty of restaurants in downtown areas, although small shops have struggled there. 
"Everything is really right here for me," said Valerie Grella, who paid about $200,000 17 years ago for a Cape Cod now worth about $350,000. "It's diversified, it's waterfront, the restaurants are great and the night life is terrific." 
Rosemary Olsen, the executive director of the city's community development agency, was 5 when her family left Glen Cove, where she was born. She came back many times over the years to visit her grandmother and moved back for good in 1985. "A lot of people come back," she said. "There's a sense of community here."
For golfers, the Glen Cove Municipal Golf Course, with views over Dosoris Pond and Long Island Sound, charges residents and nonresidents $17 on weekdays and $20 on weekends for 18 holes. Residents must purchase an annual permit costing $50. Nonresidents pay $850. 
Three public beaches -- Morgan Park, Crescent Beach and Pryibil Beach -- are reserved for residents, although Morgan Park, a gift from the Morgan family in 1932, is also open to residents of neighboring Locust Valley. 
A city boat ramp on Hempstead Harbor near the mouth of Glen Cove Creek charges residents $10 a day or $30 a season for boats or jet ski access. Nonresidents pay $35 daily and $150 for a season. There are several private marinas. The Hempstead Harbor Club, a privately managed club owned by the city, is open to residents and nonresidents.
Tennis, paddle ball, basketball and handball courts as well as children's playgrounds are located in Stanco Park and Old Tappan Park. An eight-field baseball and softball complex, also used for soccer and football, is at the John Maccarone Memorial Stadium. There is a separate soccer complex at Pascucci Field and large numbers of local children play on junior soccer teams.
Mayor Thomas R. Suozzi, a Democrat, is serving his final weeks as Glen Cove mayor before taking office as Nassau County executive. In November, he defeated the incumbent, Thomas S. Gulotta, a Republican. Mr. Suozzi's successor will be City Councilwoman MaryAnn Holzcamp, a Democrat.
The Matinecock Indians called the Glen Cove area Musketa, meaning a place of rushes. Joseph Carpenter came from Rhode Island to buy harbor lands from the Matinecocks in 1668 and with partners built a saw mill on what is now Glen Cove Creek. Other lumber mills followed.
By 1829, steamboats brought city dwellers, establishing the area as an early summer resort. A starch factory employed Irish immigrants and a power-transmission belt company gave work to Italian immigrants beginning in the mid-19th century. Others worked at estates that wealthy New Yorkers began building in the same period. The name Musketa, regarded as too much like mosquito, was changed to Glen Cove in the 1830's. 
In the early decades of the 20th century, many residents worked in local industries and on estates. After World War II the estates declined, and the population soared with suburban development. After commercial declines in the 1970's and 80's, the city rebounded in the 90's and now harbors plans to revive a long moribund tourist industry. 
One of the city's attractions is Welwyn, a surviving Pratt family estate, which now houses the Holocaust Memorial and Education Center of Nassau County, and where nature trials are open to the public. The winding, tree-lined entrance gives some hint of what it was to live in such a place.

HEADLINE: Suozzi Assembles His Advisory Panels 

BYLINE:  By BRUCE LAMBERT 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY 

 BODY:
PREPARING to take over Nassau County government on Jan. 1, the county executive-elect, Thomas R. Suozzi, has assembled advisory panels that include two former New York City police commissioners, the deans of two law schools, the co-owners of the New York Mets and other prominent business and civic leaders.
 Mr. Suozzi called his transition advisors "the best and brightest" of more than 1,000 candidates. They will serve for $1 a year and, with a few exceptions, are not expected to become county administrators themselves. 
 Their role is twofold. One is to help select prospective officials to serve in key posts in the Suozzi administration, Nassau's first Democratic regime in three decades. They will also review county agencies and functions and recommend ways to revamp the government.
As part of his shakeup, Mr. Suozzi sent letters to about 140 non-civil service officials, like agency commissioners and their deputies, asking for their resignations and also their resumes, if they wish to continue. Not all the posts will necessarily be filled, Mr. Suozzi said, as he tries to pare the government. Although most top officials are expected to be replaced, Mr. Suozzi said he does not preclude keeping some holdovers, based on performance. 
A spokesman for the Republican minority in the County Legislature, Robert Lazaro, criticized the transition, saying Mr. Suozzi's appointments of top aides are lagging behind the pace being set by Michael Bloomberg, the mayor-elect of New York City.
Given Nassau's chronic fiscal problems, a high-priority panel is the one on the budget. Its co-chairs are Adam Barsky, New York City's budget director, and Kathleen M. Carrano, Westchester's budget director.
A related panel on economics is headed by Dr. Irwin Kellner, an economist at Hofstra and chief economist of CBS Marketwatch. Other members include James L. Dolan, president of Cablevision; Rhonda Brown, president of Nine West Group; Scott Rechler, chairman of Reckson Associates Realty; Charles Wang, chairman of Computer Associates; Fred Wilpon, co-owner of the Mets; Edward Travaglianti, Citibank's president for commercial markets; John Bransfield, president of Roslyn Savings Bank and John J. O'Neill, executive vice president of Fleet National Bank.
The cochairmen of the police panel are William Bratton, a former city police commissioner, and Anthony Cancelliere, Rockville Centre's village administrator and a former police officer who will serve as a deputy county executive.
The assessment and real estate panel's cochairmen are Michael Martone, a lawyer who specializes in that field, and a state Supreme Court justice, Frank Rossetti.
Heading the panel on the county attorney's office is Joseph W. Bellacosa, the dean at St. John's University law school and a former judge.
The cochairmen of the social services panel are Willy B. Edlow Jr., president of the United Way of Long Island, and Brooke Spiro, dean of social work at Adelphi University.
On the information technology panel, the cochairmen are Bert Brodsky, chairman of the Sandata company, and Yogesh Gupta, senior vice president of Computer Associates.
The cochairmen of the community development panel are Patrick G. Duggan, director of Sustainable Long Island, a "smart growth" advocacy group, and David Mejias, a lawyer who ran unsuccessfully for the County Legislature as a Democrat.
The cochairmen of the evaluations and productivity panel are Tom Germano, the Long Island director of the Cornell School of Industrial and Labor Relations, and Hezekiah Brown, a Hempstead village trustee.

HEADLINE: Finding a Connection, Though a World Away 

BYLINE:  By ALAN BISBORT 

 BODY:
ACCORDING to an environmental mantra, one must think globally and act locally. Some Connecticut residents, however, have the means to turn that mantra on its head by thinking globally and then acting on their thoughts. Because of this, Connecticut residents have had an impact on the environmental health of the planet. 
 Stewart H. Greenfield, a Westport financier, decided in 1988 that he wanted to help protect the world's rain forest. 
 Though soft-spoken and philosophical by nature, Mr. Greenfield does not go lightly into any effort, and he brought the same focus to his conservation business that he has brought to his highly profitable Oak Investments, a venture capital firm. He was particularly drawn to the Nature Conservancy's Latin American program. 
"My concerns were twofold," Mr. Greenfield said. "One, to save the maximum amount of biomass per dollar, and, secondly, to focus on species preservation. There's such an enormous number of indigenous species in the tropical rain forest and acreage is therefore important. For the price of a building lot in Westport, you can save 100 square miles of rain forest."
Specifically, he was able to help purchase a 25,000-acre ranch on the sparsely populated high Bolivian plateau. That initial investment became the headquarters for the then-2.2 million-acre Noel Kempff Mercado National Park, home to 600 bird species (the United States is home to 768 bird species according to the Nature Conservancy).
Set along a river that borders Brazil, the park had been ravaged by drug traffickers and timber poachers, who had built a bridge across the river and logged hardwoods. An on-site inspection convinced Mr. Greenfield it was time to make some serious moves.
"When I visited in 1991, we went to the center of the lumber operations," Mr. Greenfield said. "We saw incredibly wasteful cutting of mahogany, where only 10 percent of the hardwoods were used.
"It's a major problem to re-establish mahogany because trees don't grow in separate stands in the tropics. On an acre down there you'll find 125 different species of trees, whereas here you are lucky to find eight species."
The Brazilian government has since interceded to stop the poaching and a Bolivian environmental group worked to disassemble the bridge. The national park has expanded to four million acres, when the Bolivian government rescinded timber licenses on an adjoining 1.8 million acres. 
"The park is now half again as large as Connecticut," Mr. Greenfield said.
Dorinda and Mark Winkelman of Essex have assumed a different role. Before this year, they had acted locally, donating $250,000 to protect the tidelands of the Connecticut River. But, after being offered a chance to visit Palmyra Atoll, a "flyspeck on the map" 1,052 miles south of Hawaii, they donated $1 million toward the purchase the fragile sanctuary, considered the last marine wilderness of America's tropics.
The atoll, a fragile cluster of islets, covering 680 acres of land and 15,512 acres of reefs, has three times as many coral species as all of Hawaii, and it is one of the few nesting areas for sea birds within 450,000 square miles.
"This came about in a serendipitous way, when Mark went bonefishing," Dorinda Winkelman said. "The fragility of the atoll is just incredible. It is said to have one of the biggest indigenous forests in the Pacific, just a few acres of a dwarf pin oak that looks more like scrub. No indigenous people were displaced by the project, which was an extra bonus that made it special."
The Winkelmans' gift also kick-started a Nature Conservancy grant program, whereby the national office gave 50 percent in matching funds to the state chapter. Thus, saving the Pacific atoll will have an effect on Connecticut's landscape as well.
"The Greenfields and the Winkelmans provide a great example for the kind of thinking and generosity we'll need to succeed at global conservation in the years ahead," said Dennis McGrath, director of the Nature Conservancy's Connecticut Chapter. 
The Winkelmans' gift also spared Palmyra a different fate.
"There was some talk to use it as a dump for plutonium rods, and the Japanese were interested in basing a seaweed processing plant there," Dorinda Winkelman said. "There was a real opportunity to protect it, and the Nature Conservancy put together the deal, with the U.S. government." 
Other projects, of course, beckon. Mr. Greenfield, for one, continues to focus on Latin America, partly because he has seen positive results. He has also donated to programs in Paraguay, Panama, Costa Rica, Belize, Mexico and the Dominican Republic. 
"Environmental concerns were a low priority 20 years ago, but there's a growing body who have been able to use television to inculcate in the people the rich holdings of species and natural gifts that they have in Latin America," Mr. Greenfield said.
Jim Brunton, who is based in Westport, runs JAB Enterprises, a computer software company whose profits drive the work of two conservation efforts, the Pajaro Jai Foundation (www.jabinc.org) and Ocean Wood Gallery, which sells "rain forest furniture" and other products created by indigenous peoples.
The area Mr. Brunton seeks to protect is the Darien Rainforest in Panama, and his conservation partners are the indigenous Chocoe Indians in the village of Mogue.
Their symbol is a boat, named the Pajaro Jai (a half-Spanish, half-Chocoe phrase that describes a phoenix-like bird). This 92-foot ketch, due to be completed in July 2002, is being built by the Indians from the hardwoods found in the nearby forest.
Though it will become the foundation's flagship, it is the resurrected kindred spirit of the original Pajaro Jai, also built by the Chocoe and launched in 1986. That vessel had a string of environmental successes, including being a driving force behind preserving the coral reefs of Montego Bay in Jamaica, but it was lost in a tropical storm in 1991.
"The key to everything is to let the people themselves do the work," Mr. Brunton said. "We can't solve ecological or human economic problems with Band-Aids. Money alone sometimes brings action to a halt. I've seen it do more damage than good."
Mr. Brunton said the Chocoe are skilled with their hands, "so the project emphasizes boat-building and furniture."
"But, in the long run," he added, "we want to create an economic development dynamic inside the culture itself, to catapult them 20 years ahead. They'll be eaten alive if we don't."
Mr. Brunton dates his relationship with the Chocoe to 1967, when as a Peace Corps volunteer he found himself in the Panamanian rain forest.
"They had dignity, beauty and an intact culture, and I began to fear that my presence was going to destroy some of this," Mr. Brunton said. "Fate dropped me, an ordinary person of average morality, into an extraordinary situation. Since the cultural disintegration would proceed with me, or without me, would it be a cop-out to walk? Might I contribute to a healthier future in some way?"
Almost 40 years later, Mr. Brunton is still involved with the Chocoe. "All of this comes from my guts, from knowing these people," he said. "Trust is important."
Mr. Brunton said that the products the Chocoe can produce from a single tree in the rain forest are worth the income generated from 40 acres of cattle grazing, and three trees can generate as much income as a village the size of Mogue's entire cropland.
"Despite all the awareness and efforts to do green business in the tropics, the rate of destruction of the rain forest is increasing, not diminishing," he said. "Something we're doing is wrong."

HEADLINE: A Holiday Gift for Retailers: Plenty of Sales Help 

BYLINE:  By FRAN SILVERMAN 

 BODY:
LAST year, Emmanuel Hemelsoet, the manager of the Eddie Bauer store at the Stamford Town Center, was having such a tough time finding employees to staff his holiday shifts that he walked the mall trying to recruit employees from other stores.
 This year, he is turning people away. 
 "Loads of people came in," he said. "We are feeling much more comfortable."
With the economy sagging, retailers across the state said they are having an easier time finding holiday help. Many said they haven't had to advertise for employees as aggressively as last year, offer quite as high salaries and have been able to hire more experienced staff. 
"Last year, people thought they were doing me a favor by walking in and punching in," Mr. Hemelsoet said. "This year, if they don't do their job, I can politely say goodbye."
The labor market was so tight last year, retailers went to some unusual lengths to hire staff, offering benefits and employee discounts to their part-time temporary help that they had not offered in the past. And still some stores were unable to fill their spots.
John Michaels, co-owner of Michaels Jewelers, said he had to offer his existing staff time and a half to work extra shifts at his 12 stores in the state last year and a higher base salary regardless of experience. This year, he hasn't had to.
"Because there is more unemployment, people are not switching and jumping, so we have less turnover," said Mr. Michaels, who is offering his staff between $8-$15 an hour based on experience. "People are more committed to what they are doing and are willing to inconvenience themselves to work the extra hours."
Marc Gratt, 54, of New Fairfield, a car salesman, is working nights and weekends at Macy's at the Danbury Fair Mall for the season. He said he had earned less at the Honda dealership in commissions than in previous years and sought the part-time holiday job to help make ends meet.
"It's getting harder and harder to make the car sales," he said. "Business is not as good as a year ago. The economy is playing into everything. You just don't know what will happen next."
Megan Wicklund, 23, works at the pocketbook counter at Macy's. She graduated from the University of Connecticut in June, but has been unable to find a job. She said she had interviewed at an insurance company in Boston three times, but the company has a hiring freeze, so she applied to Macy's shortly after Thanksgiving. The store offered her $8 an hour and a 20 percent discount on purchases.
"I'm living home with my parents, so I will save up some money and try to develop a wardrobe for when I do get a job," she said.
Retailers said the big question this year is not whether they will be able to fill their sales spots, but whether shoppers will fill their stores.
"What's on everybody's mind now is how business is going to be, will we do the same numbers as last year," said Kevin Keenan, general manager of Westfarms Mall in Farmington.
Retailers said they had seen an increase in applicants from people who were recently laid off and those looking to earn extra money in an uncertain economy. In October, the state unemployment rate was 3.2 percent.
Deidre Goodrich, marketing director at Westfarms, said there was a sudden surge of applicants looking to fill retail slots right before Thanksgiving.
The mall kept lists of which stores were hiring at the customer service desk and handed out dozens of them to people looking for work.
"That certainly didn't happen last year," she said.
She attributed the surge to unease among workers about their financial security.
"When you hear a lot of mixed news about how things are going in the economy, if you see an opportunity to make yourself a little more secure, you will go for it," she said.
A spokeswoman for Filene's said the department store chain had cut back on recruitment efforts this season.
"We've seen an increase in applicants over last year, more walk-ins and as a result we've been able to reduce our advertisements for sales help," said Robin Reibel, the spokeswoman.
While Ms. Reibel wouldn't discuss details about holiday staffing needs or what salary and benefits the department store is offering its temporary workers, she said the stores were able to fill most of their staff levels this year.
Larry Davidson, chief executive of Weathervane, a New Britain-based chain of women's clothing stores, said the quality of holiday applicants had improved from last year. While he attributed the change to an increase in the store's popularity, he said the economy was also playing a role. 
"We've been able to be a little more selective and to hire quicker," he said. "The applicant pool seems hungrier. Last year, there was trepidation of would you be able to fill your positions, forget quality, could you just find them."
Two years ago, Bob Hertzel, owner of Kleins of Westport, a frame and stationery store, had to take out advertisements to attract holiday help. This year, people approached him for work. 
"I had two or three applicants right away," he said. "The applicants were older and had more experience."
Retailers said staffing for the holiday season was tricky this year because of the uncertainty of the market following the Sept. 11 attacks. Mall traffic dropped from the previous year by 5.3 percent in October, plummeting by 17 percent on Halloween alone. Traffic dropped by 7.4 percent on Thanksgiving weekend, according to the National Retail Traffic Index.
Because of the drop in sales, many retailers said they didn't expect to need as many holiday workers as last year -- and can't afford to hire as many.
Mr. Hertzel usually hires three additional workers for the holiday season. This year, he hired just one.
Isiah Robinson, manager of FAO Schwarz in Stamford Town Center, said the store hired only 12 extra workers for the season this year. Last year, the store hired between 15 and 20.
"We had a lot of people come in this year, but we didn't need them," he said.
Leon Magarian, owner of Travel Necessities at Westfield Shoppingtown in Trumbull, didn't hire any holiday help this year. He said sales plummeted in his store, which sells luggage and other travel-related items, after Sept. 11.
"Business is very bad. Last year, I hired three workers, this year, I can't afford to hire anyone," he said. "I am working seven days a week, 12-14 hours each day."
Mr. Magarian said sales were down by 40 percent from last Thanksgiving. 
Other retailers said sales were starting to pick up.
"Our traffic was up over last year on Friday of Thanksgiving weekend," said Karen Pollard, general manager of the Brass Mill Center in Waterbury.
Mrs. Pollard said stores in the mall, stung by last year's tight labor market, recruited earlier this year and were easily able to find enough workers. 
Tim Phelan, president of the Connecticut Retail Merchants Association, said consumers might surprise retailers this year.
"Consumers are starting to bounce back," he said. "They weren't necessarily ready at Halloween, but they may be by the time Christmas comes around. Retailers may not feel a great need to staff like they did last year, but the need is still there."
Because of the unpredictability of the holiday market, retailers said they ha've had to be more fluid with their staffing levels this year, hiring part-timers who could easily expand or reduce their hours depending on sales levels.
"We are being very careful and monitoring what our needs are every day," said Ms. Reibel of Filene's. "It requires a closer eye than in other years."

HEADLINE: Certainly a Recession, but an Odd One 

BYLINE:  By HARLAN J. LEVY 

 BODY:
RESTAURANTS from Southport to Vernon to West Hartford are crowded; some manufacturers are reporting growing profits and are considering hiring more workers; housing permits are up, and defense contractors are saying they expect to have a good year in 2002.
 What kind of recession is this? 
 The state, along with the rest of the country, was slipping into recession before Sept. 11, when the terrorist attacks pushed the economy over the edge. But while the national unemployment rate rose to 5.4 percent in October, the Connecticut rate actually fell to 3.2 percent, down from 3.6 percent in both August and September.
By all accounts, this recession isn't going to be anything near what the state experienced during the last one, when from 1989 to 1992 the state lost 158,000 jobs, jobs that weren't fully replaced until January 2000. This time many economists estimated that only a maximum of 45,000 jobs will be lost and the recovery will begin as early as the middle of next year, although the recovery itself may be slow. 
"We will stop the declines in jobs in 2002," said Daniel Kennedy, senior economist at the Connecticut Department of Labor. "In 2002 we'll be trying to come out of it, and it's going to be anemic. You may see some job growth in 2003, but nothing significant until late 2003 and early 2004."
Economists said that what is muting the recession in the state, at least so far, is that the economy is more diversified than it was during the last recession and that the state does not have to contend with the speculative building boom and bust and subsequent bad debt crisis of 10 years ago. Also, the growth in service jobs has offered some protection, said Steven Lanza, an economist at the University of Connecticut.
"Services are holding up pretty well," Mr. Lanza, "and our economy is more reliant on service jobs."
Nicholas Perna, an economist in Ridgefield who was chief economist for Fleet Financial Group, said that barring anything unexpected, like another terrorist attack, the downturn will not last long.
"This recession will be over in four or five months, and it's going to be followed by a fairly impressive recovery," Mr. Perna said. "We're going to look a lot like the national economy, and the national economy should be out of recession next spring, around March or April."
Stimulation from the 11 interest rate cuts with another one possible, the federal tax refunds that were distributed this summer, "plus the added defense and security outlays ought to make for a pretty decent expansion starting in the spring," Mr. Perna said.
Although October figures show that durable goods manufacturing, financial services, retail and wholesale trade, and technology continued to have the largest job losses, which started after Sept. 11, pockets of profitability sprinkled statewide have some business owners very relieved.
Owners of moderate-priced restaurants in Southport, Stamford, Vernon, Hartford, Glastonbury, Avon and West Hartford all said they had solid though not spectacular 5 percent to 6 percent increases from September through November over the same period last year.
It took anywhere from one to six weeks after the attacks for their businesses to recover, they all said.
"Weekends are particularly strong, but there's less during the week," said Richard Rosenthal, owner of the Max chain of five restaurants in Hartford and its affluent suburbs. "People are spending, but businesses aren't. People go out on the weekends. But when the boss decides he needs to make year-end numbers, he freezes discretionary spending."
The Southport Brewing Company and its sister location in Stamford had "a lot of corporate parties cancel," the owner, William daSilva, said. "Now it's starting to pick up again. We're booked for Christmas both places, partywise."
In manufacturing, the W. E. Bassett company of Shelton, which employees about 120, also reported growing sales. It makes the Trim brand of nail clippers and emery boards.
Sales are up 13 percent for the year through November over the same period last year, with a 25 percent gain in October and 20 percent in November, William Bassett, the president, said. After Jan. 1, he said, a decision will be made on "how many permanent employees we will need to hire."
On the other hand, Allyson Bernard, a real estate agent in Danbury and president of the Connecticut Association of Realtors, has seen a drop in her residential sales. Ms. Bernard usually sells or buys about 25 to 30 homes a year, most going for $200,000 to $300,000.
"Before Sept. 11, I had four to five active listings and eight to 10 contracted buyer clients on average," Ms. Bernard said. "Now I have three listings and five contracted buyer clients, but it's not all doom and gloom."
The end of the year is traditionally slow, she said, but low interest rates and sparse inventory have kept traffic flowing, and prices have held steady.
"Buyers are waiting and being more patient," Ms. Bernard said. "Before, if a new property came on the market they might make an offer right there and then. Now they sleep on it. The good news for everybody involved is they're more positive and committed once they decide to go forward."
Ms. Bernard, reported home sales down in most of Fairfield County, with an average price of $381,734, down from $403,506. The Greater Hartford market saw new listings rise, with an average price of $201,594, up from $187,694. Eastern Connecticut had more home sales in the third quarter with an average sale price of $190,891, up $14,000. And the shoreline/Middlesex County area had fewer home sales from Sept. 1 through Nov. 28.
Lux Bond & Green, a jewelry, watch, and giftware chain with stores in Hartford, West Hartford, Glastonbury, Westport, Greenwich and the Mohegan Sun casino, reported profits off "double digits" in September. But October and November were up by "single digits," said Marc Green, the owner.
"We were pleasantly surprised at how much business came back in Fairfield County," Mr. Green said. "But the merchandise is a little different mix. I'm selling a lot more religious jewelry and charm bracelets, and we've sold more engagement rings in all the stores."
Some of the state's largest employers are also continuing to report solid results. 
United Technologies, the Hartford defense contractor, showed a 14 percent third-quarter gain in earnings, although it announced in October that it would be cutting 2,500 jobs in the state. The drug company, Pfizer, which has a research operation in the New London area, also reported double-digit earnings growth in the third quarter. The company also predicted it would have an even better year in 2002, as did Fairfield-based General Electric.
Still, the manufacturing industry lost 1,600 state jobs from September through October, and for the first 10 months of the year 9,200 jobs disappeared from the same period last year. Most of that was in durable goods manufacturing. James Moor, a professor at the University of Connecticut Business School, said he doesn't expect the manufacturing industry to do well.
"It always tends to take it on the chin in a global recession," said Mr. Moor, formerly chief economist at the Hartford Financial Services Group. "This is the first synchronous global recession since the early 1980's, so exports, which we are long on in Connecticut, are not going to be a strong suit."
He also said that a lingering weakness will persist in financial services, "which is getting the double whammy of a recession plus World Trade Center losses for local insurers and re-insurers in particular."
The state reported that it lost about 4,000 jobs from the end of September through October, but actually gained 800 jobs from October of last year. With forecasts ranging from 35,000 to 45,000 jobs lost for this recession, the overall total of lost jobs would be a mere quarter of the last recession's.
Minnie Clancy of Bloomfield, who worked for LSG Sky Chefs of East Granby, which prepares in-flight meals for airlines at Bradley International Airport, lost the job on Sept. 25. Her job became expendable when many airlines cut back meal service on domestic flights.
Since then Ms. Clancy, 49, has applied for similar food service jobs but has had no luck. "The places I did have luck I didn't want it because it starts back at the bottom again," she said. "I'm finding very low-paid jobs, and even those are snatched up, so I'm giving up right now."
In October, the state had 542,200 service jobs, down 600, or 0.1 percent, from 542,800 during the previous October, but up 1,300 from September. Restaurant services gained 300 jobs, health services 2,300 jobs, hotels lost 200, and business services lost 5,300 from October 2000. Restaurant jobs, such as Ms. Clancy's, however, fell by a total of about 2,000 in September and October.
Construction, usually hit hard in recessions, actually increased by 200 jobs from September through October, although they were down by about 2,000 from the previous October.
Transportation, communications, and utilities lost 1,000 jobs between September and October, with 2,200 jobs lost from October, 2000. The retail and wholesale trades lost 1,800 jobs from September to the end of October and lost 3,800 jobs compared with October, 2000.
The recession has also hit the state's tax revenues. For the first 10 months of the year, total tax revenues declined 4.3 percent. Although revenues fell 7.9 percent in September compared with the same month last year, revenues in October fell only 3.2 percent.
Housing permits also showed some life. The state issued permits for 820 units in October and 7,912 for the year through October, compared with 7,850 a year ago.
Economists warned that there are still many unkowns. Consumer spending, for example, is a key issue, much of it coming in the fourth quarter as people shop for the holidays.
"Consumers represent two-thirds of Connecticut's gross state product, but it's difficult to forecast anything in these times," said Mark Prisloe, chief economist of the State Department of Economic and Community Development. He said that with New York State reporting a 30 percent decline in Wall Street bonuses this year, spending on big-ticket items such as cars and vacations will likely decline, especially in Fairfield County.
Edward Deak, an economics professor at Fairfield University, said other risks include the war against terrorism, increasing personal bankruptcies and business failures, the erosion of the dollar, energy prices and supplies, and the effect of job worries.
"The risks are just a laundry list of potential events, some or all of which may never materialize," he said. "However, collectively they raise concerns that breed caution at a time when cyclical recovery demands confidence."
How long before Connecticut gets back on its feet is the big question, Mr. Kennedy said.
"To quote Yogi Berra," he said, "it ain't over till it's over."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
Restoring the Glory of an Early Hotel in Cape May

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
BEFORE Cape May turned from a whaling colony to a premier seaside resort in the middle of the 19th century, there was Congress Hall, among the first large hotels in this coastal community and in the state.
 Though the building, where four United States presidents summered, has changed its look, size, name and even use over the years, it has stood on the same site since 1816. It is on four oceanside acres on Beach Drive in the heart of this city of sea breezes and waves that tango with the beach at the southern tip of the New Jersey shore. Cape May is also a national historic landmark, thanks to its Victorian-era buildings, more than 600 of them, colored mauve, chartreuse or pink and adorned with turrets and gables as well as wood trim that looks like lace. 
 Congress Hall, with its tall colonnade and sprawling back lawn, is among the last of the grand shore hotels and until recently was mostly dormant and in need of repair. Now the L-shaped hotel is nearing the end of a $22 million rehabilitation that will return it to its former grandeur and help keep alive memories of the city's glory days. 
When it opens in April, the hotel will have 104 guest rooms and five suites, a 150-seat restaurant, a nightclub and a ballroom that will double as a conference center, with nearly 3,000 square feet of meeting space. The new Congress Hall will welcome guests year round -- not all shore hotels do -- and it will include 16 retail shops. 
Cape Advisors Inc. of Cape May is restoring the Federal-style, four-story building according to federal guidelines. Financing is coming from public and private sources, including federal historic-rehabilitation tax credits.
Curtis J. Bashaw, who with Craig D. Wood founded Cape Advisors, called the project an opportunity and an "emotional experience." 
Mr. Bashaw, 41, a local hotelier, spent summers as he was growing up at a range of jobs from dishwasher to bell hop at Congress Hall and the 330-room Christian Admiral Hotel, which was razed in 1996. A grandfather of Mr. Bashaw, the Rev. Dr. Carl McIntire, headed the Christian Beacon Press, a religious group that owned both hotels before it declared bankruptcy in 1990. 
In a 1995 transaction sanctioned by the bankruptcy court, Mr. Bashaw and Mr. Wood bought the mortgage of both hotels from the lender and the land under them from Christian Beacon Press. The price was $4.5 million. 
Seeing Congress Hall restored is good news for the city. "It is one of Cape May's last links to the 1800's," said Luciano V. Corea Jr., the city administrator. It also means additional tax revenue, he said. Projections are that the restored hotel will contribute more than $200,000 in local property taxes a year, compared with the $35,000 it now pays.
Still, getting to this point has not been easy. There is a legal challenge from neighbors worried that the project would hurt the area if the hotel's lawn is used for overflow parking for guests, as it has been for decades. The parties are trying to reach a solution through mediation, a process that will not hinder the hotel's opening, lawyers for both sides said.
The rehabilitation is also proceeding at a time that the state's lodging industry has slipped, as the recession and the effects of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 take their toll. Through October the statewide occupancy rate was 66.6 percent, down from 69.6 percent a year earlier, according to Smith Travel Research in Hendersonville, Tenn. 
The impact is harshest on business hotels in the northern part of the state, said Sean F. Hennessey, director of the hospitality consulting group at PricewaterhouseCoopers. But the expectation, he added, is that the statewide market will not see "a massive number of closings, since hotels have more of a cushion to absorb a downturn today than they did the last recession." 
The Congress Hall project, Mr. Hennessey said, "could have a good deal of merit," given the general lack of sizable shore hotels. In light of the sluggishness of the economy and consumer concerns about traveling by air, resort communities will benefit from a surge in "drive-in business," he added. 
That has helped to keep business fairly stable so far in Cape May, where a number of tourism businesses have made a concerted effort to extend the season beyond the end of summer, local lodging professionals said. "We will fare well in the 2002 season, if gas prices and the stock market stay the same," Barbara Jackson, executive director of the Chamber of Commerce of Greater Cape May, said, noting that the city is within a three-hour, 175-mile drive of 18 million people. "Here, you can really get away, step back in time and feel safe."
She said the restoration of Congress Hall, "has also created a buzz" and will draw the curious. The developers said they intend to attract not only tourists but also a business and meeting crowd.
UNLIKE some other hotels or motels in town, Congress Hall will have a liquor license, which is available only to hotels with at least 102 rooms.
The market for conventions is still an unopened niche in Cape May. But Mr. Bashaw said he had successfully tapped it at his 24-room Virginia Hotel -- a tattered Victorian building he restored in 1989. 
Congress Hall opened in 1816 as a three-story boarding house called the Big House and soon became a hotel. It was given its current name after its owner, Thomas H. Hughes, was elected to Congress in 1828. The hotel's appeal and size grew through 1878, when it was destroyed by fire; it was rebuilt to its present design the next year. 
For most of the 19th century, it was a dazzling attraction, visited by Presidents Ulysses S. Grant, Franklin Pierce and James Buchanan, and President Benjamin Harrison made it his summer White House. The composer John Philip Sousa also performed there and wrote the "Congress Hall March" in its honor.
With the 1920's came competition from other seaside towns, like Atlantic City, and the Depression turned Cape May into a sleepy town. The hotel closed and did not reopen until after World War II. 
From 1968 to 1995 the Christian Beacon Press, headed by Mr. Bashaw's grandfather, owned Congress Hall and the Christian Admiral. Dr. McIntire, a firebrand radio preacher and pastor of the Bible Presbyterian Church in Collingswood, drew his followers to both hotels for Bible conferences and seminars. 
In 1990 the group filed for bankruptcy and eventually the Christian Admiral, which was in far worse condition than Congress Hall, was condemned. After attempts to salvage that hotel failed, Cape Advisors in 1995 bought the mortgage on both hotels and the land under them. The next year, as required by the bankruptcy court, the Christian Admiral was razed. 
Its seven-acre site was subdivided into 26 single-family building lots. They were sold to pay creditors, Mr. Wood said. 
Essentially, Mr. Bashaw added, the Christian Admiral was sacrificed to save Congress Hall. Over the next three years the partners secured the approvals and financing to proceed with the rehabilitation. 
But some neighbors opposed the project and in 1999 challenged the city's approval, contending the approvals violated federal laws for such preservation projects. They also said the Congress Hall renovation would have a negative impact on the surrounding historic district if parking on the hotel lawn continues. 
The court dismissed the complaint, and the neighbors appealed. Last year the appeal was stayed, pending mediation. 
Mr. Bashaw said he is optimistic a solution will be reached. So are Mr. Corea, the city administrator, and Philip Walker, a lawyer representing the neighbors. "I am hopeful we can come away from this in a way that benefits all involved," Mr. Walker said.
Meanwhile, the renovation continues. The work, 80 percent completed, includes installing 11 miles of new plumbing and 18,000 slate roof shingles as well as removing, cleaning and reinstalling 158,000 bricks. The 19th century facade is also being restored. 
Inside, the rooms, some with balconies, are being refurbished to reflect how they looked in the 1920's when the hotel was last renovated. They will be furnished with antiques and fixtures original to the hotel, and the bathrooms will have tubs and pedestal sinks from the renovation era. 
Mr. Bashaw said the goal of this project, like Mr. Hughes's 1816 original, "is to create a place within the bones of this special building that people will see as their second home by the sea."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester; 
Pleasantville: Film Center Success Has Ripple Effect

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
THREE years ago, Salvatore Arcidiacono, a commercial real estate broker and property owner in Pleasantville, had 20 empty storefronts for rent in the economically struggling downtown area of the village. Today he has only one.
 One important factor in the turnaround in the eight-block business district, Mr. Arcidiacono said, was the opening last spring of the Jacob Burns Film Center, a multiscreen complex for foreign and independent films. The film center, which is at 364 Manville Road, makes use of a building that was built in the 1920's as a movie theater but housed offices in recent years. 
 The nonprofit center's board had anticipated selling 500 memberships in the first year; instead, it has sold 5,000 in only six months. Admission prices are lower for members than for the general public. 
"The new theater certainly has had an impact," said Mr. Arcidiacono, a lifelong resident of Pleasantville, explaining that the popularity of the film center theater has had a spillover effect.
In the past six months, there have been more pedestrians on the sidewalks, especially in the evenings -- with many of them coming from distant parts of the county and even from New York City and neighboring counties. Restaurateurs said they were serving more meals, and merchants reported that sales were up.
"The Film Center appears to have put Pleasantville on the map," said Martha Krakow, branch manager for Coldwell Banker Residential Brokerage. "It's brought a panache to the town. It used to be so sleepy in the evening that everything closed up at 5. Now it's lively."
The village had been without a movie theater since 1987, when the popular Rome Theater, which opened in 1925 and had 459 seats, ceased doing business. "People loved the Rome," said Toni Emerson, whose grandfather Pancrazio Aucello built the original theater in the Spanish Mission style -- with a barrel-tiled roof, porticos, outside columns and pediment -- architectural details that remain. 
Ms. Emerson, a member of Pleasantville's Chamber of Commerce and the co-chairwoman of its Business Support Council, recalled attending movies on Saturday afternoons at the Rome when she was growing up in Pleasantville in the 1940's and 50's. For the 14 years the village was without a movie house, there was a feeling that "something was missing," she said.
After the closing of the Rome, which was a two-screen theater in its later years, and before the site became the home of the Jacob Burns Film Center, it was converted into an office building with photographic studios for an advertising agency. "Then we got wind of the Burns Film Festival proposal, although no one dreamed at first that it would become as popular as it has," Ms. Emerson said. "It really has had a cascading effect on real estate and business."
In 1998, Stephen Apkon, a former merchant banker and now the executive director of the film center, formed the Friends of the Rome Theater, a nonprofit organization, and purchased the 11,000-square-foot former moviehouse and a 6,000-square-foot parcel of land next door for $1 million.
Another $4 million was spent for design and construction, and today the film center covers 18,500 square feet and houses three theaters: one with 260 seats, another with 140 and a third -- a screening room -- with 72 seats.
The center, which opened in June, has been financed in part by a $1.5 million gift from the Jacob Burns Foundation, a family foundation named for a local lawyer who died in 1993. The foundation also got $4.5 million in tax-exempt bond financing assistance from the Westchester County Industrial Development Agency, only the second nonprofit arts organization to do so. The Music Conservatory of Westchester in White Plains was the first, also receiving $4.5 million in tax-exempt bond financing. Typically, such bonds provide long-term purchase financing and short-term construction funds during renovation.
The complex was designed by Davis Brody Bond Architects of Manhattan, which also did the Rose Building at Lincoln Center, including the 268-seat Walter Reade Theater and the Juilliard School. 
NATHAN HOYT, an associate partner at Davis Brody Bond, said it was decided to leave intact what remained from the Rome Theater -- mostly the exterior -- but not to recreate the Spanish style, most of which was obliterated by the advertising firm. 
"Especially inside, there was nothing much left," Mr. Hoyt said. "So rather than mimic what was there once, we created a fairly contemporary interior. We did the addition in a modern style in contrast to the old building."
"But we didn't want it to look like a multiplex, so we gave it a more artistic look and created a more downtown kind of space with industrial materials like concrete flooring in the lobby," he said.
The architects also used steel and slate for the stairs and aluminum mesh on the acoustic panels rather than fabric. And they left the interior brick walls exposed.
"Since there would be foreign and independent films shown here, we gave the center an organic look," Mr. Hoyt said. "We chose honest materials as opposed to glitzy or fancy finishes."
Next door to the theater, one of the new commercial tenants in the village, Michael Marchica, the owner of I Fetish Optique, an eyeglass store, installed awnings outside, new plate glass windows and oak floors inside 700 square feet of space owned and formerly occupied by Mr. Arcidiacono as a newspaper and candy store. Mr. Marchica declined to say how much he paid to revamp the storefront, but he did say his investment was paying off because of what he call "the resurgence in Pleasantville."
Mr. Arcidiacono, who owns 6,500 square feet of commercial space next door to the theater, said his properties are now more in demand than ever. And although he would not specify what rents he charges, he said most properties in the village go for about $20 a square foot a year -- several dollars a square foot higher than two years ago.
Across the street from the film center, Carol Greenman, the owner of the Village Bookstore, said her business in August was double was what it had been a year earlier at another site in the village. When she lost her lease on the first store, she moved to the present storefront, which is 1,700 square feet, and paid more per square foot, in part because it is on a corner and in a more prominent location. "It's been worth the extra cost," she said. "It's been a good synergy between the theater and the bookstore, in spite of the economic recession we're experiencing."
Tara Klein, who plans to open a bed-and-breakfast in the village in a 215-year-old wood-frame Victorian house that was to be demolished, said she and her husband, Russell, an architect, were "inspired by the film center" to undertake their venture. 
"We probably wouldn't have considered something like this a year or two ago," she said. "The film center has laid the foundation for all kinds of new and needed businesses in town."
Another entrepreneur, Warren Schloat, the president of Schloat Properties, has a proposal to build a 60,000-square-foot retail, office and residential complex in the village.
"I had my plans before the film center came in," Mr. Schloat said, "and I didn't say to myself, 'Wow! The Burns is open and now I'm going to build this.' But the thing is, I have a growing confidence in Pleasantville, and certainly, the Burns is part of that. I would be planning the complex even if it were not for the theater, but now my confidence is off the charts."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The film center houses three theaters, with 72, 140 and 260 seats. (Susan Farley for The New York Times) Map of Westchester shows the location of Jacob Burns Film Center.

HEADLINE: IN PERSON; 
Creating a Community of Theaters

BYLINE:  By JILL P. CAPUZZO

 BODY:
HE may have played Tevye in "Fiddler on the Roof" and Fagan in "Oliver," but it soon became painfully clear to John McEwen -- with no singing voice and minimal dance talent -- that his love of theater would need to be redirected. Offstage.
 Mr. McEwen's onstage experiences were as a teenager. He soon decided to direct his energy toward the business side. Now after 15 years in theater and arts development, he finds himself as the executive director of the New Jersey Theater Alliance, a statewide consortium of theater companies that offers marketing, research and advocacy for the theater community. Mr. McEwen, who lives in West Orange, will be shaping theater programs and policy for the alliance's network of 23 senior professional theaters and 6 affiliate members. 
 Mr. McEwen, 40, says his passion for theater dates back to his childhood, when he saw his first professional stage production: "South Pacific" with Betsy Palmer at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn. His own performing days were short-lived -- mostly summer stock theater in his teens, since his high school in Linden (where his father was assistant principal) didn't have a drama department. His interest in the business side of theater began when he was an undergraduate student at Montclair State and he served internships at the Berkshire Theater Festival and later as jack-of-all-trades at the Ensemble Studio Theater in New York City. 
"Once I got behind the scenes I began to see how theater could be used not only to entertain but also to help in community development, how it has so many other points of value, how it can nourish the soul," Mr. McEwen said.
While Mr. McEwen was getting a master's in arts management at New York University, he was back at the scene of his first theater encounter, working in the box office of the Paper Mill Playhouse. After finishing the program in 1987, he went to work as an assistant in Paper Mill's development department and quickly moved his way up to development director, overseeing an annual $3.5 million fund drive and a $7 million capital campaign. In his 14 years at Paper Mill, Mr. McEwen also initiated many new programs, particularly those addressing the needs of the handicapped, which have become models for theaters throughout the state and country. 
Paper Mill Playhouse was the first New Jersey theater to provide sign-interpreted performances. The theater was also equipped with an infrared system that beams the actors' dialogue into the earpieces of those with hearing problems; for the blind, the earpieces also provide an account of the action on stage. Before performances, the theater also puts on "sensory seminars," allowing those with vision problems to feel the costumes, sets and props to gain a better sense of the play.
"These programs have had a huge impact on the theater going experience for those with handicaps," said Angelo DelRossi, executive producer and president of Paper Mill. "And they were all brought about with John at the helm."
Mr. McEwen's sensitivity to the disabled was awakened by a childhood friend with muscular dystrophy. "We'd listen to music and play checkers together," he said. "And I just knew how much I enjoyed theater myself and if I lost the use of my arms or legs or sight, it would be devastating."
Mr. McEwen founded the New Jersey Arts Access Task Force in 1995, to promote access for the disabled to other theaters. He also served as chairman of the Theater Alliance board at that time. His advocacy on disability issues won him a number of awards, and also gave him a statewide presence in the theater community that made him a natural choice to become the organization's second executive director, following Laura Aden, who announced her departure last summer.
"Laurie led this organization through so much growth and success, replacing her would be somewhat daunting for anyone," said Michael Stotts, the chairman of the Theater Alliance board and the managing director of the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick. Mr. Stotts said Mr. McEwen had done a good job filling Ms. Aden's shoes.
"He brings a tremendous amount of experience and knowledge of all New Jersey theaters, as well as the entire funding community and all the relationships that are needed to keep theater going," Mr. Stotts said. 
Supported by financing from the New Jersey Council on the Arts, the Theater Alliance began as the New Jersey Theater Group in 1981, changing its name last year to reflect its bigger mission of fostering a statewide identity for New Jersey's professional theaters. 
Before taking over at the Theater Alliance, Mr. McEwen had a short stint as vice president of development at New Jersey Network, where he formed a close bond with NJN's executive director, Elizabeth Christopherson. He also stays in touch with Ms. Aden, who has joined the Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation, a big contributors to the arts in New Jersey. Having these connections at a time when a weak economy has philanthropists reconsidering where their dollars will be best spent is vital to the state's theaters, most of them nonprofits. 
"Theaters tend to operate on a week-by-week basis and they are certainly feeling the pressure, but I haven't heard any stories of panic yet," said Mr. McEwen, who is encouraging theaters to continue pursuing givers and to discuss their post- Sept. 11 situations. 
Besides private donors, many theaters depend on grants from the state's Arts Council, which may be affected by anticipated belt-tightening by the state next year. 
But despite a downturn in the economy and the threat of cuts in state funding, Mr. McEwen predicts that the impact of the Sept. 11 attacks will be positive for theater.
"The word 'community' is taking on a whole new meaning," he said. "I think people are starting to look around and see what's right in their own backyard. And what better way to bring a community together than theater?" As one of his first initiatives, Mr. McEwen is organizing a symposium to discuss the impact of Sept. 11 on the theater community. The symposium, which will take place next month, is being financed by the Dodge Foundation. According to Mr. Stotts, this program represents the direction he sees the Alliance moving in under Mr. McEwen.
"It was John's idea to bring together artists and professionals to talk about the effects these events have had on our lives," Mr. Stotts said. "He'll be a great leader in identifying new projects and programs necessary for the times we are in."
Besides increasing the alliance's role as a forum for exchanging ideas, Mr. McEwen had set a goal of visiting all 23 member theaters by the end of the year. Since taking over in August, he's made it to about half of them, which, despite the relatively compact geography of New Jersey, has turned out to be quite an accomplishment. The members range in size from the 99-seat Cape May Stage to the Paper Mill, at 1,200 seats the largest equity theater in the state.
All member theaters are treated equally in the alliance's direct mail campaigns and other promotional programs, which are a major thrust of the alliance. Mr. McEwen says he'd like to see the marketing efforts tied into the state's tourism promotions.
"The beaches in New Jersey are great, but the culture here is amazing too," he said.
While Mr. McEwen refused to say which of the state's theaters he thinks are doing a particularly good job, he did suggest "keeping an eye on" some of the newer and more experimental theaters, like Luna Stage and 12 Miles West in Montclair and the New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch.
And what does he do with his time off? Attend the theater, of course, taking in four to six plays a month. His favorite recent productions have been "Three Sisters" by the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival in Madison, "Lady Day" at George Street and "Red, Hot and Blue" at Paper Mill. But his theater viewing isn't always Jersey-centric; he did catch "The Producers" on Broadway.
And though he hasn't set foot on a stage for a number of years (except to solicit donations), it's clear that theater is in Mr. McEwen's blood.
"I can't say anything else has brought me more joy in my life," he said, breaking into a smile that creased his eyes. "It gave me direction, purpose and pleasure. I've found what it does for me, and in watching other people what I see it doing for them, very fulfilling."

GRAPHIC: Photo: John McEwen, director of New Jersey Theater Alliance, at George Street Playhouse. (Richard Perry/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MONEY & MEDICINE; 
Health Care: The Sound and the Fury

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER; Jennifer Steinhauer covered health care at The Times for three years. This is her last column.

 BODY:
DURING the year and a half that I have been writing a column about the economics of health care, I have received e-mail messages from readers calling me shortsighted, hopelessly antimanaged care, maddeningly pro-managed care and just plain dumb.
 I have never been happier. 
 One thing I have learned, in covering health care generally and in writing the column, is that few subjects interest so many people more. One can write a front-page article about the doings of the mayor of a major metropolitan center (as I do in my new job, covering City Hall in New York) and hear nary a voice from readers. But write a column about prescription drug costs or even something as remote as the debate over defined contributions in health care plans, and the e-mail rolls in. 
The lessons? People care deeply about health care. And both those who receive it and those who provide it are profoundly dissatisfied with the way it is delivered these days. Many believe they have the solution. Patients feel mistreated by their doctors, who in turn feel abused by managed-care companies, which, for their part, feel misunderstood and that they are scapegoats of both groups.
No issue was too tiny, too "inside baseball," to attract attention. I was extremely impressed and often moved by how people explained their opinions and frustrations, often at length. Sometimes the stories were terribly sad -- a parent who lost a child, a young man struggling with advanced cancer, an elderly person with myriad medical problems who could not understand the paperwork involved in reimbursement for prescription drugs. In terms of legal and policy experts, there are no shortages in this business. And they are always willing to help me wade through federal waiver argot and tricky insurance laws.
Of all the columns I wrote, none generated as much comment, and perhaps as much controversy, as the one in July, describing how doctors were becoming fed up with patients whose first priority was finding doctors who participated in their managed-care plans. Many doctors were dropping the plans altogether, and saying goodbye and, in some cases, good riddance, to patients.
In the column, I noted a letter from Bradley A. Radwaner, a cardiologist in Manhattan, to the New York attorney general. In it, Dr. Radwaner described a common feeling among many doctors:
"Since the vast majority of patients cannot distinguish a quality, experienced and well-trained physician from one who is simply personable, decisions are made based on $10 co-pays versus paying full fees," he wrote. "Patients want referrals only to 'participating' physicians so they have to pay as little as possible." As such, he was moving out of managed care.
Doctors by the droves wrote in, agreeing with him. "The inability to control the way we practice medicine and deliver care to patients is the reason that physicians are leaving medicine in record numbers," one of them said. "I can tell you that on an ordinary working day, if I didn't have a single patient to see, I would still be busy for eight or nine hours doing nothing but paperwork and phone calls that are directly related to managed-care issues."
Patients often had something quite different to say. "I doubt that a single doctor I have seen over the last 10 years would know me if he or she fell over me on the street, including my current 'primary care physician' whom I have probably seen six or seven times over the past two years," one reader said in an e-mail message to me. "The feeling I get is that I am just another widget coming down the medical care assembly line."
She added: "I don't get the feeling the doctors care one whit about me as an individual. This particularly struck me when I recently was seeking a specialized type of medical care and I telephoned some providers trying to locate the right one for me. The first question with which one was invariably assaulted on the phone was not 'What could we do for you?' or 'What problem(s) are you having,' but, rather 'What insurance do you have?' "
Health care is one of the most dynamic and interesting subjects to cover as a reporter. Just when you think you understand some aspect of federal health insurance, bioterrorism or community health insurance rating, you find a whole new angle on it -- a state that does something different from all other states, or a doctor who has found a way, where none have gone before, to try to make things work. 
It was an honor to explore those issues here. Thanks to all those who helped set me straight. And thanks most of all for reading.
