HEADLINE: Meltdown Worries Literally Hit Home 

BYLINE:  By COREY KILGANNON 

 BODY:
AS concern over the security of the Indian Point nuclear power plant has grown since Sept. 11, much of the worryhas been over the health threat of a potential nuclear accident.
 Many people conjure nightmares of Chernobyl-on-the-Hudson, but environmental groups say that the more likely scenario is less extreme, one with a minimal health threat but widespread damage to property. If radioactive fallout from a meltdown contaminates portions of the county, making them uninhabitable, residents could lose their homes. 
 The property issue is coming to the fore now because the Price-Anderson Act, a federal insurance program that covers power plants in the event of a nuclear accident, is set to expire in August. 
The act, which puts a cap on what plant owners must pay to nearby property owners, was approved by the House of Representatives last month in a verbal vote in which only a small fraction of the 435-member body participated. The Senate is set to consider it early next year.
Environmental groups want the cap removed so that a larger number of homeowners will be compensated. 
Many members of the House were not on the floor during the vote, said Rob Ostrander, a spokesman for Representative Sue W. Kelly, whose Congressional district includes Indian Point and much of Westchester around the plant. Mr. Ostrander said Mrs. Kelly hoped that more scrutiny was paid to the legislation before the hasty voice vote.
"The Congresswoman feels that Price Anderson should be fully debated and revisited and that the nuclear industry needs to be held accountable for their actions," he said. "Residents should not be left footing the bill in the event of a problem at any nuclear plant."
Few homeowners' insurance policies cover loss due to nuclear accidents. The standard, most widely used policy, the Homeowners-3 plan, does not cover certain risks, including floods, earthquakes, war and nuclear accidents.
Allison Bertsche, a spokeswoman for State Farm Insurance Companies, the leading insurer of homes in the United States, said policies don't cover nuclear accidents because "the loss would be so extensive that it could put us out of business."
"Everyone talks about survivability and health risk with a nuclear disaster," said Stephen Kent, a spokesman for the Indian Point Safe Energy Coalition, "but short of that, there is a serious financial risk. People could lose their homes and still be on the hook for their mortgage. Some people might say it's silly to point to property damage when you're talking about nuclear accident, but it's a reality."
The nation has roughly 100 operating power plants; there are more people living within 10 miles of Indian Point than any other reactor. But there is little awareness among residents of the limited liability.
"If you asked 100 homeowners in Westchester County, most would tell you they were insured against disaster," said Alex Matthiessen, executive director of Riverkeeper, a Garrison-based environmental group, "but the fact is, they're not insured against nuclear disaster. You would have to sue and get in line, and once the payouts totaled $10 billion, you and I and everyone else would walk away with nothing, even people who owned their homes before the plant was built."
But Larry Gottlieb, a spokesman for Entergy, the company that owns Indian Point, said the watchdog groups were recklessly exaggerating the situation.
"We feel very confident that the money would more than cover damages resulting from an accident," he said. "Security is very strong at Indian Point, but even in the worst case scenario, if you needed to dip into funds, they'd be there."
Mr. Gotttlieb accused the groups of using scare tactics and strategically trying to exploit suburbanites' sensitivity to property values.
"They say, 'Look at what happened at Chernobyl,' and that's a terrible example to use,' he said. "We could not have a Chernobyl-type disaster here. We use a different technology. You're not going to have uninhabitable areas where people can't live again."
The Price-Anderson Act, first enacted in 1957 and renewed every 10 years thereafter until 1987 when it was renewed for 15 years, allows nuclear companies to carry a relatively small amount of commercial insurance and pay money into one collective fund to cover claims nationwide. Liability is limited at $9.5 billion in total payouts per accident.
Watchdog groups call this a tiny fraction of the amount of damage to health and property that would likely be caused by a major accident. They point to a study that estimates actual damages at hundreds of times higher. The study, the Calculation of Reactor Accident Consequences (CRAC-2) report, was prepared for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and published by Congress in 1982. It estimated the "peak" number of deaths and casualties that would result from a meltdown at reactors including Indian Point.
UNDER a so-called Class 9, or worst-case meltdown scenario at Indian Point 3 reactor alone, the report estimated peak property damage at $314 billion, in 1982 dollars. Local environmentalists say that, adjusted for inflation and the rise in real estate values since then, the figure is probably closer to $2.3 trillion today.
"It's the taxpayers who would have to pay the costs," said Richard L. Brodsky, who represents the area in the State Assembly. 
Antinuclear groups have fought for years to have the limit lifted, calling it an unfair subsidy to the nuclear industry, and having taxpayers assuming risks above the $9.4 billion limit.
The nuclear industry claims that without the limit, it would be unable to get insurance protection from private companies. Officials argue that the act provides a large pool of funds in the event of a meltdown and a simplified procedure for victims to collect immediatelywithout having to prove anyone was at fault, only that damage was caused. Without the act claims could be tied up in court.
"You look at Chernobyl and everything within 30 miles is uninhabitable," said Karl Coplan, a professor of law at Pace Law School. "How many million-dollar houses are within even 10 miles of Indian Point?"

HEADLINE: They've Got a Little (or Not So Little) List 

BYLINE:  By NADINE BROZAN 

 BODY:
THE holiday tip proffered to the doorman, super, porter, handyman or concierge -- or, in the suburbs, the gardener or gatekeeper -- is the gift no one wants to discuss. 
 People who confide their most intimate secrets to strangers turn silent when asked how much they intend to slip into the envelopes they pass out at Christmastime. 
 But silence does not mean they're not calculating to whom they should give tips or how generous they ought to be. Should a cash gift be a reward for services past or an insurance policy for the future, an obligation or a courtesy? Those are questions owners and renters grapple with every year, and then keep their solutions as confidential as their tax returns. 
"People talk more easily about sex than they do about money, and tips are money," said Renee Solomon, a professor of social work at Columbia University who also has a private therapy practice on the Upper West Side. "They wouldn't even talk about it at the holiday party in the lobby the other evening. But they do want to know how much to give. They want to be fair and repay employees for kindness and service, but they don't want to look foolish or stand out in any way." 
Moreover, this year there are financial and emotional considerations fostered by the downturn of the economy and the World Trade Center disaster to be factored in. 
"Every year I've gotten more than before, but this year, I don't know -- it looks pretty bad," said Sixto Mendez, who has been a doorman at the Fairview, a 422-unit co-op building in Forest Hills, Queens, since 1974 and who received $6,000 last year. "We have a lot of people unemployed this year. The mailman has told us he has never seen so many unemployment checks." 
In addition, Mr. Mendez said, 24 members of his union, Local 32 B-J of the Service Employees International Union, were lost in the World Trade Center collapse, and 2,000 jobs disappeared. "As long as we have jobs and salaries, we must be grateful, and whatever we get in tips, we get," he said. 
In addition to tips from individuals, the staffs of many co-op and condo buildings also receive year-end bonuses from the boards of the buildings in which they work. Based on longevity and performance, these payments tend to be at least a week's salary but frequently are more. 
"Virtually all the buildings we manage provide some sort of holiday bonus," said David Kuperberg, president of Cooper Square Realty, which manages more than 100 buildings in Manhattan. "I've seen bonuses as low as a week's pay and as high as $15,000." 
But no matter how bountiful the bonus, it does not let residents off the hook for personal gratuities. In some buildings they are spared the anxiety of figuring out who gets what by a system of pooling, where all the funds are combined and divided up by the management. That seems to work better in large buildings where there are phalanxes of employees.
"There are advantages and disadvantages," said Ronni Lynn Arougheti, president of Heron Ltd., a brokerage and management firm and treasurer of the Park Avenue co-op building where she lives. "The recipients don't know who gave what or even who contributed, and the staff knows that it is being doled out pro rata and not necessarily according to merit."
On the other hand, pooling does insure that the behind-the-scenes workers like porters and night doormen who have little interaction with residents get their fair share.
"I once worked in a 1,200-unit building downtown where they pooled," recalled Carl Perrault, who has been the super at Berkley House, a 118-unit co-op building at 120 Central Park South, for two years, "and we only got $150 each." At his current building the gifts are distributed directly. "I like this better," he said.
So do the 10 doormen, elevator operators and porters who work with him. "The men look forward to it every year," he said. "But they don't tell me how much they make. That's pretty personal." 
However much they are, gratuities can constitute a good chunk of income, which under the Local 32 B-J contract, covering most of the employees in the city, is $704.63 a week in the "handyperson" category and $639.63 for concierges, porters, doormen and other staff members, excluding superintendents. 
Enrique Calo Jr., who said from behind his lobby desk at Saga House, a 23-unit condominium at 157 East 74th Street, "Call me concierge, because that sounds better than doorman," estimated that tips can account for roughly 10 percent of his income. "They pay for my education," he said, explaining that he is a student at the Manhattan Center of Nyack College, where he is majoring in Bible and history. 
Like the four other doormen on the staff and Erika Pest, the super there, Mr. Calo wears many hats. "We polish the wood; take out the garbage; do the mail, the packages, the dry cleaning; deliver the groceries," he said, "and the gifts do reflect that we have multiple jobs." 
In addition, Ms. Pest said, bonuses equal to four to seven weeks wages are usually given by the board. "I think this is the best building in New York City," she said, "the management and the people who live here are very respectful of the staff; they're almost like friends." 
As executive director of the Council of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums, Mary Ann Rothman is familiar with a wide gamut of tipping styles. But she prefers the more personal approach for herself. "I never reach in my pocket during the year," she said. "At Christmas I want them to know the tip comes from me, shake their hands, look them in the eye and thank them for services rendered in the course of the year." 
Owners in the 415-unit Century condominium at 25 Central Park West have a choice of contributing to a pool or expressing their appreciation directly to staff members. 
The fact that there are 57 names on the holiday greetings distributed throughout the building does not daunt Roberta Brandes Gratz, the urban affairs writer, who said: "We are one of the largest buildings in the city. We have three entrances, six elevator banks and all the service elevators are manned." 
She winnows her gifts down to the people with whom she and her husband, Donald Gratz, have personal contact or those who service her line of apartments in the building, which occupies the block from 62nd to 63rd Street. 
She is helped along in that task by the fact that the staff list includes names, job titles and areas of the building to which individuals are assigned. 
For example, Ms. Gratz, who has lived in the Century for 30 years, said: "There are 18 people in the janitorial, porter and elevator category, but only three of those are on my line. There are only two full-time doormen on my door, so when you break it down, it becomes less awesome. But it does take real work to figure all this out."
For those who are left to their own devices, there is official advice from New York City.
According to a pamphlet entitled "Tips on Tipping," first issued in 1999 by the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs, $30 to $100 is appropriate for superintendents, $25 to $100 for doormen ("Consider if they actually open the door for you," the booklet says) and $20 to $30 for custodians and handymen. However, those sums presume that those employees periodically receive tips ranging from $1 to $25 each.
The agency also suggests that car owners who regularly use a garage allot $20 to $25 for each parking attendant. Newspaper delivery people should get $15 to $25.
Though many people are unaware of it, as government employees, mail deliverers are officially barred from accepting cash gifts, said Pat McGovern, a spokeswoman for the New York area of the postal service, adding, "Certain items like soda, coffee, doughnuts and calendars are not considered gifts."
Similarly in places where the trash collectors are municipal employees, acceptance of money is prohibited. 
COMPANY policy at FedEx bars deliverers from taking cash gifts, but Hilka Klinkenberg, founder and managing director of Etiquette International, said, "If you're running a business from home and get several deliveries a week, you could give them small gifts like cookies or chocolate." 
At U.P.S., Dan McMackin, a spokesman and former driver, said that there was no formal regulation prohibiting deliverers from accepting cash but that they were trained not to do so.
"We do recognize that our service providers have a special relationship with our customers," he said. "But if, from time to time, especially at Christmas, customers would like to present a token of appreciation, that's certainly fine." When he was a driver, he said he was given tokens like socks and food.
On her Web site, Ms. Klinkenberg recommends holiday gifts of $50 to $100 for superintendents and building managers, $25 to $100 for doormen, $20 to $50 for elevator operators and $10 to $20 for porters and handymen. 
But in a phone interview, she emphasized the role of economic circumstance and geography.
"You should pay according to how tony your address is," she said. "If you live, say, on Second Avenue in the 90's, that will be different from living on Fifth Avenue in the 60's. If you make several million and drive a Bentley, that will be different than if you earn $60- or $70,000 and drive a Taurus."
For those who have suffered an economic reversal -- a shrinking investment portfolio or, more drastically, a job loss -- Ms. Klinkenberg advised, "If you're not making ends meet, get a card, tuck in $5 and a little note saying, 'I wish this could be more. You deserve it.' "
Another consideration is the frequency with which residents tip during the year. "If you tip the doorman every time he carries a shopping bag for you, you will be giving him a lot of money throughout the year and should give less than if you gave at the end of the year," Ms. Klinkenberg said. 
People in the suburbs, especially those in single-family houses, have far fewer candidates for tips. While there may be no doormen, porters or handymen with outstretched palms to be accommodated, there may be gardeners, snow shovelers (assuming there is snow), newspaper carriers and other delivery people. In addition, in gated communities ranging from small and secluded compounds on the North Shore of Long Island to the sprawling towers of Newport in in Jersey City, there are the gatekeepers, who keep watch over entrances and are happy to see residents with envelopes in hand at this time of year. 
"If you have a gardener, he is probably working for you on a half-year basis, so give the equivalent of a half a week's fee," Ms. Klinkenberg suggested. "If that same guy is the one who shovels your snow all winter, then give a week's fee."
Hal Schwartz, a graphics designer and photographer who moved from the Upper East Side to Scarsdale in 1994 and now lives in Hastings-on-Hudson, said: "I give the garbage men $50 to split among themselves, the newspaper boy $10 and the postman $20." 
When he lived in Manhattan, he said, "I gave the superintendent handsomely -- about $100 -- and in exchange he made sure I had a place to store my bike." 
In many community associations, it is not customary to give holiday tips. Scott Pohl, president of the Twin Rivers Homeowners Association in East Windsor, N.J., explained: "Our staff does not perform individual services for residents. They mow the lawns, clear the street, collect the leaves, repair the walks, but that is all part of the maintenance fee. Most people here tip the mailman, and that's it." 
The situation in suburban apartments more closely approximates the city. "Most residents here tend to tip the mail carrier, the superintendent, the U.P.S. and FedEx deliverers and the housekeeper who maintains the common areas," said Lisa Galaz, the business manager for Clocktower Close Apartments, a 132-unit loft rental building in Norwalk, Conn. 
In the past, she said, "The super has gotten up to $200 from one person and as little as $10."
Ms. Galaz was not optimistic about how much residents would be able to give this year. "I think it's going to be considerably less than in the past," she said. "Most of our residents work in Manhattan and a number of them, mainly in upper management, have lost their jobs." 
Several years ago, the Applied Companies, which owns and manages properties in New Jersey, recommended that residents of a rental building they owned in Jersey City tie the amount of their tips to the size of their apartments. Some tenants did not appreciate the advice. "People thought it was either mandatory or offensive," said Leigh Carr, senior vice president for property management. "Now we would never set a standard for anyone. 
"This is a very tough year to make recommendations. People are more strapped, but they may also be more appreciative of what they have, so they may give more."
Though many employees of residential buildings say they are hopeful about prospects this season, they do not know whether a shrinking economy portends shrinking tips. 
As Benny Diaz, an elevator operator at 120 Central Park South, put it: "Every year it changes. Some years are better than others, and last year was wonderful. I'm hoping it will stay the same."

HEADLINE: EDUCATION; 
P.S. (Your Name Here)

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS 

DATELINE: BROOKLAWN 

 BODY:
JEFF BROWN was a bit perplexed over the summer when Mayor John Soubasis asked him to lunch. To Mr. Brown, who owns the only supermarket in this small Camden County town, the ShopRite of Brooklawn, a call from the mayor could only mean trouble.
 "We've done little things for people in town, helped pave a roller hockey rink, helped someone short on funds for food," said Mr. Brown. "But when the mayor calls you to have lunch, you know it's something bigger than that." 
 What Mayor Soubasis had in mind at that lunch meeting is now seen as a unique arrangement. He asked Mr. Brown to put up some money to effectively buy naming rights to a new gymnasium for Brooklawn's only school, the Alice Costello Elementary School.
Last month -- after mulling over the mayor's offer -- Mr. Brown, who also owns five other ShopRites in the suburbs of Philadelphia, pledged $100,000 over the next 20 years to pay the debt service on the $1.7 million gym. When it is finished next year, the gym will be known as the ShopRite of Brooklawn Gymnasium.
Michael Yaple, a spokesman for the New Jersey School Board Association, said he knew of no other sale of naming rights for any part of a school building in New Jersey and, as far as he can determine, anywhere else in the country.
"Certainly, advertising is in the public schools," he said. "But there is nothing permanently named in return for a donation, not until now."
So far, no voice has been raised in protest in Brooklawn, a community that is not particularly well off in terms of per capita income. The fact is, school officials would not have been able to build the gym without a tax increase or some other help.
"We've crossed the line and we know it," said John Kellmayer, Brooklawn's superintendent of schools. "The issue is really the privatization of civic responsibility. In an era when infrastructure needs to be updated and it's hard to raise taxes -- well, we may be the first to do this, but I can assure you we won't be the last."
Even in such wealthier districts as Cherry Hill, where Mr. Brown lives, the Brooklawn experiment is being taken seriously.
"Oh, yes, we're open to things like this," said Cherry Hill's superintendent of education, Morton Sherman. "I can assure you if you come up with a million or two for us, we'll find a place for your name." 
Brooklawn -- a town with little crime and little abject poverty -- finds itself in a position more difficult than that of a larger town, said Mr. Kellmayer. For one thing Brooklawn is rated by the state as one level above the poorest, so it gets little state aid. 
On the other hand, nearby Gloucester City, a larger city but with a similar economic profile, is one of 30 districts to obtain supplemental state aid -- $31 million in this case, while Brooklawn is receiving none.
While Brooklawn has been a stable community, Dr. Kellmayer and Mr. Soubasis realized that the school system had to improve for the town to remain that way. Last year, Brooklawn was designated a school-choice district by the state, meaning that starting next year any student in Camden County can attend Costello and the state will pay the pupil's tuition.
"Brooklawn is a safe school with high-achieving kids and small classes," said Dr. Kellmayer. "We have a good start."
Still, there had to be a more substantial reason for students from other communities to seek out Costello, so Dr. Kellmayer and the school board came up with innovative programs in music and technology.
"We would infuse the curriculum from kindergarten to eighth grade so, if the student and parents chose it, they would in effect be majoring in music or tech for their time here," he said.
But doing that meant upgrading. The gym was one thing. And now there are other projects on Dr. Kellmayer's wish list -- a library media center and a technology center, for instance.
"So we're out looking for sponsors there, too," he said. "They kid us about looking for sponsors for a center-jump circle and a scoreboard, but I'd think about them, too."
For his part, Mayor Soubasis said he would not stop sponsorships with the schools, noting that he had already been soliciting in the town for businesses that might want to help pay for a new street sweeper.
"Anyone who helps out will have their names printing on the side so that when the sweeper goes through town, everyone will see," he said. "When I got to council a few years ago, I saw how difficult it was to do a budget in a small town. I'm into creative finance, so this idea came up. I'm saving clippings now to show people in other towns later who talk against this. When they end up doing it, too, I'll have them."
But Dr. Kellmayer said there were lines he would not cross.
"Look, no one is suggesting us contracting with Delilah's Den," he said, referring to a gentleman's club in Philadelphia. "We wouldn't consider a product tie-in. There wouldn't be a Coke Tech Center here. No alcohol or tobacco or guns, anything like that."
He went on: "But everyone uses food, so we contracted with a supermarket, a local supermarket. We're talking to local banks, people like that." 
For his part, Mr. Brown eschewed the idea of naming the gym after himself or his family.
"I have an ego, but I thought it would be best to have a sense of the community there," said Mr. Brown. "ShopRite of Brooklawn keeps the town name on it. I could have done advertising elsewhere, but this tells us we are sticking here in this community, trying to build it."
Moreover, Dr. Kellmayer said the gym and proposed tech center would be open to the entire community during nonschool hours.
"In this sense, it is a multiple win," he said. "We really couldn't raise taxes. There are many seniors here who would just not be able to take the increase. But we needed improvements and now everyone will be able to take advantage."
"If someone wants to criticize that we have opened up a can of worms, well, they are right," he added. "Someone will eventually cross the line into something much more controversial. I hope it won't be us."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK NEWSPAPERS; 
Hey, Pal, Want an Umbrella With That Newspaper?

BYLINE:  By DENNY LEE 

 BODY:
When you buy a $2 pack of batteries at the Sheridan Square newsstand, you're buying the most expensive non-reading-matter item a newsstand is allowed to sell. But that maximum price may go up. 
 The City Council passed a bill on Tuesday raising the cap on nonreading merchandise to $5, allowing newsstand operators to sell more expensive sundries like film and umbrellas. Robert Bookman, counsel to the New York City Newsstand Operators Association, a trade group, said the increase would help the city keep its newsstands. There are roughly 300 newsstands today, down from 1,580 in 1940. 
 A spokeswoman for the mayor's office, Lynn Rasic, said the mayor is expected to veto the bill next week because of a second provision that would allow newsstands to be owned by corporations as well as individuals.
But Councilwoman Karen Koslowitz said the provision was needed to make newsstands more economically viable. 
"It would help their industry not only survive," she said, "but possibly grow."
 DENNY LEE

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS; 
Ah, That Spirit of Giving Lives On in the Legislature

BYLINE:  By David Kocieniewski; David Kocieniewski is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
With all the bellowing about spiraling budget deficits and shrinking tax revenue emanating from New Jersey's State House these days, it might be logical to assume that your elected civil servants might attend to the treasury with a bit of austerity.
 But since when did logic have anything to do with the workings of New Jersey government? 
 As the legislative session lurches toward its conclusion on Jan. 7, and Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco prepares to leave office Jan. 8, elected officials from both parties are furiously trying to slip through an assortment of sweetheart bills before the lame duck session ends. 
The national economy may be in recession and the regional economy still reeling from the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, but you can be assured that in Trenton this holiday season, the spirit of giving is in the air. Yet the recipients of that generosity are those you may not consider among the needy.
Take, for example, the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, New Jersey's largest utility, part of an energy conglomerate that last year posted $764 million in profits. Two years ago, the state enacted a deregulation plan that has brought consumers a marginal drop in utility costs, but offered power suppliers huge savings on debt run up by building inefficient nuclear and coal-fired plants in the 1970's and 80's.
Not to be outdone, this term the Legislature is trying to provide the utility with a $1 million annual tax credit, which the company says it is entitled to because it is building two power-generating plants in New Jersey. Consumer advocates say the bill, an amendment to a 1993 law enacted to reward companies that invest in New Jersey, is simply a thank you for the $381,000 in campaign contributions the company and its top executives have showered on lawmakers since the early 1990's.
Then there is the Somerset Hills School, a privately run academy for troubled teenagers. Assemblyman Richard Bagger is pushing legislation to bestow $1.5 million in taxpayer money on the school. According to state campaign finance records, the school and its owner contributed $254,000 to the Republican Party over the past decade. But the school's owner and Mr. Bagger both say the project is a worthy one and that the campaign contributions played no role in the decision.
Legislators were also sure to aim beneficence toward themselves.
A bill sponsored by State Senator Walter J. Kavanaugh, a Republican from Somerset, would fatten the pensions given to legislators who retire after 25 years of service. The rules, which Mr. Kavanaugh pushed through the Senate State Government Committe -- of which he is the chairman -- would immediately help two lawmakers: Ray Zane, a former Democrat who switched parties last year but then lost his re-election bid, and Mr. DiFrancesco, who served in the Legislature since 1976 and would qualify for the increased pension when he turns 60. Mr. Kavanaugh, who has held office since 1976, would also qualify, although he says he has no plans to retire.
Even some bills that appeared to target undeniably needy causes, like the beleaguered city of Camden, had expensive strings attached. State Senator Robert Littell, a Republican from rural Sussex County who will be leaving after the current session, showed an uncharacteristic interest in urban affairs this past month as he pressed for a $180 million economic assistance package for Camden, an overwhelmingly Democratic community on the other end of the state.
Tucked into the measure, however, was another spending plan: a $130 million initiative to rebuild an assortment of New Jersey dams, many of which are in Mr. Littell's district.
There were other proposals intended to steer taxpayer dollars to wineries and racehorse owners, plus requests for scores of pet projects by various towns, counties and villages. 
And while the vast majority of the proposals were sponsored by Republicans, who have a majority in both houses, Senator Bernard Kenny Jr., a Democrat, still managed to push for a last-minute proposal to lower taxes on corporations.
Since his election victory last month, Governor-elect Jim McGreevey has been incessantly warning that the state faces a mounting deficit and has pointedly urged lawmakers to restrain their spending. Mr. McGreevey has also apparently scuttled the expensive plans for Camden and for dam repairs, plus a proposal to finance an arena in downtown Newark. At least for now.
After Mr. McGreevey's inauguration on Jan 15, however, a new Legislature will convene with Mr. McGreevey's fellow Democrats in control of the General Assembly and in a 20-20 split with Republicans in the Senate. The unions, businesses and political leaders who helped propel Mr. McGreevey to victory will come calling and asking that their loyalty be rewarded with, at the very least, some attention to their concerns.
And when the next legislative session enters its lame duck period, and Democrats come seeking handouts for their pet projects, Mr. McGreevey will face a revealing test of his leadership -- when he shows whether he is willing to play Scrooge with members of his own party as well.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 6, 2002

 CORRECTION:
The On Politics column on Dec. 16, about the lame-duck session of the Legislature, misstated the plans of State Senator Robert Littell, a Republican from Sussex County. Mr. Littell, who won re-election last November, does not plan to step down at the end of the session.
The column also referred incorrectly to the support of State Senator Bernard F. Kenny Jr., a Democrat from Hoboken, for a corporate tax cut. While Mr. Kenny sponsored such a bill earlier in the session, he asked last month that it not be brought up for discussion because of concerns about the looming budget deficit.

HEADLINE: How Loud Does Money Talk? For Some, It Shouts 

BYLINE:  By VIVIAN MARINO 

 BODY:
WOULD you swallow a worm for $300 -- provided, of course, that you wouldn't become sick? How about shaving your head for $10,000? 
 While the very thought of doing either would make many people squirm, many others would rise to the occasion, for the right price, says Bernice Kanner, a New York writer, in her recent book, "Are You Normal About Money?" (Bloomberg Press, $12.95). 
 Of course, there is nothing "normal" about asking people to eat worms or to go around bald for cash, even a lot of it. But by asking hypothetical questions about money -- from the whimsical to the more serious -- the book provides a peek into the financial psyche of Americans. Call it a self-examination for people who wonder just how crazy they are about money, or a guide to whether other people share their opinions. 
The numbers are far from scientific. The bulk of the book, a 143-page paperback, is based in part on an informal survey conducted on the Web site of the Bloomberg media company over 18 months ending last summer. Some of the material was derived from existing data from other sources. Ms. Kanner said that she did not know exactly how many people had responded to the Bloomberg survey over all, but that each question drew 2,000 to 16,000 responses.
What surprised her most, she said, were "the incredible lengths that some people will go for money." For example, 21 percent of the respondents would wolf down that worm for $300, while 26 percent wouldn't touch it for less than $1,000. Fifty-nine percent, meanwhile, would eagerly shave their heads for $10,000.
"Your approach to money says more about you than probably any aspect of your personality," Ms. Kanner said. She acknowledged some fiscal idiosyncrasies herself, like reusing wrapping paper. (Fifty-seven percent of the respondents did the same.)
Jonathan Pond, a financial planner from Watertown, Mass., says attitudes about money are also affected by the state of the economy and personal income. "If you're unemployed and you don't know when your next meal is coming, you'd kiss a stranger for $200; if you don't need the money you probably won't," he said.
"Unfortunately, in this capitalistic society, money is the report card on how you're doing, and that's the problem a lot of people overseas have with our society."
Michael R. Bloomberg, the mayor-elect of New York and the founder of the media company, was among those who took the survey, according to Ms. Kanner. Calls to Mr. Bloomberg's aides at his transition office were not returned last week, so it was not known how he responded to all the questions, although his answer to this one is apparently clear: Is it wrong for a rich politician to spend his own money lavishly on an election? (Nearly two-thirds of the respondents thought it was O.K., too.)
Following are some of the other questions, and answers, that can be found in the book:

Views on Money
* What's more fun -- making money or spending it? Forty percent say making it, 22 percent say spending it, and the remainder enjoy both.
* How much extra money would it take to make a real difference in your life? One-third say $100,000; 14 percent, at least $500,000; 16 percent, $1 million; and 24 percent, $10 million.
* Would you rather personally strike it rich but have a nation at war, or enjoy peace without personal prosperity? Twelve percent would rather be rich and at war, 20 percent would rather be poor and have peace, and 68 percent would prefer to reach a compromise.

Penny-Pinching
* Do you take home the leftovers from a restaurant meal? Sixty-two percent say they do.
* Would you put back an item on a store shelf if you left your coupon for it home? Fifty-seven percent would forgo the purchase, while just 3 percent would return home to retrieve the coupon.

Investing
* Do you feel comfortable about your ability to earn back any money you lose? More than half say yes; 7 percent have significant doubts.
* What is the best way to get rich today? Of those earning at least $100,000 a year, 26 percent say starting a business; 22 percent, investing in stocks; and 15 percent, investing in real estate.
* Do you read the prospectus that comes with a mutual fund? Seventy-two percent never bother.
* How often do you check stock quotations? Forty-one percent say once a day; 18 percent, three times a day; 15 percent, more than three times a day; 10 percent, once a week; 5 percent, once a month; 10 percent, never.

Of Love and Money
* Do you know how much your spouse earns? Three out of 10 respondents say they don't.
* Who should pay on a date? Fifty-four percent say the man should pay, while 13 percent say the woman, provided that she earns more. Thirty-one percent say the couple should just split the bill. But if the woman does the inviting, two-thirds say she should pay.
* If you borrow money from a spouse, do you pay it back? Just 30 percent say they do.

Shopping Habits
* Do you buy store brands or pricier national ones? National brands are the winner, 85 percent to 15 percent.
* Do you set limits for holiday gifts? Fifty-seven percent say yes.
* Have you ever bought counterfeit goods, like a fake designer watch or handbag? Sixty-seven percent say no.
* Do you consider shopping fun? Seventy-nine percent of women do, while 74 percent of men don't.

Going to Extremes
* Have you ever switched tags to pay less in a store? Ten percent have engaged in such a practice.
* Would you take a three-month vow of silence for $20,000? Two-thirds would, if they could write down their thoughts.
* Would you commit a crime for $10 million if you knew you wouldn't be caught? Twenty-three percent would. But lower the amount to $100,000 and only 8 percent would.
* Would you spy for another country for a lot of money? Three-fourths wouldn't, but 15 percent would consider it, depending on the payoff.

HEADLINE: Business; 
Child Care: AnIndustry for All Economic Seasons

BYLINE:  By BARBARA WHITAKER 

 BODY:
EMPLOYERS are eliminating jobs around the country. The economy is officially declared to be in a recession. But child care businesses are expanding. 
 Institutional child care, born out of a profound shift in the labor force that began more than 30 years ago as more mothers went to work, has emerged as a surprisingly resilient industry in tougher times. 
 Professional, for-profit chains that care for children and preschoolers outside the home, such as KinderCare Learning Centers and Primrose Schools, are not growing at the fast pace of the 1980's. But these businesses also say they are not feeling much of an economic pinch -- at least not yet -- even in areas where many working parents have been laid off. 
Institutional child care experts say the industry's resistance to the ups and downs of the economic cycle has been strengthened by a growing acceptance of the value of early education and socialization for children. The high percentage of mothers in the labor force has also helped.
"We've had quite a few months into a fairly serious recession, and we don't see any letup in the number of centers," said Mike Wilson, owner and president of the Wilson Marketing Group, a consulting firm in Culver City, Calif., that specializes in child care services research. 
That does not mean the child care industry is totally insulated from national economic problems. It has always been challenged by low profit margins, constant staff turnover and heavy regulation, and it is bracing for higher insurance rates after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Moreover, moves by many states to offer public preschool education could reduce an important source of business.
"I think the child care industry is taking a very cautious approach right now," said Roger Neugebauer, publisher of Child Care Information Exchange, a trade journal based in Redmond, Wash., that has monitored the industry for 15 years. 
Mr. Neugebauer said that the largest for-profit child care chains had been projecting a growth rate of 5 to 7 percent for 2002, but that the estimate had been cut to 2 to 3 percent. 
The number of licensed child care centers has been increasing for a decade, to 111,506 in 2001 from 86,212 in 1992, according to the Children's Foundation, an advocacy group based in Washington that tracks those numbers. 
But there is much more room for growth in the market. Institutional child care, Mr. Wilson said, is now providing services to only roughly half of all American children aged 5 and younger who could theoretically enroll. "There's an awful lot of kids out there that could still be served," he said.
Some big chains are continuing to expand aggressively, assured of future business from corporate clients that offer subsidized child care as an employee benefit.
Bright Horizons Family Solutions, a Boston-based chain of employer-sponsored day care and early education centers with customers like Ford Motor, Merrill Lynch and Johns Hopkins University, opened 21 sites in the July-September quarter alone, a record for the company. 
Roger Brown, the chief executive of Bright Horizons, and his wife, Linda Mason, the chairwoman, founded the business 15 years ago. He said he expects to open 40 to 50 centers in 2002, compared with about 45 this year. The company, publicly held, reported a 23 percent increase in third-quarter earnings, to $2.3 million, on a 17 percent increase in revenue, to $87.2 million.
Others are expanding at a more modest pace. KinderCare, which is based in Portland, Ore., and is the nation's largest child care chain with 1,257 centers, plans to open 35 centers in its current fiscal year, which ends May 31, about the same as in the previous year. 
KinderCare, which expanded so aggressively in the 1980's that it faced debt problems in the recession of the early 1990's, is now far more stable financially. It was acquired in 1997 by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the investment firm.
Primrose Schools, a franchiser of day care and early education programs, said it had not wavered from a long-term expansion plan of 20 to 25 new centers a year. It now has 95.
"While I can't say we're recession-proof, child care is probably the second priority to parents after the mortgage," said Jo Kirchner, president and chief executive of Primrose, a subsidiary of the Security Capital Corporation, a conglomerate based in Greenwich, Conn., that also owns health insurance services and specialty retailing businesses. "In this slumping economy, what we're seeing is more women who might have chosen to leave careers going back to work."
Nearly 73 percent of mothers with children under 18 have jobs outside the home, Labor Department data show.
Ms. Kirchner said many Primrose clients tended to be professionals who, if laid off, pursued work elsewhere.
"They're educated," she said. "They know the importance of early childhood education. They will sacrifice to keep their children in school." 
For many child care businesses, the strength or weakness of the economy is of far less concern than a chronic inability to find and retain qualified educational professionals. The average annual salary in the child care industry is about $15,000.
"That to me is the biggest issue because if we can't attract bright, capable young people, how can you excel?" said Faith Wohl, president of the Child Care Action Campaign, a group based in New York that advocates changes in child care services.
For-profit child care centers are also becoming concerned about potential competition -- a trend among the states to offer prekindergarten programs themselves. The move could hurt or help the growth of preschools and day care centers -- depending on whether the states establish programs within the public schools or contract the work out.
ONLY Georgia offers prekindergarten universally to 4-year-olds, but New York is phasing in a program over seven years. Forty-three states have some form of state-financed prekindergarten programs in effect. 
"Economically, a center can't survive without that 4-year-old classroom," said Lynn White, executive director of the National Child Care Association, a trade organization based in Atlanta and representing about 7,000 private licensed child care centers. 
The labor in caring for an infant is much more intense than in the classrooms for 4-year-olds, which are among the more profitable age groups in institutional child care, she said. Infants may require one worker for every three or four babies, while a class of 4-year-olds may have an adult-to-child ratio of as high as 20 to 1. In a field where profit margins are about 4 percent and staffing typically accounts for 60 to 70 percent of a center's costs, a decline in the market for 4-year-olds can be worrisome.
"It's a very, very delicate economic situation that a child care center operates under," Ms. White said. "You take one component from it and it's a problem." 
For some child care businesses, the growing acceptance of dual-career households beyond the United States is an opportunity. Bright Horizons, which now operates more than 345 centers in 34 states, has expanded into Ireland and Britain and last month announced its first foray into Canada.
The company's international expansion is in some ways a circular route for Mr. Brown and his wife. They founded Bright Horizons in 1986 after returning from Sudan, where they had worked as managers for the Save the Children Foundation. 
"I often joke if I'd known more, I might not have done this," Mr. Brown said.

HEADLINE: COUNTERINTELLIGENCE; 
New Kit Bags, to Send Troubles Packing

BYLINE:  By Alex Witchel

 BODY:
THE Kate Spade store at 59 Thompson Street, near Broome, is tiny, only 300 square feet. So it's hard to ogle its owner without her noticing, though two teenage girls were recently giving it a go.
 "You feel a flutter, really?" one asked the other, who nodded mutely, the designer of her dreams at such close range. The questioner remained unconvinced. "I don't know," she said, surveying the diminutive Ms. Spade, who in turn fussed with a display, trying not to notice. "I feel a flutter for Laura Bush." 
 Well, to each her own, though Mrs. Bush's husband would certainly approve of Ms. Spade's newest venture: she has turned her original store -- the other, at 454 Broome, is at least three times larger -- into a travel boutique, stocking it with luggage, cosmetics cases, pajamas, journals and maps. 
That's right, despite forecasts by the travel industry of declines of up to 20 percent in flying from a year ago, Ms. Spade is convinced that the country will shake its travel phobia sooner rather than later. She and her husband, Andy Spade, the chief executive of Kate Spade L.L.C., came up with the travel concept well before the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, but they believe it's still viable. They've also allotted space for it in their Chicago store.
"I'm not sure the idea has changed, though I'm curious to see whether or not the customer has," Ms. Spade said last week over lunch. "I think the question is, How long can we be held hostage by fear?"
For Ms. Spade the answer has been not one second. She and her husband were in Kansas City, Mo., her hometown, on Sept. 11, where she was scheduled to do a promotional event. She and Mr. Spade drove back to New York instead.
On the day the United States began the bombing of Afghanistan she was in Paris -- alone -- buying fabric. And the week that Gov. Gray Davis warned against using bridges in the San Francisco area, she was in town for a Kate Spade store event. But for her this kind of travel is the norm. She goes to Florence six times a year to supervise the manufacture of her handbag and shoe lines, to Japan twice a year to check in on the 5 Kate Spade stores and 13 in-store boutiques there, and twice a year to her stores in Boston and Chicago.
But unlike so many people who have traveled frequently since Sept. 11, she sports no macho bluster and readily admits she was most afraid when her husband flew to Arizona soon after the crash of American Airlines Flight 587 in Queens. "When you get that nervous, you almost have to resign yourself," she said. "But I think not flying would be worse." She smiled. "I realize that's also easier said than done."
Ms. Spade, 38, is best known, of course, for her stylishly simple handbags, which somehow escape being vulgar even though her name is sewn on the outside of each one. The effect is like Mom sewing name tapes on your camp clothes. And that homespun Midwestern quality has always been offset by the clean, modern design -- as if Audrey Hepburn had been raised in Kansas City. In recent years, the handbag line has been joined by stationery, shoes and eyeglasses. And travel.
"We thought of the idea after realizing we're suddenly surrounded by hotels," Ms. Spade said. "The Mercer, TriBeCa Grand, SoHo Grand and 60 Thompson Street, which is right across the street from us. And in its history, this store is where we try out experimental ideas."
After the original Kate Spade boutique outgrew the Thompson Street space, Ms. Spade first sold rare and vintage books there; then, more successfully, stationery. The travel incarnation is now three weeks old. "It's too early to say how we're doing," she said at Quilty's, a nearby restaurant, where she debated whether to take her leftover roast chicken home to her dog, Henry. (She didn't. No Kate Spade doggie bags?)
AT the table, Ms. Spade's posture is ramrod straight, her manners are impeccable and her upturned nose, rosy cheeks and pulled-back hair conjure images of Mary Poppins, known more for what was in her magical bag than for the bag itself. But unlike the often forbidding nanny, Ms. Spade has an easy way about her, and a warm, comfortable laugh. It's not surprising to learn from one of her employees that the company's orientation materials stipulate saying please and thank you -- in the office, not just the stores.
Ms. Spade reached for her black bag, a sample from the spring line that tantalizingly called to mind a big, fat Tootsie Roll. She gamely opened it for inspection.
"Isn't it fun?" she said, which in fashionspeak beats "Isn't it divine?" any day, though a case could be made that this actually was. The lining was bright red fabric, and crammed inside were Ms. Spade's passport (she had gotten back from Florence the night before), a pen, a half-eaten candy cane wrapped in plastic, a cellphone, lipstick, a fistful of lire, sunglasses and some phone messages from the hotel.
The effect was part glamour, part girl next door, just like the company. Its success -- annual sales have grown to $70 million this year, from $10 million in 1996 -- has been due, Ms. Spade says, to her and Mr. Spade's insistence on not expanding too quickly. In 1998, the company hired away the president of Donna Karan, whose push to build resulted in his leaving within three months. Since 1999, when Neiman Marcus became the majority owner in Kate Spade, nothing has changed internally, Ms. Spade said; Neiman functions as a financial and distribution resource.
That kind of security has come in handy during the downturn all retail businesses have suffered since Sept. 11. Both Kate Spade stores in SoHo were closed for a week. But it would seem that bad times can be good times for Ms. Spade's business. The company was founded in 1993, during the last recession. "Well, it's not deliberate," she said carefully. "But if we can do something under the radar, that is good for us. When we started up we had the great luxury of being slow and small for a couple of years, which allowed us to learn and grow. Also, when it's quiet, we can sense what sells, and when things get better we'll know what people have been responding to."
The feedback so far is good. Michelle Kessler Sanders, the accessories director for Vogue, said: "It's patriotic to plow ahead and try this, instead of turning the space into yet another bag shop. New Yorkers do travel -- that's what our lives are like. And beautiful luggage does get overlooked in our accessories world. But with Kate's stuff you get a great-looking piece for a great price. With a Louis Vuitton steamer trunk, who knows if you'll ever see it again?"
For Ms. Spade, the Christmas holiday is just another opportunity to travel. She's off to Jackson Hole to ski with Mr. Spade's family. (His brother David is the comic actor.) She saw her own family at Thanksgiving; the fifth of six children, she has four sisters, one brother, a sister-in-law, two parents and a stepmother. Her parents divorced when she was 8.
"I told my sister that I wasn't going to send bags to everyone at Christmas this year because it didn't seem like a gift I put a lot of effort into," Ms. Spade recalled. "I said, 'It's not very sincere to just go through the inventory and send them out.' " She laughed. "And my sister said: 'No, no -- be insincere. We want them, it's O.K.' "
All things considered, Ms. Spade is being generous; she still remembers pining for a raspberry-pink velvet dress with a matching pink velvet purse as a child. "When it came in, it wasn't my size anymore, so my mother gave it to my sister," she said. "I got the purse and remember thinking, 'You never grow out of the purse.' "
After lunch, she returned to the store, where business was brisk. The two teenage girls ogled her, then bought wallets and boxes of Eleni's cookies in the shape of Kate Spade handbags.
"My grandmother just bought this whole line of luggage," one of the girls said, pointing to a brightly striped set. "She said it's the only one she can see on the belt."
Sunglasses, a cashmere pillow, a cashmere scarf and a cosmetics bag made it out the door in minutes, though no one picked up on the conversion charts for shoes and clothes in European sizes or the vintage copy of "I Married Adventure" by Osa Johnson. The Kate Spade travel kits, outfitted with disposable cameras, eye masks, mints, playing cards, Woolite and Q-Tips, won't be in stock until January.
Ms. Spade raced around a while helping customers and answering the phone. But finally her jet lag triumphed, and she sat slumped under a map of Europe. At that moment, she seemed so small and so tired, it was almost too much to imagine what the store might look like in the slog of January.
Then again, she was only tired, not crazy. Like any savvy businesswoman, this one has hedged her bets. Her latest endeavor? Kate Spade Home.

HEADLINE: A Harvard Shopping Guide? Charge It 

BYLINE:  By ELLEN TIEN 

 BODY:
EVEN the most experienced shopper enjoys thumbing through a Zagat or Berlitz shopping guide every now and then, in the hopes of picking up a retail tip.
 So, when I came upon an advance copy of "The Harvard Design School Guide to Shopping" (Taschen, March 2002), overseen by the architect Rem Koolhaas, I felt a flicker of anticipation. Eight hundred pages of armchair browsing! A wealth of department store secrets in a glossy tome the size of a Prada men's shoe box! Charge! 
 Don't be fooled by the title. Nowhere in its 800 pages did this weighty manual tell me where to get the best deal on tie-dyed chinchilla or when to reserve my Paris tickets for Porthault's midwinter whites sale. In fact, the book is not really about shopping at all -- at least, not in the True Shopper's pleasure-drenched sense of the word. Rather, it solemnly explores the social psychology and calculus of the Great American Pastime: how the evolution of retail shapes our culture, defines our cities and infiltrates our lives. In short, it looks at the chill behind the thrill. And then, in subliminal Socratic Method, it asks the inveterate consumer: What do you have to say for yourself?
The product of graduate-level thesis research directed by Mr. Koolhaas, who is a Harvard professor (Dutch designers are very big right now), the "Guide to Shopping" juxtaposes gorgeous graphics, charts and statistics with erudite essays on such retail groundbreakers as the air-conditioner and escalator. Mr. Koolhaas and company use precise modernist math to harness rampant mall lust, and in doing so, create their own super-controlled environment. To put it in Dutch design terms: Gerrit Rietveld wrestles Viktor & Rolf to the ground.
For all its density, the book is remarkably readable. A good thing, since career shoppers are not always known for their reading comprehension skills (I mean, how many times have I heard a customer in Saks inquire, "On what floor is the Cafe on Seven located?"). With no major text appearing until Page 93, it opens with a glut of statistics: the United States has 31 square feet of retail area per person (as opposed to four square feet per person in Europe and two in Asia). Wal-Mart sales are larger than the gross domestic product of three-quarters of the world's national economies. 
It documents how consumerism has infected every living space, from hospitals (consider Rhode Island's proposed Medical City, a $267 million hospital with a six-story atrium, a waterfall and retail shops) to the military (witness the Norfolk Naval Base's plans to become a theme park with aircraft carriers). Further, it explores the spooky concept of "captive shopping," as seen in airport and train station malls.
To be sure, this is less the book for a person who adores shopping, and more for one who is wont to study the pseudopathology of such behavior. The kind of person who has greater interest in the Manhattan Project than the Gotham Salad at Bergdorf -- and who might have nodded emphatically when Newton Minow declared television a "vast wasteland." To wit, "The Harvard Design School Guide to Shopping" is for the lepidopterist, not the butterfly.
In other words, the perfect gift for a butterfly to run out and buy for all her lepidopterist friends.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; 
As Winter Looms, Advocates for the Homeless Raise the Alarm

BYLINE:  By ERIKA KINETZ 

 BODY:
Last week, a 105-bed shelter for homeless men opened on East 123rd Street in Harlem. But advocates for the homeless say this apparently good news is not good enough. The city, they say, still has not done enough to prepare for the surge in demand for shelter that winter brings. 
 The surge may already be starting. On Thursday night, Francis Griffiths, 48, reaching into a trash bin near Bellevue Hospital for a piece of cake, said he had first sought shelter more than a week ago. "It's getting cold," Mr. Griffiths, who has been homeless for five years, said in a soft, slow voice. 
 Patrick Markee, a senior policy analyst for the Coalition for the Homeless, said Mr. Griffiths was one of hundreds of men the city might not be able to house adequately this winter. Since 1996, Mr. Markee said, the cold weather has driven an average of an additional 450 adults to homeless shelters each year. But, he said, the city is adding only 233 beds, including the new East Harlem shelter, for homeless men this winter. 
Furthermore, Mr. Markee said, the need may be greater this year because of the softening economy and increasing unemployment. The men's shelters are already full, he added, citing the city's need on Tuesday to put eight emergency beds at a men's shelter on Wards Island to meet demand.
But Bob Mascali, first deputy commissioner of the Department of Homeless Services, said the city was prepared for the winter. 
"We've never turned away anyone," he said, adding that full shelters may reflect heightened outreach work. "We have eight outreach teams out there practically around the clock to bring people in." 
The city also calculates a smaller need for beds than the coalition does. The Department of Homeless Services figures that the winter increase in demand has averaged only 322 a year in the last five years. Furthermore, said Mr. Mascali, in addition to the 233 new shelter beds, the city has increased the number of temporary folding beds by 90, bringing the total of emergency beds past 300.
But Mr. Markee says that under the terms of a 1981 consent decree, such beds can only be used during severe weather emergencies. "That's not meant to be a day-to-day remedy for a seasonal rise in demand for shelter," he said.
Mr. Mascali responded that the emergency beds were "a legal and appropriate method of dealing with occasional spikes in the shelter census." 
"Right now we feel that what we're putting on line will be sufficient, but we will also monitor the situation carefully," he added. "We're looking for additional capacity if necessary."
Local resistance can make that search difficult. "These people are not from our community," said David Givens, the chairman of Community Board 11 in East Harlem, referring to the 123rd Street shelter and other social welfare centers in the neighborhood. "How can we ever encourage development or tourism when you allow our community to be a dumping ground?" According to the Coalition for the Homeless, East Harlem and Wards Island now have 1,258 beds for homeless adults and space for about 100 families.
Still, Mr. Markee said, stuffed shelters present human as well as legal problems. "Once you start approaching capacity, there's back flow," he said. "The people at the front door end up suffering long waits or they end up getting bounced around from night to night."
 ERIKA KINETZ

GRAPHIC: Photo: With a softening economy and rising unemployment, the city's men's shelters are already full. (Edward Keating/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST VILLAGE -- BUZZ; 
Fighting for Truth, Justice And Fair Rental Practices

BYLINE:  By DENNY LEE 

 BODY:
THE SETTING -- The theatrical premiere of "Rent Wars Ronin," a full-color anime film in which the city's tenant-landlord skirmishes are recast in the fantasy of Dungeons and Dragons. In this pixel-generated world, knighted tenants and "Barracudi" lawyers possess kung fu powers to duel with the likes of Chief Judge Sleazy and Slimy Slumlord.
 Word of the premiere had spread through tenant circles like new rent regulations. At 6:30 p.m. on Tuesday, combatants in real rental wars began filing into the Anthology Film Archives in the East Village. 

THE BUZZ -- "We all dream when we go into court and defend our clients, that we are really some superhero," said Brooke Davis, 30, a tenant lawyer with the Brooklyn Neighborhood Office of the Legal Aid Society.
As several dozen people milled in the lobby, waiting for the box office to open, the creator of the film, Ronin Amano, came bursting through the door with the videotape and bad news. Two-thirds of the film had been corrupted by a software meltdown that morning, said Mr. Amano, a burly paralegal from Park Slope, Brooklyn. So the audiences would get only a "taste."
Disappointment rolled over people's faces, but most paid the $10 admission anyway. They understood this to be a labor of love, scraped together from a secondhand computer and volunteer actors.
After a 30-minute film about the making of "Rent Wars Ronin," the 10-minute clip was shown. "There is a war in progress," the voice-over warned. "For the sake of evil, the Slumlords twist the law to cause agony and despair. But there is at least one tenant who can fight back. One, Ronin."
The animation fell far below Disney standards and the original score had a Nintendo flavor, but the audience didn't care. When Ronin says to himself (as superheroes often do), "But bribes go a long way in the D.H.C.R.," the audience was in stitches at the joke, an allusion to the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal.
Potato chips and cheese were served afterward, but the audience was hungry to see more of the film. 
"It's a great concept," said David Powell, 29, a tenant organizer with the Metropolitan Council on Housing, an advocacy group. "It's good to see the age-old struggle between the landed and landless connected to the reality of New York tenants."
Others felt soothed by what they had seen.
"It makes you feel like you have an ally," said Yarrow Regan, 44, an unemployed bookkeeper who is in a protracted dispute with her landlord in Queens. "This should be shown in housing court, in the children's room." 
Mr. Amano, who stayed up all night finishing the film, only to see his work evaporate, reassured fans that the work could be salvaged from his hard drive. The plan, he said, is to show "Rent Wars Ronin" in full in February on his cable show, "Rent Wars."
 DENNY LEE

GRAPHIC: Photo: In the film "Rent Wars Ronin," landlord-tenant skirmishes are a fantasy battle.

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/Michael T. Kennedy; 
Stein Roe Intermediate Bond Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
THE chance that corporations will default on their bond payments is high because of the recession, but investors are being well paid for taking on the risk, said Michael T. Kennedy, who runs the $652 million Stein Roe Intermediate Bond fund.
 "From a valuation perspective, the difference in yield between corporate bonds and Treasuries is at a historically wide point," Mr. Kennedy said from his office in downtown Chicago. Currently, 10-year United States Treasury bonds yield 5.1 percent, compared with 6.6 percent for corporate bonds rated A. That yield spread, 1.5 percentage points, compares with a more typical spread of 0.9 points, he added. 
 "We are more than compensated for the risk of credit-quality deterioration with extra yield," Mr. Kennedy said. "And we think the economy will bounce back in 2002, which means earnings will grow and credit quality will improve."
The fund returned 6.8 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday, compared with 4.9 percent for its intermediate-bond fund group, according to Morningstar Inc. It returned 9.3 percent in the last 12 months, versus 7.8 percent for its group, Morningstar said.
Mr. Kennedy, 39, is a senior vice president of the fund's adviser, Stein Roe & Farnham in Chicago. He picks most of the fund's 100 or so bonds from among issues rated investment grade by Standard & Poor's and BB, the highest grade of junk bonds, also called high-yield bonds.
Typically, he invests 10 percent of the fund's assets in United States Treasuries and 60 percent in corporate bonds. Today, the Treasury stake is just 2 percent, while corporate bonds account for nearly 80 percent of assets. Junk bonds account for 14 percent of the portfolio, up from a typical level of 10 percent but still below the 20 percent permitted in the fund's charter. While 20 percent of the bonds are issued by companies outside the United States, all are denominated in dollars. 
A month ago, $3.65 million in bonds issued by Enron accounted for 0.5 percent of the fund's assets. Enron has since collapsed amid questions about its accounting practices, and the bonds have lost 80 percent of their value -- about $2.92 million. Because of the loss, they account for just 0.1 percent of fund assets today, Mr. Kennedy said. Like many other money managers, Mr. Kennedy was surprised by the extent of the company's problems.
When choosing bonds, Mr. Kennedy focuses on industries that he believes will perform well, given his economic forecast. Currently, he is focusing on the banking, finance and automobile industries.
Next, he reviews company financial statements, looking closely at earnings trends and multiples of debt to cash flow and debt to total capitalization. "These help us to judge the company's ability to repay its debt," he said.
Mr. Kennedy calls himself a sector rotator, moving among different classes of bonds as well as among issues of the same class. That strategy created a relatively high annual turnover rate, 356 percent, in 2000. Even so, the fund's expenses averaged 0.72 percent of assets last year, less than the 0.99 percent average for the intermediate-bond group, Morningstar said.
The average duration of the fund's bonds is now 4.8 years, slightly longer than usual, Mr. Kennedy said, to better lock in yields. That compares with an average duration of 4.2 years for the intermediate bond group, Morningstar said.
In September, Mr. Kennedy bought 10-year bonds issued by General Motors, paying $99.699 for each $100 worth. They closed on Friday at $95.585. The bonds are investment grade, rated BBB+ by Standard & Poor's; their coupon rate is 6.875 percent. He said that G.M. was cutting costs to improve its balance sheet and that the auto industry outlook should improve in the next 12 to 18 months.
IN July, he bought bonds issued by First Massachusetts Bank, with a 7.625 percent coupon and due June 2011, at $103.76. On Friday, they closed at $104.349. First Massachusetts is an affiliate of the Banknorth Group of Portland, Me.
S.& P. rates the First Massachusetts bonds BBB, the lowest investment-grade rating. "We think the agency rated the bonds too low," Mr. Kennedy said. First Massachusetts has strong earnings growth and a solid balance sheet, he said.
In June, Mr. Kennedy bought bonds of the La Quinta Companies, due August 2004, at $94.55; they closed on Friday at $97. The coupon rate is 7.114 percent, and S.& P. rates them BB, the top junk grade. The La Quinta hotel chain, based in Dallas, was acquired in 1998 by the Meditrust Companies, a financier of real estate related to health care. After management recognized that its diversification strategy was not working, Mr. Kennedy said, it sold health care assets and is using the proceeds to pay down debt.
"What's left is La Quinta, which we expect will be acquired by some bigger hotel chain," Mr. Kennedy said. "If not, we have a solid hotel company."

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
NestEggs Have Shrunk. But Tuition Bills Haven't.

BYLINE:  By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
JO-ANN AND CHRISTOPHER DAVIS of Haddonfield, N.J., spent the first years of their marriage building up their electrical contracting business. It was not until about six years ago that they could start putting away college money for their six children, now 9 to 18 years old.
 Mrs. Davis, 41, is on the interviewing committee for applicants at her alma mater, Georgetown University, so she knew that college would be an expensive proposition for her family. Its grocery bills alone run $1,200 a month. 
 Lately, the Davises have been feeling especially under pressure. Like millions of other people, they have watched the volatile stock market lop off a big chunk of their college nest egg, which was invested in six mutual fund accounts, one for each child. As of last week, the values of the four accounts that had not been cashed in were down about 40 percent from their peaks. 
To make matters worse, college tuition continues to rise faster than inflation. In an annual survey released in October, the College Board found that the average in-state tuition and other fees for public four-year colleges rose 7.7 percent this year, to $3,754 a year, while tuition and fees at four-year private colleges rose 5.5 percent, to $17,123 a year.
To meet those rising expenses, the Davises, like many other families, are aggressively seeking financial aid. Their oldest child, Lauren, entered St. Joseph's University in Philadelphia in September with a $16,000 academic scholarship as well as an $8,000 work-study grant for all four years. In addition, she has taken out $28,000 in federal and college loans.
The College Board survey found that a record $74.4 billion in aid -- in the form of grants, loans and work-study jobs -- was available to students and their families this fall, an increase of more than 7 percent from last year. Still, some parents have been liquidating retirement accounts or even pulling their children out of schools, according to financial planners.
"Most lower-income families are still going to get a lot of financial aid," said Raymond D. Loewe, the president of College Money, a firm in Marlton, N.J., that helps parents plan for college expenses. "But a lot of wealthier parents, like those who are midlevel executives, are panicking -- they thought that they had it all figured out."
Mr. Loewe said that instead of cashing in their stock investments, a growing number of his clients who might not be eligible for direct financial aid were turning to loans offered by the federal Parent Loan for Undergraduate Students program, better known as PLUS. The loans let parents borrow up to all the cost of a college education, with no collateral. The current interest rate is 6.79 percent, the lowest since 1994.
For students, the most widely used plan is the low-interest, federal Stafford Loan program. Eligibility is determined by the school's financial aid office. In the subsidized version of these loans, based on need, the government pays the interest while students are in school. In the unsubsidized version, students pay all the interest, although they can defer payment until after graduation. The current rate is 5.39 percent.
Many colleges have their own low-interest loans for incoming and continuing students, Mr. Loewe noted. Students who are already enrolled when they run into financial problems should inquire at their schools' financial aid offices about retention loans and grants, he said.
These loans are usually for $1,000 to $7,000 and are most often offered by medium-priced private colleges and universities. 
"These are the schools that tend to be struggling because they don't have as many applicants as the state schools or the Ivy Leagues," Mr. Loewe said, adding that such schools often found it less expensive to keep good students than to bring in new ones.
College financial planners are also urging parents to be more flexible in choosing schools.
"Most parents naively assume that public schools will save them money," said Milton E. Eisenhardt, the director of counseling services at College Money. "But too often they're focusing just on tuition costs. Private colleges are doing some very creative things when it comes to money for students. And a small private college may actually pay more attention to moving a student through the system so that they graduate in four years instead of six."
Michael A. Tedesco, a counselor at New Rochelle High School in New York, said college-bound students in his area were increasingly looking at "solid, non-Ivy League schools where they can get good and, in some cases, great financial packages."
Mr. Tedesco, who is also a part-time adviser for college financial aid, said he had noticed such packages lately at schools like Case Western Reserve, Emory, Vanderbilt, Carnegie Mellon and the University of Rochester. Rochester offers $5,000 scholarships to residents of New York State, as well as $5,000 scholarships to students who have SAT scores of 1,350 or more.
Although tuition keeps climbing at most colleges, some have actually reduced their costs. Examples are on the Web site of the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities, which tracks its more than 900 members (www.naicu.edu). Based on a recent informal survey, the association found four colleges that charge no tuition at all (Cooper Union in New York is one), three that have recently reduced tuition and almost three dozen that have either frozen tuition for the 2001-02 year or have kept their recent tuition increases below the national average.
This fall, Bethany College in Bethany, W. Va., announced one of the largest tuition cuts ever reported by a private college: it is cutting tuition for its incoming freshmen next fall by 42 percent, to $12,000 from $20,650. Almost three-quarters of Bethany's students come from West Virginia, Ohio or Pennsylvania; the reductions were made in response to the weaker economy in those states, but also because they help make the school stand out, said Brian C. Ralph, a vice president for enrollment management and marketing.
"We felt that many students weren't even giving our school a look because of price," Mr. Ralph said.
(He added that many continuing students would receive financial aid, including scholarships, grants and merit awards, to offset their higher tuition.)
Since the plan was announced, the number of new applicants to Bethany has jumped 33 percent, he said; to make up for the lower tuition income per student, Bethany plans to increase the size of its next freshman class by 14 percent.
Elsewhere, officials report rising interest in colleges that offer a fifth year of tuition free -- in most cases so that students can finish accelerated master's degree programs. That means that the students can essentially receive two degrees for the price of one.
At Clark University in Worcester, Mass., David P. Angel, the dean of the graduate school, said 15 percent of Clark students were taking advantage of the school's "fifth year free" program.
Persistence appears to be more important than ever in seeking help with college costs. Mr. Tedesco said he knew of a father who was able to get an extra $10,000 in financial aid for his daughter after he wrote a courteous letter to the school, explaining that his business was about to go under and detailing the family's monthly budget.
Joan Winer Brown, 56, a widowed mother of three who lives in New Rochelle and works for a nonprofit group in Manhattan, used a written appeal to get more financial aid for her daughter Alice, 21, a senior at the University of Massachusetts in Amherst who is spending this semester at McGill University in Montreal.
MRS. DAVIS is learning the ropes as well. After spending $4,000 last summer just to set up her daughter Lauren with college needs like a computer, she decided to establish a simple savings account for such future expenses. She now deposits $50 a week into that account.
"It's not much money," she said. "But I didn't prepare for my first child like I'm going to prepare for the next few children."
Early preparation may be more important than ever, though financial planners say most parents still wait until the last minute.
Mr. Eisenhardt, for example, said 70 percent of the parents who came to him for advice had children who were already seniors in high school.
"The biggest problem I have in this business is that parents tend to deny that they'll have to pay for college until the end of a student's junior year," he said. "My ideal parent would be the one who is in a maternity ward."
