HEADLINE: Equal Opportunity Recession: Almost Everyone Is Feeling It 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT; This article was reported and written by Daniel Altman in New York; Pam Belluck in Boston; David Firestone in Elba, Ala.; Rachelle Garbarine in New Jersey; Laura M. Holson in Stateline, Nev.; Peter T. Kilborn in Alton, Ill.; Ross E. Milloy in Houston; Terry Pristin in New York; and Matt Richtel in San Francisco, with Mr. Leonhardt.

 BODY:
The nation's first economic downturn in 10 years began, like many of its predecessors, with a drop in factory orders along the manufacturing spine that runs from the Great Lakes to the Gulf of Mexico. By early this year, the slump had spread to the technology cubicles of Silicon Valley and elsewhere, courtesy of the deflation of the Internet bubble.
 But in the three months since Sept. 11, the recession's narrow early focus has been lost. The downturn has quickly become one of the broadest on record. 
 Every large industry, save health care and housing, is shrinking. Almost every state is losing jobs. Unemployment has risen for nearly every group, climbing most sharply for college graduates and others who usually escape the brunt of a downturn. 
However weakened, today's economy remains much stronger than it was in the 1980's or early 90's. Many fewer people are out of work today than then. Yet most remarkably, the blanket of recession has managed to cover the country despite remaining relatively thin.
"This is a very broad-based, shallow recession," said Mark Zandi, the chief economist at Economy.com, a consulting firm in West Chester, Pa.
In resorts around Lake Tahoe, in California and Nevada, hotels are offering rooms for $39 a night to keep up their business. In Boston and elsewhere, temporary-help agencies continue to pare their payrolls. Business is still weak in technology centers like San Jose, Calif. And old-line industries like steel and textiles, which were shrinking even before the recession began, are faring even worse now.
Almost no part of the country has been spared, Mr. Zandi said, but nearly every part of the country is worse off than it was a year ago. And the magnitude of the decline has been unusually uniform.
This pattern contrasts with the patchwork of past recessions, when layoffs were concentrated in a few regions and among those who worked with their hands on assembly lines and construction sites. The recession of 1990-91 was the first to leave large numbers of white-collar workers jobless, but it still did not spread its pain equitably, pushing the Northeast and California into such a deep hole that they did not catch up with the rest of the country for several years.
Even the vast service sector, which normally serves as the economic stabilizer, is now suffering. It has lost more jobs since September than it did in any other three-month period since World War II.
People who remain secure in their jobs are receiving smaller salary increases than they did in recent years, and many well-off Americans -- whose prodigal spending helped fuel the boom -- will be receiving much smaller bonus checks in coming weeks than they did in recent years.
The end of rapid income growth could make consumers thrifty for months, some economists worry, and could mean that the recovery gets off to a slow start. Still, with interest rates and energy prices low, forecasters expect the recession to end early next year, even if they disagree about how strong the recovery will be.
The breadth of the current downturn is not solely the result of the shock caused by the terrorist attacks. In recent years, as many cities and towns have lured companies from elsewhere with tax breaks and cash grants, regional economies have diversified and begun to look more alike.
Between March, when the recession officially began, and November, 37 states lost more jobs than they gained. Many of those states, now grappling with revenue shortfalls, are considering budget cuts that themselves are likely to aggravate the downturn. Although the 1990-91 recession was more severe than this downturn, employment fell in only 31 states through its first eight months. 
For many younger people, who have known nothing but prosperity since they entered the work force, the new situation has come as a shock. Many without work are unsure how soon they will be able to find a job that pays as much as their old one did.
"Growing up, you never heard of this: this didn't happen to my friends' parents," said Allegra Kochman, a 31-year-old graduate of Dartmouth and Columbia who was laid off this month, along with 40 other people, from her job at an architecture firm in New York.
"I was stunned," said Ms. Kochman, who was locked in a stairwell the night she was laid off, when her company turned off her electronic key before she was finished cleaning out her desk. "This isn't supposed to be happening."

Travel
The Industry Hurt the Most
Snow for the nearby ski slopes was on its way outside a huge casino in southern Lake Tahoe in Nevada, but inside, the chairman of Harrah's Entertainment Inc. was anxiously watching the chips fall instead.
"Those are $100 chips," said Philip G. Satre, Harrah's chief executive, peering across the floor of the casino at an elderly man seated at a nearly empty poker table. The problem, from Mr. Satre's standpoint, was that there were not enough of them.
When Mr. Satre's eyes lit upon six young players clustered around a nearby game, however, they brightened. "I like that table," he said. "It's fully occupied."
While almost every sector of the economy ground to a halt at least briefly after the Sept. 11 attacks, companies dependent on travel-and-leisure spending were hit the hardest. Already in retreat as companies cut back on business travel, airlines and hotels lost even more business when many Americans simply stopped flying.
Now, three months later, more people are traveling again, but that has done nothing to reverse the loss of more than 202,000 jobs -- about 6 percent of the total -- in the airline and lodging businesses since March.
Particularly hard hit have been gambling meccas like Las Vegas and vacation destinations like Orlando. In a typical year, the Lake Tahoe region in California and Nevada has two million visitors, who provide the spending that supports jobs for about 80 percent of the working population in this town of 40,000 people. But not this year.
Mr. Satre said he first saw the downturn at Harrah's casino after the Internet boom imploded in Silicon Valley. The company has a sophisticated system to monitor customers; last spring business dropped 30 percent among the casino's most infrequent guests -- casual younger visitors who ski or hike for a weekend and gamble a little as well.
To combat the downturn, Mr. Satre said that Harrah's, in Stateline, Nev., decided to pursue customers it knew could spend as much as $1,500 a year gambling. It usually only goes after much bigger spenders. "What we did is reach down into our database and make offers to customers we otherwise wouldn't," he said.
In October, Harrah's and its sister casino, Harvey's, mailed cards to those customers, offering rooms for as little as $39 a night. They also hit hard on the theme "We're close to home" in advertisements in newspapers in the San Francisco Bay area to capture affluent travelers who, in rosier times, might take off to Vail or Aspen instead.
That strategy has helped hold the tide. For October, Harrah's occupancy rate rose to 91 percent from 82.5 percent last October. Visitors held steady in November, traditionally one of the casino's slowest months.
Gambling revenue for the entire market of southern Lake Tahoe rose 3.25 percent for October, the most recent month tallied, from October a year ago. That is a turnaround from earlier in the year, when monthly revenue fell as much as 10 percent.
But while Harrah's casino has so far avoided long-term layoffs, Mr. Satre is worried about what will happen to the area as it heads into ski season.
Instead of the giddy glee that accompanies a snowfall before a weekend here, resort executives fear the fallout from the terrorist attacks will keep skiers away this winter.
At the Heavenly ski resort, about 60 percent of the skiers arrive by air and most from within the United States, executives at the resort said. Michael Allen, director of Heavenly's ski school, said he was hiring only 275 ski coaches this season, 27 percent fewer than last. He said he expected about 90,000 students, well below the 115,000 the school gets in a good year.
Looking across the Sierra Nevada, where miners sought their fortunes 150 years ago, Mr. Allen, too, was hopeful of better times.
"Our customers," he said, "are worth more than gold."

Temporary Workers
Economic Slump Ends 20-Year Rise
Last year was Bill Bastian's most successful. Business had more than quadrupled from more than a decade ago, when he became president of Command Temporary Services, a temporary staffing agency in Boston that places waiters and kitchen staff.
At this time last year, he was assigning more than 200 workers a day, and had contracted for 40 office holiday parties a week, mostly with companies along the Route 128 technology belt west of the city. 
"A computer company with a new product would bring in 200 people at the Hilton, and they would stay there for three days," Mr. Bastian said. "We couldn't keep up with it. We could not get enough people to handle the business we had."
Not anymore. This year, Mr. Bastian is lucky to send out 125 people a day, and there are virtually no office parties. "All of that is gone because of the recession," he said. 
The recession has ended a nearly continuous 20-year rise in the number of Americans working for temporary-help agencies. In the early 1980's, about 1 of every 200 Americans got their paychecks from temporary work. By the late 1990's, about 1 of every 40 people did, as employers found they could cut costs by paying temporary workers relatively few benefits and being able to hire and fire them with ease. 
But the rapid downturn in the economy, particularly among manufacturers, which are heavy users of temporary workers, has brought an end to that expansion. Since employment at the temporary agencies peaked at 3.5 million in September 2000, it has fallen by 17 percent, to 2.9 million.
Earl Tate, founder and president of Staffing Solutions in Boston, which provides clerical and other workers, said that his business had been down 35 percent this year compared with last, and that since Sept. 11 he had laid off three of his seven staff recruiters. 
"When companies are laying people off they tend not to hire temporaries," Mr. Tate said, "because it does not seem to work as good public relations within their office."
Those that are still hiring temporaries are now looking for workers with more flexibility, Mr. Tate added. "Companies are realizing they can demand workers with higher skills," he said. "Rather than get a receptionist, they may ask for a secretary-receptionist. They are upgrading to a person that can do two or three jobs."
Mr. Bastian said the downturn had not caught him completely by surprise.
"I read the tea leaves," he said. "You could see the recession coming down the pipeline. You tighten up all of your costs and eliminate all the frills. And make sure your receivables are all up to date." 
Mr. Bastian began to call in for overdue payments at computer start-ups that looked as if they might go belly up. He expected the economy to slow him down by about 20 percent. But he was not prepared for the terrorist attacks and the chilling effect they would have on the hotels and convention sites he helps cater.
"It really rocked the food service," said Mr. Bastian, whose business is down about 35 percent. He said no one was in the mood for an office holiday party or a college alumni party. 
As a result, Mr. Bastian said, he has purged a lot of the not-so-good workers and has been placing the best ones in jobs that they might not have taken before. 
"People will do stuff today that they would not do even a year ago," he said. "I have cooks today that will do dishes without blinking an eye."

Health Care
In an Ailing City, A Sign of Strength
The last few months have not been kind to Jason Goode's hometown, Houston. Enron, the local energy giant, has filed for bankruptcy. Continental Airlines, which dominates the city's main airport, has canceled dozens of flights since Sept. 11. And the executives of Compaq Computer believe their best chance for survival involves being acquired by another company and potentially laying off thousands of Houston workers.
But Mr. Goode sounds as if he is still living in the oil-boom days of the 1970's and early 80's. "We're crying for people in almost every category," he said.
He is a recruiter for Memorial Hermann Hospital, and he is working in the single strongest sector in the United States economy today. Even in a recession, people continue to need medical care.
Mr. Goode's employer has more than 500 vacancies for a regular full-time staff of 8,000 people. "Hospitals all across the state are expanding," he said, "and we're all fighting desperately to fill positions that are empty."
His predicament is shared by health care providers nationwide. While overall employment has fallen by about 1.2 million jobs since peaking in March at 132.7 million, the health care industry has added 200,000 jobs over the same span. It now employs 10.5 million workers, according to the Labor Department.
In Houston, the contrast between health care and other, hard-hit industries is readily apparent at a jobs fair attended by about 4,000 laid-off Enron workers. Mr. Goode was just one of several health care recruiters who had come to the fair to find workers.
Among the others was Pam Sumner, whose company hires nursing and other personnel for hospitals and nursing homes.
"I have over 2,000 hours each week of unfilled vacancies," she said. "In 15 years in the nursing industry, I've never seen the shortages of trained personnel as bad as it is right now."
Ms. Sumner said she expected her business, NI Healthcare Inc., to grow three times larger in revenues and employees in the next year, and to grow fivefold in two years. "The demand is just incredible," she said.
In a city where an estimated 7 percent of the work force is employed in some aspect of the health care industry, the single largest health care employer is the Texas Medical Center, a complex of 13 hospitals and 41 member institutions with a direct work force of 61,000. A recent report published by the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas estimates that the center has a $5.8 billion economic impact on the Houston area, and indirectly helps to employ more than 147,000 people.
Dr. Richard E. Wainerdi, president of the center -- which had 5.4 million patient visits last year -- said his facility was also in an expansion mode. "We'll grow from 22 million square feet to 32 million square feet in the next eight years," he said. "We had planned to accommodate that growth over 15 years."
Dr. Wainerdi points to two main reasons for growth in the health care industry: an aging population, and medical research that is lengthening life spans.
"The research is providing means to keep people who might have died alive longer, but it also means that they need continuing care, sometimes for several different problems at once," he said. "Those people require more care, more medicines, more facilities and more clinical services."
Also, he said, although new research requires new facilities, much of the hospital infrastructure in the country itself is aged and must be replaced. 
That need is feeding regional economic expansion, he said, pointing to one other finding of the Federal Reserve report: Already the largest medical complex in the world, the Texas Medical Center is dwarfing the economic impact of another large and famous Houston-area employer, the Johnson Space Center.

State Budgets
Shortfalls Imperil Local Classrooms
In the southeast corner of Alabama, the small town of Elba felt a tremor last week from the crash in tax revenue that has immobilized state government for the better part of the year.
The town of 4,185 people had already suffered through its own problems: two floods in the last decade and the closings in recent years of a plant making trailers and a textile manufacturer, which cost nearly 1,500 jobs in Coffee County. School enrollment, reflecting the declining population, dropped to less than 1,000 from 1,300 three years ago. 
But a few days ago, Ed Richardson, the state school superintendent, brought Alabama's larger economic problems to Elba's doorstep. The state's tax revenue had dropped so low, Mr. Richardson said, that the state would have to consider disbanding five shrinking school districts, including Elba's, and merging them with that of the surrounding county. He also warned that sports and music programs in schools around the state might have to be dropped.
Such threats have been used before to goad the Legislature into action, and lawmakers meeting in special session quickly began working on a package that would raise corporate taxes for school aid. But in places like Elba, as in many small towns with fragile economic foundations, the prospect of losing autonomy for the schools was a frightening reminder of the effects of a downturn.
"I don't think the state is really going to cut football," said Danny Weeks, superintendent of the Elba schools, "but talk of school closings and consolidation is something none of us like to hear about. We've already got our teachers painting the school and cutting the grass, and we're using some of our textbook money to pay them. It means a lot to our city to have local control of the schools, and I hope we'll be able to keep that."
Alabama is one of 43 states where tax revenue is coming in below expectations because of the recession, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures, and one of 36 states that have started cutting the budget as a result. Like many Southern states, it has been particularly hard hit because so much of its budget is based on the volatile sales tax. Last year the state school budget was cut by $260 million because of falling revenue, and the school deficit this year is estimated at $160 million, unless the Legislature acts on a new tax package by this weekend.
Legislators in dozens of states, as well as Alabama, have been called into emergency sessions to cut spending or find new revenue to balance budgets, even after months of warning that boom-time balance sheets were over. There have been across-the-board cuts in Arkansas, Delaware, South Carolina, Virginia and other states, and some have exempted only education from reductions.
That is not possible in Alabama, where the school budget is directly tied to tax revenue, but some sectors of the economy are clearly not willing to accept a new reality. After Gov. Donald Siegelman proposed raising corporate taxes by $160 million to keep the schools afloat, business leaders began running a scornful television commercial.
The governor, says one character in the advertisement, "must be crazier than a sprayed roach."

Technology
Once Unstoppable, A Sector Retrenches
Even in an era of ambitious high-tech dreams, it was a grand vision.
Candescent Technologies, a 90's-era start-up in the business of making ultrathin computer screens that was backed by some of the biggest names in venture capital, started planning several years ago to build a huge manufacturing plant in San Jose, Calif. The plant would finally give the United States a powerful presence in an industry long dominated by Taiwanese manufacturers.
That expensive dream now lies in disarray.
"We basically have a building," said David L. White, the chief executive of Candescent, who explained that the company finally threw in the towel on the project in the last couple of months. "We never even committed to the equipment."
For a long time, Candescent, like many better-known Silicon Valley companies, resisted the notion that the bursting of the dot-com bubble last year would affect its plans. Mr. White said he only gradually accepted the idea that the market would not recover soon, requiring his company to rest its hopes instead on licensing its technology to others.
Candescent is not alone in reining in its ambitions. For example, Intel, the world's leading maker of computer chips, conceded recently that its expansion in the 1990's would have to be sharply scaled back.
"In the first half of 2000, we were under capacity for manufacturing," said Chuck Malloy, an Intel spokesman in Santa Clara, Calif. "The demand was clearly there then."
But this is now. Intel has been forced this year to abandon about 20 office and manufacturing projects already under construction, including buildings in Austin, Tex., Chandler, Ariz., and Folsom, Calif.
Craig Barrett, Intel's chief executive, says he hopes the worst is over -- but even he is not sure what to expect.
"I take solace in the fact that normally these things last 18 months or so, and we're 12 months into it," he said. "So hopefully we're more than halfway through it."
But demand for high-tech products is not expected to improve very much in the year ahead. The most recent monthly survey by CIO magazine and Yardeni.com, the Internet site of Ed Yardeni, the chief investment strategist of Deutsche Bank Alex. Brown, found that chief information officers, the company executives who oversee spending on technology, remained pessimistic.
They think investment in technology equipment, while looking somewhat better than at the low point in September, will grow barely more than 5 percent in the next 12 months, slightly less than it did in the previous year. Only a year ago, they were projecting an annual technology spending increase of nearly 19 percent.
It is all a vivid illustration of how Silicon Valley's technology firms succumbed to their own mantra that the new economy was unstoppable.
In many cases, the companies and their investors felt they had little choice but to chase the dream. If they failed to grow, they worried, shareholders would accuse them of failing to catch one of the great waves of American capitalism.
As for Candescent, it has cut its work force to about 250 people, from a peak of 400. The company once raised $600 million from a variety of investors, who figured that Candescent's technology would satisfy demand from consumers and businesses for the next generation of lower-cost, higher-quality digital screens. 
Instead, Candescent's would-be manufacturing plant in San Jose has become a monument to the era's exuberant investment. Faced with a huge glut in the thin screen display market, it was never able to raise the $500 million more needed to complete the facility.
Now, rather than relying on venture capitalists, Mr. White said he hoped to sustain the company by licensing its technology and relying on investment from corporate partners. "We'll have to be more self-sufficient in terms of financing," he said.
And what happened to his company, Mr. White said, happened throughout the industry.
"People were throwing caution to the wind," he said. "Investors lost their entire perspective."

Housing
Market Rebounds From Sept. 11
While the recession has meant that fewer people are buying houses in many parts of the country, prices have not fallen significantly. Even in the luxury market -- which had been expected to suffer because of the decline in the stock market over the last two years -- sales have rebounded since their lows in the weeks immediately after Sept. 11.
"To my surprise, it's been holding up quite well," said Jeff Hyland, president of Hilton & Hyland, a luxury real estate agency in Beverly Hills, Calif.
The housing market may not be as robust as it was in the final years of the economic boom, but its continued strength remains one of the only bright spots in the economy. Behind that bright spot are low mortgage rates, as well as the long rise in incomes, stocks and home prices in the boom.
Now that a recession has arrived, many buyers and sellers alike have decided waiting is an attractive strategy. Buyers are betting on a longer economic slump in which sellers will eventually have to accept lower prices, Mr. Hyland said. Sellers are patiently watching the market, aware that a house seems as good a place as any for keeping large sums of money right now.
Homeowners, said Bob Becker, the president and chief executive of NRT, the nation's largest residential real estate brokerage, "are not being talked into panic sales."
The median price of previously owned houses fell to $145,000 in October from $152,000 in June, according to the National Association of Realtors. But the decline has simply returned prices to where they had been this spring -- still 9 percent higher than at the start of 2000.
The market already seems to be rebounding from the weakness just after Sept. 11, brokers say. One of the largest residential developers in the Middle Atlantic region, Toll Brothers, says that sales of its houses had already begun to slow before Sept. 11. After the attacks, they plunged 33 percent and stayed that way for a month.
But business began to improve after Toll offered buyers incentives, like an extra room on a house, and below-market mortgage rates.
"Our optimism for 2002 has been rekindled," said Frederick N. Cooper, the company's vice president for finance.
Part of the reason the decline at the high end of the market has not been worse, said Mr. Hyland, the Beverly Hills real estate agent, is that only one section of wealthy Americans has slowed its purchases. Families seeking houses worth less than $1 million -- the low end of the luxury market -- have continued to buy because of low interest rates. The biggest spenders, those seeking houses worth $5 million or more, have not slowed either. 
But for those between, the calculus may be more complicated. The sharp fall in stock prices since early 2000 has left many of these midlevel buyers with a big hole in their portfolios, Mr. Hyland said. Low mortgage rates may not be enough to persuade them to buy into the $1 million-to-$5 million housing market, since these houses usually require down payments of hundreds of thousands of dollars.
House construction has diminished in some high-priced areas, too. In metropolitan San Jose, Calif., the heart of Silicon Valley, 20 percent fewer permits were issued in the first 10 months of this year, compared with the same period last year, said Steve Berman, a statistician at the Census Bureau. The Bay Area as a whole suffered a loss of 13 percent. In New York and its suburbs, permits have slipped 7.5 percent.
That could be a temporary blip or the start of a long decline, brokers said. They expect the uncertainty to continue for at least a few months. "The market today," Mr. Becker said, "is significantly different than it was 30 days ago -- and 30 days prior to that."

Steel
Obsolete Workers Try To Build Future
The recession may be broad-based. But for the steel industry at least, it is not shallow. For steel towns like Alton, Ill., and for workers like Jonathan Walker, the recession began early, and is deep and entrenched.
Six-foot-one and 280 pounds, with hands as meaty and firm as a fielder's mitt, Mr. Walker is one of the sagging economy's hard-core unemployed, a man with knowledge and skills for which the economy no longer has much use.
In the cruel phraseology of industrial demise, the Laclede Steel Company, 400 grim, rusting acres of mills in Alton where Mr. Walker worked for 23 years, is being liquidated. Upon the company's bankruptcy in July, Mr. Walker and 500 other Laclede steel workers were dismissed. 
Foreign steel and a weak global economy have ravaged the American steel industry. According to Mr. Walker's union, United Steelworkers of America, 27 steel companies, union and nonunion and with more than 63,000 workers, have filed for bankruptcy in the last four years. Most are still operating and trying to pay their creditors.
"The real crunch started in the early 80's," said Terry Wooten, the president of Laclede's Steelworkers Local 3643 on Broadway, Alton's industrial thoroughfare, where the huge gravestones of dead factories stand like rusty pyramids. "We tried everything we possibly could to keep this company solvent and viable." 
Now, the industry is looking to Washington for help. Steel makers want trade protection from low-priced imports, but they also want billions of dollars to help pay health and pension benefits. And because they see consolidation as critical to making the industry more efficient and competitive, they want assurances that any mergers will not run into antitrust problems. 
That help, if it comes, will not be of much use to the Laclede workers let go in July. Of those workers, Mr. Wooten said, some have taken low-wage jobs to supplement their wives' mostly low-wage jobs. They also collect about $300 a week in unemployment benefits.
But the unemployment checks end after six months, and that could imperil more than 100 workers who are living on them while going to school to learn new skills. Among them is Rodney Crader, 45, who was a stripper in Laclede's wire mill. Today, he wears the royal blue uniform of Vatterott College, a trade school where he is learning welding. But the course runs until April, and his unemployment checks stop in January. He has some savings, however, and his wife has a full-time job at Western Union. 
The Walkers, whose children are grown, have money concerns as well. Mr. Walker, who earned more than $40,000 a year at Laclede, has no way right now to keep up the $650 in monthly mortgage payments for his house, and menacing collection notices pile up on the desk. Mr. Walker's health insurance has stopped.
In addition to his $300 weekly unemployment check, he earns about $150 delivering pizzas 20 hours a week. His wife, Angelica, earns $150 to $210 a week working up to 33 hours as a supermarket cashier.
Together, they are living on about $16,000 less a year than the $55,000 they had before Laclede closed. When the unemployment checks stop, it will be $31,000 less. 
With little white lights strung on the walls, a two-foot artificial tree in one corner and a big, lush tree in another, the Walkers' home is an exuberant celebration of Christmas. But the big tree was a gift from a friend. For Christmas presents for friends and relatives, Mrs. Walker has filled 20 white cotton socks with beans. With buttons and beads for faces and belly buttons, she has sewn them into jolly snowmen.
Mr. Walker says he does not know what he will be able to give; out of a job, he says his life is out of his control. "I'm in a washing machine," he said, "going up and down, up and down."

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases; 
Outdoor Adviser Gets Warm Clothes After His Savings Are Used Up

BYLINE:  By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
Famous for advising presidents from Wilson to Truman during conversations on a bench across the street from the White House, Bernard M. Baruch, a City College graduate and early 1900's Wall Street millionaire, became known as the Park Bench Statesman.
 Ed Felder, 77, is considerably less famous than Baruch, who died in 1965 at the age of 94. But Mr. Felder is well known among the students and administrators at Baruch College as an informal adviser with a bench of his own. 
 Rather than talking with presidents about international economic policy, Mr. Felder, a World War II veteran and former public relations specialist, speaks with film students about his experience in the field, and with administrators about fund-raising and public relations.
Baruch's favorite bench was in Lafayette Park in Washington, but Mr. Felder's, a backless wooden model, is not in a park. 
It is on Lexington Avenue, in front of the busy revolving doors of a Baruch campus building. One gets the feeling that if Gramercy Park, a block and a half to the south, were open to the public, Mr. Felder would continue sitting right there on that bench, in the midst of students going to class and busy pedestrians.
"I get all the important ones here," he said from his perch on a mild December morning, "the deans, the heads of all the different departments."
Mr. Felder was himself once a student at the college, then called City College's School of Business and Civic Administration. It was renamed for Baruch in 1953. But in 1943, after Mr. Felder had completed a year of study, he was drafted to serve in the Army.
After the war, he began working in public relations, fund-raising and television production. Over the course of a 50-year career, he said, he worked for 15 different companies and nonprofit agencies, including the Muscular Dystrophy Association of America, the New York Philharmonic and the United Jewish Appeal (which later merged with another agency to become UJA-Federation of New York). The jobs he had were lucrative, and by the time he retired, he had saved $100,000.
Throughout the years that he held these jobs, Mr. Felder never lost his love for walking through the streets of New York. At his peak, he walked five or six miles a day, he said: "The East Side is one thing; Eighth and Ninth Avenue is another world."
But by the late 1990's, his spine had weakened, deteriorating because of a condition known as spinal stenosis. Doctors gave Mr. Felder a brace to wrap around his midriff, but it did little to solve his problems, he said. "I had gotten to the point where I couldn't walk without excruciating pain," Mr. Felder said.
So he checked into Beth Israel Medical Center. He had four operations to have his spine corrected, he said. Medicare paid for 65 percent of the cost but the rest came out of his pocket. After five years he was penniless. "I had to go bankrupt last year," he said. "My life savings, everything was wiped out."
Mr. Felder, who at the time was receiving roughly $600 a month in Social Security and a $288 veterans' pension, could barely afford the $600 monthly rent for his single room across the street from the college. "Because I was living on such a slim margin," he said, "I actually didn't have warm clothing for last winter."
Fortunately, a relative told him that he could receive help from the Jewish Association for Services for the Aged, a beneficiary agency of UJA-Federation of New York, one of the seven local charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
The agency assigned a worker, Sheila Siegel, to assist Mr. Felder. When she found out that he needed clothing, she used money from the Neediest Cases Fund so he could get some. He got a new black leather jacket and some good walking shoes with $240 from the fund.
"We want people to have dignity in the last years of their lives," Ms. Siegel said.
Now, she reports, Mr. Felder looks splendid sitting on the bench in his new shoes and jacket. "This gave me the confidence to sit at the bench and give people advice," he said. "It made an enormous difference psychologically."
One of the people who sits down with him regularly is Jane R. Crotty, the director of community and external affairs at the college. Six years ago, the two got to talking about Baruch's reputation as a park bench adviser and talked about ways to improve awareness of the man and his life. At the time, the school was planning a new building a block away. Mr. Felder suggested that the school put a bench in the lobby with a life-size replica of Baruch there.
Earlier this year, the college did exactly that. At the bench's dedication ceremony, Mr. Felder was honored for his idea, and he was the first person to have his photograph taken on the bench, sitting next to the bronze Baruch. "I'm the broke Baruch," he joked recently, back at his bench on Lexington Avenue, between 22nd and 23rd Streets.
"Do you think they will have a bench of me someday?"

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: PERSONAL SECURITY; 
Steep Rise in Gun Sales Reflects Post-Attack Fears

BYLINE:  By AL BAKER 

 BODY:
Gun and ammunition sales across the country have risen sharply since Sept. 11 as more Americans take what many consider to be the most personal step toward feeling safer: arming themselves.
 According to statistics from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, surveys by firearms associations and anecdotal evidence from storefront gun shops and distributors from Arizona to Florida to Lower Manhattan, the jump in weapons sales followed quickly on the first jarring images of the terrorist attacks. 
 The rise was anywhere from 9 percent to nearly 22 percent during September, October and November, according to F.B.I. statistics on background checks for purchases. The total peaked in October, at 1,029,691, up from 845,886 in October 2000. 
Those in the gun industry say a range of firearms have been purchased, from high-priced handguns small enough to fit inside a purse to shotguns and assault rifles that can be leaned against a wall inside a clothes closet. And, they say, there has been a steady stream of serious-minded first-time buyers. 
"Sept. 11, like other catastrophes, makes people panic, makes them fearful, makes them want to protect themselves and their families against the enemy, who, in this case, is hard to identify," said James Alan Fox, Lipman professor of criminal justice at Northeastern University in Boston. "People may say: 'Let Tom Ridge watch out for our shores. I'll watch out for my doors.' "
To many in and out of law enforcement, such a proliferation of deadly weapons is unsettling, even as scores of new gun owners argue that their right to bear arms is worth exercising to gain a feeling of personal security in troubled times.
"We are always concerned with the overall numbers of guns that are available and out on the street making things unmanageable for law enforcement," said William B. Berger, the police chief of North Miami Beach, Fla., who is president of the International Association of Chiefs of Police, the nation's oldest and largest group of law enforcement executives, with 19,000 members worldwide.
Some gun manufacturers -- like those in other industries -- are aggressively seeking new clients because of Sept. 11. Ithaca Gun Company is selling its Homeland Security model for "our current time of national need." The Beretta gun company has its "United We Stand," a 9-millimeter pistol bearing a laser-etched American flag. The company sold 2,000 of them to wholesalers in one day in October, said Jeff Reh, vice general manager of Beretta U.S.A.
Gun control advocates have voiced strong concern about the increased sales, citing statistics showing that guns, though purchased by the law-abiding, sometimes end up later in criminals' hands. Some law enforcement officials echo that thought. The advocates also say that more guns in circulation, particularly in the hands of the untrained, increase the chances of violence in the home, suicide, or accidental shooting.
Nevertheless, guns are being bought with the feeling that they will make the buyer safer. Scott Abraham, a Long Island investment broker in his 30's, said he never dreamed of buying a gun until Sept. 11. Last month he bought a Mossberg shotgun because "I don't want to be caught shorthanded," and made a spot to hide it in his house. Thomas M. Iasso, 53, a former police officer who stopped carrying a gun two years ago, bought a .40-caliber Glock after the terrorist attacks -- and he carries it.
"You can't sit there and tell me you can protect me anymore, because you can't," Mr. Iasso said, explaining his purchase.
Both Mr. Abraham and Mr. Iasso bought their guns at John Jovino Gun Shop, the city's oldest, in Little Italy. The shop owner, Anthony F. Imperato, said there had been a steady increase in potential customers expressing interest in obtaining a New York City pistol or shotgun permit. Other people, with permits, want additional weapons, and some people just want to buy self-defense equipment, like pepper spray. 
At Mr. Imperato's gun factory, Henry Repeating Arms Company in Brooklyn, there has been a run on the Henry U.S. Survival Rifle since Sept. 11. It was first manufactured four years ago, but its "name and style and features make it particularly desirable" now, Mr. Imperato said. The components of the gun, a version of the United States Air Force AR-7, can be disassembled and placed in its stock, which is waterproof and floats.
Gun shops and distributors across the country tell similar stories. Local reports in several states, including Texas, Nevada and Virginia, said officials have cited increases in gun sales, and in applications for concealed-weapons permits in the days immediately after the attacks. Members of the Air Line Pilots Association may soon be allowed to carry firearms in their cockpits.
According to Andrew M. Molchan, the director of the 4,000-member Professional Gun Retailers Association in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., firearms retailers have seen significant jumps in sales, especially among first-time buyers and the wealthy.
"Maybe they had more to protect or maybe they had more to lose, or, psychologically, they thought they had more to lose," Mr. Molchan said.
In a survey done about 10 days after the September attacks, the National Shooting Sports Foundation found that 15 percent of gun retailers who were questioned had reported sales increases of more than 25 percent, said Douglas Painter, executive director of the 1,800-member, Connecticut-based organization. The majority of those retailers were in places close to the attacks, like New York City and Washington, as well as in Florida, where some of the terrorists are believed to have lived for a time, he said.
Now the big question is how long the increase in sales will continue. Opinion is split. Many retailers say the buying habits may be affected by global events. "Only time will tell if this current increase in sales will be long-term," Mr. Painter said. 
Some gun retailers say that sales have already begun to level off or decrease in recent days, and that they do not think overall gun sales for the year will break records.
The F.B.I. statistics show increases in the number of background checks for firearms sales and other transactions from September through November. But they had increased very slightly in August as well.
Daniel A. Wells, the assistant operations manager for the National Instant Criminal Background Check System, the F.B.I. section that keeps data on the sales of long guns and handguns, pawn shop redemptions and permit requests, said the number of checks increased 12 percent on Sept. 12 over the same day in 2000.
The number of background checks for gun purchases and other transactions increased to 864,038 for September, an increase of 10.5 percent over the same month last year. In October, they were 1,029,691, a gain of nearly 22 percent over October 2000. And last month, they were 983,186, an increase of more than 9 percent over November 2000, the F.B.I. figures showed. That followed declines in each of those months -- traditional hunting season months -- between 1999 and 2000. So far this month, however, the numbers are on track to be slightly lower than they were last December, though the holiday buying season is not over. 
The checks are considered the most accurate gauge of the number of gun purchases. The totals are not precisely equivalent, because more than one gun may be bought after a single check, or the check may prevent any purchase at all. 
The recent increases were expected, just as gun sales jumped in limited geographical regions after incidents like the Los Angeles riots or before the passage of the Brady Act of 1994, which established a nationwide system of background checks for handgun purchases.
"This time you can project it nationally," Wayne R. LaPierre, chief executive of the National Rifle Association, said of the increased sales.
No one can say for sure if the increase can be attributed solely to the Sept. 11 attacks, but many law enforcement officials and gun industry insiders agree it is a primary reason. Because the F.B.I. has been keeping statistics only since November 1998, it cannot determine whether the increases are part of some cyclical pattern. Some buyers said part of the reason was their feeling that crime was beginning to inch up and that a worsening economy might bring increases in crime. 
"If they were sitting on the fence between 'should I buy a gun or not buy one,' well, this was the catalyst that pushed them over," said a former employee of a major gun manufacturer who lost his job early this year as a result of slumping sales.
The gun industry has been in a general decline over the last three decades as the popularity of sport hunting has waned and fewer young people have been introduced to firearms. Low crime rates and a buoyant economy are also thought to have contributed to the downturn in gun ownership.
Still, the vast number of weapons already loosed upon American streets often wind up in the hands of those with insufficient training, gun control advocates say. And they stay in circulation for years.
"We will see the ultimate consequences of that down the road when we see death and injuries that are associated with the proliferation of handguns," said Tom Diaz, senior policy analyst at the Violence Policy Center, a nonprofit gun control group in Washington.
He said most guns would sit on closet shelves or in glove compartments, never used to fight crime, let alone terrorism. "What are you going to do, shoot an envelope filled with anthrax or stop a 747 with a handgun?" he asked. "It's literally crazy."
The executive director of Doctors Against Handgun Injury, Robert V. Seltzer, has said that people need to think before buying a weapon and that if they buy one, they "need to store it properly: unloaded, locked, with the ammunition stored separately and securely."
Around the country, gun instruction classes have shown significant increases in enrollment. Mr. LaPierre said the waiting period to attend courses for weapon-carrying permits had jumped to more than two months from two weeks.
At the Firing Line, a South Philadelphia gun shop and pistol range where gun sales have increased 20 percent since Sept. 11, the owner, Gregory J. Isabella, said economic fears have not stopped sales. He said he sold 58 guns in the first 20 days after the attacks, an increase of 20 percent or more over the same period last year, and sold 18,000 rounds of ammunition in the same period, an increase of more than 30 percent. Sales at his shop have steadied, but are still ahead of last year's pace. He said women were buying their own guns, or ammunition for their husbands as a Christmas stocking stuffer. Other customers, he said, come by just to shoot at the Osama bin Laden targets.
"I got him!" Mr. Isabella said he could hear shooters saying, or, "I got even with him!" He said: "It's a way to blow off steam and, perhaps, practice for some nebulous future event.
"Let's just say that personal security is now on the mind of individual citizens," Mr. Isabella said. "Definitely."

HEADLINE: Fortress New York, Falling to Time; 
Across City, Vestiges of the Days of Redcoats, Rebels and Russians

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
In the Rockaways, sand dunes ripple past underground silos that once housed nuclear-tipped missiles. On the island where New York City maintains potter's field, prisoners bury the indigent near the foundations of former Army barracks. At a Staten Island park, children dig soccer cleats into land that offers a faint outline of a former Army air field.
 Almost anywhere you go in New York City, there are vestiges of a colorful military past. 
 Today, the city is home to only one active-duty base, Fort Hamilton, at the Brooklyn foot of the Verrazano Narrows Bridge, a small garrison whose primary mission is recruiting. As late as the 1960's, however, several thousand soldiers lived on more than a half-dozen installations scattered throughout the five boroughs, continuing a tradition that has guarded against redcoats, civil unrest and cold war shenanigans. 
But the uniformed men and women standing sentinel at vulnerable locations in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks provide a rare reminder of the military's once significant presence in New York.
"There's a rich tradition, but there's a tendency to forget," said Jack Fein, the unofficial historian of Fort Totten, in Queens, which was decommissioned in 1967 and is now used primarily by the Army Reserves and the Police and Fire Departments. "You had organizations and people and museums. Tremendous. All over the city. It was military, more than you can possibly realize."
New York can certainly claim its share of military distinctions. Fort Totten was the site of the Army's earliest East Coast radar installation. Floyd Bennett Field was one of the country's busiest military airports during World War II. Abner Doubleday served at Fort Hamilton. So, too, did Stonewall Jackson, who just missed overlapping with another Confederate leader, Robert E. Lee.
But the history of the military in New York is largely a story of fortifications built out in concentric rings, away from the heart of the city, according to Russell S. Gilmore, a historian and author of a 1983 monograph, "Guarding America's Front Door: Harbor Forts in the Defense of New York City."
To defend the city, first from warships, then much later from missiles, the fortifications began with earthen berms built by the Dutch. Then they moved out to the stone forts at Liberty and Governors Islands, to the granite forts in the outer boroughs guarding the harbor, and, finally, to the underground silos on the city's fringes and in the suburbs.
For the most part, the strategy worked. In fact, before Sept. 11, the only time New York was attacked was in 1776, when the British won the Battle of Brooklyn and occupied the city for the rest of the Revolutionary War.
In the early 19th century, the military sought to protect the southern flank of New York harbor by building two sister fortifications facing each other at the Narrows: Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn and Fort Wadsworth in Staten Island. Later, the same strategy was applied to Long Island Sound on the east, with the erection of Fort Totten in Queens, and Fort Schuyler in the Bronx.
During the Civil War era, when the city already had large contingents of both Union and Confederate sympathizers, tensions climbed with the Draft Riots of the 1860's, a rash of fires, ethnic rivalries, widespread labor strife and roving, undisciplined militia units.
"There was a lawless potential, and it was truly a militarized situation," Mr. Gilmore said. "It really frightened the upper classes."
In time, New Yorkers grew accustomed to the military.
In the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn near Fort Hamilton, residents knew to remove or protect mirrors and pictures hanging on their walls on the days that the Army conducted its loud and jarring gun tests. In the 1950's and 1960's, residents within earshot of Floyd Bennett Field grew inured to the roar of Navy planes, taking off and landing, taking off and landing.
Indeed, by the early 20th century, air defense had become a vital component of New York's military makeup. During World War I, the Army relied on a small air field in Staten Island called Miller Field. Floyd Bennett Field, meanwhile, was built in 1931 as New York's first municipal airport, and was later sold to the Navy, which used it extensively during World War II.
New York had a sizable role in World War II, particularly as a transit point for supplies and enlisted men. Tens of thousands were deployed out of New York. The Brooklyn Navy Yard, where the U.S.S. Missouri was built, was probably the single largest industrial entity in the country, with 70,000 workers working three shifts, said Arnold Markoe, executive editor of the Scribner Encyclopedia of American Lives.
New York's military focus in the 1950's shifted largely to missile defense, as evidenced by the 20 or so sites throughout the metropolitan region that deployed surface-to-air Nike Ajax and Hercules missiles. But given the atmosphere of the cold war, few, if any, protested their existence so close to the urban core.
"The notion was the Russkies had these things, too, and they were a vital part of the defense of the nation's major cities," Mr. Gilmore said. 
While most of the Nike sites were in suburbs like Livingston, N.J., Orangeburg, N.Y., and Lido Beach, on Long Island, two were within the city: at Fort Tilden, in the Rockaway section of Queens, and at Hart Island, near the Bronx, which is also the home of potter's field.
Hart Island was also linked by underwater communication cable with Fort Slocum on Davids Island, perhaps a mile away in New Rochelle. And together, the 100 or so troops who lived on the islands were responsible for maintaining two underground missiles, said Donald E. Bender, an expert on Nike missiles who runs Cold War Research, a historical consulting company.
"Each missile could have been topped with a warhead as powerful as the atomic bomb dropped on Hiroshima, Japan," Mr. Bender said. "Or even more powerful. The notion of all of that nuclear firepower within the confines of New York City seems hard to believe today."
By the time the Nike program ended in 1974, the military was shrinking because of economics and politics. The Brooklyn Navy Yard closed in 1966. Six years later, Fort Tilden, Fort Wadsworth and Floyd Bennett Field were transferred to the National Park Service as part of the creation of Gateway National Recreation Area.
These days, Fort Hamilton struggles to overcome the perception that the military is now completely absent from the city. When Lt. Col. Rodney W. Gettig, a native of Boalsburg, Pa., was named its commander last year, he had never heard of it.
Since then, however, he has become the base's biggest cheerleader and salesman, securing money to renovate facilities for the 1,400 people from all branches of the military who live on the base.
"We were kind of a backwater, but we're trying to bring it up to where we can say, 'Hey, we're a big player, too,' " Colonel Gettig said.
In all, there are still about a dozen or so military installations in the New York area. Fort Wood, shaped like a star, rests at the base of the Statue of Liberty. Fort Schuyler, near the Throgs Neck Bridge, is now home to the Navy's only remaining reserve center and the State University of New York Maritime College.
The control tower still remains at Floyd Bennett Field but is littered with debris and battered chairs. The apartment building for enlisted Navy seamen stands, too, but barely: it is boarded up, with broken chairs, abandoned toys, holes everywhere.
"Kind of like an Ellis Island feel," said Lincoln Hallowell, a National Park Service ranger.
On the other side of Queens, Fort Totten still looks reasonably preserved. But the last family moved out almost two years ago. 
Rick Stricker, who lived at Fort Totten from 1968-1977 as the son of a Navy officer who helped train reservists, fondly recalled children playing with abandon in the late afternoon, then snapping to attention and saluting the flag when the public address system played "Retreat" at 5 p.m.
Four years ago, Mr. Stricker returned to Fort Totten for the first time in decades, after attending the 20-year reunion of his class at Bayside High School. Outside the officers' houses, the screened porches were in tatters. Inside, the paint from the tin ceilings was peeling.
"It had everything but the tumbleweeds rolling down the streets," said Mr. Stricker, 42, a Navy veteran himself who now runs a computer services company in western Michigan. "It was very depressing. I had to remind myself that I had some of the best memories of my life there."

HEADLINE: City to Offer Free Tickets To Brighten Broadway 

BYLINE:  By DIANE CARDWELL 

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration is buying 50,000 theater tickets to help Broadway shows, which have been hard hit since the World Trade Center attack and face even more difficult times with the typical post-New Year slowdown.
 Shortly after Sept. 11, the industry asked for government aid, according to Jed Bernstein, president of the League of American Theaters and Producers. 
 State help came in the form of $1 million for marketing to increase ticket sales throughout the winter, and city aid materialized recently in the form of the direct purchase of tickets to those shows that are in the most dire financial straits, Mr. Bernstein said. 
The seats, costing the city $50 each, for a total of $2.5 million, normally cost $60 to about $95, Mr. Bernstein said.
The ticket purchases, which were first reported on Friday by Variety, come at a time when officials are working to cut millions from the city's budget, which also suffered as revenue dropped as a result of the attacks.
The ticket purchases are intended to prop up the ailing productions as well as to bolster other spending in the city.
Mr. Bernstein said the purchases are coming in three waves.
In the first, the city bought about 16,500 tickets for December performances of six struggling shows, including "Beauty and the Beast," "Contact," "Hedda Gabler" and "The Phantom of the Opera," which were distributed to World Trade Center rescue workers, victims' families and to workers involved in the recovery effort.
But most of the tickets will be for January and February performances and will be used as part of a promotion called Spend Your Regards to Broadway, meant to stimulating tourism and shopping just after the new year.
"This is really to generate spending," Cristyne L. Nicholas, president of NYC & Company, the city's tourist board, said. "Hopefully we will soon be back to where we don't need something like this."
The program will furnish two free Broadway theater tickets to shoppers who show $500 worth of receipts dated Jan. 1 to Jan. 15 from stores, restaurants and cultural institutions, Ms. Nicholas said. Some purchases will be exempt from the promotion.
Some tickets will also go to radio stations and to retail outlets in Lower Manhattan to run similar shopping promotions, Ms. Nicholas said. 
The promotions could yield from $7.5 million to $12 million in spending in the city, she added.
Although some people have criticized the move, Ms. Nicholas and Mr. Bernstein both defended it on economic grounds, with Ms. Nicholas saying that for retailers, "January was going to be very bleak, so this is a way of generating some spending."
Mr. Bernstein agreed. "Broadway is in trouble, but no more deserving of help than anyone else," he said. "But we've always felt that the city could use Broadway as a lure to bring attention to other things, because it is so visible and it is so glamorous."

HEADLINE: DECEMBER 9-15: ECONOMY; 
WALL STREET'S PAIN

BYLINE:  By Leslie Eaton

 BODY:
 Stockbrokers are crying in their (imported) beer, and New Yorkers of all stripes are sharing their pain. That's because 2001 bonuses will total just $10 billion, far less than last year's record $14.3 billion, according to the New York State comptroller, thanks to recession, sagging stocks and, of course, the events of Sept. 11. The missing $4.3 billion translates into fewer taxi rides, apartment buys, restaurant meals, golf lessons and Chinese food deliveries. Tax revenues and charitable donations will also take big hits. Leslie Eaton

HEADLINE: New Weapon in Discount Warehouse Wars 

BYLINE:  By IRA BRESKIN 

DATELINE: EAST FARMINGALE 

 BODY:
A SANDWICH sign heralding what may be the area's cheapest gasoline lured a steady stream of bargain-hunting drivers the other day to a recently opened gas station at the far end of Daniel Street, a dead-end road off Route 110.
 Customers said they pulled in for the rock-bottom prices. "I come here because the gas is cheap," Alexander Clement, a 60-year-old East Northport resident, said in a typical response. 
 But this nondescript 12-pump outlet is not just another off-brand gasoline retailer. BJ's Gas, the first Long Island gas station associated with a warehouse outlet, marries two routines of suburban life -- buying oodles of groceries and slaking the thirst of the insatiable creature in the driveway. 
To qualify for the advertised price -- $1.119 a gallon for regular and $1.199 a gallon for premium, as of midweek last week -- patrons must present a valid membership card for BJ's Wholesale Club, the station operator. Otherwise, they pay higher but still competitive rates: $1.259 a gallon for regular and $1.359 for premium. The corresponding average for all Long Island stations was $1.251 and $1.367, according to the Automobile Club of New York's daily survey.
Like other grocery warehouses, BJ's is famous for selling in bulk, but the gas station doesn't require you to buy 100 gallons per visit. The idea is to get shoppers into the megastore with a frequency closer to their need to fill up with gas than to their ability to go through a 24-pack of paper towels.
Danielle Ryan, 20, of Bethpage, owns a BJ's card but was filling her S.U.V. at a self-service Amoco station on Route 110 and Millbar Drive, about a half a mile up Route 110 from the BJ's discount outlet -- and paying at least 12 cents a gallon more.
Learning about the recent opening of the nearby BJ's station, Ms. Ryan said she intended to patronize it rather than the Amoco location, which she said she had chosen "because it's close to my job."
Mr. Clement said he pulled into the BJ's station regularly to fill the tank of his S.U.V. before venturing off to the BJ's Warehouse store at 123 Smith Street in East Farmingdale, less than a mile away on the other side of Route 110.
That extra jog will be a thing of the past early next month when BJ's opens a new 108,000-square-foot warehouse store adjacent to the gas station at 50 Daniel Street and closes the 15-year-old Smith Street store.
Operators of warehouse stores have been pushing to add discount gas stations like the one here because they bolster revenue and profit in this thin-margin business. The first such filling stations opened about five years ago. Now, 50 of BJ's 127 stores along the East Coast and in Ohio offer discount gasoline.
Other operators of warehouse stores on Long Island are eager to compete. "We want as many of these as we can get, as fast as we can get them," said Melissa Berryhill, a spokeswoman for Sam's Clubs, the nation's largest chain of warehouse stores. She said Sam's sold gasoline at 130 of its 495 outlets nationwide.
But neither Sam's, a subsidiary of Wal-Mart, nor the No. 2 chain, Costco Wholesale, plans to add a gas outlet to a projected or existing Long Island store. Costco has stores in Lawrence, Melville and Westbury; Sam's sole Long Island store is in Medford. BJ's other Long Island stores are in Westbury, Riverhead, East Setauket and Islandia, with a sixth scheduled to open next month in Freeport.
Competitors may have trouble matching BJ's venture into Long Island gasoline sales because of the limited space available near existing local outlets and arduous zoning restrictions that must be addressed when space exists.
David Blumenfeld, a vice president of Blumenfeld Development Group of Syosset, which developed the BJ's store scheduled to open early next month, said the gas station added three months to what would have been a six-month process of getting permits from the Town of Babylon. The station opened Nov. 2.
The average BJ's filling station sold 4.2 million gallons of gasoline last year, the company said. That's about five times the volume of the average corner station, according to several retailers.
Though BJ's did not release figures on the profitability of its gasoline sideline, Richard Galanti, chief financial officer of Costco, said gas, while not a loss leader, was a low-margin item for warehouse store operators.
The warehouse gasoline outlets cut costs by offering only two grades of fuel, not the three typically offered by competing stand-alone gas stations, and doing no advertising, he said. It's all self-service. There are no mechanics on duty. And at BJ's in East Farmingdale only credit and debit cards are accepted, though the station will take cash once the adjacent store opens.
However, Mr. Galanti said that each $1 of gasoline sales generated an additional 40 cents in incremental annual revenue. That 40 cents includes cash generated from enlisting additional new members, higher retention of existing members (last year 84 percent of BJ's family members chose to renew) and additional purchases by shoppers, some of whom visit more often.
Annual memberships, which are $40 for a family and modestly more for a small-business customer, flow right to the bottom line and account for much of the warehouse store operator's profit, said Howard Davidowitz of Davidowitz & Associates of New York, a retail consulting firm.
"We continue to experience incremental sales and new memberships upon opening a gas station at one of our clubs," BJ's said in a recent filing. "We believe that the availability of a gas station has often motivated existing members to shop more frequently, an important goal of most BJ's merchandising and marketing activities."
Shopping frequency is a big issue because warehouse stores are a destination location, drawing traffic from a much larger radius than the two-mile arc addressed by the typical supermarket, Mr. Davidowitz said.
Operators of giant no-frills warehouse stores also like adjacent bargain gas outlets because they reinforce the value-pricing image they're trying to project.
"There is a higher awareness by consumers of gas prices as opposed to other items," Mr. Davidowitz said. "Gas is a perfect add-on business."
The discount gas offering helps offset the fact that warehouse stores lose appeal over time. BJ's said that following the third year of operations, its stores typically increased annual sales by 9 percent, down from 12 percent gains registered in each of the previous two. And very mature stores, those almost 10 years old, typically boost annual sales by only 4 percent, essentially matching inflation. 
But Charles Bietche, 41, of Bay Shore, who was visiting BJ's pumps for the first time, said cheap gasoline was a modest incentive to visit an adjacent warehouse store. "If I need gas and I'm here filling up near the store, I would probably go in," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 23, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about an East Farmingdale filling station operated by BJ's, a discount warehouse outlet, reversed two prices. On Dec. 12, customers with BJ's membership cards were paying $1.259 a gallon for premium gasoline, and nonmembers were paying $1.199 for regular.

HEADLINE: THE ECONOMY; 
Post-Holiday Blues Come Early

BYLINE:  By SUSAN WARNER 

 BODY:
FROM the malls to Main Streets -- and New Jersey has more than its share -- shoppers usually fling themselves into the holiday routine and figure the bills will come due later. This year, they're coming due earlier.
 The news seemed to crystalize last week when Moody's Investors Services forecast that the New Jersey economy would face a sharp downturn over the next 18 months. In the clearest sign yet of the state's weakening fiscal condition, Moody's decided to change the state's rating outlook from stable to negative -- placing the state on notice that its bond rating could be downgraded in the future. 
 Moreover, the agency said that the state was likely to exhaust its budget reserve fund of $1.2 billion this fiscal year and could face a deficit of $2.4 billion next year. 
Not surprisingly, the bleak forecast intensified the dispute between Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco and Governor-elect Jim McGreevey over the extent of the state's budget shortfall, but that invariably is the background music that plays whenever a new administration is poised to take over.
For commuters, however, the news was not Muzak but more like brakes screeching.
After holding the line for more than 10 years, New Jersey Transit announced last Wednesday that it would seek a 10 percent fare increase -- to take effect April 1 -- to help close its $3.1 billion budget gap. In addition, in each of the following five years, automatic fare increases would be pegged to the inflation rate.
Moving with a swiftness not always evident to its passengers, the agency scheduled six public hearings on Jan. 2, and could approve the increases at a board meeting as early as Jan. 7.
The fare increase is expected to generate an additional $44 million over the first year, though it is only part of a larger six-year plan to close the budget gap. Operating expenses are up 67 percent since the last fare increase in 1990, but after adjusting for inflation, fares have declined 29 percent, the agency said.
Also last week, the Delaware River Joint Toll Bridge Commission, which manages 20 Delaware River bridges, approved its first fare increase since 1988.
The increases -- part of a proposed $526 million 10-year capital improvement plan -- will more than triple revenue, to $106 million from $31.5 million. The highest toll increase will be at the Interstate 78 Bridge, where the toll will rise to $1 from 50 cents. 
The gloom in the public sector comes at a time when consumers are facing their own perils as they grapple with job security, shrinking income from smaller bonuses and stock market gains that have dried up. Of course, all of that has been exacerbated by the attack on the World Trade Center, which hit New Jersey disproportionately harder than the rest of the nation.
This year, the timing of the gaps in the state and transit budgets seem particularly cruel. One question that keeps arising is why the government and transportation agencies did not set money aside or raise fares gradually during the boom times, when consumers were better equipped to bear them.
"Maybe they should plan for the future a little better," said Michele Baccare of Cherry Hill. "When things were that good, there's only one way to go. You knew this was going to happen."
The state's budget problems are related to the sharp, unexpected increase in revenue due to capital gains and other taxes associated with the stock market boom of the late 1990's. But that revenue dried up with the collapse of stock prices and the recession.
To be sure, other states are experiencing similar revenue shortfalls, but they are exaggerated in New Jersey, several economists say, because of the state's progressive income tax, high level of income and exposure to the stock markets.
"In the last few years, state governments received huge windfalls," said Jim Diffley, a regional economist with DRI-WEFA, an econometric firm in Eddystone, Pa. "They knew this income stream could not be counted on to last forever. What they didn't know, and could not have known, was that it would happen all at once. They didn't know the pattern, and by the way, they still don't."
As for the budget gap, economists are forecasting a mild recession for New Jersey that could ease the crisis by 2003.
Gus Faucher, who tracks the state economy at Economy.com, an econometrics firm in Chester, Pa., said his firm predicted that the New Jersey economy, like that of the rest of the nation, would emerge from the current recession in late spring.
Oddly, Mr. Faucher noted, New Jersey benefited somewhat from the Sept. 11 disaster in that the state gained about 15,000 jobs in September and October, most of them finance jobs coming from New York City following the attacks.
As for the transportation finance problems, he said they were more reflective of long-term difficulties rather than the current recession.
James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers, said the gap in transit financing stemmed in part from the failure to add capacity in the 1990's while the state added 585,000 jobs.
"We systematically underinvested in transportation," Mr. Hughes said. "Unfortunately, that's part of the political reality."
He pointed out that three years ago, a plan by Gov. Christie Whitman to raise the gasoline tax to finance mass transit and highway improvements failed in the Legislature. During that time New Jersey Transit used federal funds earmarked for capital improvement to close operating deficits, which Mr. Hughes termed unwise but allowable.
"It's been a real struggle to meet the capital needs that we have," he said. "Then the events of Sept. 11 have added enormous pressure. The absence of PATH has made the whole situation much more visible."
But Joel Naroff, chief economist at Commerce Bank, said the reality was that transit boards were reluctant to raise fares -- in good times or bad --because of the danger of losing riders.
"Nobody wants to raise prices when demand is weak," said Mr. Naroff. "But there always reaches a point where you simply have to do it."
Shifting his attention from the transit difficulties to the state's budget, Mr. Hughes said the problems awaiting Mr. McGreevey resembled the situation in which Jim Florio found himself when he was elected governor a decade ago. Faced with budget problems, Mr. Florio raised taxes, and effectively ended his political career.
"That was a signature event that sill reverberates in the State House," Mr. Hughes said.
In this instance, he said, the timing might spare Mr. McGreevey a period of finger-pointing. "Clearly he's coming into office at a time when everybody knows we're in a recession, and Sept. 11 is absorbing a lot of the blame," said Mr. Hughes. "There's less likely to be as many accusations about who caused the downturn."
As for the disturbing economic news, Mr. Naroff said more could be on the way. If the state makes deep cuts to balance its budget, more expenditures will fall to municipal governments, which finance operations with property taxes, perhaps leading to a wave of property tax increases.
"It's not happening yet," Mr. Naroff said, "but there is a trickling down. Any economic slowdown hits at every level of government."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
TV's, DVD's: All Yours, But First Do the Math

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
DOES John Madden have a deal for you!
 He can sell you a five-disc DVD player. Or he can sell you a portable stereo. He can even sell you a 27-inch television on which you can watch him, the country's most famous football commentator, announce this year's Super Bowl. 
 And don't think you're going to pay any old price, either. That DVD player regularly sells for $250, but Mr. Madden can get it to you for only $1,000. The stereo? It costs about $350 at the Wiz but $1,500 from Mr. Madden. The TV may be the best deal. It is only $2,000, compared with $450 normally.
All of these so-called deals are available at Rent-a-Center, a company that uses Mr. Madden as its public face and that is easily the nation's largest retailer in a category known as rent to own. Rent-a-Center, based in Plano, Tex., operates 2,400 stores mainly in poorer areas, often selling to people who do not have credit cards. In exchange for regular payments -- $24 a week over almost two years for the TV, coming to $2,000 in all -- customers can buy electronics, appliances and furniture. If they stop making payments, they must return the products. 
Rent-a-Center is one kind of business that flourishes in a recession, as people are laid off or lose overtime hours and become unable to plunk down $450 all at once. Mitchell E. Fadel, the company's president, said recently on CNNfn that a downturn "actually helps us from a revenue standpoint."
The same cannot be said, however, about the effect that the rent-to-own industry has on the American economy. In fact, at a time when even President Bush has urged people to spend more of their money, Rent-a-Center offers an important reminder that some kinds of consumer spending can do more long-term harm than short-term good. 
Paying $2,000 for a $450 product is never a good idea. It is a particularly dangerous one when debt levels are high and layoffs are rising.
As Mr. Madden tells it, however, rent to own is a great deal. "Hey, Rent-a-Center has a holiday gift for you," he says, playing off his folksy blue-collar image, in a recent TV commercial trumpeting a discount. "But you got to be lively and quick."
Rent-a-Center executives credit Mr. Madden, their spokesman since last year, for raising Rent-a-Center's profile and lifting sales. This summer, Fortune magazine named the company one the fastest-growing in the country.
Why are there so many customers? Some people, lacking the income and credit history to get credit cards, feel they have no option. They need a dishwasher, and they know a store that will sell them one.
But rent-to-own companies have also succeeded in masking the true cost of their products. New York City requires electronics stores to list the standard retail price of a product, but at a Rent-A-Center in Brooklyn last week, that part of the price tag was blank. Christopher A. Korst, the company's general counsel, said it was talking to city officials about how to comply with the law.
The industry has also persuaded most states to treat its contracts more like rental agreements than loans -- even though customers eventually buy 70 percent of all products they rent, according to a survey of 12,000 households by the Federal Trade Commission. (Mr. Korst said the portion is much lower.) Thanks to those state laws, Rent-a-Center does not need to list the underlying interest rate -- which can exceed 200 percent, making even credit card rates look good. 
"They don't want it to be a free market in which consumers are making knowing decisions," said Attorney General James E. Doyle of Wisconsin, who has sued the industry to reveal more information. "Let's have a competitive marketplace."
Such tactics have helped consumers win tens of millions of dollars from the company, in court settlements and verdicts, over the last decade.
Rent-a-Center executives say the company's size is its best defense. People obviously like the store enough to continue patronizing it, and they can return the products at any time without penalty. 
Mr. Madden has a similar view, his agent, Sandy Montag, said. "Rent-a-Center provides a good service," Mr. Montag said. "They are a successful public company, and we have heard a lot of positive feedback from many happy customers."
But consider this: if a family saves $20 a week for two years, it could buy a large TV after five months, a stereo after four more months, a five-disc DVD player after three more months and still have almost $1,000 left. At Rent-a-Center, it would get the TV immediately but nothing else.
Which is better for shoppers and for the economy? Faced with such a question during one of his football broadcasts, the famously straight-talking Mr. Madden would doubtless have a pithy answer.
