HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED -- AN OVERVIEW: DEC. 15, 2001; 
Al Qaeda's Last Legs, Preparing for Peace, Holiday Shadows

BYLINE:  By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
The war in Afghanistan moved inexorably toward a climax. American warplanes bombed the ridge positions and cave and tunnel hideouts of Al Qaeda's remnant forces in the eastern mountains around Tora Bora, and on the ground the Afghan militia was closing in on what may be Osama bin Laden's last redoubt.
 RESISTANCE CRUMBLING -- Afghan commanders said that ridge-to-ridge and cave-to-cave searches had led to the capture of 50 Al Qaeda fighters and that bodies of 33 others had been found. That left 300 to 1,000 enemy fighters in the mountains, ravines and man-made tunnels. With limited supplies of food and ammunition, they had only two options -- give up or fight to the death. 
 There was still no clear sign that Osama bin Laden was in the area, but if so his options were also limited: run or be killed or caught. There was a plan in place if he was captured alive, but American officials refused to say what it was. As for Al Qaeda prisoners, some might be taken to Kandahar airport, where American marines were building a detention camp for 300.
ON THE MOVE -- Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld was on a tour of Central Asia, with stops in the former Soviet republics of Azerbaijan, Armenia and Georgia to offer military assistance in return for using their airspace in the war. He said American and Afghan forces had made advances in Tora Bora, and had begun the dangerous business of clearing caves and tunnels.
The videotape of Mr. bin Laden gloating over, and admitting responsibility for, the killing of more than 3,000 people on Sept. 11 was still making news. A senior Saudi official said that the mysterious dinner guest pictured with Mr. bin Laden was Khaled al-Harbi, a legless, 38-year-old Saudi and a veteran of conflicts in Afghanistan, Bosnia and Chechnya.
WINNING THE PEACE -- With the end of the war approaching, some extraordinary events are coming up. In Kabul, Hamid Karzai is to become prime minister, the first person to take power in Afghanistan peacefully in 30 years. That will be the easy part. The hard part will be getting a bewildering coalition of tribes, warlords, political parties and nations to work together to rebuild the nation. That task will be compounded by the worst drought in 50 to 100 years. For three years it has stricken a country where farming is 80 percent of the economy: blowing away seeds and soil, drying up wells and rivers, killing vegetation and livestock. Unless winter brings rain, experts foresee tragedy in efforts to feed millions and restore stability.
WAR STORIES -- There are countless tales in wartime Afghanistan. Take, for example, the five men imprisoned by the Taliban in Kandahar for "political" offenses. Actually, there were 1,800, but most were freed when the city was liberated. The five -- Arabs, Russians, Chechens perhaps -- are in limbo. They, too, were released, but are still being held because officials say they could be mistaken for foreigners who aided the Taliban or Al Qaeda, and killed.
After 20 years of war, guns are more common than books, and it is easy to forget that Afghanistan has a rich cultural tradition. At the Herat Literary Association most days, artists and writers meet to read and talk about Persian and Afghan poets, the great writers who were shaped by the literary riches of poverty, drought, political and religious oppression and ethnic hatreds.
HOLIDAYS AND GUNS -- Christmas is little more than a week away, and America seems to crave the warmth of the holiday hearth. But the effects of Sept. 11 go on relentlessly, especially in the homes of the thousands of families who lost loved ones, or jobs, in the terrorist attacks. Parents say the rituals of the season -- the cards, the tree, the decorations and presents -- are just too much this year, but they are going ahead for the sake of the children. It doesn't take an expert to note that the holidays, with their obligatory good cheer, can magnify grief. One trade center widow killed herself last week, and for others there is holiday sorrow and depression.
Another Sept. 11 legacy is fear. Worried about safety, many Americans are arming themselves. Federal statistics and other evidence suggest that sales of guns and ammunition have risen sharply, between 9 and 22 percent in the last three months. Officials say the proliferation of guns is troubling because many wind up in the hands of people who lack training. Weapons classes are also growing, but guns are rarely used against criminals, let alone terrorists.
 ROBERT D. McFADDEN

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: CLIMATE; 
Afghan Drought Inflicts Its Own Misery

BYLINE:  By ANDREW C. REVKIN

 BODY:
The monumental task of rebuilding Afghanistan after the war has been made far more difficult, experts say, by a problem that would have existed even without the Taliban and Osama bin Laden: the drought that has gripped the country and much of southwestern Asia for three years.
 There is a chance that the drought -- the worst in much of the region for 50 to 100 years -- may end this winter, experts on global climate and agriculture said in interviews over the last week. But they warned that damage to fields, grazing land and water supplies would linger for years, hampering efforts to feed millions of famished refugees and restore Afghanistan's shattered economy. 
 The damage has not been confined to Afghanistan. Throughout much of southwestern Asia, soil and seeds have blown away, vegetation has baked brown, livestock have been slaughtered and wells and rivers have run dry. Parts of northwestern Iran have had no measurable rainfall in 30 months, and more than 200,000 nomadic herders there have lost their source of income as flocks of sheep and goats have been slaughtered or died. Cities and villages have instituted water rationing. 
The wide reach of the drought means that Afghan refugees heading west to Iran or east to the dry side of Pakistan have found little comfort. At one camp along the Pakistan border, well drillers had to bore a mile deep before reaching the greatly sunken water table, relief workers reported.
When the war ends, political tensions are bound to rise as Afghanistan rebuilds its northern provinces and begins drawing more water out of the Amu Darya, which forms part of its borders with three former Soviet republics -- Tajikistan, Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan. The river is already taxed to the limit, with every drop of its annual flow of 19 cubic miles of water -- nearly four times the flow of the Colorado -- siphoned by irrigation and for water supplies before reaching the shriveled Aral Sea.
"In this region, water is more important than money," said Dr. Michael H. Glantz, a senior scientist at the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colo., who has studied the Amu Darya. 
But the continuing lack of water and food will pose particularly daunting challenges in Afghanistan itself, where farming is the basis for more than 80 percent of the economy. Even after a generation of warfare and violence, the drought remains "the single most important factor influencing the Afghan economy," Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general, said in a report to the General Assembly this month.
The latest assessments remain bleak, even with the chance that a change in global weather patterns -- which many scientists say is long overdue -- could bring rain and snow to Afghanistan this winter. 
During the wheat-planting season, which started in October and ended two weeks ago, rainfall across the northern provinces, where most wheat is grown, was extremely scant, according to a report released last week by the Foreign Agricultural Service of the Department of Agriculture.
For the wheat-growing regions, the report said, cumulative precipitation from Oct. 1 to Dec. 12 was only 29 percent of the average for the period. Without rain during planting, seed rarely sprouts in the spring. The lack of rainfall in October and November came as a blow to farmers because September -- just before the planting season -- was tantalizingly wet.
Even the temperature has conspired against the Afghan farmers. Runoff from melting snows and spring rains supplies most of the region's rivers and irrigation systems, but a string of unusually warm winters melted mountain snows, causing "ill-timed runoff" too early to be of any help, the report said. This month, the mountain weather is warmer than usual once again.
The farmers' problems have been compounded by extensive damage to irrigation canals and pipelines from the continuing warfare.
If the drought persists, agriculture experts say, a further consequence could be more planting of opium poppies, which tolerate dry conditions far better than wheat.
By the middle of January, the United Nations, the World Bank and other international institutions hope to create a plan for rebuilding the country. But experts say the drought will prove a lasting hindrance.
"The deficit in groundwater is so severe that even with a normal or above-normal winter, you'd have to expect a two to three year recovery period," said Dr. Matthew A. Barlow, an author of an analysis of the drought by the International Research Institute for Climate Prediction at Columbia University. "In some instances," he added, "that would be a little on the optimistic side."
The report (available online at http://iri.columbia.edu) says the drought may be linked to unusual conditions thousands of miles away: raised temperatures in the western Pacific and frequent rainstorms over the Indian Ocean. Indirectly, the scientists say, these changes appear to be preventing winter storms from sweeping east out of the Mediterranean.
A preliminary analysis by the Columbia scientists suggests that the last severe drought in the region, from 1970 to 1972, occurred when similar ocean conditions developed. That dry spell, State Department experts say, helped topple a previous Afghan government, that of the former king, Mohammad Zahir Shah, in 1973.
The ocean condition is a rare variation on La Nina, part of a regular cycle of Pacific warming and cooling episodes that can influence weather patterns around the world. In a typical La Nina year, unusually cool water covers the eastern Pacific along the Equator, contrasting with warm water to the west. For the last several years, the Pacific has been locked in La Nina conditions, but the western waters have been particularly warm. 
Many scientists say the Pacific is overdue for a shift back to the opposite pattern, called El Nino, in which warm water spreads east toward South America. But that has not happened yet, and La Nina could hang on for another winter. 
If that happens and the Columbia scientists are right, Afghanistan's plight could go on even longer. Still, they say more research will be required to confirm the relationship between La Nina and the drought. 
Looking ahead, climate experts said an important part of any rebuilding of Afghanistan would be prompt re-establishment of basic, regular measurements of precipitation and other weather conditions. No local weather data have been collected for several years, and without a long-term record it is difficult to spot trends that might indicate a return of drought conditions, said Dr. Barlow at Columbia.
Eventually, Dr. Barlow said, researchers hope to be able to use close monitoring of telltale shifts in global patterns to predict future severe droughts in the region and help governments and relief agencies gird for battle.
The same feature of the drought that made it so destructive -- its vast size -- also raises scientists' hopes that the forces that conspired to create it can be discerned.
"The good thing about its size is that it's probably more than just a chance occurrence," Dr. Barlow said. "The larger scale something is, the more likely it is that we can understand and then predict it."

SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Pg. 60

LENGTH: 7704 words

HEADLINE: Show Us the Money 

BYLINE:  By Frank Bruni; Frank Bruni is a staff writer for the magazine based in Washington.

 BODY:
It must gall her a little -- to come begging at the door of a colleague who once articulated the possibility, or maybe really the wish, that lightning would strike her before she took her seat in the United States Senate, sparing Republicans her dread company. But right now, Hillary Clinton needs Trent Lott. She needs him and any other senator who can be made to rain dollars upon New York, which is thirsty for them like almost never before. So she walks with a hopeful, beseeching smile into Lott's private conference room and takes a seat next to his, although not too close.
 Chuck Schumer, on Lott's other side, presses in tighter. He doesn't carry the kind of baggage she does, and it has always been his way to be more aggressive than his peers, turning his insistence into an edge. The mere fact of Clinton's presence seems to sharpen this instinct, in ways good and bad. When Schumer addresses Lott, he presses in tighter still. 
 "Our situation in New York is this," he says, cutting to the chase. "We're all trying to put on a nice face, but it gets worse every day." This is his first card: the city's stoicism and bravery, which can elicit only sympathy. Then Schumer plays his second: the fact that New York did not merely happen to find itself in the path of destruction but was put there because of what the city means to America. "You know," he tells Lott, "the attack on New York was an attempt to destroy our financial capital, to destroy our country." His third and final card is the simplest of all: desperation. "If we don't do something now," Schumer warns, "we are in trouble."
There is not that much left for Clinton to say, other than to stress that New York's downfall would not be isolated and that its economic pain is every American's. "The ripple effects," she says, "are really going out throughout the entire country." Her voice is steady but also a little weary. She has sung this refrain so many times already.
You would think that none of this would be necessary. That the images alone -- planes slicing through two of the world's tallest skyscrapers, terrified people scrambling for their lives -- would open federal coffers as wide as New York could want them to be. That the statistics -- millions of square feet of office space crumbled, more casualties than Pearl Harbor -- would seal the deal.
But by this morning in early November when the two Democratic senators from New York visit the leader of the Senate's Republican minority, they have learned that memories fade, that new priorities emerge and that New York, even now, is not an easy magnet for national sympathy. President Bush's initial promise of $20 billion in aid has turned slippery, which is why, in a conversation an hour before their meeting with Lott, Senator Max Baucus, a Montana Democrat, told Schumer and Clinton: "I would urge you to kind of think how you could make America even prouder of New York and buy into New York as a national asset. A lot of Americans, deep down, have a certain. . . . "
"We know, we know," Schumer said, halting Baucus's sentence before its inevitable and dispiriting conclusion.
In Lott's office, Schumer and Clinton are getting fresh reminders. About a dozen business, labor and political leaders have come down from New York to show support for the senators' case and offer their own testimonials to the city's pain. Lott's response suggests a skepticism at odds with his genial grin. He trots out a metaphor, saying that a city's attempt to rebound from catastrophe is like a "jet going off a carrier." The pilot, he explains, thinks that the plane will plummet into the water but then, remarkably, feels it rise. The moral seems to be that premonitions of ruin always overestimate the danger.
A member of the city's delegation refers to New Yorkers in neighborhoods like Battery Park City who were forced to flee their apartments, and Lott's interjection demonstrates just how little he -- and many other federal lawmakers -- understand New York. "When I went there with Hillary and Chuck," he says, referring to a trip to ground zero that a group of senators made, "they talked about getting people back in their homes. And I looked around and said, 'What homes?' Because when you say 'home,' I think of a free-standing building." What Schumer and Clinton were drawing his attention to, he recalls, were high-rises. "I never thought of them as homes," he concedes. "But they are."
This is what Schumer and Clinton are up against, and it confronts them more squarely than it does any other politician involved in the fight for New York. When it comes to federal aid, their stations in Washington give them votes and a kind of internal influence that Governor Pataki, Mayor Giuliani and Mayor-elect Bloomberg don't have. Additionally, the Senate, under Democratic control, is a more likely engine of munificence than either the Republican-controlled House or the Bush administration. Until Sept. 11, Clinton says, their days were "a multitasking kaleidoscope of issues and places and people." Now there is this one enormous battle, which trumps all the others. So they game out their talking points and legislative strategies and carom around Capitol Hill, pleading and persuading. And they do it side by side, or at least they try to, which is one of the trickiest parts of all. 
They are alike in their willfulness and ambition, but there are other, crucial differences. Over a quarter-century, he ground his way from the State Assembly to the House of Representatives and then to the Senate, only to look up, in his third year, and see a new partner with no prior experience in elective office but a hold on the public's attention that he cannot match. She spent much of her marriage and many of her eight years as first lady smiling and nodding as the man in front of her sucked most of the oxygen out of the air, only to find herself in another kind of union where her best bet for getting along is to smile, nod and take very deep breaths.
It makes for an interesting match and awkward moments, like a news conference on the last day of October, when Schumer and Clinton introduce legislation to foster cooperation between the F.B.I. and local law-enforcement agencies. Schumer speaks first, his privilege as the senior senator. Clinton speaks next. Then both step to the side of the lectern so that other senators can speak, and as the television cameras roll and nearly a dozen reporters watch, Schumer leans over and picks at a stray thread or speck of lint on the jacket of Clinton's red Oscar de la Renta pantsuit, pointing out an imperfection in her armor that no one else noticed. She tucks the errant material into a pocket and silently thanks him, but she seems to be smiling with only her teeth.
bout a week after the discussion with Lott, I join Schumer and Clinton for dinner at a French restaurant on Capitol Hill. They have already talked to each other several times earlier in the day, so she knows that he is trying to fight back an incipient cold and tells him she is concerned about it. "Let's get you some onion soup," she says, and with that she leads the way up a flight of stairs to a private room in the back. This is her place, with pastel walls and pastoral watercolors; his is a brightly lit, sparsely decorated Chinese joint just a few blocks away.
I ask them when and how they met.
"I remember the first time that I really knew who Chuck was, and that was in '94, during the gun debate about the Brady bill and the assault-gun ban," Clinton says. She recalls meetings in the White House during which her husband, Schumer and Democratic Congressional leaders wondered if they could hold fast for gun control against pressure from the National Rifle Association and the qualms of Democrats from rural states.
Schumer chimes in, noting that a few of the leaders wanted to cave. "The president didn't know what to do," he says. "And I said, 'Mr. President, if we back off, we'll become a laughingstock in America.' And she" -- he glances toward Clinton -- was always backing us up. Always helping. Always. And the president didn't back off. And it worked."
"And we lost the Congress," she adds with a rueful laugh -- a defeat that many political analysts agree was largely due to gun control.
They are in many ways natural political allies. They believe in an activist government. They get whipped up by causes. They do not like to surrender. For these reasons and others, they have long respected each other, and each has aided the other's career. In 1998, when Schumer challenged Al D'Amato in one of the most intense, expensive Senate races in history, Clinton came to New York repeatedly to stump for Schumer. This was during the whole Monica mess, as humiliation drove her popularity to a peculiar peak. The crowds adored her.
"The last few weeks," Schumer remembers, "I would call her every few days and say, 'You've got to come in, you've got to come in."' She did, four times in all. It was partly her success during those appearances that kindled the idea among Democrats that she should run for New York's other Senate seat, the one that Daniel Patrick Moynihan was poised to vacate in 2000.
During her campaign, Schumer stood with her at a few crucial times. As she was trying to mend fences with Jews in New York, he accompanied her to a Salute to Israel parade, where some members of the crowd lining Fifth Avenue shouted "Go back to Arkansas!" when she passed. "He was wondering when it would be over," said Senator Dick Durbin, an Illinois Democrat who lives during the workweek in the same fraternity-style Washington town house as Schumer and two other lawmakers. "At the end, she turned to him and said, 'That wasn't so bad.' I mean, this is a woman who has been tested."
Schumer knew all along that having her as a partner in the Senate would be tough for him, and so did his friends. At his 50th birthday party a year ago, the running theme in the jokes told by the people who roasted him was that Schumer, an inveterate presshound who is easily best in breed, would be driven crazy by the ever-present scrum of reporters around her. "This was a collision waiting to happen," Durbin says, hastening to add that in his view, Schumer and Clinton have worked admirably to avoid any carnage.
It is an axiom that lawmakers from the same state and same party have worse relationships than lawmakers from the same state and different parties, because they delve into the same issues and depend on the same supporters. Lawmakers who are at similar points in their careers and trade on similar strengths have worse relationships still. Schumer, now 51, a Harvard-educated lawyer who ranks 80th in Senate seniority, prides himself on his drive, intelligence and detailed mastery of policy. Clinton, 54, a Yale-educated lawyer who ranks 97th, prides herself on precisely the same attributes. "These are two thoroughbreds, not plow horses, and putting them in the same harness is probably a feat worthy of great trainers," says John Podesta, a White House chief of staff during the Clinton administration.
But Clinton's posture of resolute humility as she went about her Senate business helped to smooth over potential rough spots. Determined to prove that she was not on some giddy star trip, she mostly kept her head down and got to work, almost never missing votes or committee meetings, no matter how tedious. Even Senator Peter Fitzgerald, an Illinois Republican whom Clinton attacked when she campaigned for his opponent, Carol Moseley-Braun, now professes respect for her. "She's not just a Democratic figurehead," Fitzgerald says. "She's an everyday working senator." For the first eight months of her tenure, Clinton consistently turned down invitations to prattle away on the Sunday morning talk shows. She said no to CNN, no to Tim Russert.
Then came Sept. 11, and she started staying yes. It was not only appropriate now; it was mandatory, because getting help for New York meant broadcasting the city's horror to the rest of the country. Schumer was invited on many programs, too, but Clinton was probably more conspicuous. She had been all bottled up, contained by her new and carefully constructed identity as New York's hardworking junior senator, not a national spokeswoman. Now there was no difference between the two. The events of Sept. 11 uncorked her.
A day in mid-October when I went to Capitol Hill to see both of them yielded a telling contrast. Exiled from his suite of offices in the anthrax-shuttered Hart building, Schumer met with a half-dozen aides in his town house's dimly lighted living room, where two beds -- his and that of Representative William Delahunt, a Massachusetts Democrat -- are wedged in among a motley collection of couches. (Durbin and Representative George Miller, a California Democrat, sleep in the two rooms upstairs.) From this unglamorous warren, he telephoned lawmakers and federal officials.
Clinton, meanwhile, stood outside the Capitol, in brilliant sunshine, doing an interview with Ted Koppel for ABC's "Nightline." A crowd of reporters, including a crew from the BBC, watched and waited, then descended on her, after which several tourists corralled her for a picture.
In private, Clinton had in fact been trading on her political celebrity for some time. Shortly after she moved in February into her $2.85 million house in Washington, made affordable by her $8 million book advance, she began using it for fund-raising events for Democrats, establishing herself as perhaps the party's second most potent draw for donors -- her husband being its first. She played host at a benefit that helped Maria Cantwell, a Democrat just elected to the Senate from Washington State, erase about $150,000 of her campaign debt. She raised hundreds of thousands of dollars for the Democratic National Committee and the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee. For her political action committee, Hillpac, which she started in January, she has amassed a sum estimated to exceed $1.1 million.
Schumer, who had never been much of a national party fund-raiser, was not about to compete with her on that score, and nothing she was doing threatened his own fund-raising for himself. He already has an estimated $8 million for his reelection campaign in 2004 -- nearly half what he spent in 1998. Besides, in Democratic circles in New York, he has as much clout as Clinton does. Neither has sought the kind of control over the party that D'Amato wielded over state Republicans; both prefer not to take sides in Democratic primaries and stayed out of the recent mayor's race until Mark Green won the runoff against Fernando Ferrer. Some Democrats say that Schumer and Clinton may have a more difficult time maintaining distance from the governor's race, because minority resentment over Ferrer's fate may put pressure on them to help Carl McCall, who is black, in his campaign against Andrew Cuomo. Schumer doesn't like Cuomo much, according to political insiders, who also say that despite the fact that Cuomo served in her husband's cabinet, Clinton has no special attachment to him, either. Still, the senators are likely to resist making a public show of support for McCall. "We will cross that bridge when we come to it," Schumer says.
Schumer cannot do as much financially to boost state Democrats as Clinton, but he remains a less polarizing figure. This was reflected in a state poll in early October, when his job approval rating climbed to 69 percent, 10 points above hers. A higher percentage of New York voters had a favorable impression of him than of her, while a higher percentage had an unfavorable impression of her than of him. Their political bases are different. Hers is narrower, but deep: she taps especially fervent support among women, minorities and party activists. He works a broader, more centrist spectrum.
Before Sept. 11, there was plenty of space between them. She used her positions on the Senate committees on labor, health and education and on the environment as platforms to push for more public school teachers and to expose hidden health hazards. He used his chairmanship of the Senate subcommittee on the courts to call publicly for a new approach to judicial confirmations, one that openly took ideology into account rather than shrouding that concern in investigations into nominees' private lives.
But after Sept. 11, their turf abruptly converged. Both stood to be judged on one thing: how much federal help they got for New York City's recovery -- how much bacon they could bring home. They had a shared investment in the same endeavor, which made each more vulnerable to the other's effectiveness and gave each an interest in the same patch of foreground. This was the context for what happened early on Sept. 13, a rare semipublic glimpse of naked friction between the two. On the Senate floor, she announced that they would be asking for $20billion for New York. Schumer had not yet committed to a strategy of making such a figure public, according to several Democrats privy to the incident, and blew up at her in a room just off the Senate floor, yelling loudly enough so that people outside could hear. Some Democrats believe he felt usurped and upstaged.
Schumer, talking in general about events since the terrorist attacks, says that he has never nursed such a sustained, intense worry about every step being just right, nor has he experienced such a profound sense of obligation, a word that Clinton also uses. Both describe a feeling of pushing a very big rock up a very steep hill, with the summit nowhere in sight. "It will be the primary obligation for my term," Clinton says, meaning the next five years. Construction costs and lost corporate revenue, dollars and cents -- these are what now obsess them, to the point where they sometimes sound as much like accountants as politicians.
oney became their fixation just 36 hours after the terrorists struck. They were in Manhattan on the night of Wednesday, Sept. 12, when their aides telephoned them with disturbing news. The evolving $20 billion emergency package of federal aid -- for defense, intelligence operations and the areas hit hardest by the attacks -- did not have any guaranteed appropriation for New York. Polly Trottenberg, Schumer's legislative director, put it to him bluntly: this was a big problem.
Schumer, Clinton and their staffs began doing careful reconnaissance, working the phones to gauge how generous House and Senate leaders were inclined to be. They were led to believe that $20 billion might be more of a floor than a ceiling and that New York could get a significant allotment. Huddling in a van that Clinton uses to toodle around New York, Schumer and Clinton tried to reach Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the majority leader.
"I dial Daschle, and we each -- we get him, because he's at home," Schumer says. "Fortunately, he picks up. I'm saying a sentence -- I'm handing the phone to Hillary, she's saying a sentence." Daschle signaled a willingness to fight for whatever the senators deemed necessary, which turned out to be a separate $20 billion for New York alone. Back in Washington the next day, Clinton placed an early-morning call to Senator Robert Byrd of West Virginia, the chairman of the Appropriations Committee, whom she had presciently and profitably turned into a mentor. He, too, pledged to help.
They could now go to the Bush administration with some powerful backing. They had a meeting scheduled with the president on Thursday afternoon and were not sure at first that they should hit him up for an exact amount -- it defied the usual etiquette for such an encounter. But these were not usual times, and when they learned that Bush would be visiting downtown Manhattan on Friday, they figured that he would prefer to go there with headlines trumpeting his generosity, not his stinginess. So they decided to ask him not simply for help, but for $20 billion of it.
Neither senator had a close relationship with Bush, but Schumer had a less loaded history with him, and he took the lead. Although Daschle's aides had told Bush's advisers what the senators would be requesting, a senior administration official who was in the Oval Office that day says he does not think the information had reached Bush, and Bush was hearing the $20 billion figure for the first time. Schumer recalls: "You could almost see in his mind he was saying, 'This is a lot of money.' But this is why I have a little faith in him, and maybe this is imagining or wishful thinking, but I don't think so. I could see he was calculating in his head: 'I have to bring America together. I know New York was not for me, the blue state and all that, but I'm going to do this."' Bush said yes.
The administration official remembers that when he heard Bush's answer, "My mouth dropped open." So, apparently, did that of Mitch Daniels, head of the White House Office of Management and Budget, when he found out. Within a few hours of the senators' departure from the Oval Office, the O.M.B. was instructing the leaders of the Republican-controlled House to appropriate much less than $20 billion for New York. That word quickly reached Schumer and Clinton, who again hit the phones.
With Clinton next to him in the Senate cloakroom, Schumer called the White House chief of staff and offered a preview of how they were prepared to brandish the president's promise. "I said to Andrew Card, 'Hillary and I don't want to have to say, on the eve of his going to New York, that the president backed off,"' Schumer recalls.
This was all happening as various Republican and Democratic leaders lurched through a six-hour meeting on Thursday night in House Speaker Dennis Hastert's office to decide what level of emergency spending would be put to a vote in the House. Daschle made the case for New York to get its own $20 billion, separate from the rest of the appropriation, while Senators Don Nickles of Oklahoma and Phil Gramm of Texas, both Republicans, lobbied against it. Hastert, it seemed, was taking his cues from the White House, and at some point after Schumer's conversation with Card, Hastert threw his support behind a $40 billion appropriation, with half to go to the three states in which the hijacked planes had crashed -- New York, Virginia and Pennsylvania -- and the majority of that $20 billion to go to New York.
Schumer and Clinton had been discouraged from participating in the meeting; when they approached the door around 10 p.m., Daschle waved them away, letting them know he was handling the negotiations. He left the room after midnight to call them with the good news. To his shock, he found them slumped in chairs just outside Hastert's office. They had spent much of the intervening two hours hovering near the door and pacing the floor.
But what the House and Senate quickly passed was a general appropriation, not a line-by-line allocation of how the $40 billion would be spent. Several weeks later, when the O.M.B. released its recommendations for divvying the money up, there was only about $8.5 billion to be spent on New York City this year.
The anthrax scare then took hold, and federal lawmakers began worrying about bioterrorism. The air strikes over Afghanistan began, diverting attention from Manhattan to Kabul. New York had competition for the nation's sympathies -- and those sympathies, of course, have always been a little tenuous. In 1995, when Newt Gingrich was the House speaker, he railed against the city's "culture of waste" and claimed -- mistakenly -- that the city absorbed more federal funds than it contributed in taxes. That myth apparently persists. A Democratic aide called me one day with concerns about how I might quote his boss, who represents a rural state. The aide did not want the legislator sounding too reflexively supportive of financial aid for New York, because it might not play so well with suspicious constituents back home.
As time passed, Schumer and Clinton began to encounter a distressing trend -- lawmakers framing the city's plight in terms of areas in their own state hit by natural disasters. Clinton and Schumer reiterated everything that made the World Trade Center attacks different, but some senators seemed to resist the distinctions. Clinton told Lott: "You and I have been to a lot of disasters together. This is beyond anything I've ever imagined." Lott, in response, mused on all the bad weather his state of Mississippi had absorbed.
"We've had everything but locusts," he laughed, "and I expect the locusts will come."
In the middle of all of this, I accompany Clinton one Friday afternoon to New York City. She looks exhausted, and as we walk through La Guardia Airport, she asks if it would be all right to stop for coffee. She is desperate for caffeine. "If they had a place where you could lie down and take it intravenously," she says, "I would." The clerk behind the counter, who cannot stop stealing glances at his famous customer, works on her cappuccino for an awfully long time. "This is the most thorough milk foamer in the world," Clinton whispers.
Then it happens, a brief interchange that hints at her personal stake in her struggles in the capital, at what she has yet to accomplish. A young man spots her, asks the officers in her ever-present Secret Service detail if he can approach her, then walks up to her with a dazzled expression. "I just want to say that your husband is a great man," he tells her. "If he could run for a third term, I'd vote for him again."
"Thank you," she says, "I'll be sure to tell him that." The young man leaves without a compliment or nod of support for her, even though her image has saturated the television airwaves for weeks. Her smile never falters. "Happens all the time," she tells me, and off we go, her gait as brisk and purposeful as ever, to her van, which is waiting at the curb.
Clinton is waging several fights at the same time, one of which is to emerge once and for all from her husband's long shadow. She is trying to move beyond the ethical questions that have long dogged her, and also to prove that for all the talk about carpetbagging and using New York as a steppingstone to national power, she can and will come through for the people of her new home state. The need for the latter was demonstrated by the loud boos from police officers and firefighters when she appeared onstage at Madison Square Garden during a benefit concert for New York in October.
"Oh, you know, I was just happy to be there," she tells me when I ask her about it. "I have gotten used to being in situations in political life, either vicariously or on my own, where that just happens sometimes." She says it was "almost part of the healing process" and that she did not take it personally. "They can blow off steam any way they want to," she shrugs. "They've earned it."
Her husband also took the stage that night and was cheered, but he later scolded one of the event's organizers over her reception, as if the organizer could have controlled it. His attempt to protect her demonstrated what the couple's friends say is a strong if not entirely conventional bond, one that survived all that happened in the White House, a miasma of personal 
scandal that she has clearly not forgotten. (In her van, as we ride from La Guardia into Manhattan, she candidly remarks, "People used to ask me all the time, when Bill was in the White House, 'Gee, it's awfully tough, how can you get up every day?"')
She says that she talks on the phone with her husband all the time, soliciting his advice on all sorts of matters, a mode of conversation that is necessary because they seem to be physically apart more than they are together. He usually stays in Chappaqua or travels when she is in Washington, and when she goes back to New York, as she does almost every weekend, she often heads upstate for political events during the day. There have long been questions about how rooted in Westchester the Clintons are, but friends who have visited them at their Chappaqua house say that it feels very much like the family's shared home, redecorated to a degree that reflects a real emotional investment.
Schumer has been a New Yorker, and his own person, long enough that he has nothing to prove in those regards. But he remains a relatively unknown face on the national scene and a newcomer to the Senate, where he would like a glowing aura of distinction and a career like that of one of his Democratic idols, Senator Ted Kennedy of Massachusetts. He certainly has the legislative creativity and tenacity. "He is unbelievable," one Senate aide says. The aide remembers when Schumer, eager to hurry along one of his projects and tired of waiting to get the "score" from the Joint Committee on Taxation on what it would cost, called the committee's chief of staff himself rather than leaving the matter to his staff. "Other senators are too proud to do that sort of thing," the aide says. "He called her like five times in two days."
Other aides and politicians say Schumer lacks the necessary temperament and generosity, calling him abrasive and needlessly eager to hoard credit and headlines. New York Republicans cited those attributes in explaining why, especially since Sept. 11, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, Gov. George Pataki and their staffs have much preferred working with Clinton and her office than with Schumer and his. Bush, by contrast, has a softer spot for Schumer, because he can relate better to Schumer's earthy, extroverted style than to Clinton's cooler reserve.
But a few administration officials are put off by Schumer. One said that when Schumer and Clinton joined Bush on Air Force One for a trip to New York last summer and Bush took the open seat beside Clinton's, Schumer responded by chattering so incessantly that even Bush had a limited chance to speak. When Clinton and Schumer accompanied Bush to ground zero on Sept. 14, Schumer stuck much closer to the president's side, seemingly intent on getting in every television shot. Nick Calio, the administration's chief liaison to Congress, lampooned that tendency in a joke that he later told at a Washington roast. Calio said that when Clinton and Schumer were asking for the $20 billion, she made an additional request that proved impossible to fulfill: a photograph with Bush that did not include Schumer.
Both Clinton and Schumer have not just the obligation of a political lifetime, but also the opportunity of a political lifetime -- to make long strides toward their preferred destinies, to grow in the kind of widespread public regard they want. For her as well as for him, that requires beating back less attractive impulses and habits. She can be gracious and charming, attending bipartisan Congressional prayer meetings with some of the Republicans who most viciously attacked her husband, cracking jokes at her own expense, trying to make nice with the president. When she met with Bush on Sept. 13, she told him that few people could understand the loneliness of the White House, but that she did, and she wanted him to know that.
But she can also be partisan -- going to Daschle earlier this year and recommending a kind of rapid-response war room from which to lob grenades at Republicans and the administration. And she can be prickly. A week after the mid-September Oval Office visit, when Bush delivered his address to Congress, television cameras caught her rolling her eyes. Her aides insisted it had nothing to do with the president, but when I later saw her at a Senate budget committee hearing, she silently and reflexively shook her head and rolled her eyes almost every time one of the economists who were testifying mentioned Bush's tax cut.
Through September and October, as the O.M.B. whittled away at the president's promise, Schumer and Clinton expressed persistent confidence. They arguably had an interest in not publicly doubting Bush's pledge; that might diminish their accomplishment in obtaining it. But they also genuinely believed that the president deserved credit for going out on a limb. And in closed-door meetings with city leaders, they said that they had never firmly expected all of the nearly $20 billion pledged to New York to be delivered right away. They wanted the marker out there as something that they could hold Bush to down the line, something that might increase whatever New York did immediately receive. But they knew that construction in Lower Manhattan could not begin quickly enough to spend the money now. That was the O.M.B.'s argument for delay, and Schumer and Clinton said they at least partly understood it.
They were just as concerned with finding other streams of money, hoping they would ultimately reap much more than $20 billion. Along with other politicians, they succeeded in folding a "victims' compensation fund" into legislation that bailed out airlines. It guaranteed economic restitution to people who were injured or lost family members on Sept. 11 and agreed not to file lawsuits. Much of that money would go to New Yorkers, and the amount might climb toward $10 billion or more.
Then they turned their attention to a $5 billion economic revitalization package of tax cuts and other incentives to try to keep paralyzed businesses in downtown Manhattan from leaving the city. This kind of assistance was not included in the $40 billion in emergency spending, nor was it typical disaster aid. But it was the sort of tonic that Schumer and Clinton thought Manhattan needed instantly, before too many companies left. Trying to get it into a broader stimulus package for the American economy that Senate Democrats were putting together, they sold the $5 billion as something that could be counted against the nearly $20 billion, though they really didn't want that to happen.
"Hillary and I, from the beginning, planned this out," Schumer told the assembled city leaders just before their meetings with Baucus and Lott. "We have to ask for both at the beginning" -- both tax breaks and emergency funds -- and then let both trees grow, hopefully into giant oaks."
"Whole forests," Clinton added.
But getting other New York politicians on the same page proved impossible, because everyone had different stakes and different agendas, which only complicated the already convoluted process of obtaining federal aid. Whatever rivalry existed between Schumer and Clinton paled beside some of the other rivalries at play. With the help of Senator Bob Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat on the Senate Finance Committee, New York's senators got their tax cuts included in a stimulus package that the committee passed. But several House Democrats from New York State, who had failed to get similar measures into a stimulus package approved by the House, were more interested in agitating for the nearly $20 billion in spending, an unresolved matter over which they might still be able to claim some effect. Besides, screaming at the president was good theater, and it fit the more partisan dynamics of the House. At a news conference in early November, Schumer and Clinton wanted to trumpet the tax cuts, and more strident House Democrats like Carolyn Maloney and Gary Ackerman wanted to browbeat Bush. The result: New York's lawmakers ended up shouting over one another. A few left the room in frustration and disgust.
Meanwhile, the new national state of emergency triggered such a rush on federal booty that the Senate stimulus package was initially larded with new subsidies for bison and sugar-beet farmers and money to wipe out citrus canker. Senate Republicans, who were ideologically opposed to the bill's preference for spending over tax cuts, now had an even better excuse to kill it, and they did. As a result, when Senate Democrats began meeting with House Republicans in recent weeks to negotiate a stimulus package palatable to both chambers, they did so without any legislation that had actually passed the Senate, potentially weakening the prospects of the $5 billion in incentives for New York businesses.
Pataki was doing his own thing, too. Worried about his 2002 reelection campaign, he felt the need to release a recovery proposal so comprehensive that no opponent could accuse him of leaving anything out. New York Republicans say he also wanted to make sure there was something for upstate, which was feeling the economic aftershocks of the attacks and which provides Pataki with much of his political support. The result was a wish list that totaled $54billion in desired federal aid and included not just cleanup costs and tax cuts but also a high-speed rail link between Manhattan and upstate cities. Even New York Republicans now admit that it chilled lawmakers from other states, who smelled pork.
Pataki told me it was appropriate to "tell Washington the truth of what we're thinking and not have some stealth agenda -- give us this, and then a month later we're going to ask for that." Besides, he added, "I never intended or expected to be standing on the steps of the Capitol with a giant check for $54 billion." Publicly, Schumer and Clinton took only mild exception to Pataki's approach; privately, their feelings seemed to be stronger, ranging from concern (Clinton) to actual pique (Schumer). The question was not whether Pataki had exaggerated the economic damage to New York City, which a local official estimated to be about $100 billion over two years. It was how to best sidle up to the federal government and wary lawmakers from other states at such a difficult time, with demands from various quarters multiplying and the economy stuck in a slump. Schumer and Clinton struggled with that question, walking in tandem for many weeks after their blowup off the Senate floor, then subtly drifting just a bit apart.
In early November, both senators made peace with House Democrats from New York State by agreeing to push publicly for all of the nearly $20billion in emergency spending, but Schumer worried that New Yorkers were using their best weapon -- the president's guarantee -- before it was necessary or prudent. "We just don't want to be forced to fire our nuclear bomb prematurely," he told me.
Clinton seemed to me less hesitant, more ready to play rough with the administration, an approach with its own risks. "There was lobbying against New York getting this necessary money from the highest places in the administration, which I just for the life of me don't understand," she said on the Senate floor one night shortly after Thanksgiving. "What a shame it would be," she concluded, referring to the nearly $20 billion, "if that promise isn't fulfilled." 
When Schumer spoke on the Senate floor two days later, he was still focusing on the $5 billion in tax cuts, and he never mentioned Bush. They were covering all the angles, but the different roles they assigned themselves perhaps reflected different sensibilities and even an attempt to distinguish themselves from each other. She used fighting words certain to please Democratic activists. He tried to avoid alienating the president, with whom he had a better chance of amity. He told me at one point that he thought Bush could be nudged to the center, and he told others that he wanted to help nudge him there.
The House vote on how to allocate the $40 billion in emergency spending left New York with about $10 billion. Schumer and Clinton hoped to get more from the Senate, and it was possible that once the Senate voted in December and the difference was split, New York would be looking at an amount between $10billion and $12.5 billion. In a sense, Schumer and Clinton had created a monster that came back to bite them: with the promise from the president, they had built up an expectation -- $20 billion for New York alone -- that could not be met. But it was the consensus of many Republicans and Democrats I talked to that beneath that public disappointment remained a private triumph, and that whatever New York received, both now and in the future, would be greater than if its senators had not set the bar so high.
Toward the end of November, just outside the Capitol, various lawmakers from New York gather around a lectern to bemoan their lot. Schumer shows up before Clinton but assures the others: "Hillary is on her way. We'll give her two minutes." Maloney, who arrived 15 minutes early and has been standing at the lectern, ready for her close-up, ever since, starts anyway. When Clinton appears, she is no more than 60 seconds late, if that. Schumer immediately whispers a greeting to her, and she leans in close to him, taking hold of his forearm. When it is his turn to speak, he keeps mentioning her, referring to their joint efforts. When she speaks, she does the same.
They often come across like an old married couple, each always aware of the other's doings; they even finish each other's sentences at times. Fate has hitched them together, no matter what flaws each has come to see in the other or what frustrations they harbor. People who know them well say that she considers him overbearing, and it is true that when they conduct meetings together, he talks more, and he flops around in his chair when she has the microphone. He considers her politically clumsy, and it is true that many Democrats winced when she sullied her campaign victory tour by advocating the abolition of the Electoral College.
They struggle to make the best of it, not just for New York but for themselves. Both could use some softening in their public images; neither would be served by a relationship that degenerates over time into constant public tension, which even some of their supporters believe is a distinct possibility. If they can avoid that, most political observers agree, they have enough combined experiences and assets to accomplish as much as any pair of senators.
"If I were to sit down and choose my home state based on who I thought could represent me the best, there's no question that New York would be in the top two or three," says Luke Albee, the chief of staff for Senator Patrick Leahy, a Vermont Democrat. "They both care, and they work it hard. Part of it is who they are. Part of it is knowing the other one is working. I don't know if they can see the lights of each other's offices, but it's like the first year of law school: nobody leaves the library if nobody else leaves the library."
Therein lies the challenge. When D'Amato -- and then Schumer -- were in the Senate with Moynihan, there was little direct competition. Moynihan was the lofty and aged thinker of big thoughts, which left his partner free to make a louder racket and claim the mantle of the deliverer. Schumer and Clinton both want that mantle. Representative Peter King, a New York Republican, remembers that a while back, when the Senate voted for an appropriation he cared about, Schumer and Clinton called separately to tell him about it within a span of five minutes. "You ask yourself: are they racing to be the first one to tell you or are they both just working hard?" he says. "I'm here eight years and I never got a call from Moynihan." He pauses, then adds, "If the two of them are competing, it's only going to be good for New York."
They indeed seem to jostle for position, in ways that may not be entirely conscious. When I run into Schumer in November, a few days after an American Airlines flight crashed in Queens, he notes that he was in Buffalo at the time and could not get to the city until 4:30 p.m. "Hillary and Joe Allbaugh had just left," he says, an unsolicited detail suggesting his awareness that she had reached the scene before he had, so that she was the one to appear at a televised news conference with Allbaugh, head of the Federal Emergency Management Agency. A House Democrat from New York observes, "In poker, I think that's what they call a tell."
Schumer sometimes sprinkles his remarks with allusions to being in the State Assembly during New York's financial crisis in the 1970's and with reminders that he could once see the World Trade Center from the windows of his Brooklyn apartment -- claims of belonging and history that she cannot make. When they sit together for a conference call with New York reporters one afternoon and she cites their regular consultations with Giuliani, Schumer mentions that he just spoke to the mayor at a Yankees game. She would not feel welcome at Yankee Stadium because of the flap during her campaign about her credentials as a self-professed fan of the team, and her face seems to harden a little at Schumer's remark.
Her staff carefully monitors news reports to make sure that she is not being stinted in descriptions of what the two senators are doing. After a reporter for a leading newspaper left her out of an account of the November news conference that turned into a shouting match, one of her aides sent the reporter a chiding e-mail message, asking him why he would "censor the news" to eliminate her role "in this battle for funding." "Imagine you and a colleague spent equal time and effort writing a story," the aide complained, "and your editor ran the story with your colleague's byline and not yours."
At the French restaurant on Capitol Hill, he asks for hot tea, on account of his cold. She tells him some red wine might also do him good.
"You know, it kills germs," she says.
"Then I'll have some," he agrees.
She chooses a bottle of Bordeaux. "Red wine is very good for your heart, No. 1," she says. "It truly is. . . . "
Before she can get to No. 2, he adds, "They say the French have a lower heart-attack rate."
"Absolutely," she says. "Now, Boris Yeltsin had a theory. . . . " 
"That vodka was good for the heart," he jokes, keeping pace with her, maintaining the delicate rhythm they have tried to establish.
"That vodka was good for the heart," she repeats, acknowledging Schumer's contribution, "but that red wine was good to protect submariners from strontium-90. He told me one time at a dinner party -- he said, 'The submariners drink this. Very good. Protects from uranium."' Clinton lowers her voice and clips her words to imitate Yeltsin, which validates the anecdote as a firsthand memory, not a secondhand story. "So if you're ever going near a nuclear reactor," she finishes, "take your red wine, according to Boris."
Schumer politely chuckles. He cannot touch that.

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES; 
A Grassroots Fight

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA ROWE 

 BODY:
IT began quietly after Sept. 11, with a few neighbors meeting to talk about their fear of living in the shadow of the Indian Point nuclear power plant. But those conversations spread rapidly and now thousands of people in more than a dozen area towns, villages and school districts have signed petitions and passed resolutions urging the plant's shutdown. 
 At a petition drive in front of the A&P supermarket in Yorktown on Dec. 8, volunteers could hardly keep enough pencils free as they collected signatures from residents who wanted officials to consider converting the plant to natural gas. On Dec. 11, Laura Seitz, a member of the newly formed Citizens Awareness Network in Croton, stood at the train station, handing out fliers for a hearing on Indian Point's evacuation plan, and was stunned by the commuters' response. 
 "All I had to say was 'Indian Point' and people grabbed them," she said. "We ran out of 500 fliers in an hour and 15 minutes. That's very unusual. Usually, when you hand out political stuff a lot of people won't take it."
Less organized are those who support the plant but their presence is becoming apparent. At the A&P petition drive a couple yelled insults from their car and so frightened the volunteers that they called the police. 
To some, simply closing Indian Point seems a misguided goal because even if it were decommissioned, nuclear waste from four decades of operation would remain. Then there are the job figures. Entergy Corporation, which owns the plant, employs about 1,500 people there full time. 
Still, the anti-Indian Point faction appears to be gaining momentum. Each week, new towns and villages join the list of those passing resolutions to decommission the plant or investigate using alternate fuels. 
"I've never seen anything like this in all my years in politics," said Paul J. Feiner, 45, supervisor of the town of Greenburgh, who has been in politics one way or another since he was 13. He held a meeting at his home in October to coordinate disparate community groups. Activity has snowballed so quickly since then -- with chat lines devoted to Indian Point discussions, media inquiries from as far away as Japan, and a rally that was scheduled for this past Thursday -- that Mr. Feiner worries the advocates could burn themselves out. 
"This is just growing by leaps and bounds," he said. "I haven't seen anything like it since the Vietnam War. My e-mail list for Indian Point stuff has 220 names on it and I add new ones every day. The thing that's sort of incredible about this effort is it's so grassroots. People are organizing in their living rooms, they're having meetings in their kitchens." 
Skeptics dismiss these efforts as merely symbolic, pointing out that the town boards of genteel Bedford, tiny Irvington and the other municipalities that have passed resolutions hold no sway over the billion-dollar Entergy operation. Only the federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission has the power to close the plant. 
"We know there's a lot of concern among members of the public about this facility, but there are a lot of actions under way to try to improve plant security," said Neil Sheehan, a spokesman for the N.R.C. "We're not going to shut it down unless we've got evidence that it's not being run safely and that has not been demonstrated to us at this point." 
Alex Matthiessen, executive director of Riverkeeper, the environmental group in Garrison, whose resolution opposing the plant provided a model for many of the Westchester municipalities, understands the realities. The strategy, he said, is to create such an enormous groundswell of local sentiment that elected officials will be forced into action. 
"These are political decisions in the end," he said. "There's no doubt that it is an uphill struggle. But when you've got politicians listening to their constituents, you can make a difference."
Larry Gottlieb, northeast communications manager for Entergy, said he was just as confident that the Westchester towns would reverse their decisions once the economic impact of closing the plant becomes clear. 
"There are some people who, God bless 'em, will say, 'Hey, I'd rather live by candlelight,' " Mr. Gottlieb said. "That's fine for them, but what about people with businesses who need the energy Indian Point provides? Even shutting it down doesn't alleviate the risk because the spent fuel still sits there. So it's not just as simple as saying 'Gee, I'm scared and I don't like nuclear power and I don't care what the consequences are.' " 
One county legislator, Michael B. Kaplowitz, said his campaign to win re-election this fall was clearly affected by the concern over Indian Point. Though he had long been unhappy with the plant's operation -- "they run it like someone who never takes their car into a mechanic," he said -- after Sept. 11, his constituents, from soccer moms to small business owners, began telling him they wanted action. 
Working with Westchester County's Department of Public Safety, Mr. Kaplowitz drafted two resolutions calling for increased security at Indian Point and a feasibility study on converting the plant to natural gas. He sent copies to every government entity within 50 miles, asking for support. 
Ms. Seitz, the advocate handing out literature at the train station, said that after 40 years of this kind of work she had no illusions about the years of effort it would take to end nuclear operations at Indian Point. But for the first time in a long while, she feels encouraged. 
"In my lifetime I have seen huge outpourings from ordinary people change the way we look at things," she said. "It's not as if it has never happened before. They've closed plants in other areas. It's going to be tough. Entergy is not going to let a couple of housewives and upset parents throw them. But this is the first time that I feel there actually is a chance to get this done. Everything has changed because of Sept. 11 and the Bush administration is going to have to respond."

SECTION: Section 3; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 2270 words

HEADLINE: Luxury's Old Guard, Battered by New Realities 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE KAUFMAN

 BODY:
THE Neiman Marcus catalog arrived in mailboxes in November, its famed swagger and over-the-top opulence intact. There was a customized helicopter with entertainment center for $6.7 million, a limited-edition jar of La Mer face cream for $1,200 and a $65 mink-covered coat hanger.
 For customers who visited the stores last week, though, the atmosphere was decidedly less cocky. All of Neiman's house-brand cashmere sweaters were 50 percent off. Giorgio Armani suit jackets were under a "30 percent off" sign. As for evening wear, Bill Blass's exquisite black, beaded floor-length gown, with a vine motif and sheer bodice, was $2,876, down from $4,460. 
 Neiman's is hardly the only place to find discounts on sequins or fur and other relics of the cash-flush 90's. At the height of the December selling season, the venerable Saks Fifth Avenue has as many red markdown signs as its sales-obsessed midpriced cousins like Macy's. 
As the economy has soured, Saks and Neiman, the two icons of department store luxury, have been hit hard. Part of their troubles in this downturn stem from more competition: during the Clinton-era boom more and more stores appeared to cater to the proverbial "ladies who lunch," not to mention dot-com multimillionaires and stock market retirees. As a further blow, it is the department stores' key designers, upon whom they long relied to propel sales, who have been building these dazzling emporiums -- often in the department stores' own backyards. Such palaces of consumption are popping up monthly at the Galleria in Houston, on Rodeo Drive in Beverly Hills, at the Bellagio in Las Vegas or along Madison Avenue in Manhattan.
After the terrorist attacks, the luxury market, which was already slowing, shrank sharply. If it does not come back soon, there may not long be room for both giants of the business. Among the problems that must be solved by Burton Tansky, the chief executive of the Neiman Marcus Group, and R. Brad Martin, his counterpart at Saks Inc., are the rise of a younger, more casual generation, more interested in homes than clothes, and designers determined to present collections on their own terms. 
Perhaps no group of retailers was as greatly affected by Sept. 11 as the sellers of luxury goods. Buying a $13,000 mink or a $500 nylon handbag, always an act of indulgence, suddenly seemed too frivolous for perilous times. Now goods like camel-hair coats and pashmina are stacking up in stores, going begging at 40 percent off.
At Saks recently, the squeeze was all too apparent. A long wool-and-cashmere blend sweater by TSE was $749.90, down from $1,250; a navy Armani evening gown with a low back was $1,379.90, down from $2,300; and a jacket with gold sequins and dyed Finnish fox cuffs and trim was $2,659, down from $3,800.
FOR an industry grown fat, it has been a hard fall. After years of record sales, revenue in recent months at some of the strongest names in the business has dropped as precipitously as the last leg of an amusement-park flume ride. Since the attacks, LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton has issued three separate profit warnings, most recently estimating that profits for 2001 would fall 10 to 15 percent from 2000. Gucci has said it expects to meet its earnings estimates for 2001, but it recently let go of 130 people, or 14 percent of its United States work force. Tiffany & Company reported that third-quarter earnings fell 34 percent from the period a year earlier.
On Thursday, Barney's New York announced a third-quarter loss of 61 cents a share, a dizzying decline from the period a year earlier, when it had net income of 24 cents a share.
While the pain has been widespread, the downturn has been particularly perilous for Saks and Neiman Marcus. Late last month, Neiman reported that first-quarter earnings for the group -- which includes 33 Neiman Marcus stores as well as the Bergdorf Goodman division -- would plummet by more than half, to $42 million from $87 million last year. Saks Fifth Avenue, a division of Saks Inc., the former Proffitt's, reported operating losses of $18.9 million for its 64 stores, a steep fall from $30.3 million profit it posted a year earlier.
And their designer rivals keep coming. Today, Louis Vuitton has 37 stores in the United States; five years ago, the total was 26. Giorgio Armani has 24 free-standing stores under its various brands -- not including the more midmarket A/X stores -- double what it had five years ago. Hugo Boss started retail expansion in 1997 and now has 38 American stores, which bring in 40 percent of its sales. Gucci has 27 stores and is aggressively expanding its newly acquired YSL brand. Escada has 16 stores and is adding at least two a year, and Donna Karan, whose company is now part of the LVMH chain, has expressed a desire to build her luxury stores into a worldwide chain.
Not only is there more competition among luxury retailers, but as the lifestyle and aspirations of America's ruling legions become more casual, many top stores are now even doing battle with cleverly stylish downmarket ones. Target, Kohl's and Costco -- all of which seem to be handling the economic downturn just fine -- attract many upper-middle-class dollars with fun, holiday-theme dishes or post-modern tea kettles.
"I think basically both Neiman and Saks are out of sync with the customer," said Walter K. Levy, managing director for retail trends and positioning at Kurt Salmon & Associates. "They are much more formal and fussy; there is not enough casual weekend wear that matches what people will wear on a daily basis." 
The rising tide of wealth in the 1990's was enough to float every yacht, but if the recession continues, investors and bankers say the overall luxury market will shrink.
"Look, there are more people in the middle than in the upper and lower ends," said Peter J. Solomon, chairman of an investment banking firm of the same name, who believes that some consolidation in luxury is inevitable. "There is a risk in dealing with the more narrow band. It is safer in the middle."
If and when one of the great fashion chains becomes obsolete, it may well be able to trace its decline to the designers who opened their own stores. Once, the big stores were the perfect middlemen, guiding the American woman to the proper designer and conferring status on the brands they selected to showcase. Now name brands want to control their own destiny, sometimes even expanding into new product groups. Coach, the bag maker, for example, now makes shoes and furniture.
So why are the designers striking out on their own?
Because both sides have a stake in the relationship, both contend that designers opening their own stores five blocks away from a Neiman's or a Saks can generate traffic for everybody by raising the profile of the brand. Hot merchandise, the theory goes, is hot wherever it is sold.
Still, in conversations with designers' companies, it is easy to get the impression that they think high-end department stores cannot be relied on for the future. "The Armani group has had a strategy in recent years of developing its own store networks," said Robert Triefus, the group's executive vice president for communications. "We are able to present and control our own image."
Presentation is a recurring complaint for designers, who are, after all, in the business of being hyperconscious about image. But it is also a matter of economics.
When designers have their own stores, they are more likely to sell more of their own goods each time a customer walks in, because the shopper can be shown entire ensembles at once. The designer stores also earn more on each article, because they generally discount less and can keep the markup margin that used to go to the retailer.
"The big challenge for luxury department stores is that we are in the era of the consumer," said Marty Staff, president and chief executive of Hugo Boss USA. "In the old days, you'd pick up your suit, walk 30 yards, pick up your ties, go downstairs and look for shoes." Customers, he said, want to see everything together, the way the designers envisioned. At Boss's private stores, an average sale is five products, he said, far more than at department stores. 
He is also concerned about department stores' effectiveness in capturing young customers. "Our core customer is 35 to 54," he said. "But their core male customer is at the high end of the spectrum. They've gone after the 50-year-old customer nicely; the question is, where will the 35-year-old shop in 10 years?"
The designer Zoran, who has built a loyal following with a women's line of simple classic shapes in sumptuous fabrics, is also watching the future with some concern. "Neiman's has the richest clients now, but it has to recognize that America has a different aristocracy," he said. "It is no longer the Rockefellers or the Vanderbilts; it is the Hillary Clintons.
"The privileged one once had money and time; now she doesn't have either," Zoran said. "She comes twice a year only, and you have to be prepared to have the right thing."
If there is a consolation for the luxury chains, it is that the dangers are clearly the long-term type -- unless, contrary to expectations, the recession long and deep.
Of the two giants, Saks is financially weaker. Its merger with the midmarket department store chain Proffitt's in 1998 has provided less cost savings to either side than projected. Moreover, with management distracted by acquisitions, sales at Proffitt's, then at Saks Fifth Avenue, sank, sending the company's stock into a tailspin. The shares now trade at around $9, compared with a 2001 high of $14.23 in February and far from their five-year high of $44.08, just before the merger.
MOST analysts say Saks's position is far from desperate, though Moody's Investor's Service put its bonds, already rated in the high-risk, or junk, category, on review in October for further downgrade. Elaine Francolino, Moody's debt analyst, pointed to a new $700 million secured bank loan the company received in November. "The company has consistently made progress on reducing debt and is managing cash flow well," she said.
Mr. Martin, meanwhile, says he is moving aggressively to position Saks for the evolving marketplace. At 50, he has something to prove. As chief of Proffitt's before the Saks acquisition, he made his reputation as an acquirer king, snapping up midpriced department stores in the South and streamlining their costs to the delight of Wall Street. Now he is determined to fix Saks Fifth Avenue.
Two months ago, the store opened its first home-furnishings boutique in the Manhattan flagship; it is intended as a prototype to be expanded to the chain. The company has been introducing younger casual apparel, along with a pointed marketing campaign it says has lowered the average age of customers by two to three years. 
Neiman's, which is coming off record sales in 2000 and is more conservatively financed than Saks, is stable, but it is not without its own concerns. The Neiman Marcus Stores division lost H. W. Mullins as chief executive and chairman in November last year. Mr. Tansky, the president and chief executive of the parent company, the Neiman Marcus Group, took over for him on an interim basis. But Mr. Tansky still has those extra duties, because the company has been unable to attract the talent it wants, several executive recruiters said.
MR. Tansky is not exactly an unknown quantity. He ran Neiman's stores division before Mr. Mullins did, and they helped negotiate partial-ownership deals with high-growth brands like Kate Spade, the handbag maker, and Laura Mercier cosmetics. Still, Mr. Tansky, 63, had said when he appointed Mr. Mullins that he did not have time to run the stores and be an executive at the larger corporate group. It is doubtful that the downturn has made his schedule any easier. Neiman's acknowledges that the situation is not ideal. "We are continuing to look at our executive structure," said Jim Skinner, the group's chief financial officer.
Moreover, Neiman's has focused so intently on high couture -- rarefied fashion accounts for 60 percent of its sales -- that it may have painted itself into a corner. If current trends continue, as the next generation comes of age it will prefer to spend less money on formal clothes and more on casual clothes and fancy home decorating. Mr. Skinner seemed relatively unconcerned with the trends and suggested that the increasing focus on the home and casual styles are cycles that might already be nearing their end. Besides, he added, "every generation has a fashion-focused component."
Whatever obstacles they face, the chains have one thing in common: confidence in their future and an unwavering faith in the luxury market. "I have a very strong belief there is a rising tide of affluence in America and globally long term," said Mr. Martin, 50, the chief executive and chairman of Saks Inc. "The economy does not work in a linear fashion, but in the long run, luxury is where we want to be."
Dana Telsey, a luxury goods analyst at Bear Stearns, agreed. "This is not a market that is over-stored; it is under-stored," she said. "The rich are getting richer, and the wealth among high-net-worth individuals is going to grow at 8 percent annually over the next five years," on average, she estimated. 
Still, Ms. Telsey expects plenty of expansion among companies she covers, including Coach, Gucci and Tiffany's, which means plenty more competition for Neiman and Saks. "Coach only has 120 stores," she said. "There is room for 250." If she is correct, the pressure on the grand old carriage-trade department stores will be enormous.
