PERSON: Joseph M. Tucci 

HEADLINE: Private Sector; 
He Knows This Bumpy Hill Well

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
JOSEPH M. TUCCI calls himself a car nut. He says the used sports cars he acquires -- a Porsche twin turbo is his current prize -- are treated so lovingly that he can sell them at a profit. 
 No wonder Mr. Tucci, the chief executive of EMC, sometimes slips into car-and-driver analogies when discussing the company's remarkable rise to leadership in the data storage industry, its current problems or its plans for regaining momentum. But Mr. Tucci, 54, said those slips made him impatient with himself. 
 "I hate car analogies," he said, abruptly halting one in a recent interview. They tend to lead to oversimplification, he explained. 
Fair enough, but a snapshot of Mr. Tucci's career might read like this: Energetic, ambitious young executive proves adept at keeping Sperry and Unisys computers from being blown off the technology racetrack by I.B.M. More mature executive pulls the onetime office automation leader Wang out of the bankruptcy ditch, soups it up with new products and gets it running smoothly enough to sell to a European competitor. Seasoned manager is rewarded with the driver's seat in the front-running car on the data storage circuit. Ready to finally experience the thrill of putting the pedal to the metal with everyone else in the rear-view mirror, he has barely tightened his seat belt when . . . kaboom! 
This is going to require more than a minor pit stop.
Mr. Tucci has had the misfortune of starting his job at one of the worst possible times -- at least when it comes to problems beyond his control. Since his promotion almost a year ago, the country has fallen into recession, and companies have cut technology spending. The cuts have been especially deep for big-ticket products like the multimillion-dollar storage systems built around EMC's flagship, Symmetrix, a refrigerator-size box full of memory disks.
EMC, which finished 2000 with a burst that lifted its sales to $8.9 billion, aimed to hit $12 billion this year. Analysts now expect sales to slump to about $6.8 billion this year and to decline as much as $1 billion more in 2002.
EMC was also blindsided by a price war initiated by Hitachi Data Systems, a unit of Hitachi Ltd., the deep-pocketed Japanese company, and joined by I.B.M.'s data storage division. 
Fighting back in a shrinking market destroyed EMC's profits. After earning $1.8 billion last year, EMC, based in Hopkinton, Mass., is expected to lose at least $600 million this year. The loss will reflect about $675 million in restructuring charges that included provisions to cut 4,000 additional jobs, bringing the total to 5,500, or 23 percent of the work force.
Critics say EMC has problems in addition to uncontrollable market forces. They say that its technology advantages have eroded and that years of aggressive behavior by EMC sales representatives have soured relations with many customers.
Fortunately for EMC, Mr. Tucci may be even better suited to managing upheaval than the prosperity that the company projected when he joined it nearly two years ago. "He has made a career out of stewarding transitions," said James Berlino, an analyst at Merrill Lynch who has known Mr. Tucci since his days at Unisys. "He's a hands-on guy who is incredibly direct."
Mr. Tucci is already credited with pushing a sales force reorganization on the company that helped it overtake Network Appliance, the early market leader in the fast-growing new segment of smaller storage devices attached to networks instead of mainframe computers. He used a friendship from his days at Wang with Kevin Rollins, president and chief operating officer at Dell Computer, to clear the way for a recently announced alliance in which Dell will market EMC's smaller systems. 
"He seems to know someone everywhere in high tech and in all of the Fortune 1,000," said Frank Hauck, an EMC executive vice president. Not that Mr. Tucci is all business: in his office are photographs of him with Pope John Paul II and, reflecting the transition in athletic passions from sandlot baseball and skiing to golf, Jack Nicklaus. 
Mr. Tucci is more of a gregarious team builder than his predecessor, Michael C. Ruettgers, who did much managing through one-on-one discussions. Some who have sat through the everyone-gets-to-speak meetings favored by Mr. Tucci fret that important decisions might be slowed, but the benefits have been clear. 
"Everyone feels like they are a part of the process," Mr. Hauck said.
That includes Mr. Ruettgers, who assumed the title of executive chairman when Mr. Tucci became chief executive. The continuing active presence of Mr. Ruettgers raised questions on Wall Street about who was running EMC. One of the most successful chief executives of his era -- his nine years spanned virtually all of the 1990's, when EMC was the fastest-growing stock on the New York Stock Exchange -- Mr. Ruettgers meets regularly with major customers and speaks for the company at public events.
"There were a lot of people wondering what was going on," said H. Clinton Vaughan, who follows EMC for Salomon Smith Barney. 
It is a delicate relationship, but it works, those involved say. "He's the boss," said Mr. Ruettgers, who turned 59 last week. The two consult on all strategic issues and almost always reach similar conclusions, though by such different routes that they kid each other about it, Mr. Ruettgers said.
"Employees are more comfortable approaching him," said Mr. Ruettgers, adding with a chuckle that there was no overcoming ancestry. "I'm German and he's Italian."
Mr. Tucci's clearest assertion of control occurred two weeks ago, when he announced a reorganization dividing the company into three groups and reducing the role of Moshe Yanai, the longtime champion within the company of Symmetrix. The new organization emphasized Mr. Tucci's strategy of reducing EMC's reliance on hardware sales and software designed specifically for EMC products. The first major product in support of the open systems strategy, a software suite called AutoIS that runs storage hardware from many companies, will roll out next year.
MR. TUCCI, who was born in the Bronx and spent his early childhood in Brooklyn, entered the computer business with RCA after graduating from Manhattan College. His youthful conviction that he would someday run a major company got a boost when Sperry, his next destination after RCA, financed his studies for an M.B.A. from Columbia University. 
His success in rebuilding Wang caught the eye of Richard Egan, then EMC's chairman, who approached him about joining EMC's board shortly before Getronics, a Dutch company, bought Wang. When it became clear to Mr. Egan and Mr. Ruettgers that Mr. Tucci would soon be a free agent, they switched their pitch to another position they were trying to fill: president, chief operating officer and heir apparent to Mr. Ruettgers.
Although some of EMC's headiest growth was ahead of it, Mr. Tucci took the job expecting major challenges, said Joseph Kroger, his former boss at Sperry and a longtime mentor. "He knew the stock price was too high when he went," Mr. Kroger said. 
Mr. Tucci's challenge now is to prove that this is no longer true. The stock closed Friday at $15.04, down nearly 85 percent percent from its peak of $102.64 in September 2000 and about 70 percent from where it stood the day he joined the company.

 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 3; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 2344 words

HEADLINE: Visions of a Brand-Name Office Empire 

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: CHICAGO 

 BODY:
SAM ZELL is not a man plagued by self-doubt. He never has been. The only son of an uncompromising immigrant who did not brook dissent once he fled Poland just hours before the Nazis invaded, Mr. Zell grew up driven, ambitious and as certain of his own judgment as his father was of his.
 One of the world's richest men, Mr. Zell controls public companies that own nearly 700 office buildings in the United States with 125 million square feet of space, as well as 225,000 residential units. No one -- not Donald J. Trump, not Mortimer B. Zuckerman, not Leona Helmsley -- has that much office space. Mr. Zell is so confident that, even as the real estate market weakens and as Wall Street analysts question his deals, he says he is writing a new chapter in real estate history. 
 Mr. Zell, a flamboyant 60-year-old with a penchant for riding to work on a Ducati motorcycle, has spent $27 billion during the last four years in a series of blockbuster acquisitions that created two huge REIT's, or real estate investment trusts. 
Now, Mr. Zell says, he will transform the real estate market by turning those REIT's, particularly Equity Office Properties Trust, into national brands recognized by big corporations. By offering convenience and consistent quality to big companies with many offices, Mr. Zell believes, they will start to view those offices as something more than a commodity chosen chiefly by price and location.
Developers like Mr. Trump and the late Harry Helmsley have used branding -- essential for things like cars and hotels -- in local real estate markets, but with spotty success. Mr. Zell is trying to take the idea nationwide, with the help of new ancillary services like high-speed Internet connections.
But Wall Street analysts and real estate experts say that Mr. Zell overpaid for some of the office properties and that his real estate empire will be hard-pressed to deliver profit growth. Branding, they say, is a sideshow to the real issue -- whether he can justify his enormous investment.
Shares of Equity Office have staggered since the company acquired Beacon Properties for $4 billion in 1997, Cornerstone Properties of New York for $4.6 billion in 2000 and Speiker Properties of California for $7.2 billion in February. On Friday, they closed at $29.33, near their level in late 1997, despite years of solid profits. Worse, the real estate market is heading for a downturn, experts say, leading some to contend that Mr. Zell has yet to demonstrate the advantage of his bigger-is-better strategy.
"Sam is now the dominant landlord in Boston, San Francisco and Seattle," said Fred Carr, a principal at the Penobscot Group in Cambridge, Mass., which tracks REIT's. "But it remains to be seen what the real advantage is in that."
Mr. Zell, who controls a $25 billion corporate empire from his office in the old Daily News Building here, overlooking the Chicago River, has had his share of failures. American Classic Voyages, a cruise line in which he had a 50 percent stake, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in October after the drop-off in tourism from the terrorist attacks. And shares of Chart House Restaurants, a restaurant chain of which he took control in 1997, have plummeted to penny-stock status.
BUT, used to playing the odds, he has often fared well. In the 1970's, he made millions buying distressed real estate, fixing it up and collecting the profits. After writing an essay about his ability to acquire good properties that most considered dead, he was tagged "the grave dancer." He then moved on to other things, investing in businesses from radio stations to fertilizer companies to rail cars.
Among his big holdings, usually acquired with the backing of major banks, were the Revco drug store chain and Sealy, the mattress company. Both were re-engineered and yielded big gains. Mr. Zell bought Revco for about $7 a share in 1992, for example, and sold it to CVS for $40 a share five years later.
These days, Mr. Zell says he is again "testing the limits" of his entrepreneurial skills. "There's no one in the world who has ownership on this scale, and no one is trying to run it as a network," Mr. Zell said in an interview. 
Consolidation means cheaper access to capital, he contends, as well as lower insurance premiums and the ability to attract national customers. Equity Office is already pulling in about $20 million a year from ancillary services, Mr. Zell says, and that number should grow substantially because 75 customers account for about 20 percent of the company's square feet of space. 
MR. ZELL, who speaks in raspy tones, occasionally sprinkled with obscenities, has a derring-do quality about him. His sentences jab, then punch. Outlining his latest vision, he talks about cheaper supply contracts and selling national advertising spots that can be shown on all Equity Office elevator monitors and in parking lots. "There will be a concierge, selling telecommunications," Mr. Zell said. "We'll create preferred services; we'll have software off the Web. We want to put the landlord where he ought to be -- as the intermediary for delivering a number of services."
The intent, he said, is to transform a leasing company into a full-fledged service provider.
The problem is, so few people want to buy those services. Companies are trying to cut costs. No other REIT is trying national branding, and those that have tried adding similar services have noticed little effect. Analysts dismiss these plans as small improvements on the margins, not big enough to reshape the economics of a huge company.
"Lots of local businesses have become national companies -- local food brands, newspapers, television, the media, said David Shulman a real estate analyst at Lehman Brothers. "So there is precedent everywhere else in the economy."
"The question is: How amenable is real estate?" he added. "The economies of scale are getting better deals on executives, insurance and finance. After that, it's hard to find economies."
Though Mr. Zell has earned praise for selecting good management teams for his buildings, operating as a corporate giant out of regional offices may be problematic, analysts say. "Accepted wisdom in the industry is you want a local sharpshooter," said Mr. Carr of Penobscot. "The presumption is the local sharpshooter knows more. Sam has done a remarkable job even though he's not a local sharpshooter, but it's still a hurdle."
Twice in his career, Mr. Zell has been dragged into investigations of possible tax evasion by the Internal Revenue Service. In 1976, he was indicted for conspiracy to avoid paying taxes in a real estate deal. The charges were dismissed after he agreed to cooperate and testify against his brother-in-law, Roger Baskes, who was sentenced by a federal judge to two years in prison. In a more recent case in tax court, the I.R.S. is seeking up to $83 million from Mr. Zell's former business partner, concerning a tax reduction scheme involving Mr. Zell, who was not accused. The case is pending.
But even critics tend to praise him as an eccentric who can zero in on problems and opportunities, even if they disagree with his strategy.
"What he's extraordinary at, compared to almost anyone else I've ever met -- and I've dealt with Nobel Prize winners and key executives -- is his ability to advance the thought process," says Peter D. Linneman, a professor of real estate at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania and a former assistant to Mr. Zell. "He's good at quickly grasping the key issues and saying, 'I'd think about this, this and this.' "
This is Sam Zell the seer, who believes he can anticipate boom-and-bust cycles. In 1988, he wrote an article entitled "From Cassandra, With Love," predicting a commercial real estate bust, which came in 1990. In 1999, during the dot-com boom, he was among those who repeatedly warned that the bubble would not last and mostly stayed clear of technology investments.
His message now is that the American real estate market is remarkably healthy, that the overinvestment and excess borrowing, the overbuilding and huge credit shortage of the 1980's and early 1990's are gone.
True, the real estate market is softening, with a growing office vacancy rate, but structural changes -- including the tremendous growth of publicly traded real estate investment trusts like his own -- have created a more stable and rational marketplace, he contends.
Renewed corporate efficiency and better information among investors and developers has tempered the tendency toward excessive lending and overbuilding, he says. Nor does he believe that Sept. 11 terrorist attacks will have a lasting effect on the office building market.
Industry experts tend to agree that overbuilding may not be a problem. Vacancy rates are not expected to approach 20 percent, as they did a decade ago. "Veterans call the early 90's a real estate depression," said John Lutzius, a real estate analyst at Green Street Advisors. "We've had a rapid decline in the health of the national office market, but it doesn't look as bad from an operating view; they're going into this downturn with much less leverage."
This is all good for Mr. Zell, who is betting a large part of his estimated $2 billion personal fortune on the future of American real estate. In addition to owning about 6 percent of Equity Office Properties, his empire includes 3 percent of Equity Residential Properties Trust, another REIT, as well as the Equity International Properties, a private company invested in Latin American properties and hotels, and 10 percent of Manufactured Home Communities, a public company that operates mobile home parks in the United States.
Once the chief executive of many of the companies he invested in, Mr. Zell is now chairman -- that is, strategic adviser, elder statesman, real estate guru and chief deal maker. He has a staff of about 60 to help manage his holdings, and each company has its own chief executive. Often, the companies do business with one another and with Mr. Zell's private companies -- something he defends.
Allied Riser, for example, a provider of data, video and voice communications services that has lost $375 million so far this year, rents space from Equity Office and signed a contract to install fiber optic equipment in 350 of the REIT's buildings. And Allied Riser bought $8 million worth of equipment from Anixter, a computer cable manufacturer in which Mr. Zell has a large stake. He says there are no conflicts.
Mr. Zell assumed the chairman's mantle gradually after his financial empire was rocked in 1990 by a collapsing real estate market and the death of Robert H. Lurie, a friend and longtime business partner. That forced him to reorganize his operations. After Mr. Lurie's death, he said: "I didn't want to have extensive operations. By creating these public companies, each company has its own management team and balance sheet. I can be a strategic adviser, but I'm not in the day-to-day operations."
Friends and relatives say Robert Lurie's death at 48 had a devastating effect on Mr. Zell. The two were ideal partners. Mr. Lurie, who had studied engineering at college, was the math whiz who crunched the numbers; Mr. Zell was the visionary salesman. "I was the rainmaker and he ran the store," Mr. Zell said.
Mr. Zell, whose father sold everything from flour to jewelry to property, has always had an instinct for sales. At 12, he bought copies of Playboy magazine under the elevated train tracks in Chicago for 50 cents each and then peddled them in the suburbs for $1.50.
By the time he graduated from Highland Park High School in 1959, he showed some of the intransigence he shared with his father. The caption beneath his yearbook picture reads: "I am not arguing with you, I am telling you."
At the University of Michigan, where he was a political science major, Mr. Zell talked his way into managing some off-campus housing property. He made enough money to start a small real estate company with Mr. Lurie, a fraternity brother. It was the beginning of their real estate empire.
Mr. Zell continued to manage and own properties as he attended law school at Michigan. After graduating in 1966, he briefly worked at a small Chicago law firm, then returned to real estate. He and Mr. Lurie bought apartment buildings in small but fast-growing cities, from Orlando, Fla., to Reno, Nev., and used favorable tax laws to attract wealthy investors to his real estate deals.
When the real estate market collapsed in 1974, he swooped in to buy properties from other REIT's that were selling property cheap.
Early on, he said, he was "a student of inefficient markets," which took him from existing real estate to development to distressed corporations. Some, like Schwinn, a bicycle maker, taught him a painful lesson -- it failed in July. Others, like Anixter, have outperformed the market.
THE last recession, in the early 1990's, was as close as his empire ever came to a breaking point. But when the real estate market recovered, Mr. Zell began taking his companies public, selling shares in Equity Office and Equity Residential as real estate investment trusts, which are required by law to return 90 percent of their profits to investors. The two companies have outperformed the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the REIT industry over the last three years, during which they returned about $3.5 billion to investors by way of dividends, earning a total return of about 14 percent a year. 
Industry experts say the inclusion of Mr. Zell's second REIT, Equity Residential, in the S.& P. 500 a few weeks ago brought real estate investment trusts further into the mainstream of investing.
Despite his recent setbacks, his zest is undiminished. He enjoys motorcycle trips with his friends, who call themselves Zell's Angels. At a party last month -- postponed from September because of the terrorist attacks -- he sailed 600 guests up the Chicago River to a renovated warehouse. There he treated them to a concert by Bette Midler and a spectacular fireworks display. As usual, Mr. Zell was not thinking small.

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
Government Fiddles And the Economy Burns

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
IN the real world, as this recently fat and happy nation has learned once again, the economy can change with distressing speed. Hundreds of thousands of jobs disappear in a month. Confidence -- and stock market gains -- evaporate in a blink. Companies whose strategies appeared brilliant are exposed as overreaching, or even fraudulent, the moment times get tough.
 In the political economy, however, nothing ever seems to change. Republicans insist that, whatever the question, the answer is tax cuts. Democrats demand help for the little guy, often invoking class warfare in the process. Lobbyists tailor their pleadings to the climate of the day, and members of both parties sidestep principle to help or protect favored interests back home. 
 Such predictable clashes of ideology, combined with the pursuit of parochial interests, all but ensure that political leaders in Washington will respond in slow motion -- if they respond at all -- to the fast-forward blur of a deteriorating economy.
So it was that Congress and the Bush administration were still haggling over an economic recovery package last week, even as the Federal Reserve cut interest rates for the 11th time this year and some private economists began seeing signs, albeit tentative ones, that the recession may be entering its final stages.
But though they may run at different speeds, politics and the economy are inextricably intertwined. And as they confront this downturn, however haltingly, Democrats and Republicans are facing the likelihood that the hopeful possibilities glimpsed in recent years -- of paying off the national debt, shoring up Social Security, helping the elderly bear the rising costs of prescription medicines -- may have vanished.
Whether this recession fundamentally alters the politics of the economy depends to some extent on how long it persists. An outbreak of Japanese-style deflation in the United States, or a long and costly war on terrorism, would change the terms of the debate. But even if the future proves less dire, the changed situation already holds implications for everything from the 2002 elections to the ability of the nation to get its finances in order for the aging of the baby-boom generation.
Assuming that they complete a deal on a stimulus bill that includes tax cuts and additional benefits for the unemployed -- by no means a certainty -- Congress and the White House could have a substantial effect on the strength if not the timing of the recovery. While many analysts expect the downturn to end by spring, there is considerable debate among economists about how robust the rebound will be, with some forecasters projecting tepid growth and others seeing a boomlet.
In political terms, both parties are positioning themselves for an election-year battle in 2002. They have rediscovered their inner Keynesians, eagerly seeking new spending (Democrats) or tax cuts (Republicans), while arguing over who lost the surplus. Democrats blame President Bush and his big tax cut. Republicans blame an economic slowdown that started when Bill Clinton was still in the White House, and big-spending Democrats in the Senate. 
Either way, the agendas of both parties will be severely constrained in coming years by the lack of money on the table. More broadly, the combination of recession and war is forcing both parties to rethink the relationship between budget policy and the economy. 
The Social Security lockbox, the centerpiece of that relationship for the past few years, was shorthand for a commitment that the bulk of the projected surplus, the portion coming from the retirement system, go only to reducing the national debt. 
It had an economic rationale: that reducing the debt would give the nation more financial flexibility a few decades from now when the aged baby boomers place a huge strain on the social welfare system, and in the meantime would help bring down long-term interest rates, spurring more growth-enhancing investment by businesses and consumers alike. 
But debt reduction was always as much a political concept as an economic one, adopted by the two parties as a way of keeping each other from getting their hands on what seemed at the time to be limitless surpluses. 
It also proved to have great appeal to voters, who seemed to feel virtuous that the government was paying for its profligate past even as they were running up record levels of consumer debt and driving down their own savings rates to near zero.
The popularity of debt reduction also muffled the traditional ideological arguments about how best to encourage long-term economic growth, which in any case didn't seem to be much of a problem. 
WITH unemployment at record lows, Democrats had a hard time making the argument that more government spending on education, health care and transportation would yield a payoff in the form of a more productive work force and a more efficient economy. And until Mr. Bush's election, when the projected surplus was so big that the biggest tax cut in a generation could be portrayed as fiscally responsible, Republicans had little success selling their idea that cutting taxes would generate more investment and create more jobs. They were able to sell Mr. Bush's tax cut only by promising that there was still plenty of money for debt reduction -- an assertion that now is likely to be proved false.
Robert B. Reich, a liberal Democrat who was labor secretary in the Clinton administration and is now considering running for governor of Massachusetts, said the current fiscal troubles and the disappearance of the lockbox are an opportunity to re-engage a vigorous debate between the left and right on economic policy.
"The right would say you need tax cuts to generate incentives for the wealthy and companies," he said. "The left of center would say, what about public investment? If you don't have good education and healthy people and a good transportation system, you can forget about productivity improvements in the future. The chances of having that debate now are higher than when we were locked into the silly debate over the Social Security lockbox."
Those arguments, from both left and right, will still have to compete with the case for debt reduction. Paying off the debt resonated with voters not only because it was easy virtue, but because this is a nation of homeowners and credit card holders who are well aware of how rising interest rates bite into their wallets.
Of course, the whole notion of debt reduction hinges on the existence of surpluses, and there are credible studies circulating on Capitol Hill that show nothing but deficits for the next decade. Having sold the nation on fiscal responsibility, politicians could now have a difficult time explaining why it is no longer possible -- and how the opportunities it yielded got away from us.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: INTELLIGENCE; 
New Clue Fails to Explain Iraq Role in Sept. 11 Attack

BYLINE:  By CHRIS HEDGES with DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

 BODY:
When Czech officials disclosed that Mohamed Atta, the suspected mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks, had met last April with an Iraqi diplomat in Prague, it stirred immediate speculation about whether Iraq had a role in killing thousands of Americans.
 But in the weeks since, the Prague meeting has emerged as an object lesson in the limits of intelligence reports rather than the cornerstone of the case against Iraq. Interviews with Iraqi defectors, Czech officials, and people who knew the Iraqi diplomat have only deepened the mystery surrounding Mr. Atta's travels through central Europe. 
 Iraqi opposition groups say the episode cannot have been a coincidence. According to several former Iraqi intelligence officials, the diplomat was actually a well trained spy with ties to terrorist operations, a master of disguise whose movements are supervised by Iraq's most senior officials. 
American officials in Washington, by contrast, said the diplomat was a minor functionary who happens to have the same last name as a more important Iraqi intelligence agent. These officials said that they had no evidence that Iraq was involved in the attacks on the World Trade Center and Pentagon.
There are even questions about whether the reports of the meeting took place. An associate said the Iraqi diplomat had a business selling cars and met frequently with a used car dealer from Germany who bore a striking resemblance to Mr. Atta. Just this week, there were even reports from Prague that the Mohamed Atta who visited Prague last April was a different man with the same name. 
In a retreat from the earlier definitive statements by his government, the president of the Czech Republic, Vaclav Havel, recently said there was "a 70 percent" chance the meeting between Mr. Atta and an Iraqi agent named Ahmed Khalil Ibrahim Samir al-Ani took place.
With the Taliban vanquished and Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda fighters cornered in Afghanistan, this sort of arcane debate among experts has taken on new significance. President Bush has said he intends to defeat the nations and groups that support terrorism, a global war whose targets will be selected by intelligence agencies sifting through fragmentary conflicting evidence comparable to the reports about the Prague meeting.
"There was definitely one meeting," between Mr. Ani and Mr. Atta, an intelligence official in Washington said. "We don't know if it was significant. We certainly don't attribute to it the significance others attribute to it automatically. Just because there was a meeting doesn't mean it was connected to 9/11."
This much has been asserted. Mr. Atta went to Prague last April and then flew to Florida as the plot to ram jetliners into buildings gained momentum. It has been reported by Czech authorities that he met with Mr. Ani, the diplomat who Iraqi opposition leaders insist is an important spymaster for Saddam Hussein.
American intelligence officials who believe that Mr. Ani is a low-ranking diplomat of little consequence emphasize that the Iraqi National Congress, the opposition group seeking to overthrow Saddam Hussein, has an agenda and a history of coloring fact to suit its needs.
As if the waters were not muddied enough, some in Prague who knew the diplomat say he met with a used car salesman named Saleh from Nuremberg, Germany, who looked like Mr. Atta. "He is a perfect double for Atta," said a Syrian businessman who has lived in Prague for 35 years and says he knew the diplomat and the car salesman. "I saw him several times with Mister Consul." 
On Friday, a major Czech newspaper, quoting Czech intelligence officials, offered still another theory: the Mohamed Atta who came to Prague last April was not the hijacker but a Pakistani of the same name.
"He didn't have the same identity card number," an unidentified Interior Ministry official told the newspaper Mlada Fronta Dnes. "There was a great difference in their ages, their nationalities didn't match, basically nothing -- it was someone else." The details of the meeting, as reported by the Czech authorities, remain vague. The Czech intelligence service has not said how it knows the meeting took place, or what was said.
"We went to the public just with the thing we can really prove," said Hynek Kmonicek, the Czech ambassador to the United Nations who gave Mr. Ani his expulsion orders last April. "And we can really prove just one thing: that these two people met." But his proof, he acknowledged, is the Czech Interior Ministry announcement. 
Mr. Ani was expelled from Prague for activities that were described as "incompatible with his diplomatic status." Details of his infraction have never been made public but they had nothing to do with Mr. Atta, who was unknown to Czech intelligence, Mr. Kmonicek said.
A number of Arabs in Prague who knew Mr. Ani say he had every attribute of a minor figure in a minor post, a woman chaser and drinker with a tyrannical penchant whose main task seemed to be urging Iraqis to return home. Yet former Iraqi intelligence agents in exile in Europe, made available for interviews by the Iraqi National Congress, say they grew up with and worked with Mr. Ani and that he is an established and respected spymaster.
His specialty is said to be the recruitment of foreign Muslim militants who support Iraq's long campaign against America and the close surveillance and intimidation of Iraqi dissidents.
The former Iraqi agents in Europe say that Mr. Ani, is in fact, Muhammad Kailil Ibrahim al-Ani.
"Baghdad would only use Ani for big jobs, serious jobs," said a former major in Iraqi intelligence. "He had something very important to tell Atta, or Atta had something very important to tell Baghdad."
Mr. Ani, for his part, adamantly denied any ties to terrorism or Sept. 11 and said he had never heard of Mr. Atta until after the terror attack. Jaroslev Kmenta, a Czech journalist who knew Mr. Ani in Prague, interviewed him in Baghdad last month.
' "I've never in my life met him, never seen him, never spoke to him," Mr. Kmenta quoted him as saying. "The first time I heard of him was after Sept. 11." 
Mr. Kmenta said Mr. Ani seemed to be living well in Baghdad, driving a late-model BMW and eating at a riverside restaurant, which would support the thesis that he is a figure of importance to the regime because economic sanctions have left most Iraqi civil servants living in penury. 
The defectors in Europe said that like many agents sent abroad, Mr. Ani altered his real name from post to post, dropping his first name, Muhammad, in Prague and going by Ahmed.
"I went down to renew my driver's license in 1991 in Baghdad," said the former major in the intelligence service, who fled to Europe after his brother was executed for involvement in a failed coup in 1994 against Mr. Hussein. "I saw Ani dressed in jeans, with an earring and with long flowing hair. He looked like a hippie. He was on a job. I could not speak with him. I saw him a year later dressed in long Arab robes."
He said Mr. Ani grew up in a middle class neighborhood in Baghdad and joined the intelligence service, following a year or two of university studies. He was sent to study at The Institute of National Security, the preparatory school for Iraq's intelligence service. In 1994, the defectors said, he was transferred to a new intelligence branch created for foreign operations called Al-Amin al-Khas. He soon was part of special operations, a unit for covert activities like recruitment and assassination.
In Prague, few who were interviewed about Mr. Ani thought of him in such vaunted terms. But they recognized allegations of highhandedness. Waled Majed Bahnam, 56, and his son Majid Waled Majed, 22, both Iraqis, own the Bavodo restaurant in Prague. In July 2000 for the Iraqi national day, Mr. Ani ordered $1,200 worth of food and catering from the restaurant.
After three days, when the bill still had not been paid, the mother called asking for the money. The family said Mr. Ani and the accountant came over and screamed at them. "They said 'We are the embassy, you are nothing, we are the boss, you are animals,' " Mr. Bahnam said. Mr. Ani threatened to revoke their passports and the accountant said he would kill the couple's eldest son. When the family complained to the Foreign Ministry, the embassy paid the bill.

HEADLINE: O Brave New Bavaria! So Much More Than Beer 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN ERLANGER

DATELINE: MUNICH 

 BODY:
Germany's huge economy has slipped into recession like a tanker slowly sinking, but here in Bavaria life continues to be rich, profitable, hoppy and sweet.
 From its famous beer to its famous BMW's, from lederhosen to laptops, the Bavarian economic miracle continues apace, both annoying and attracting the rest of Germany. Of the 16 German states, Bavaria consistently ranks first or second in growth rate and living standards and among the lowest in unemployment. 
 Bavarians do not care how they are perceived. They see themselves as Texans in lederhosen -- more ambitious, more brave, more willing to take risks than the stiff Prussians in Berlin. With a united Germany now at the center of a united Europe, the center of that larger Europe, in their view, is here, not in the old coastal trading centers like Hamburg. 
Italy, Switzerland, Austria, Poland and the Czech Republic are steps away, and pro-business Bavaria has plans. Its state president, Edmund Stoiber, 60, a law-and-order conservative, is the favorite to run against the current German chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, in next fall's elections. Given Germany's rising unemployment and crime, Mr. Stoiber would have a chance to win.
Though Mr. Schroder is more popular than his Social Democratic Party, it is running only a few points ahead of the Christian Democratic Union and its sister party, Mr. Stoiber's Bavaria-based Christian Socialist Union, and that is while those parties are in the midst of a leadership battle.
Angela Merkel, the easterner who is chairwoman of the Christian Democrats, fares badly against Mr. Schroder in polls, but she is resisting Mr. Stoiber's not-so-quiet push to lead the Christian parties into the elections.
The two say they will solve the leadership question between themselves, sometime before spring. But it is Mr. Stoiber -- tall, white-haired, efficient, rigid and bland -- who would benefit most from Germany's malaise. What gives him credibility is the Bavarian model.
"Bavarians really are the Texans of Germany," said Michael Stiller of the Suddeutsche Zeitung, Bavaria's excellent newspaper. "They're very conservative and very rich, with a good economy, high technology and little unemployment. People think, 'We can get work here, we can educate our kids here.' "
Erwin Huber, Mr. Stoiber's deputy, waxes expansive: Bavaria has Germany's lowest unemployment rate, the country's highest growth rate over the last decade, and what he calls "our strong partnership with businessmen and managers, our effort to make a modern network between politics and the economy."
Unemployment in Bavaria is just under 6 percent, compared with an average in Germany of more than 9 percent and an official rate in the former East Germany of 18 percent.
It was not always like this. Before World War II, Bavaria was a rural backwater, pretty for vacations, but with a wretched infrastructure of poor roads and rail connections to the rest of Germany.
"Here it was poor and mountainous, with no connection to the sea, with the Alps to the south, and no natural resources," said Hans-Werner Sinn, director of the IFO Institute, an economic research organization here. "The heart of prewar Germany was in the east."
But after the war, with the division of the conquered nation, ties in Germany went north-south, no longer east-west, a new axis that brought a lot of companies, fleeing the new Communist state occupied by the Soviet Union, to the west.
The lack of old industry -- iron, coal and steel -- was a kind of hidden benefit, forcing Bavaria to concentrate on what was modern, becoming the Silicon Valley of Europe, or at least one of the new high-tech centers.
Politicians here pushed hard for business to come to Bavaria, developing the cozy notion of "Bavarian mercantilism," offering companies a welcoming climate, with financial incentives, good schools, improving infrastructure and help in cutting bureaucratic red tape. A lot of skilled workers came here from the Sudetenland, fleeing postwar Czechoslovakia, and more came, later, from Italy and Turkey. 
Siemens was the most prominent catch, moving from Berlin to Bavaria. Even today, Siemens dominates the scene, making everything from computers to some of the best medical diagnostic instruments in the world. Still, said Mr. Sinn, the economy's real strength here is the thousands of medium-size companies, often privately held by families, each employing 200 to 500 people.
Franz-Josef Strauss, the longtime boss of Bavaria, was a deeply conservative man, a cold warrior. But he was also a kind of economic visionary, trying to create the right climate for economic growth.
He built up one of Europe's best education systems, including fine universities, started a system of "clusters," for associated industries to grow near specialized schools that could train their employees, and spent millions on better roads, rail connections and one of Germany's largest and most modern airports, opened finally in 1992 and named after Mr. Strauss. The airport was criticized for being too large, but is already being expanded.
Mr. Stoiber, Mr. Strauss's longtime deputy, continued the tradition on taking over in 1993, says his own deputy, Mr. Huber. Interviewed here in the elegantly modern state chancellery office built around a fine older building, Mr. Huber is unashamedly a promoter of Mr. Strauss, Mr. Stoiber and all their works.
"This sense of a future with high technology makes a very strong stamp on this land," Mr. Huber said. Mr. Stoiber privatized state companies, raising more than $4.5 billion, which was invested in creating new clusters, where basic research, applied research, entrepreneurial support and venture capital could come together to create jobs.
Mr. Sinn, the economist, said that when he came here 15 years ago, he used to joke about the idea of the Silicon Valley of Europe. "But now I see the success of this strategy," he said.
Bavaria has created a cluster for environmental technology in Augsburg and for medical technology around Nuremberg, and is seeking other areas of supremacy. It is trying to develop a new cluster for biotechnology in and around Martinsried, where a Biotechnology Park is located at the Max Planck Institute of Biochemistry. More than 120 pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies are already there.
But Mr. Stoiber has also added a strong touch of law and order, popular in a Germany with a growing fear of foreigners and crime. The revelation that Hamburg was a center for a cell of Islamic radicals that attacked New York and Washington has brought demands for harsher immigration laws and procedures. Mr. Schroder's government has responded, but the Christian Democrats and Christian Socialists say that the new measures are not tough enough. 
The conservatives intend to try to block the new immigration proposals in the German upper house, where the government does not have a majority, and to make crime an election issue. Mr. Stoiber has also sometimes seemed less than generous about unification, criticizing the huge amounts of aid going to eastern Germany -- a populist issue for many who complain about their taxes -- and urging easterners to work harder.
The medical cluster is a good example of what makes Bavaria work. In Erlangen, near Nuremberg, Siemens dominates the town, where every fifth worker toils in the field of health care, and there is a fine university that helps train potential staff.
"Erlangen became the capital of health care in Germany with the help of the government of Bavaria," said Ulrich E. Kripps, a manager with what is called Siemens Medical Solutions, which specializes in applying computers and information technology to medical equipment. 
The company makes diagnostic imaging equipment, from ultrasound and magnetic resonance scanners to computer-assisted tomography, which can show the action of a beating heart in three dimensions. 
But the biggest problem remains the search for excellent people. "What we need are good computer engineers," Mr. Kripps said. "We need engineers, and we need them from anywhere. We have to be attractive to the best people in the world."
For that task, too, Bavaria is a help, Mr. Kripps said. "Compared to other regions in Germany, there is a real advantage to living here, in the south. People like it here."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE HEALTH THREAT; 
Anthrax Shot Considered For Civilians

BYLINE:  By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 

 BODY:
The government is considering making the anthrax vaccine that is now used by the military available to postal workers and others at high risk of exposure to the deadly bacteria, federal health officials said today.
 Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services, could make a decision on expanded anthrax vaccinations next week, officials said after a forum, arranged by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, on what to do next to prevent inhalation anthrax in people who have already taken antibiotics because of possible exposure. 
 The Defense Department has agreed to turn over 220,000 doses of vaccine to the health department and the Food and Drug Administration has given the disease centers permission to use the vaccine in an experimental treatment program.
Since early October, more than 32,000 persons have been given initial courses of antibiotics to counteract possible infections of anthrax from contaminated mail, officials said. Of these, about 10,000 were advised to continue taking antibiotics for 60 days because they were most likely to have been exposed. Five people have died of inhalation anthrax since the outbreak began. 
Dr. D. A. Henderson, director of the office of public health preparedness at Health and Human Services, said candidates for the vaccine would be those with possible exposure to large amounts of anthrax spores.
"We are concerned with people who may have had a very heavy dose," Dr. Henderson said after the meeting. This group, he said, probably numbers about 3,000.
Once in the body, the spores are believed to germinate into disease-causing bacteria within 60 days. But because antibiotics kill the bacteria, not the spores, there are concerns that some spores might remain after the 60-day treatment and turn deadly, experts said.
Dr. Anthony S. Fauci of the National Institutes of Health said that there was not yet a consensus among health experts on whether to offer an anthrax vaccine to civilians because the antibiotics treatment is considered sufficient. If the vaccine becomes available, patients will have to make their own decision about taking it, he said.
If the vaccine, which previously has been used only by the military and only for protection against a future exposure, becomes available for civilians, its use as a treatment after exposure would be considered experimental and require special informed consent agreements from the patients, said Dr. Katherine Zoon, an official at the Food and Drug Administration. 
Animal-test data suggests that the vaccine should be given in three doses over a month's time, while the patients are getting an additional 30-day course of antibiotics to ward off any potential disease before the vaccine takes effect, experts said at the meeting.
About 2.1 million anthrax vaccine doses have been administered to 521,000 members of the military with few severe adverse effects, experts said. While most reactions are mild, including redness, itching and swelling at the inoculation site, severe allergic reactions have been seen in 1 in 100,000 cases, they said.
Dr. Ivan Walks, health commissioner for the District of Columbia, said any vaccine program should be accompanied by education and communication programs directed at various economic and racial groups. He reminded participants that when antibiotics were recommended early in the crisis, some postal workers voiced concerns that they were not tested and treated as quickly as workers on Capitol Hill who were exposed to anthrax from tainted mail in the offices of senators.
Al Ferranto of the National Association of Letter Carriers also cautioned the policy makers to consider how any vaccine recommendation might affect postal workers, who tend to be older than soldiers, with some having diabetes and other medical problems. He asked health authorities to look at "the big picture," including how a vaccine program might hurt confidence in the postal system.

HEADLINE: The World; 
The Morning After Dawns on Moscow

BYLINE:  By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
UNTIL last week, Russia and its leader were on a roll. In this season of strategic realignment and war against terror, Russia once again became central to American foreign policy and it seemed that one of the big winners was its president, Vladimir V. Putin. Then came President Bush's announcement that the United States was pulling out of theAntiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972.
Now a question arises: In the most interesting game of diplomatic casino in decades, between the son of a former C.I.A. chief and a man who grew up in the K.G.B., who is getting the better of whom?
 After the inferno of Sept. 11, no foreign power acted as swiftly and decisively as Russia to offer intelligence support, air rights and a free hand for United States military forces to fly into bases in Central Asia to conduct their war in Afghanistan. 
 And no one gained from that cooperation more than Mr. Putin. His exposure at Mr. Bush's side in four summit meetings stripped away much of the negative image he had in the West -- as a former K.G.B. officer who had brutalized Chechnya and stifled Moscow's independent news media.
Now, with victory in sight in Afghanistan, President Bush's decision to pull the plug on the ABM treaty, which had come to preoccupy the affairs of the two big nuclear powers, raises the question whether Mr. Bush is moving on from his Russian dalliance. 
If foreign policy was a song, said Toby T. Gati, the Russia specialist who was the State Department's intelligence chief in the Clinton administration, Mr. Bush's actions brought to mind the Paul Simon refrain, "Fifty ways to leave your lover." An aide to Mr. Powell had a similar thought, likening the question on the minds of Russian parliament members who recently met with Mr.Powell to another song: "Will you still love me tomorrow?"
Those Russian legislators did not know that the ABM announcement was coming, but they were already concerned that Mr. Putin's decision to align Russia squarely with the United States, to open the doors of Central Asia to American forces and to renew Russia's embrace of the NATO alliance could backfire -- if it turned out that Mr. Bush was simply "playing" Mr. Putin to win support for American war aims.
That would be rich irony, since some of Mr. Bush's American critics have grumbled for many months that Mr. Putin has been using wiles learned in K.G.B. days to manipulate the American president.
It was, after all, Mr. Bush who said he had looked into Mr. Putin's soul and found a partner to be trusted. And now, in Afghanistan, America was fighting the war against terrorism that Mr. Putin wanted. Russia did not have to contribute a single soldier for the military operations. But it gained immensely from them, stanching the flow of heroin from Afghanistan and cutting the infiltration routes of Islamic militants who have been part of the Chechen rebellion.
For three months, Mr. Putin has cheered America from the sidelines, offering political support at the United Nations and opening for Washington a library of Russian intelligence dossiers on Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda's terror network, which has plagued Russia and Central Asia for years.
"Putin now had the Americans doing his business in Afghanistan and he was fighting to the last American," Ms. Gati said.
When Kabul, the Afghan capital, fell last month, the Russian-backed Northern Alliance was the first to claim the city. Russia's guys had won. A dozen Russian air transports flew in to Kabul even as British and French troops -- hoping to play a role in the security and humanitarian chores of liberation -- were barred from entry by the Northern Alliance and by Gen. Tommy Franks, the American commander.
For Russia, it was clear that America did not want to stay in Central Asia and, therefore, Russia's role there -- as a member of the coalition and a new American partner -- would gain legitimacy even though the whole region's newly independent leaders had spent the last decade straining to keep Moscow at arm's length. Russia was back in the great game, garnering influence and a chance to dominate oil and gas extraction in the region because all roads there -- especially pipeline routes -- lead to Russia.
And there was more. Saudi Arabia's image has been suffering from the discovery that so many of its mosques were infested with bin Laden radicalism. Mr. Putin deftly suggested that Russia -- with its abundant energy resources and pipeline network -- could assume the role of a critical supplier of energy to the West if the Arabian peninsula was convulsed by instability.
But if that was a clear vision of how things looked last week, to many in Moscow it now feels like the morning after.
Mr. Putin's first reaction to the ABM decision was tempered, as Washington had hoped. No hysterical recriminations in public. The decision was a mistake, he said, but it "does not create a threat to the national security of the Russian federation."
Where does that leave Russia now in American foreign policy? Mr. Putin and the political establishment that has been supporting him would certainly like to know.
Ivo Daalder, a Brookings Institution specialist on Russia who served under President Clinton, wonders whether Russian-American relations "can endure and become stronger even with this big blot" on the ledger. Russian cooperation might slowly dry up again in critical areas, like securing Russian nuclear weapons and their radiological innards that many terrorists would like to get their hands on.
"I don't know the answer," Mr. Daalder said, "but I fear the worst."
The reason a number of specialists are thinking so darkly about the long-term impact of Mr. Bush's ABM decision is that the Russians see -- as Americans can see -- that there is an ideological struggle going on within the Bush administration and Russia policy is often the fulcrum of that debate. To some of Mr. Bush's advisers, it is a mistake to give Russia an exalted status; they think it just doesn't deserve it, given its decline and its geopolitical irrelevance in a globalized economy. 
A month ago, Mr. Bush promised Mr. Putin at their meeting in Crawford, Tex., that the United States would welcome Russia into NATO's decision-making councils. But Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld sought to remove from a press statement all references to "NATO at 20" -- the new characterization of 19 NATO members sitting with Russia as an alliance of 20 nations.
Mr. Rumsfeld lost the battle, but his intervention delayed the debate over how to integrate Russia into the alliance. One thing the hard-liners wanted to insure was that Russia would not get to influence next year's round of NATO enlargement, in which as many as nine new nations will enter. 
AT week's end, the White House statement welcoming Mr. Putin's acceptance of the ABM decision was conspicuously void of any reference to Russia's role in Western security and seemed to drive home the new reality that the strategic chips are falling exclusively in America's favor. 
"Raw national interests dictate that other countries" -- including Russia -- "will continue to cooperate with us when it is in their interest to do so," Mr. Daalder pointed out. But in the long run, he said, Russia's disappointment over the ABM treaty could end "the presumption of future cooperation that has been so central to our relations with allies and friends around the world."

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL: INSIDE THE N.B.A.; 
Stern's Look to a Future on Cable TV Will Put NBC in the Past

BYLINE:  By MIKE WISE

 BODY:
It began as a win-win relationship more than a decade ago. David Stern had the players, Dick Ebersol rolled the cameras, and away they went, promoting each other's products until the world started paying attention.
 Together they made lots of money and commercials and guided the National Basketball Association to the pinnacle of popularity. To gauge the league's mass-culture growth since 1990, one need only see the Palestinian youth in the background of a recent CNN report wearing the No. 23 Chicago Bulls jersey. 
 But now they are parting ways. Michael Jordan's second retirement in 1998 did not help. Neither did a contentious lockout that cost the league 32 of its games in the 1998-99 season. 
Ratings initially dipped, then spiraled downward -- a 35 percent drop from the end of the 1997-98 season. NBC was losing an average of $90 million a year on its deal with the N.B.A.
Rivalries developed too slowly to capture the public's imagination. The icons who came after Michael, Magic and Larry were fading as well.
With Shaquille O'Neal and Kobe Bryant fighting off Allen Iverson last June in the N.B.A. finals, the N.B.A. and NBC seemed to be on their way back. Ratings were coming back. But the end was nearing.
Although it will most likely not be official until this week, Stern, the N.B.A. commissioner, and Ebersol, the chairman of NBC Sports, are ending their business partnership, and the league will sign a rights agreement with ABC and ESPN to carry N.B.A. games.
 As the incumbent, NBC was supposed to have an edge over ABC-ESPN, mainly because of Stern and Ebersol's 12-year association. Also, the idea of multiple cable networks competing for viewers and advertising dollars was not supposed to be a viable alternative for the N.B.A. when negotiations began. But in a depressed economy -- some of which was caused by the Sept. 11 tragedies -- Stern gambled. 
Beyond the deal with ABC-ESPN, he entered into an agreement with AOL Time Warner that would allow the league to create its own channel with the company. AOL Time Warner is the parent company of Turner Sports, which holds the cable part of the league's television package.
More than 100 games would be shown on the new channel, which would probably replace the AOL-owned CNN/SI. Some games would remain on TNT. 
As the most forward-thinking businessman among sports commissioners, Stern has made an asset play for his owners. Given that the N.B.A. already owns a store and a restaurant, a channel televising its games seems a logical progression. 
Rather than only a rights-fee agreement, Stern's newest deal becomes a business-building venture for his owners.
Selling the AOL network deal to fans may initially be tough, especially the ones who do not get CNN/SI. But the league could make an argument that the prior agreement had almost overexposed the N.B.A. the past two seasons. That is why Ebersol began eliminating Saturday games on NBC this season.
And as a property, the N.B.A. will probably do better on ESPN, the recognized sports leader in the cable industry.
"The N.B.A. is operating right now in a severely depressed economy," said Neil Pilson, the former head of CBS Sports and now an industry analyst. "If they can maintain their current level of income, with the significant drop in revenue stream from TV rights fees, that's a significant achievement. If on top of that they can generate a growth in the asset value of a property like AOL Sports, the Basketball Channel, or whatever they call it, that is a major growth opportunity at a time when the economy is quite depressed."
NBC has now lost the National Football League, Major League Baseball and the N.B.A. within a span of a few years. Ebersol could no longer hold on to the network's last jewel. It was no longer valuable enough.
"They certainly have given that impression that they're close personally and professionally," Pilson said of Stern and Ebersol. "But David's obligation is to his owners and Dick's obligation is to his shareholders. If the gap was too great, then NBC was going to have to let it go. Especially if you're talking about anticipated lost dollars."
More than anything, the economy and the declining interest in the league broke them up.

Bedtime for Van Gundy
 A week after Jeff Van Gundy's surprising resignation as coach of the Knicks, conspiracy theories are still running amok.
While the unemployed coach continues his Christmas shopping, here's a quick attempt to debunk at least a few of the rumors.
 Will Van Gundy end up in Miami with Pat Riley?
No. Stan Van Gundy, Jeff's brother, has all but been promised the head coaching job when Riley steps down. Only if Stan moved to another team would his brother consider moving south.
Portland would be a shoo-in for Van Gundy if Maurice Cheeks faltered after one season. Talented roster. Paul Allen's money. All in all, a good fit.
But Philadelphia would make more sense if Larry Brown stepped down after this season. It might be easier to take the 76ers back to the finals than ever getting the beleaguered Trail Blazers there.
Don't rule out Golden State, where Dave Cowens was fired yesterday. The Warriors are big and young, and moving Antawn Jamison could bring back another potential All-Star. Also, compared to the intense scrutiny in New York, you can almost coach under the radar in the Bay Area.
 Was there a secret pact with another team that made Van Gundy leave as much as $8 million on the table by walking away from the Knicks?
Again, no. First off, Van Gundy is not very good with a fax machine or with e-mail messages. Second, he understands that he will get another job in due time.
Did Van Gundy leave because of his utter frustration with Knicks management?
Yes, partly. He understood that the Knicks were further from winning a title today than they were when he took the job, that they simply had no real inside presence to advance in the playoffs.
And, yes, he would have liked a contract extension after the team denied him permission to talk to Portland about its coaching vacancy last summer.
Most of all, Van Gundy was so beaten down by his job that not even winning provided solace anymore. Like many people, he wanted to decompress, take a sabbatical and be with his family. And he had the financial wherewithal to do it. 
That he should be ridiculed for such a decision -- quitter was the word used most by several fans and journalists last week -- tells you more about his detractors than about Van Gundy.
 What is it about coaches and athletes leaving New York before New York leaves them that makes the town turn into a scorned lover? It is so provincial to knock people for wanting to leave the fish-bowl existence, the fish bowl they have given every amount of their passion and energy to.
Van Gundy could not possibly find more quality of life elsewhere? When was the last time an organization asked a coach it was thinking about firing if he wanted to finish out his deal? It works both ways. 
Van Gundy has 37 N.B.A. playoff victories at age 39. He ranks third in coaching victories in Knicks history. He had to do his job in a much more critical environment than Joe Lapchick or Red Holzman. He has a better postseason winning percentage than George Karl or Don Nelson. He worked hard and won much more than he lost. Enough already. Let him sleep.

Issel at Center of Controversy
The pressure is starting to subside for Dan Issel, and it looks as if he will keep his job.
On Thursday, Hispanic groups launched a boycott of the team, demanding that Issel be replaced as coach after he shouted an insensitive ethnic remark and a profanity at a Hispanic fan in the crowd. After Issel apologized to a group of Hispanic leaders Friday, the boycott was dropped.
Issel has been suspended for four games by the Nuggets, but many people feel his actions deserve a stronger punishment. The League of United Latin American Citizens, based in Washington, said Issel should resign.
As Issel walked off the court after a 99-96 loss to the Charlotte Hornets on Tuesday night, he went back and forth with a fan in the stands. He was caught on camera exclaiming, "Go drink another beer, you Mexican. . . ." He added an expletive at the end of the sentence. 
Issel, openly weeping during a news conference the next day, apologized to the team, the community and the fan. His suspension will cost him $112,000.
Issel's supporters have rallied around the coach. They do not want one ugly moment to stain his reputation forever.
"Everyone in the locker room knows Dan the man, and he is not a racist," Nuggets forward George McCloud said. "It was a situation where his emotions were running, frustrated by the fact we are losing."
Dialogue between the team and the Hispanic organizations may help bring about a resolution that could save Issel's job. But even if that happens, it should not mask recent history. 
While coaching the Nets, John Calipari was fined $25,000 by the league and reprimanded by the team for referring to a Hispanic reporter covering the team as "a Mexican idiot." 
Long after the incident, players and team officials joked among themselves about Calipari's comment, the idea being that it was almost O.K. to poke fun at the reporter because of his ethnicity.
But no one dares to use derogatory language in regard to any white or black player's ethnicity. That is off limits. The same double standard exists with the use of Indian mascots. Somehow, Redskins is still acceptable in our culture. Imagine the outcry if the team were named the Washington Blackskins. 
Should Issel have lost his job? Without a pattern of racial insensitivity over time, probably not. 
And the proximity of N.B.A. fans to the action contributes to such ugly altercations. Simply, enraged people can get closer to players and coaches in pro basketball than they can in any other major sport during an event.
But like many basketball lifers who see only black and white, Issel could do well to stay away from derogatory remarks about other ethnic groups who are barely represented in the N.B.A.

HEADLINE: Economy & Business; 
A New Sense of Urgency in Debating the Future of Airlines

BYLINE:  By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Long before Sept. 11, many executives, analysts and consultants were convinced that the airline industry had fundamental problems. Even in the best years, returns lagged those of other industries. And recently, with profits slim to nonexistent, the calls for better service, cheaper fares, more public accountability and tighter security have grown louder and louder.
 Now, after the attacks, which presented the biggest commercial threat to the airlines in aviation history, the question of the industry's future has taken on new urgency. 
 The events would appear to strengthen the hand of those who argue that the industry will never satisfy passengers and investors until it is concentrated among fewer, more profitable companies. But whether significant change will occur in the next year is an open question.
Even some of the most vocal proponents of consolidation say it is no panacea. Furthermore, powerful forces, notably labor unions and lawmakers eager to appeal to consumers or support their hometown airlines, strongly oppose it. The new board overseeing the $10 billion loan guarantee program passed by Congress 10 days after the attacks has the power to remake the industry, but it could also end up insulating it from market forces.
"The business model of the existing companies is just flat-out broken," Kevin Murphy, the aviation analyst at Morgan Stanley, said. It is a mantra that he and others in the industry have been chanting for years.
In January, Mr. Murphy issued a joint study with the consulting firm Stern Stewart that concluded that the airline industry had created little wealth and had not earned a return exceeding its cost of capital for most of the years since the industry was deregulated in 1978.
From 1997 to 2001, the industry generated a return on capital lower than the average of the companies that make up the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, even though the industry reported record profits in three of the four years. Another steep down cycle began this year and has accelerated with the decline in passenger traffic after the September hijackings. Industry losses this year could reach $10 billion.
Mr. Murphy's conclusion is that airlines are unlikely to generate acceptable returns until there are more mergers, acquisitions and cross-border ownership, which is now restricted by laws that prevent foreign control of domestic carriers.
Fewer airlines, proponents argue, would increase efficiency by letting the survivors extend their networks, make better use of management expertise and, most important, eliminate overcapacity so airlines could raise fares. Of course, there would be less competition, Mr. Murphy said, but airlines need to earn a better return to attract more capital, and in turn passengers will benefit through better service.
But opponents of consolidation argue that it would not solve the industry's problem. "If the industry can't earn its cost of capital unconsolidated, it won't earn it after consolidation," said Michael E. Levine, a former airline executive who now teaches at Harvard Law School.
He argues that fewer, larger airlines would simply increase the leverage of the industry's already powerful unions, enabling them to siphon off any higher profits in the form of higher wages and benefits.
In addition, high concentration in a network business like the airlines would hinder competition because the more extensive route networks of the one or two top airlines would tend to attract a larger proportion of the traveling public.
This was one of the dangers, critics said, posed by the agreement earlier this year between United Airlines and American Airlines to divide up the assets of US Airways, creating two mega-carriers that together would have controlled half the market.
"Nobody knows how many competitive airline networks are needed," Mr. Levine said. "But it is better to have four or five partially complete airline networks competing with one another rather than two complete networks."
The Justice Department's antitrust division appeared to make the consolidation debate a moot point last summer when it blocked United's $4.3 billion bid for US Airways, calling it anticompetitive.
But Sept. 11 renewed the speculation about mergers. Some experts argue that the industry is in such trouble that deals could be approved under a provision of the antitrust laws that gives preference to companies that would go out of business if they were not bought by competitors.
The Air Transportation Stabilization Board, which was created by Congress to decide which airlines would receive some of the $10 billion in loan guarantees, has the power to compel airlines to merge if they want access to credit.
If cash aid and loans can keep airlines flying until ticket sales return to normal, the structure of the industry will probably not change much. But that may be a tall order.
The best course, according to Darryl Jenkins, the director of the Aviation Institute at George Washington University, would be for weak carriers to fade away. Airline mergers, he wrote recently, "raise costs above any potential expected benefits" because integrating healthy carriers is disruptive.
"Sept. 11 has speeded up what was looming: the need to restructure and reduce costs," he added. "Mergers will move the industry in the wrong direction."

HEADLINE: International Business; 
Falling Trade Barriers Will Pose a Challenge For China's Economy

BYLINE:  By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI 

 BODY:
Its restaurants are full, its airplanes are packed and its always volatile stock market is looking remarkably steady. While much of the world skids toward economic recession, China is showing off to the world the upside of a still largely closed and tightly controlled economy.
 That economy -- the gross domestic product already ranks sixth in the world, according to the World Bank -- is on track to expand by more than 7 percent this year and is not likely to slow much in 2002. In contrast, the United States, Japan and Europe are expected to experience this year their first collective contraction since the oil price shock of the mid-1970's, with little likelihood of a recovery before the second half of 2002. 
 China has been able to defy economic gravity thanks largely to two phenomena: foreign exchange controls that prevent money pumped into the economy from leaking out, and the benefit of a continental economy with a consumer market big enough to potentially drive growth on its own.
A far bigger challenge to China than a global slowdown is the country's membership in the World Trade Organization, which took effect last Tuesday. Trade barriers will begin to fall next year, setting off a multinational rush to grab a piece of China's promising market of 1.3 billion people.
That is expected to send the country's imports surging, surpassing the growth of its exports and eroding the country's enviable trade surplus, which widened to $3.9 billion in October, bringing its 10-month trade surplus to $17.3 billion.
Yet, while W.T.O. membership will widen access to its market, the country is certain to guard its economy and find ways to protect domestic sectors whose survival is threatened by foreign competition. Already, new rules on the import of genetically modified crops briefly disrupted American soybean imports, until recently the country's highest-volume agricultural import.
The country's export growth will most certainly take a hit from a drop in consumer spending in the United States, Chinese government economists say. But China's export growth was already shrinking before the Sept. 11 attacks, and exports to the United States, its second-largest trading partner after Japan, account for only about 9 percent of China's gross domestic product. Other big trading partners include the European Union and Southeast Asia. Trade is growing, but the rate is slowing.
China has been deliberately weaning its economy off what had been a growing dependence on exports ever since the Asian export glut of the late 1990's crippled other export-dependent economies in the region. In 2000 exports totaled $249.21 billion, the Chinese government reported, or nearly a quarter of the $1.077 trillion gross domestic product. Economists inside and outside China predict that export growth will drop to around 5 percent this year, down from 28 percent in 2000.
In 1998, Beijing began spending heavily to keep economic growth from shrinking as economies around Asia tipped into recession. It has not stopped: this year, even more government spending will pour into public work projects, like roads, dams and high-voltage electrical lines that will light previously darkened villages. The country borrowed $18 billion through the sale of special stimulus bonds this year to help keep the economy growing and Finance Minister Xiang Huaicheng has promised to issue the same amount next year.
Beijing has also worked mightily to get China's people to spend more money. One of the most visible strategies has been to extend the country's most important holidays to a full week each. The efforts have gradually had the desired effect: consumer spending has steadily increased, retail sales are on the rise and a long battle with deflation appears to be ending in apparent victory. Retail sales rose about 10 percent in the first 10 months of the year, and most economists expect consumer prices, which were falling in the late 1990's, to edge up about 1 percent annually this year and next.
Western analysts estimate that China's domestic consumer spending will rise 9 percent or more this year from 2000, roughly two percentage points more than G.D.P. growth for the year, far stronger than most of the world's economies.
Unlike many other economies around the world, China's vast economy barely registered a tremor from the Sept. 11 attacks.
First of all, most Chinese feel more secure today than they have at any point in their lives. China is now entering its third decade of shifting from a centrally planned to a market-driven economy. During that time the economy has grown swiftly and steadily and China has had its longest stretch of social stability in a century, excepting the demonstrations and their bloody suppression in the summer of 1989.
While Beijing is criticized abroad for its repressive security apparatus and human rights abuses, few Chinese feel oppressed by their government. Most support the government's strong-arm tactics as necessary for maintaining order, and feel immune from the sort of terrorist attacks that have rattled confidence in the United States.
Nor are the attacks likely to weaken capital flows here. With China joining the W.T.O., its strong economic growth and vast consumer market make it one of the few targets for investment on embattled American executives' radar screens.
"Multinational corporations are consolidating their operations at home and moving to China," said Andy Xie, an economist at Morgan Stanley in Hong Kong. "Sept. 11 accelerates this trend."
Motorola has said it will invest $6.6 billion in China in the next five years at a time when demand for telecomunications gear in Europe and the United States has slackened. Ericsson of Sweden said earlier this month that it would create thousands of jobs in China and triple exports from the country by 2005, even as it trims jobs elsewhere.
The most obvious impact that China is likely to see from the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks, barring a global recession (which it still might be able to spend its way through), is a measurably higher fiscal deficit as it spends to make up for slowing export growth. Beijing expects to run a record 260 billion yuan ($31.4 billion) budget deficit this year, equal to 2.6 percent of G.D.P., up from 0.8 percent in 1997.
