HEADLINE: Emergency Medicaid 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "States Calling for More Help With Medicaid" (news article, Dec. 10): In New York, there have been more than 100,000 new Medicaid applicants since the state began its disaster-relief Medicaid program after the events of Sept. 11. This dramatic response brings to the fore a significant problem: the many people in need of health coverage but not enrolled in programs. 
 Disaster-relief Medicaid is an example of the government's responding quickly and appropriately to a crisis by streamlining the Medicaid application process and the eligibility requirements. Keeping people uninsured is poor fiscal policy, as they tend to come in for treatment at a later stage of illness, adding to the cost of medical care. Enrolling people in health coverage is the fiscal equivalent of preventive health, benefiting not just the uninsured but also hospitals and taxpayers.

DAVID JONES
President, Community Service
Society of New York
New York, Dec. 13, 2001

HEADLINE: International Business; 
With the U.S. Economy Slumping, Canada and Mexico Are Reeling

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
While the slowdown in the United States has roiled all national economies, no countries were hit earlier or harder than the two that are closest to and most thoroughly integrated with the American economy -- Canada and Mexico.
 As partners with the United States in the North American Free Trade Agreement, Canada and Mexico -- both heavily reliant on exports -- now trade more with the United States than do any other nations. Each sends more than 85 percent of its exports to the United States, and gets a similar percentage of its imports from the United States. But when Americans stop buying, that mighty stream -- which once totaled more than $2 billion a day -- dries up, stranding many businesses and tens of thousands of workers. 
 What these two neighbors are learning is a hard lesson in economic realpolitik: grow with America, go slow with America. Their dependence on the economic engine of the United States -- which kept their own economies humming during the American expansion -- is so complete that they are now essentially powerless to do much but wait for the United States economy to get going again. 
"This is the price both countries are paying for their close integration with the United States," said Riordan Roett, director of the Western Hemisphere Program at the Paul H. Nitze School of Advanced International Studies at Johns Hopkins University. "They benefit greatly when the United States grows, but when there is a downturn they feel the social and economic consequences immediately."
Since the United States economy exerts such a pull on the global market, watching close neighbors like Canada and Mexico can give some sense of what will happen elsewhere. In that sense, the two nations resemble canaries in a mine shaft, early warning systems of shrinking markets for other economies around the world that trade with the United States.
Economists and government officials in Canada and Mexico expect to see the American economy begin to turn around no later than the second half of 2002. Although the recovery is not expected to bring a sudden repeat of the boom years of the late 1990's, the expected increase in American economic activity is considered sufficient stimulus to make substantial improvements in the financial pictures across the northern and southern borders.
Economists expect there will be a slight lag -- three months or so -- between the beginning of a recovery in the United States and a corresponding turnaround in economic activities across the borders. However, the picture could be complicated by factors unique to each country.
In Canada, a bitter dispute over lumber exports to the United States is having a serious economic impact throughout western Canada. Tourism and the weak Canadian dollar will also be watched carefully as 2002 begins.
In Mexico, a continued slump in oil prices could complicate the country's recovery. If President Vicente Fox is able to push through a tax restructuring, it will go a long way toward setting the tone of Mexico's economic comeback. The change had been widely anticipated when Mr. Fox took office a year ago, but was ultimately tied up by a recalcitrant Mexican Congress. Now he is ready to try again.
Surveying North America's prospects for 2002, Roger M. Kubarych, an adjunct senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations and senior economic adviser for HVB Americas, a part of the large German bank group HypoVereinsbank, is worried about the slowdown in industrial production, which began in the United States last year and is spreading north and south.
For Mexico, the impact will be severe. As the country recovered from the peso crisis of 1994-1995, the industrial sector led the way, pumping out car radios, clothing and other goods to such an extent that exports to the United States have soared 175 percent since 1994, the year Nafta went into effect.
Over the years Canada, too, has grown increasingly linked to American industry. Many large international companies, led by the Big Three auto manufacturers, have reorganized their North American operations into separate divisions, neither foreign nor domestic.
Given such complete integration, "times are tough for manufacturers North America-wide," Mr. Kubarych said.
Canada still has a big inventory of industrial goods that will carry over to 2002. As companies stop production to sell warehoused goods, unemployment -- at 4.7 percent this year -- could rise to about 6.1 percent in 2002, according to economists at J. P. Morgan Chase.
Canada will also have to deal with a low currency exchange rate. Although the Canadian dollar has edged up from a record low of 62.4 United States cents reached on Nov. 9, it is far below historic levels. And Canada will struggle to overcome devastating cutbacks in high-technology manufacturing, a field that had become one of the country's most important sources of new jobs. High-technology giants like Nortel Networks, a Canadian company, and JDS Uniphase, which has sizable operations in Canada, cut thousands of jobs in 2001 as sales of telecommunications equipment slumped badly. With business down, many investors turned their backs on the companies, and stock prices plunged.
"Canada bought into the notion that high tech is the future," Mr. Kubarych said. "So the decline in high tech is particularly bad for Canada." However, he said, the worst may be past.
A recent poll of Canadian chief executives showed an emerging optimism. Just over half of those surveyed by Compas Inc., a Canadian polling company, predicted that the country's economy would do better in the coming six months. Just a month earlier, in October, only 36 percent of chief executives held that view.
George D. Vasic, chief economist of UBS Warburg in Toronto, said there were several reasons for optimism in Canada. A program of tax cuts for 2002, approved in 2001, could help buoy the economy, he said, provided the downturn does not last too long. Interest rates have dropped steadily, although they remain above rates in the United States. The government forecast for 2002 is for 1.5 percent growth in gross domestic product, about the same as this year.
Beyond that, Mr. Vasic said, what had once seemed to be intimidating aspects of the coming year have been ameliorated. A tightening of the border after Sept. 11 seemed to presage a slowdown in the transfer of goods, but a report in November by Statistics Canada, the government's central statistical agency, did not find any impact on economic activity caused by delays at the border. To make sure border traffic keeps flowing, Ottawa has earmarked over $300 million for bridges, roads and new security technology.
And while it seemed for a while that the terrorist attacks would cut into Canada's tourism revenues by making people afraid to fly, it now seems that Canada might actually benefit because Americans can drive to Canadian vacation destinations.
Tourism is important to Mexico, too. On a visit to New York in November, Guillermo Ortiz, the governor of Mexico's central bank, said tourism revenues would decline over all even if many American tourists choose to drive across the border into Northern Mexico because many of Mexico's largest and most profitable tourist destinations are far from the border.
The weakened economy in the United States will mean decreased Mexican exports, less direct foreign investment and delays in the start of important new manufacturing projects, Mr. Ortiz said.
Mr. Ortiz expects the United States economy to recover in the second half of 2002, with Mexico following close behind. Mexico will grow at a 1.5 percent rate in 2002, he said, but he acknowledged that his estimates were based on a price of $19 a barrel for Mexican crude oil by the end of 2001 and $16 to $17 a barrel for 2002, which most experts say is several dollars too high.
Though petroleum revenues remain an important part of the Mexican government's income, oil represents less than 10 percent of Mexico's exports. Even a drastic decline in oil prices is not expected to cause the kind of severe problems that occurred in the 1970's and 1980's, when the Mexican economy was dominated by oil.
With the peso relatively stable and with foreign banks acquiring several Mexican banks to give the industry a firmer footing, the country is in much better shape to withstand economic uncertainties than at any time in the past. Many economists think that even a complete collapse in Argentina would not hurt Mexico severely.
"Mexico would have to live with a higher cost of capital than would be the case if Argentina's problems were resolved more smoothly," said Michael Gavin, executive director of emerging market research for UBS Warburg. "But Mexico is fundamentally a pretty solid story."

HEADLINE: Economy & Business; 
A Bruised Economy Leaves Everyone Guessing

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
THE last two years have made spectacularly clear what the legacy of the decade-long economic expansion will not be. The coming year should go a long way toward determining what its legacy really will be.
 The boom did not rewrite the rules for valuing stocks, as many investors had thought less than two years ago. It did not promise a future without recessions, as many boosters were still predicting a year ago. It did not even herald the start of a new era of government surpluses, as nearly all analysts had expected earlier this year. 
 But for all of its now-apparent excesses, and for all of the hangovers those excesses have caused, the 1990's boom still has a solid claim on being the most important, broad-based expansion in 30 years. The question that now hangs over the $10 trillion United States economy is whether the 90's brought prosperity by anticipating the riches that the future would hold or simply by borrowing against that future. 
For now, even nine months into the first recession in a decade, the nation looks quite different than it did before the long boom. A 25-year period in which workers' raises were all but erased by inflation has ended. Companies are making leaps of efficiency they had not been able to make for decades.
Although the downturn and the terrorist attacks have recently shaken Americans' confidence, they remain far more optimistic than they were for most of the 1970's and 1980's. Few people express envy today for other countries' economic systems, in clear contrast to the public discussion about Japan and Europe in past decades.
This would be a towering legacy. Whether it proves to be less fleeting than the notion that the business cycle had been repealed depends on the way that the country emerges from the current recession.
A return to strong, sustainable growth by the end of 2002 would suggest that the digital revolution, along with a handful of other changes, truly did alter American business, making it far more productive and allowing it to increase its profits and its workers' wages at the same time. A deep recession -- or, more likely, a slow recovery that remains uneven for years -- would confirm fears that the Roaring 90's depended on a stock market bubble and an explosion of debt for much of its glory.
"When you introduce important changes, any kind of complicated system like our economy is very likely to go through these periods of surges and enthusiasm and then disappointment," said Robert Hall, a Stanford University economist and the chairman of a committee considered the official arbiter of when recessions begin and end.
"In a year or two, we'll know a lot more" about whether the enthusiasm or the disappointment will prevail, Mr. Hall added.
In many ways, the picture is brighter than it was immediately after Sept. 11. New security measures do not seem to have damaged the efficiency of companies significantly. Lower energy prices and interest rates have left consumers and executives with cash to spend.
All of this has reduced the chances that the current downturn will stretch well into 2002 and rival the 16-month recession of 1973-75 as the longest since World War II.
The biggest issue, however, is not when the recovery will begin. It is whether the robust growth of the late 90's and 2000 was an aberration or the new norm.
On this question, there are strong indications that more disappointment is still in store for the nation.
Most immediately, unemployment is almost certain to rise for much of 2002. In recessions, companies usually continue to cut their costs, including their payrolls, until they are certain that revenues are growing at a healthy rate again.
By the time each recession of the last four decades had run its course, the number of jobs fell 1.4 percent to as much as 3 percent, relative to its peak. Through November of this year, the drop was less than 1 percent -- suggesting that the United States could lose another 600,000 jobs, or more, next year. That would make the days of 4 percent unemployment -- the norm in the late 90's -- feel far away.
Of course, for all the pain that they bring, layoffs are a part of every downturn. Many economists say that the United States has prospered in part because it allows companies to get rid of workers with ease, making businesses both efficient and readily willing to hire new workers.
"The United States has been extremely pragmatic and extremely aggressive," said Craig R. Barrett, the chief executive of Intel, adding that relatively low trade barriers have similarly forced American companies to become more competitive.
But there are reasons to worry that the job market could remain weak for months, much as it did in the early 1990's. This time, a big cause would be the same boom in corporate investment -- much of it in new technology -- that was a centerpiece of the long expansion.
By themselves, those investments created hundreds of thousands of new jobs for people to build semiconductors, computers, engines and warehouses. The investments also made their owners more productive, letting them increase profits and expand.
Those profits, along with a dose of exuberance that was at least partly irrational, sent the Dow Jones industrial average from less than 3,000 when the expansion began to 11,750 at its peak two years ago and still more than 9,800 today. With more money in both their retirement accounts and their paychecks, consumers kept buying new products, and companies responded by making yet more investments.
In the last year, however, it became obvious that they bought more equipment than they could profitably use. In other words, the nation inadvertently borrowed against future economic growth by creating jobs and opening factories it was not yet ready for.
"We really had a capital investment bubble," said William S. Stavropoulos, the chairman of Dow Chemical. "The overhang is unbelievable."
The payback will continue into 2002. American industrial companies are now using less of their capacity than they have at any point in almost two decades -- only about 75 percent in recent months, down from 83 percent early last year. Many high-technology industries are making fewer products, relative to the amount of the machinery they own, than they have since the government began keeping capacity statistics in the 1940's.
"People saw the benefits of e-commerce and digitization, but it became a race in which you didn't want to be left out," said Robert L. Nardelli, the chief executive of Home Depot.
The spending binge that both businesses and consumers went on means that there is unlikely to be the pent-up demand that usually greets the end of a recession. There are not a huge number of companies that need new equipment but simply cannot afford it. The country is not filled with households that have held onto an old dishwasher or car for months and will quickly buy a new one as soon as their optimism returns.
This dearth of demand threatens to undercut the aspect of the 90's boom that affected more Americans than any other. From the mid-70's to the mid-90's, median family income remained stuck at around $45,000, adjusted backward for inflation, according to the Economic Policy Institute. The value of benefits increased over the same period, but so did the number of hours a typical family worked, as wives increasingly took jobs outside the home. Many people were working harder simply to maintain their standard of living.
That changed in the second half of the 90's, as brisk demand sent the unemployment rate to its lowest level in 30 years. Median family income leaped to almost $51,000 -- giving it roughly the same gain in the last five years of the 90's as in the previous quarter-century.
The good old days of the 1960's, when wages last rose at a healthy clip, seemed to have returned. "For the first time in decades," said Jared Bernstein, an economist at the Economic Policy Institute, "you had employers chasing workers, rather than the other way around."
Mirroring the rise in incomes, many social ills -- poverty, crime, pregnancy among teenagers -- declined, and the government decided it could tighten welfare benefits without worrying that many thousands of people would become homeless. The current downturn has the potential to reverse these gains after the safety net has been weakened -- or to solidify the gains, proving the broad improvement in living standards to be more lasting than dot-com mania.
One deciding factor will be the rate of increase in productivity -- what the average worker accomplishes in an hour. When productivity is rising rapidly, living standards improve, and wages and profits can increase without setting off inflation.
In the late 1990's, productivity growth accelerated to about 2.5 percent a year, after more than two decades of averaging less than 1.5 percent. That may sound insignificant, but a percentage-point increase in productivity would translate into almost $3 trillion of additional growth for the $10 trillion United States economy over the next 20 years.
In fact, the recent jump in productivity convinced the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, that he and his colleagues could keep interest rates low, even as the unemployment rate fell and economic theory suggested inflation would accelerate. He was right. Inflation remained mild, and millions of workers benefited from new jobs and higher pay. The experience is one of the decade's most significant legacies for future policy makers.
There is no magic-bullet theory that explains the recent rise in productivity, but most analysts agree that technology played a crucial role. They also say that the recent growth rate is unsustainable.
"There were factors at work that will not continue for the next four or five years," said William Lewis, the director of a research institute at McKinsey & Company, the consulting firm, who oversaw a recent productivity study.
For example, the bull market made financial service companies more productive, according to the government's data, because they were making much higher profits, Mr. Lewis said. The rise in stocks also caused many consumers to buy higher-priced items, making retailers appear more efficient.
Once these one-time effects recede, the Internet will take its place alongside the airplane and Interstate highways as just one of many reasons productivity continues to rise.
"The notion that it was significant is true," Robert E. Rubin, the former Treasury secretary and now an executive at Citigroup, said of the new technology. "The notion that it was dramatically different than other developments over the last century is not sensible."
Based on this popular view, the productivity rate should settle somewhere between its recent average and the average of the two decades before 1995. That will set the stage for a struggle in the next few years between the lingering effects of the millennial bubble and the underlying strength of the new economy.
The outcome will shape nearly every aspect of the American economy.
If the current recession turns out to be merely an average one, said Douglas M. Steenland, the president of Northwest Airlines, "then the 1990's boom warrants historic status."
"If it lasts longer than the normal downturn," he added, "the 1990's boom is likely to be just a footnote."

HEADLINE: Economy & Business; 
New York, Badly Battered but Stronger Than in the 1970's

BYLINE:  By AMY CORTESE 

 BODY:
It probably came as no surprise to most New Yorkers that the nation had officially slipped into a recession by spring, or that the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 knocked the wobbly legs out from under an already shaky economy.
 From Wall Street to Kew Gardens, the pain has been palpable. Just as nearly every resident of the city and surrounding area knew someone who lost a life in the World Trade Center, most know someone who has been directly affected by its economic aftermath -- dislocations, pay cuts, job losses. 
 That giant sucking sound? It is the gasp of collective belt-tightening across the five boroughs. Statistics confirm the anecdotes. New York City lost 44,200 jobs just in October, the New York State Labor Department said. It could lose 50,000 more by mid-2002. 
Economists and accountants have tried to tally the damage stemming from the attack, and though their figures do not always match, the costs are undeniably substantial. In addition to the physical damage and cleanup expenses estimated at $30 billion, the attacks could cost New York City some $20 billion in lost economic activity like retail sales and tourism services this year and $10 billion more next year, according to Economy.com, a research firm based in West Chester, Pa.
The $20 billion pledged by the federal government in emergency aid and billions more in insurance payments will help offset those costs, though only about half the federal assistance has actually been appropriated. A sharp falloff in tax revenue, however, will leave the state and city with yawning budget gaps not seen since the early 1990's. The city alone projects a shortfall of $1.3 billion next year and $3.6 billion in 2003.
That will keep New York's prospects dim even if the national economy emerges from recession, as economists predict it will in the second half of 2002. New York, they said, will endure a deeper and more protracted downturn than the rest of the country will feel. The gross city product, a measure of the city's economic output, declined 1.6 percent in the third quarter, compared with a 0.4 percent fall for the nation as a whole.
Some economists compare the situation in New York to that of cities hit by natural disasters, like Hurricane Andrew in 1992 or the earthquake in Kobe, Japan, in 1995. Initial slumps were followed by building booms that led revived economies, said Stephen Kagann, chief economist for Gov. George E. Pataki's office.
New York, however, will not be helped by a building boom, he said. Rebuilding the World Trade Center, as huge as such a project would be, is unlikely to have a significant impact on the economy, Mr. Kagann said. The original construction had 3,500 jobs at its peak, with maybe 1,500 more ancillary jobs created -- together, only 0.2 percent of all jobs in the region. "The city's economy is simply too large for rebuilding to be a significant boost," he said.
If New York's situation is worse than previous American disasters, it is at least brighter than the economic trough New York dug itself into in the 1970's. That fiscal crisis, with sky-high unemployment, crime and energy costs, pushed the city to the brink of bankruptcy. New York is certainly better positioned today than it was 25 years ago -- energy costs and unemployment rates are relatively low, for example, and the city is better managed.
Still, some city officials warn that the circumstances today are in many ways just as grim. Sharply lower tax revenue will require deep budget cuts, and some fear a return to high crime and fewer services.
New York's economy is more diversified today than it was in the 1970's, when manufacturing accounted for 18 percent of jobs. But it still relies heavily on financial services -- banks, brokerage firms and insurers generate 24 percent of New York City's economic output and 14 percent of the city's tax revenue, according to the New York City Partnership, a business group.
More than 11 percent of the city's jobs in October were in financial services. That is down from a peak of 14 percent in 1987, according to Economy.com, but because those jobs pay so well, financial services accounted for almost 30 percent of all income in the metropolitan area in 1999, the latest data available. From 1992 to 2000, Wall Street alone was responsible for 39 percent of the growth in business and personal income tax for the city.
"What happens in financial services largely determines what happens to the New York economy," said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Economy.com.
What is happening in financial services is not encouraging. With stock markets plunging and public offerings drying up, bonuses for Wall Street professionals are expected to be down as much as 60 percent from record levels last year. Many financial firms had announced layoffs even before the terrorist attacks, but Sept. 11, said Mr. Zandi, "opened the floodgates." In October alone, the industry shed 24,800 jobs, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
New York's other big employers -- retailers, travel and tourism companies and business services like publishing -- have also been hurt. The $34 billion travel and tourism industry could lose $7 billion to $13 billion in revenue by the end of 2003 and eliminate 25,000 jobs this year, according to the New York City Partnership.
Hotel occupancy rates fell from 80 percent before the attacks to as low as 30 percent after Sept. 11, said Economy.com, though they have since recovered somewhat. New York City retailers could lose $4 billion to $5 billion in sales in the 12 months after the attack, the partnership said.
Even with a speedy recovery for the national economy and a swift end to the war in Afghanistan, the New York City Independent Budget Office expects the city's economic growth to decline 0.6 percent this year and 1.8 percent in 2002. A slow national recovery and a prolonged war could lead the local economy to shrink 0.8 percent this year and as much as 5 percent in 2002.
Over the long term, the biggest issue facing the city is persuading businesses to stay in New York. Transportation disruptions and added security made the city, which had already ranked No. 1 nationally in relative business costs, even more expensive.
City officials -- led by Michael R. Bloomberg, who will succeed Rudolph W. Giuliani as mayor next month -- have told federal officials that their aid is needed quickly to begin restoring transportation services and rebuilding Lower Manhattan to entice companies to stay.
"It's not like we're going to turn into Tombstone, Ariz., overnight," said Lawrence J. White, professor of economics at the Stern School of Business at New York University. "But if New York is perceived as a riskier and costlier place to do business, that is going to have an effect."

HEADLINE: Economy & Business; 
Insurers' Outlook (Unexpectedly) Good, Despite Big Claims

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
This has been a terrible year for the commercial insurance business. Yet the insurers say it is hard to remember a time when prospects looked better.
 Prices for coverage are soaring and are likely to keep rising in 2002. After that, many insurance executives say, prices may stay on a high plateau for several years with what the industry regards as healthy annual increases of 10 to 15 percent. 
 The terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 were the crowning blow for the insurers -- and the major impetus for higher prices. Earlier, a string of small, but costly storms had cut earnings for the first half of 2001 by 75 percent from a year earlier, and the drops in the stock and bond markets had chopped $18 billion out of the insurers' investment portfolios. The terrorist attacks were the single largest disaster they had ever endured, with costs estimated at $50 billion and climbing.
Already, two small insurers -- one in Japan, the other in Denmark -- have failed under the financial burden of the attacks. More bankruptcies are expected.
Despite the heavy losses, the insurers say they can pay the claims stemming from Sept. 11, and most expect earnings to rise sharply. As in previous insurance disasters, this one, by all indications, is going to have a silver, if not golden, lining.
"The opportunity out there is tremendous," Henry C. V. Keeling, the chief executive of XL Re, an insurer based in Bermuda and a subsidiary of XL Capital, said at a recent industry conference.
The economics go like this: The industry loses a chunk of capital, reducing its ability to provide coverage just when customers are more worried than ever and want more insurance. Demand far exceeds supply, resulting in a roaring seller's market.
"A simple way of saying it is that adversity breeds opportunity," said Rod Fox, the chief executive of Benfield Blanch, an insurance brokerage firm in Dallas that is part of the Benfield Group of Britain. "That's probably a little too crass. But that's the way capital looks at it."
Individual investors can share the wealth through stocks. Analysts say the best bets are powerhouses like the American International Group and Berkshire Hathaway, Warren E. Buffett's investment vehicle.
Nothing, of course, is certain. More terrorism or a natural catastrophe could hammer the insurers again, though they have appealed to Washington for help in reducing losses if there are new attacks.
The insurers are nearing the end of their heaviest policy-renewal season. Prices are running five or six times the level of a year earlier for some lines of coverage, like worker's compensation, liability or protection against lawsuits and property coverage for skyscrapers in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles that are considered prime terrorist targets. Renewals through the next year are expected to come at the same, if not higher costs. Eventually, prices on insurance for cars and homes -- which were already rising -- are expected to reflect the impact of the terrorist attacks.
Insurers say that customers seem to be accepting the higher premiums.
"You get a big incident, and it increases people's fear; it increases the value of insurance," said Stephen J. O. Catlin, the chairman of the Catlin Underwriting Agencies Ltd., which is part of the Western International Financial Group and manages two insurance businesses, or syndicates, at Lloyd's of London. "People want to buy insurance now, and they are prepared to pay for it. A corporation goes 10 years without a loss, and they start asking, 'Why do we need to buy insurance?' "
That question, the insurers say, is not coming up now.
The last big surge in insurance prices came after Hurricane Andrew tore through southern Florida in 1992 in the previously worst insurance disaster, with losses of nearly $20 billion in today's dollars. Then the companies that profited were mainly home insurers, not commercial insurers.
Customers may be tolerant of an industry recouping losses from a tragedy. But if prices stay high, as they did after Hurricane Andrew and as insurers hope they do now, big profits can begin to look like gravy.
J. Robert Hunter, the director of insurance for the Consumer Federation of America, has protested to state insurance regulators that many of the latest price increases are unjustified. Both he and Senator Bill Nelson, a former insurance regulator in Florida, have urged the regulators to monitor commercial insurance prices closely. But a committee of regulators responded by voting in early December to relax controls.
The insurers' response to the criticism is that they need to make up for a lot of lost profits. After more than a decade of cut-throat pricing, they say, commercial insurance coverage now costs 60 percent less than it did in 1990. During the price war, which began fading away a little more than a year ago, the insurers' annual return on equity averaged 8.1 percent, or nearly five percentage points less than the rest of corporate America, said Robert P. Hartwig, the chief economist at the Insurance Information Institute, a trade group in New York.
Since the attacks, the insurers have not only raised prices, but they have also been rewriting policies to take back some of the features they dispensed to woo customers in the lenient years.
For example, it became commonplace for insurers to write what Mr. Catlin in London referred to as "holy cow" coverage, broadly encompassing "whatever might happen."
A corporation with perhaps 20 plants around the country, would buy, say, $50 million worth of coverage that could be applied to losses at any of the plants from a fire, an explosion with heavy casualties or a big lawsuit. The insurers simply closed their eyes to the likelihood that the plants represented vastly different levels of risk. Now, Mr. Catlin said, the coverage for each of the plants and for each of the kinds of coverage is being priced separately and at considerably higher cost.
The industry looks so attractive these days that new money is pouring in, both to start new insurance companies and to expand existing operations. Analysts expect $25 billion to be raised by the end of the year. The industry's fear is that this new money will shift supply and demand back in favor of the customer, creating, once again, a buyer's market, driving down prices.
But Ronald W. Frank, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, said he did not expect that to happen soon. The money raised so far, he said, is not nearly enough to offset the losses from Sept. 11 and the increased demand. Moreover, he said, he expects the new investors to insist on a high return and not be willing to accept bargain prices.
Those founding the new companies agree. "Return on equity for the first couple of years is going to be astounding," said Andrew J. Barile, an insurance consultant from Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., who helped start one of the companies.

HEADLINE: Technology & Media; 
Chip Makers See a Speedy Recovery; Others Have Doubts

BYLINE:  By CHRIS GAITHER 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif. 

 BODY:
Semiconductor makers have never seen a year as bad as 2001.
 Sales plummeted an estimated 31 percent, to $141 billion, as companies and consumers bought fewer personal computers, mobile phones and other devices. The decline is almost twice as much as the next-worst year, 1985, when sales fell 17 percent because of slumping demand for the memory chips that dominated the market then. 
 The pain now is especially acute because chip makers were among the biggest beneficiaries of the boom in telecommunications and the Internet in 2000, when sales soared 37 percent, to $204 billion. 
With the economy slowing, businesses still smarting from excess capacity and consumer confidence at the lowest point in seven years, recovery seems distant. Many analysts forecast that 2002 will be flat at best, and may even see another decline in sales if consumers continue to refrain from buying more electronics.
Chip sales, which have grown on average by nearly 15 percent a year since the devices were first produced four decades ago, have never declined for two consecutive years. Such a slump would highlight the depth of the trough the industry has dug itself into, and bodes poorly for the electronics powered by the chips.
The industry group for chip makers contends that the downturn will end this year, however. While conceding some trouble in the first half of 2002, the group, the Semiconductor Industry Association, forecasts a rebound in the summer that will propel the industry to revenue growth of 6 percent for the entire year and 21 percent in 2003.
Driving this growth, the association said, will be reduced inventory levels; increased memory-chip prices, which have fallen as much as 90 percent this year; and a recovery in demand for personal computers and cellphones.
"At this point, I think the worst of this cycle is truly behind us," said George M. Scalise, the president of the association, based here.
Not convinced, some analysts dismiss the association's forecast as wishful thinking.
"The global economy is going to be pretty soft in the first half of next year," Mark Edelstone, a managing director with Morgan Stanley, said. He predicted that chip sales would decline 5 percent in 2002. "I think it will rebound in the second half of next year," he added.
In 2000, spurred by demand for all things Internet, chip sales soared 37 percent. The industry hired more workers, built more factories and increased production to meet demand.
But then the bottom fell out of the market in the last three months of the year -- and kept falling through 2001. As the Internet bubble burst and the economy slowed, electronics devices powered by their chips sat on shelves.
No region of the world was immune. The North and South American market fell an estimated 43 percent this year, while the decline ranged from 23 percent to 29 percent in Europe, Japan and Asia.
Japanese electronics makers like Fujitsu and NEC temporarily shut down chip plants -- as the overall industry slowed operations to about 64 percent of its capacity -- to try to save money. In the United States, Advanced Micro Devices eliminated 15 percent of its jobs and closed two plants. Intel, the world's largest chip maker, said earlier this year that it would eliminate 5,000 jobs, and recently reported that its net profit fell to $787 million in the nine months ended Sept. 29, from $8.34 billion in the period a year earlier.
Jean-Philippe Dauvin, the chief economist at STMicroelectronics, a European chip maker, called 2001 "annus horribilis -- the horrible year you really don't want to remember."
While he added that he expected the industry to stabilize in 2002, he warned that the recovery would be much slower than the industry association forecasts. Instead of growing by 6 percent, he said, chip sales will most likely be flat to down 2 percent.
But Richard K. Templeton, chief operating officer at Texas Instruments, insists the recovery has already begun. The association predicts the fourth quarter will be better than the third, with revenue growth of nearly 5 percent. That would be the first time this year that revenue rose from one quarter to the next.
But while the fourth quarter may improve over the third, sales will still be down 40 percent from the comparable period last year and off 25 percent from the first quarter of this year.
Even then, the association, which says its member companies produce 90 percent of the chips made in the United States, has a weak track record of prognostications.
In 1999, for example, coming off a year of 19 percent growth, the association predicted a 21 percent gain in 2000, to $174 billion. Sales actually grew nearly twice as fast.
Then, at the peak of the boom, in October 2000, the association predicted that the good times would continue in 2001, with sales growing 22 percent. "The industry is going to have the wind at its back for the next several years," the chairman and chief executive of Advanced Micro Devices, W. J. Sanders III, said.
The wind Mr. Sanders described turned out to be a gale, hitting the industry square in the face. Sales slumped and the forecast was $108 billion too high.
The association "does not have a good record of forecasting," said Terry Ragsdale, who follows semiconductors for Goldman, Sachs. But he quickly added, "I don't know anyone who does."

HEADLINE: Technology & Media; 
For Some Dot-Coms, There Are Real Profits

BYLINE:  By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Meet Brad D. Greenspan and at first it seems like he's a visitor from another era -- the Internet bubble of 1999.
 He's a 28-year-old chief executive of a public Internet company, eUniverse, with tens of millions of users and big backers like Sony. 
 But listen to Mr. Greenspan, and it becomes clear that his story is far from the fairy tales that made millionaires, at least for a while, of so many recent graduates who had the good fortune to cross paths with venture capitalists at just the right moment. 
Since its founding in 1999, eUniverse has scraped by with barely enough cash to keep the lights on. While the bigger sites tried to emulate prime-time television, with quality programming and big brand advertisers, eUniverse resembles late night fare on the more obscure channels. Aimed at women aged 25 to 54, its network of sites are cheap, corny, crass and profitable. Its advertisers are more likely to sell debt refinancing and online diets than cars or perfume.
But the network of sites has become the 15th-biggest service on the Internet, with 18 million visitors in November, according to Nielsen/NetRatings, which researches Internet traffic patterns. And while it is a small business -- with only $6.7 million in revenue in the quarter ended Sept. 30 -- it actually makes a profit.
EUniverse is a prime example of a new species of Internet companies that are thriving even in the harsh climate that has killed off many of the dot-com giants of a few years ago. Indeed, this new breed emerged dodging the feet of their seemingly fearsome rivals. As a result, they are small, scrappy, able to live on the leanest diet and willing to do whatever it takes to survive.
"We made it work in the mean streets without venture capital funding," Mr. Greenspan said. "We have had to build and grow at a fraction of the costs that other guys are spending. And we have not been afraid to stop and change where we were going. The companies that raised all that money had to stick to their business plans."
The other Internet companies doing well have a similar low-rent strategy. Overstock.com, for example, is one of the few growing online merchants not affiliated with traditional retailers. Founded by Patrick Byrne, a former aide to Warren E. Buffett, the chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, Overstock buys distressed inventory from failing dot-coms and other businesses that need cash and sells it from a no-frills operation in Salt Lake City. Mr. Byrne says Overstock, which is privately held, is profitable -- having become so in November -- and expects to post revenue of about $11 million in December.
Another up-and-comer is classmates.com, which charges users $29.50 a year to find old school chums. IWon.com, an Internet portal that gives users a chance to win cash prizes as they surf, is thriving and has just agreed to take over Excite.com, the once high-flying portal that was backed by the elite of Silicon Valley.
The biggest force in online commerce these days is not Amazon.com, but eBay, a flea market of individuals and small businesses who collectively sell three times as much as Amazon. And sites linked with Fingerhut, the downscale catalog merchant that is a unit of Federated Department Stores, and QVC, the shopping network subsidiary of Comcast, post far more sales than sites for big names like Wal-Mart Stores and Sears, Roebuck & Company, according to ComScore Networks.
EUniverse, in fact, now is aimed at the same moderate-income women as Fingerhut and QVC, but it did not begin that way.
As a senior at U.C.L.A. in 1997, Mr. Greenspan wanted a job at a big Wall Street firm, but he couldn't get one. So he started his own firm. What he named Palisades Capital was the telephone in his dormitory room and the fax machine at a nearby Kinko's from which he sent unsolicited pitches to raise money for companies whose filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission showed that they were low on cash.
Amazingly, several agreed, and even more amazingly, Mr. Greenspan found investors who put $60 million into four of them, including the remains of the Hayes Corporation, once a leading maker of computer modems. Mr. Greenspan walked away with $2 million in commissions, with which he decided to bootstrap himself into the Internet business.
His first move in putting together what was to become eUniverse was to buy CD Universe, a small online music store founded and largely run by one person, Charles Beilman, in Wallingford, Conn., in April 1999. He used his newfound fund-raising skills to get $6.3 million in investments from Lehman Brothers and some others.
Mr. Greenspan's strategy was to use his money and stock to buy popular sites that he could link together to sell CD's and other goods. He searched the Media Metrix ratings that measure online audiences to find mom-and-pop sites with growing popularity.
By the end of last year, Mr. Greenspan had sold the CD business back to Mr. Beilman, for $500,000 less than he paid for it, renamed the company to eUniverse, moved it to Los Angeles and focused on serving women through other small sites he had bought. The most popular is flowgo.com, which offers goofy animated e-mail greeting cards. Dancing babies, dancing animals and dancing fat people are common themes. So are illustrated versions of the sort of corny jokes that fill so many e-mail boxes, like "10 reasons why it's great to be a dog."
Other eUniverse sites, like funone.com and justsaywow.com, offer similar content with different styles. Ishaah.com, for example, offers inspirational poems and e-mail greetings with a native American theme.
"This is television," Mr. Greenspan said. "People come to get their minds off something else."
Unlike television, the eUniverse sites constantly ask users for their e-mail addresses. That's why online greeting cards are so useful. The company now has 40 million addresses, and half its revenue comes from sending e-mail advertising to them. The company boasts it sends one billion e-mails a week.
But the advertising market is soft, so Mr. Greenspan now wants to develop eUniverse's own products and services to sell to its audience. It started a venture to sell refilled printer ink cartridges and Cupid Junction, an online dating service. With lots of women, who can use the service free, eUniverse can sell memberships to men, who pay $1.60 to $3.33 for each message they send to a woman. The service now has $300,000 a month of revenue and 80 percent profit margins, Mr. Greenspan said.
Next up, eUniverse has bought exclusive online rights to distribute a home anthrax test kit. Never mind that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention runs multiple bacteria and genetic tests that take days to confirm cases of anthrax, this is exactly the sort of product that will keep the new smaller Internet companies afloat.
"It may be controversial," Mr. Greenspan said, "but the demand is there."

HEADLINE: Technology & Media; 
Tech Investors Cautiously Return, Focusing on Hardware and Biotech

BYLINE:  By MATT RICHTEL 

 BODY:
Jim Fraine, chief executive of Neocera Inc., a start-up company that makes equipment for computer chip companies, was driving to Logan International Airport in Boston when news of the terrorist attacks came over his car radio. In addition to the grief and shock he felt, Mr. Fraine took a deep breath for his personal setback; he had hoped to remember Sept. 10, not the 11th.
 The day before the hijackings, Mr. Fraine had pitched his company to venture capitalists in the Boston area to try to raise several million dollars in seed capital. When he heard the news of the attacks, Mr. Fraine said, he feared that his chance to get a positive response from the investors had gone from long shot to "hopeless -- just hopeless." 
 Mr. Fraine should hope he turns out to be a better entrepreneur than prognosticator. Within weeks, the venture capitalists made an offer to Mr. Fraine's company, based in Beltsville, Md., and at least one other group of investors is now competing to back Neocera, whose technology is used to check computer chips for design flaws.
While venture capital investment, the bread and butter of technology start-ups, is far down from the highs of the dot-com bubble, it is by no means dead. Indeed, venture capitalists and entrepreneurs point to a number of types of technologies that interest them and which they may invest in during the year ahead.
Among those technologies are nanotechnology computers built using minute processors; Web services software that moves business functions onto the Internet; biotechnology; and wireless technologies. In fairness, though, it is tough to generalize about the main sectors, because there are some 700 venture capital firms nationwide, and many of them focus on different niches. What is easy to identify is what is not being widely financed: consumer-oriented Internet companies.
The billions of dollars poured during the late 1990's into companies that provide content like news and information, or into online retailers, was an anomaly for most venture capitalists. Historically, they have focused on core technologies, niche software and hardware products, which often are far less sexy than the glamorous world of Internet start-ups; the venture capital world has long backed the technologies described in the pages of Scientific American, not the fads in Teen People.
And some venture capitalists, many of whom call themselves science geeks but who have a gift for marketing, say they are quite happy to be going back to being boring. Indeed, just hearing them talk about the latest technologies is enough to put an insomniac into a deep slumber.
"One of the holy grails is a tunable optical laser," said Sean Foote, a partner at Labrador Ventures, a venture firm based in Palo Alto, Calif., sounding like an 8-year-old describing the advent of the Nickelodeon cable channel.
Simply put, Mr. Foote said, if optical lasers were tunable, meaning they could be programmed to send different colors of light down fiber optic networks, then a single laser could replace many individually programmed lasers, reducing costs for network operators and users. In addition, Mr. Foote said, he is looking at other technologies that could cut the costs of building networks, including figuring out how to wire homes with high-speed networks and with wireless Internet access.
"Security is a huge area," he added. "Antivirus protection, intrusion detection -- look at the things in a chief information officer's purchase list, and security is the last thing" to be eliminated.
Labrador Ventures invested in a security start-up called Green Border Technologies Inc. last May, an investment that underscores a second trend in the industry. While Labrador is seeking new investments, it has not put money into a new venture since Green Border. The slowdown may continue through 2002.
According to the National Venture Capital Association, an industry trade and research group based in Arlington, Va., venture capital firms in the United States invested $7.72 billion during the third quarter of 2001, a 73 percent decline from the period a year earlier. Further, 81 percent of the investment in the third quarter of 2001 was made as follow-up financing of existing portfolio companies, indicating how tough it is for start-ups to attract venture capital dollars.
Among those companies that have attracted funds is ReefEdge Inc. of Fort Lee, N.J., which makes software to secure and manage wireless networks, like wireless Internet access for offices. Ethan D. Ayer, a senior associate for Allegra Partners, the New York venture capitalist firm that backed ReefEdge in August, said wireless technology would attract attention from investors in 2002. "It's not a question whether wireless networks will take off," he said, "it's a question of who the winner will be."
His firm, too, remains interested in the broad category called Web services, a phrase that may well become a catchall to describe many companies that receive venture financing in 2002, according to the investors. Others call it "metaware" and refer to it as the next stage in the evolution of software. At the heart of the wide-ranging category is the idea that business functions can be moved onto the Internet, and away from both proprietary networks and proprietary hardware systems, like automated teller machines.
Some venture capitalists say they are looking at technology that would let a company send updates to software across different operating systems, devices and computers. Rather than updating all servers and computers individually, they could do it once, and send it across an entire system.
There continue to be hardware investments too, as is the case with Neocera, Mr. Fraine's company. Founded in 1989, the 35-person company uses magnetic resonance imaging, commonly known as M.R.I., to look for shorts in integrated circuits. The company's device, which looks like a microscope, would be used by makers of semiconductors to see if there are flaws in newly designed microprocessors.
Mr. Fraine said the technology, already used by some chip makers, could save companies one to four weeks in detecting flaws. "Time measured to market can be hundreds of thousands of dollars a day," he said. For some popular, name-brand chips, like the Pentium, "it can be measured in millions of dollars an hour."
Mr. Fraine declined to say which venture capital firms had offered to back his company. But Labrador Ventures, which also has offices in New York, has said it is considering making an offer to become one of the company's backers.
Discussing such technologies, Mr. Foote of Labrador Ventures said, "It's not real sexy, except the part where they make a lot of money."

HEADLINE: Technology & Media; 
Advertising Industry Becomes Ensnarled In the Perfect Storm

BYLINE:  By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
For Madison Avenue, the last 12 months brought the perfect storm -- a rare alignment of perfectly awful events from the dot-com meltdown to the economic slowdown to the weeklong shutdown of most advertising after Sept. 11. The result is what may be the largest reversal of fortune for the American advertising and media industries as a big gain in ad spending in one year swings to a big decline the next.
 Ad spending will probably decline again next year, but not so much as in 2001. 
 "There are agencies in trouble, no question about it," said O. Burtch Drake, president and chief executive at the American Association of Advertising Agencies in New York, the industry trade organization, but "the indications are that perhaps the worst is behind us."
"By the third quarter of 2002, we should start to see a pickup," he added, that would generate "fairly modest growth." 
After a record year in 2000, when ad spending rose a robust 9.6 percent, to $243.7 billion, ad spending this year is expected to fall by 6 percent to 7 percent, according to an average of estimates from a dozen analysts. That would represent the first downturn since 1991, a recession year, when ad spending fell 1.2 percent from 1990. It would also be the biggest decline since a Depression year, 1938, when ad spending fell 8.1 percent from 1937.
If ad spending declines in 2002 after falling this year, it would mean the first two consecutive down years since the Depression, when ad spending fell for four years, 1930-33, according to a leading industry forecaster, Robert J. Coen of Universal McCann in New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.
Mr. Coen, senior vice president and forecasting director at Universal McCann, predicts that Madison Avenue will avert that fate, albeit barely; after ad spending falls 4.1 percent this year from 2000, he estimated, it will start "the gradual crawl back" and rise 2.4 percent in 2002 over 2001.
Certainly neither Mr. Coen nor his counterparts' forecasts amount to a depression for 2002. But now that economists have officially declared that a recession began in March, the significant toll on the advertising and media realms is becoming apparent.
People say it's not possible for ad spending to fall in both 2001 and 2002 "because it's hardly ever happened," said Michael J. Beebe, an analyst who follows advertising and media for Goldman, Sachs in New York. "I don't care about history; the world is different."
"I think you'll see a return to normalcy in 2003," Mr. Beebe said. He estimates ad spending will fall 4 percent in 2002 after dropping 9 percent this year. "I'm more willing to believe there will be a healthier economy in '03 than in '02," he added.
So far, the cutbacks in ad spending have meant layoffs at many agencies; closings of shops like Dweck, Favara & Raffle Advertising, Pagano Schenck & Kay and Warwick Baker O'Neill; shrinking budgets at broadcast and cable television networks for news coverage and for developing new series; and reductions in editorial budgets at magazines and newspapers. There have also been forced closings of publications as disparate as Expedia Travels, Lingua Franca and Mademoiselle.
"The number of media outlets has expanded exponentially" during the recent boom years, said Lauren Rich Fine, an analyst for Merrill Lynch in New York who follows industries including advertising and newspapers, "and the excesses masked all the supply being added."
Now that the glut is becoming apparent, "there's a herd mentality" among marketers, she added, who are proclaiming, " 'I know media is cheap, but there's a ton of it out there, so I don't have to act.' "
"At what point does corporate America decide it needs to stimulate the consumer?" Ms. Fine asked. "Everyone wants to believe things will improve, but people are trying to hold onto their ad budgets and won't spend until they see it."
That delayed decision-making is described by analysts like Joe Mandese, editor of Media Buyer's Daily, a newsletter published by the Media Central division of Primedia, as "just-in-time media buying," invoking the process by which automakers and other manufacturers wait until the last moment to have parts delivered.
"This very, very short-term, close-to-the-vest planning," Mr. Mandese said, "means you can't predict" advertisers' spending intentions. "It's bizarre."
Most of the predictions that are being made do not call for ad spending to revive until the third or fourth quarter of 2002.
"No one can tell you the first half looks good," said Michael J. Russell Jr., an analyst who follows advertising and broadcasting for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in New York. "But the worse things get in 2001, the better it looks for the second half of 2002." That is because there would be easier comparisons with this year's results. Mr. Russell forecasts a 9 percent decline in ad spending for 2001 and no growth in 2002.
"That puts us on the more positive side of the coin," he said, laughing ruefully, "which is a sign of the times."
The main reason 2002 is expected to be another disappointing year for advertising and media is the continued softness in important categories in which marketers once spent freely, like travel, retail, telecommunications and consumer electronics.
"I'm not seeing any real, positive indications for an upturn next year," said Jack Myers, chief economist at Myers in New York, which publishes media and research newsletters. His forecast for 2002 is for a decline in ad spending of 5.7 percent from 2001, which he estimates will record a fall of 6.8 percent from 2000.
"If we get through the rest of this year and the first half of 2002 without another significant domestic terrorist attack, travel would come back, which would be helpful for radio and newspapers," Mr. Myers said. "But television and magazines would continue to struggle."
Indeed, the Television Bureau of Advertising in New York, the trade association for local TV stations, has reduced its own forecasts. Revenue for commercials bought on local stations in 2001 will fall 15 percent to 17 percent from 2000, the bureau now estimates, compared with a previously forecast decline of 9 percent to 11 percent. Next year, local stations' revenue will increase only 2.5 percent to 5.5 percent, according to the revised forecast, down from a previous estimate of 5 to 7 percent.
"I'm an optimist by nature," said Chris Rohrs, president at the bureau, "but we've widened the range and lowered it a little bit, just to be prudent."
"The two big uncertainties that steer us that way are: How will the war go? And what about terrorism?" he added. "If the war and antiterror efforts go well, the downturn could become an upturn sooner rather than later."
Though the trade organization for the magazine industry, the Magazine Publishers of America, does not make predictions, its leaders say they are cautious. Magazines are grappling with the uncertainties generated by the anthrax scare, the war and the fight against terrorism.
"There may be more magazines that close this year than in a normal year because it's really tough times," said Nina B. Link, president and chief executive at the organization in New York.
"But there are also new launches as well as existing magazines reaching more readers," she added. "We will ride this out."
Ellen Oppenheim, executive vice president and chief marketing officer at the organization, is touring the country to explain a research study conducted on its behalf by Media Marketing Assessment.
The study concludes that brands spending a higher percentage of their marketing budget on advertising -- in various media outlets, not just in magazines -- can get a higher return on overall marketing investment than brands that shift ad dollars to other ways to woo consumers like promotions in stores or coupons.
"The forces at play this year are different from the forces at play in previous downturns," Ms. Oppenheim said. "Media and media associations must act on those challenges and be better positioned to come out of the downturn."
As fast as the downturn took place, so, too, could an upturn.
Advertisers that "get spooked to get out for fear of getting burned will get spooked to get back in for fear of getting left behind," said Alan J. Gottesman, an analyst at West End Communications/Consulting in New York. "As soon as they think they can sell more stuff again by stepping up spending, they will."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Cutbacks in ad spending have forced some publications to close, meaning few choices at newstands like this one in in New York. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: International Business; 
In Japan,a Lack of Political Will To Act Decisively on the Economy

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO 

 BODY:
Only a decade ago, Americans were telling pollsters that they feared that the Japanese economic juggernaut would one day wipe out their jobs. But somewhere on the road to No. 1 status, Japan took a disastrous turn. After Japanese government bonds were downgraded to the bottom of the industrialized world, American writers started calling Japan "Asia's Italy."
 Weak political leadership, weak control over government finances and huge corporate debts, problems that have plagued Italy, are modern Japan's main challenges as the rest of the world wonders whether the country, home of the second-largest economy in the world, will be a help or hindrance in confronting a global recession. 
 But all indicators point to Japan's ailing for several years to come. The Japanese government and the International Monetary Fund forecast that Japan's economy will shrink this year and next. The fund forecasts that the economy will shrink next year by 1.3 percent, dragging global growth down to 2.4 percent.
Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi has proposed sweeping reforms, from having banks write off billions of dollars in bad loans to letting weak companies fail, but is being stymied by traditionalists in his own party, the Liberal Democrats, who want to use his reformist image to perpetuate their own power. If Mr. Koizumi cannot right the economy, which has been slumping for a decade, there is no likely savior in the wings, economists say.
"The worst scenario is the most likely: that Koizumi stays in power for the next two years and accomplishes next to nothing," said Gerald L. Curtis, a visiting political science professor from Columbia University who has followed Japanese politics for over three decades.
The hole in Japan's government finances is easy to understand. Tax receipts this year will be 16 percent lower than they were in 1990, while this year's government expenditures will be 29 percent higher. After a decade of trying to spend its way out of recession and near-recession, Japan starts the new year with public debt at 130 percent of its gross domestic product, by far the highest among the major industrial nations.
About 95 percent of this debt is held by Japanese investors at rock-bottom interest rates, and since late November, three ratings agencies, Fitch IBCA, Moody's and Standard & Poor's, have downgraded Japanese government debt ratings to AA, the level of Italy. 
Giving little credence to government vows to control spending, Fitch forecast that Japan's indebtedness would exceed 150 percent of G.D.P. by the end of 2002 and could approach 200 percent by 2007, barring strong government intervention.
"Koizumi is very committed to reforms," Brian Coulton, a Fitch analyst, said. "But there is still an element of denial about how bad the problems are among the political community."
Mr. Koizumi's standing as a reformer was badly dented toward the end of the year when the government ignored self-imposed limits on public borrowing and enacted highway and medical spending bills that austerity advocates criticized as excessive.
But with no other reformer on the horizon, the Japanese cling to Mr. Koizumi. Almost 80 percent of the public approves of his job performance, according to recent polls.
Foreign investors are less sanguine.
"Japan is a hopeless case," Jim O'Neill, a Goldman, Sachs strategist, said last month in London in a speech that reflected increasingly harsh foreign views of Japan's short-term prospects.
About the economy itself, many Japanese seem almost as gloomy.
With unemployment creeping up to 5.4 percent, the highest rate since World War II, a late November poll of 1,791 Japanese adults found 87 percent saying that they worried about their job security and 94 percent pessimistic about the economy, according to Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's leading business daily. 
More than one million Japanese lost their jobs this year because of bankruptcies or restructurings, and the number of plant closings is jumping. So far this year, 46 factories in the electronics and information sector have closed, up from only two last year. As Chinese imports eat into Japanese manufacturing, factory job offers here are down by a third from last year's levels.
"Every economic measure you can look at -- disposable income, G.D.P., household spending, deflation -- are all bad," said Mark Fields, president of Mazda Motor, in which Ford Motor owns a controlling stake. "The only way Japan looks good is if you turn the charts upside down."
Nihon Keizai Shimbun surveyed 1,790 of Japan's largest publicly listed companies and calculated that net profits will be down 74 percent for the year that ends in March.
"I have talked to several important business leaders and they are scared," said Robert F. Grondine, a longtime lawyer here who steps down this month as president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Japan. "They don't see the bottom."
Japanese executives, traumatized by real estate and stock collapses that began around 1990, are devoted to reducing debt, not borrowing for future expansion.
"You have shell-shocked executives saying they will never borrow again," Richard C. Koo, senior economist for Nomura Research Institute, recently said. "But with all companies minimizing debt, you have an invisible hand pushing toward depression."
Many of Japan's problems are self-induced. A chummy financial system, where banks served as cash conduits to affiliated conglomerates, has bad corporate debts of almost $2 trillion, according to Goldman, Sachs. The kind of big American bankruptcies seen this fall -- including Polaroid, Bethlehem Steel and Enron -- are rare here.
In recent weeks, Japan's four largest banking groups set aside $44 billion to cover bad loans. Their combined earnings of $366 million last year are forecast to plummet this year into losses of $20 billion.
Japan's long-suffering taxpayers, having seen few bankers lose their jobs and none go to jail after a major bank bailout in 1997, are expected to resist a new rescue.
Telegraphing a lack of confidence in some banks, Japanese savers are quietly moving out of time deposits into more liquid savings, according to Bank of Japan statistics.
"By March, there's a danger Japan's economy could face a major crash, if no reforms are pushed through," Yukio Hatoyama, an opposition politician, said. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Job seekers at a government-run placement center in Tokyo checked employment offers. Japan's unemployment rate of 5.4 percent is the highest since World War II. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: International Business; 
South Korea Slips Away From Changes Imposed in Bailout

BYLINE:  By DON KIRK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea 

 BODY:
Four years after a $58 billion bailout put together by the International Monetary Fund, South Korean executives and bureaucrats appear determined to reverse many of the reforms imposed upon them in the rescue of the debt-ridden economy. While the economy remains the world's 13th largest, the danger exists of reversion to some of the bad habits of the decade before the financial crisis.
 "A great deal of economic and financial reform has been accomplished," the United States ambassador to South Korea, Thomas C. Hubbard, said, but "there have been some signs of backtracking and less-than-transparent business practices." 
 Jang Ha Sung, a finance professor at Korea University, complained that "there's still no brake on the chaebol," using the word for any conglomerate with more than $1 billion or so in assets, generally dominated by the founder or his heirs. 
Mr. Jang, who has been crusading for years for the rights of small investors, and other would-be reformers who turn up regularly at shareholder meetings every spring have had little real impact on chaebol policy other than to persuade some of them to appoint a few more outside directors.
Confirming the sense that the more things change, the more they stay the same, the Korea Institute of Finance, a government research center, said that the top four chaebol, comprising the Samsung, SK, LG and Hyundai groups, despite a pledge to streamline operations, devoted only 17.5 percent of their investments to their core companies.
But the finance and economy ministry shares no sense of dismay -- far from it. Byeon Yang Ho, director general of the ministry's financial policy bureau, said, "We would like to eliminate the arm-twisting type of regulations and introduce market-friendly regulations in their place."
The finance ministry, he said, is "on the same side as the Federation of Korean Industries," a sort of club of chieftains of the chaebol. "We want to reduce controls as much as possible."
Companies worth less than $4 billion face no constraints on investment other than the limits of their bank accounts and the willingness of creditors to extend credit.
Mr. Byeon acknowledged, however, that the Fair Trade Commission, which issued some of the first warnings about the overweening power of the highly leveraged chaebol years before the economic crisis of 1997-98, "is a little more reluctant."
In the years of nonstop expansion of the conglomerates, the commission offered a dissenting voice amid all the cheers for chaebol growth, trying to encourage fiscal discipline and more competition. Much the same outlook prevails at the commission today.
Because of the commission's reluctance, the 17 largest chaebol, those with assets of more than $4 billion each, are still restricted in investing more than 25 percent of their assets in other companies or groups. Before going over that level they must show they are uniquely qualified in the same fields as the companies they want to buy, or prove that a target company is in dire straits.
Mr. Byeon contends that watchful officials as well as shareholder-rights groups would prevent the chaebol from circumventing the rules.
But there are signs of backsliding on restraints intended to keep the conglomerates from reverting to the excesses that pushed the country to the brink of financial collapse. For example, bureaucrats and executives now tend to overlook the requirement imposed three years ago as President Kim Dae Jung sought to rein in the chaebol, that every company cut its debt-to-equity ratio to no more than 2 to 1. At the time, ratios were typically 4 or 5 to 1 -- and in some cases much higher.
The government is also lifting another critical constraint, that large companies could not own controlling stakes of banks, lest they turn banks into their private treasure chests, as they had done before the economic crisis.
Now, as long as a financial company devotes 75 percent of its assets to finance, it will be able to buy 10 percent of a bank, enough in most cases to influence policy. Government officials say other companies in the group could not tell the finance company what to do, but critics disagree.
The People's Solidarity for Participatory Democracy, for example, a group led by Mr. Jang, the advocate for minority shareholder rights, implored the government to stop loosening regulations.
The move to lift the investment ceiling of the conglomerates, Mr. Jang's group said, "illustrates the government's intent to slow the chaebol reforms." The investment cap, it said, was "the core part in the nation's corporate restructuring that should be maintained."
In another sign of trouble, the Institute of Finance found that the 30 leading chaebol had put 41 percent of their equity investments into enterprises that lost money.
Lee Dong Gull, the author of the report, said the figures showed that the chaebol "have struggled to maintain their fleet-style group structures, though they repeatedly vowed to streamline their far-flung businesses in accordance with the government's reform policy."
To be sure, the corporate landscape is changing in a cosmetic sense.
The Hyundai Group, once the largest chaebol, has fragmented. The most successful new company may be the Hyundai automotive group, including Hyundai Motor and Kia Motors, which Hyundai acquired in 1998 as Kia came apart with a debt-to-equity ratio of at least 12 to 1.
In contrast to the motor group's success, other once-great companies remain in constant turmoil. The creditor institutions that now control Hynix Semiconductor, formerly Hyundai Electronics Industries, for example, are struggling with whether to lend it billions more or let it slide into bankruptcy, and the Institute of Finance study holds that the Hynix case is just the tip of an iceberg that could yet sink the chaebol system.
Foreign analysts are constantly surprised to discover that companies that they had assumed had faded into oblivion still exist in the hands of creditors. The Daewoo Group, which collapsed in mid-1999, is an example. Far less visible than Daewoo Motors, now under bankruptcy protection while General Motors negotiates to take it over, are a dozen other Daewoo companies in fields as diverse as telecommunications, construction and shipbuilding.
All are more or less for sale, but as long as no one is willing to pay the price, the creditors' institutions that took them over prefer to keep them going.
