HEADLINE: International Business; 
Globalization Marches On, as U.S. Eases Up on the Reins

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
To hear Eastman Kodak tell it -- and many other multinationals -- globalization marches inexorably forward. Neither incessant protests, nor worldwide recession nor the war on terrorism stops it.
 Kodak's overseas sales, after all, generate more than half its annual revenue, and the percentage is rising. The company has factories in Britain, France, Brazil, Mexico, Canada, India, China and Japan. Cameras and film flow constantly across borders, at a cost of $200 million a year in tariffs. And now, despite the anger and turmoil surrounding the issue, the nations of the world have agreed to negotiate yet another round of tariff-cutting. 
 "The globalization debate has changed, but the underlying reality has not," said Christopher A. Padilla, Kodak's director of international trade relations. "Reducing tariffs means you can reduce artificial costs, and that means you can sell more overseas." 
That same focus shows up in the Bush administration. Getting the 142 member nations in the World Trade Organization to agree in Doha, Qatar, last month to another round of negotiations to lower trade barriers required significant compromises by the administration. Mention them to Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, however, and he insists on calling them "solutions," not compromises.
But they were compromises. Globalization is gradually slipping from the control of the United States and the other industrial nations. The developing countries are gaining ground in a few battles. The protests that started in Seattle in 1999, the third world poverty made worse by recession, the ravages of AIDS in Africa, the anti-American sentiment stirred up in the war against terrorism, the sudden pressure to turn critics into wartime allies -- all were felt in Doha, and the agreement that emerged was harder for Washington to savor.
"There are some things that are irritating in the Doha agreement," Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill acknowledged, "but we are going to have another round of trade negotiations. That is what really matters."
Constant tariff reduction is only one aspect of globalization, which has come to mean not only the increasingly unrestricted flow of merchandise across borders, but also the free flow of money, people and all sorts of services. Bankers, lawyers, brokers, insurance companies and investment firms routinely operate from offices in a dozen countries. Merchandise trade, which once meant making a product in one country and exporting it to another, now means making a product in phases in several countries.
A Kodak instant camera sold today in France may have been assembled and packaged in that country, but the camera mechanism came from a Kodak factory in China, and its film from the United States. Cameras, and many other products, are no longer even made in America, which helps explain why Kodak and other powerful companies struggle to influence the rule-making that governs the globalization of their activities -- and to bring as many countries as possible into the World Trade Organization and thus commit them to the rules. China and Taiwan are the newest members, having formally joined at Doha.
The last set of rules, adopted as a result of the Uruguay Round, began to take effect in 1995, with the W.T.O as the supervising body. A new round of rule-making was to have been authorized at a W.T.O meeting in Seattle in 1999, but violent protests broke up that gathering.
Two years later, the Doha agreement finally set the guidelines for negotiating new globalization rules that would be ratified by 2005 -- and the House of Representatives approved a bill this month that would give President Bush more authority in negotiating the rules. The Senate has not yet acted.
"After the failure in Seattle, many of us felt that failure at Doha would have put the W.T.O. at serious risk," Mr. Zoellick said. Sept. 11 only raised the stakes.
A failure at Doha would have undermined the American effort to build a coalition in the war against terrorism, said Prof. Dani Rodrik, an international economist at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, "and the United States exerted an enormous effort to accommodate the less developed countries."
So ground has been given. The Doha guidelines, for example, water down patent protection for brand-name drugs by giving poor countries the right, in emergencies, to license inexpensive generic versions. That is a big concession to AIDS-ravaged Africa, although Mr. Zoellick shuns the word. He talks not of concessions but of turning problems into opportunities and of making globalization "fit with coalition building."
Similarly, the antidumping rules that now protect America's steel and lumber industries from lower-priced imports are likely to become less protective, although in the horse-trading this month to win House passage of the bill that would give the president more authority in trade negotiations, the administration rescinded, in effect, some concessions made on steel and textiles. There is also recognition in the Doha guidelines that the less-developed countries are often at a disadvantage in trading with the developed nations, and therefore need special treatment.
Beyond the Doha accord, globalization is gradually being altered in other ways. It is also shrinking as a percentage of global economic activity. The worldwide recession has reduced nearly every country's exports, and also curtailed the flow of foreign loans and foreign investment from the industrial to the less-developed countries. The shrinkage is almost certain to be temporary, disappearing when recovery kicks in. But the changes in response to the anti-globalization protests and the pressures of Sept. 11 are likely to be permanent.
"What is happening now," said Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., president of the Economic Strategy Institute, a research group in Washington, "is a recognition that the global marketplace, left to itself, is not going to automatically produce wealth and prosperity in less-developed countries unless there is rule-making and new structures that reduce the potential for destructiveness."
In a speech last month, Anne O. Krueger, the Stanford University economist who was named second in command at the International Monetary Fund in June, unexpectedly proposed just such a new structure. Nothing had drawn more outcry against globalization in the late 1990's than the practices of the Clinton administration and the I.M.F. in dealing with the Asian financial crisis. Foreign capital had flowed freely into the Asian tiger countries. Then, when their economies got into trouble, and the foreign lenders fled with their money, the Clinton administration and the I.M.F. made matters worse, the critics charged, by insisting that the suffering countries raise interest rates.
The administration and the I.M.F. thought that when the return on the risky loans rose, the foreign lenders would keep their money in place. But the foreign money disappeared anyway, and the higher rates discouraged economic activity, thus pushing the countries into recession and greater unemployment. Meanwhile, multibillion-dollar emergency loans, mostly from the I.M.F, meant in effect that the countries in crisis suddenly had the wherewithal to repay the foreign lenders, who seemed to come away whole.
Addressing this dynamic, Ms. Krueger, in her speech, proposed the creation of an international bankruptcy mechanism that would require foreign lenders to keep their money in place while debtors and creditors worked out an orderly repayment plan. A bankruptcy mechanism would make foreign lenders more cautious, Ms. Krueger said, by convincing them "that the official sector is not waiting on the sidelines to bail them out when things go wrong."
The surprise proposal drew support from two persistent critics of I.M.F. practices during the Clinton years -- the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and Prof. Jeffrey D. Sachs, an economist at Harvard and the director of its Center for International Development. "It is an attempt to do something other than push official money into these crises," Professor Sachs said. "I am pleased, and also surprised; globalization has its downsides and one has been unrestricted capital flow."
The economic theory that justifies globalization is also increasingly debated these days. The Bush administration and many mainstream economists hold that economic growth and a rising standard of living come to any country that lowers its tariffs, opens its borders and welcomes foreign capital without rules governing its movement in or out of the country. Foreign competition forces a country to modernize its economy, become more efficient and concentrate on what it produces best, the administration says. As exports rise so does a nation's output and employment.
Applying that dynamic to the United States, Mr. Zoellick has argued "that one-quarter of our economic growth in the 1990's was generated by exports." The North American Free Trade Agreement and the Uruguay Round "have boosted the annual income and lowered the cost of purchases for an average American family of four by $1,300 to $2,000 a year," he has said. These figures assume, however, that all of the tariff reductions and adjustments in the trade agreements occurred instantaneously, even though the agreements themselves permit them to occur over a period of years. A worker in an apparel factory, for example, who loses his job because of low-priced imports, finds another job right away in electronics or some other industry.
"International trade theory," said Thea Lee, a trade expert at the A.F.L.-C.I.O., "assumes that we live in a world where everyone who loses a job is immediately re-employed in a better-paying job, and every dollar of exports is balanced by a dollar of imports. It does not happen."
Professor Rodrik, the international economist, raises another issue. He agrees that free and rising trade does raise living standards over the long run. The short run is another matter. While Mr. Zoellick points to Korea and China as countries that have benefited from trade, Professor Rodrik says they protected their industries until they were strong enough to compete in the global market. "China was and until very recently remained one of the most closed countries in the world in terms of a trade regime," he said.
For Kodak, with its powerful brand name, globalization works. Efficiency rises and costs decline as Kodak spreads manufacturing and marketing around the globe. Employment alone has fallen below 80,000 worldwide from 94,800 in 1996, and 53 percent of the company's $14 billion in annual revenue now comes outside the United States.
"That is why the Doha agreement is so welcomed around the world," Mr. Padilla said, "and certainly by Kodak."

HEADLINE: South Korea Expects Its Economy to Grow 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 16 

 BODY:
While much of the world hunkers down to weather a recession, South Korean officials see fairly bright near-term prospects for their own economy, assuming conditions do not get much worse in the United States or Japan.
 Jin Myun, the minister of finance and economy, said last week that he expected growth in 2002 in excess of 4 percent -- not exactly roaring by Korean standards, but much more robust than any of the big industrial economies now hopes for. 
 He also predicts that his government will make significant headway next year in cleaning up a morass of money-losing companies on government financial life support. 
The Korea Chamber of Commerce and Industry has predicted hefty increases in exports by carmakers, chipmakers and other manufacturers.
Confidence in the economy rests on the outcomes of long-running dramas surrounding the crumbling of two empires, Hyundai and Daewoo. General Motors has nearly completed a deal to take over most of the bankrupt Daewoo Motor Company. AIG, the American insurance group active in Asia, is working to gain control of three financial companies once part of the Hyundai empire.

HEADLINE: To Help Land, Australians Rethink Role Of Kangaroos 

BYLINE:  By JOHN SHAW 

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 16 

 BODY:
"Throw another roo rib on the barbie" may lack the sales appeal of the grilled-shrimp slogan that Australia once used to attract American tourists.
 But harvesting Australia's 25 million-strong kangaroo population to sell the meat around the world is a central element in a new land care strategy being promoted here by scientists, ranchers, environmentalists and government officials. 
 The kangaroo, unique to Australia, is among the world's most numerous large mammals, a pest in some areas that competes with cattle and sheep for grasslands, and, for some, a low-fat delicacy. 
Despite the kangaroo's symbolic status, about two million are killed each year to control the population, and most of those end up as pet food. The kangaroo's value and treatment are now the subjects of renewed debate here.
Advocates of kangaroo ranching differ on the specifics, but agree that it has a place among a variety of long-term actions needed to halt chronic soil degradation and diversify sources of farm incomes.
They urge making the prolific kangaroo an export product as a way to jump-start economic and conservation reforms in arid rangelands.
Animal welfare activists here and in the United States argue that mass harvesting could lead to the extinction of several major species.
But although vast numbers of kangaroos are killed each year by professional shooters and on the nation's roads, kangaroos still outnumber the human population of 19.3 million.
The main lobbying groups on rural issues, the National Farmers Federation and the Australian Conservation Foundation, are warning of "an alarming crisis in degradation of the productivity and environmental value of rural landscapes."
Citing "a long history of inappropriate land use," the groups called, in a recent report, for "changes in rural economies" to enable 15 percent of all agricultural output to come from "environmentally accredited" land within 10 years.
That would require public and private investment of about $30 billion to protect and repair threatened and damaged soil, water and vegetation resources. It would also require a change of heart and habit among beef and wool producers, as well as most of the nation's political leaders.
In last month's national election, in which Prime Minister John Howard and his conservative government won a third term, the major parties did not address the erosion, salinization and acidity already degrading an estimated five million acres.
Michael Archer, an American-trained biologist who is the director of the Australian Museum here, is raising money for a research and advocacy program of "land experiment" called the Future of Australia's Threatened Ecosystems.
Professor Archer called for a new "economic strategy to reduce dependence on conventional livestock, increase sustainable kangaroo harvesting, and double protected zones to about 20 percent of all land."
Around the township of Wentworth, 500 miles west of Sydney, 16 sheep and cattle ranchers who work 800,000 acres recently decided to rotate herds and encourage the growth of resilient native grasses.
Annabel Walsh, a rancher whose family has 10,000 sheep on 60,000 acres, says they have to shoot 1,200 kangaroos each year. "Pressure on the land is our problem," she said. "There has been overgrazing for a century. But solutions have to be ground-up from local people, not top-down from city experts."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: HOLIDAY; 
Fast Ends in Kabul, But a Hunger Grows For a New, Better Life

BYLINE:  By AMY WALDMAN 

DATELINE: KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 16 

 BODY:
The rollicking call-and-response of gunfire that echoed throughout this city on Saturday night was meant to celebrate the end of Ramadan and the arrival of Eid al-Fitr. But the exuberant fusillades seemed to signify more than the endurance of 30 days of fasting dawn to dusk.
 Afghans had emerged, battered but unbowed, from yet another war, one of many in their brutal history. With apparently unintentional irony, the settling in of peace here was celebrated with the sounds of war. 
 Eid, which Muslims throughout the world began observing today, is a time for visiting family, making peace with enemies, and of course eating. In Afghanistan, where the three-day observance of Eid came sandwiched between the fall of the Taliban and the inauguration of a new government, it was also a time for personal celebrations of change and hope.
The bazaar on Saturday pulsed with the ebullience of pre-Eid shoppers. "We are freer now the Taliban cannot inflict cruelty anymore," said Mirza Khan, a 45-year-old shopkeeper from Kandahar.
The hugs exchanged at the mosque after prayers this morning carried a special warmth. Everywhere were reminders of small freedoms restored -- a dandy strutting about in new, Western-style trousers he could not have worn a year ago; a woman at the bazaar lifting her burka off her face to get a better look at a pile of secondhand clothes.
But like a flashlight sending its beam into the darkness, Eid also cast a cold light on how many lives here had been broken by war and poverty. The expectations of Eid -- new clothes for the family, cookies, nuts and sweets to offer visiting relatives -- stretched thin the wallets and ingenuity of the army of jobless here. It was painfully easy today to tell the comfortable children, in bright new clothes, from the poor.
On Friday, Habibullah, a government employee who has not been paid in four months, lined up for the third day in a row to try to get some wheat so that his four children could eat during Eid. On Saturday, Mr. Khan, whose carpentry shop in Kandahar, and thus his livelihood, had been damaged by American bombs, bought a meager amount of cookies from Ghulam Rasoul Faizi, a former professor who had been fired by the Taliban.
Nafisa Mahmoudi, whose husband was fired by the pre-Taliban government of President Burhannudin Rabbani, picked through a bin of secondhand clothes looking for one "new" thing she could bring her five daughters. Anisgul, a widow unable to outfit her children in new clothes, bought socks for her daughter, a hat for her son and a packet of sweets for visiting relatives. Mari, married to an unemployed mechanic, bargained for shoes with money her 13-year-old son, Rohullah, had made baking cookies for Eid.
This morning, women and sooty children gathered in a line well-ordered by soldiers outside the Wazir Akbhar Khan Mosque, waiting to beg from the men who had gone inside to pray. When a man produced a bill, they clawed over one another trying to reach it, then rearranged themselves and their burkas as if sitting for a portrait.
At her home, a Kabul resident named Saleha set out a tray of dried peas and raisins and a plate of cookies -- all she could afford -- poured some weak tea and talked about the darkness of the last half-decade. For the fifth straight Eid, since they were fired by the Taliban from a government education office, she and her husband were without jobs. She had managed to find some work cleaning and doing laundry. Her husband, 60, had slowly lost his mind and his health.
"My life is one of sadness," she said, at 34 looking more like her husband's daughter than his wife. From her window, she could see a hill where American bombs had landed.
But for the first time in years, she at least had hope. "This is the first Eid we have had happiness," she said. "We are the most optimistic we have been."
It was a theme echoed at least among the most destitute: things could change only for the better. For now, Mr. Khan, the carpenter and cookie buyer, said, "it does not matter that I do not have money." He was enjoying his freedom, and waiting for Western aid to change his life.
This morning, for the first time in several years, thousands of men exercised their freedom of choice about where to worship. The Taliban had tried to force everyone to go to the main mosque.
This year, it was sparsely attended, as men fanned out to mosques around the city. At one, the Wazir Akbhar Khan Mosque, a cleric exercised his right to free expression.
Last year, clerics-in-training had come to speak in Arabic, although almost no one understood them. This year, the cleric spoke bluntly about Afghanistan's hopes and its vulnerabilities. He called on government ministers abroad to return home and bring their educated children, and money, with them. If they only came seeking power, he said, those at the mosque should pray that they would be killed on the way.
It was a serious note on a day of fun. Children crowded onto ramshackle wooden playground equipment. Families crowded into parks.
Children and adults played a game of cracking two hard-boiled eggs against each other. The one whose egg cracked had to give it up. The game had been banned by the Taliban, who said it was gambling.
With almost every shop in the city closed, the streets were virtually empty. The balloon sellers, however, were out -- their peddling part of the eternal struggle here to stay financially afloat, their wares aloft like the newly untethered spirits of Kabul.

HEADLINE: Back in Her Truck, Reno Jump-Starts Her Campaign 

BYLINE:  By DANA CANEDY

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 16 

 BODY:
It was a different crowd than the one Janet Reno faced when she wiggled her hips and pumped her fists on "Saturday Night Live" in January, but she drew chuckles just the same when she did a similar dance in a campaign appearance at a retirement community in Boca Raton last week.
 Ms. Reno has, in fact, been doing the unexpected since she started her campaign for governor from the back porch of her house in September. Though she suspended much of her campaign in the weeks after the terrorist attacks, Ms. Reno is plowing ahead once again, raising money, hiring a campaign manager and making the case for why she should replace Jeb Bush, the president's brother, in Tallahassee. 
 From the start, it has been an unorthodox campaign, which seems to suit the Clinton-administration attorney general just fine. When, for example, a potential voter asked Ms. Reno during a recent appearance if it would be O.K. to call her at home to ask a few questions, Ms. Reno ripped a deposit slip with her phone number on it from her checkbook and handed it to the woman. And shortly after Ms. Reno announced her candidacy, one of her fans, the talk show host and actress Rosie O'Donnell, called to offer her support. Ms. O'Donnell is giving a $250-a-plate fund-raiser for Ms. Reno in Miami this month.
But whether Ms. Reno's celebrity and folksy campaign style will translate into votes is hotly debated in restaurants, centers for the elderly and political circles here. After Sept. 11, a race that was expected to be driven to a large extent by voters' already strong views about the two high-profile candidates is even more likely to center on issues like states' roles in national security and on Florida's economy.
"I would say the state budget and economy and how it affects things like education may end up at the top of the list," said Jim Kane, director of the Florida Voter Poll, a political news and polling service.
Since the terrorist attacks, Florida's economy has been hit hard by a steep decline in tourism. Weeks after the attacks, the Fort Lauderdale-based Renaissance Cruises announced it was going out of business. Then the ANC Rental Corporation, the parent of the Alamo and National car rental companies, which is also in Fort Lauderdale, filed for bankruptcy protection. 
Walt Disney World, meanwhile, has reduced employee hours at some attractions. At the same time, the state faced such a severe budget crisis that legislators held a special session in which they made cuts in a wide range of programs, including education and social services.
"We know from past experiences that governors tend to get beaten in elections when the economy is doing bad," Mr. Kane said. "But one thing Reno seems weakest on is the budget and economy. She tends to speak on children and the elderly, but she needs policy advice on how to deal with Florida's economy crisis. Otherwise, she will lose credibility." 
Ms. Reno, 63, a former Florida attorney general, has just hired a campaign manager, who says she will lay out her agenda in the coming months. "It's clearly a long road ahead, and it's going to be a challenging race, but we feel very good about where things are, and we're going to have a lot of fun over the next year getting her message out," said Mo Elleithee, the campaign manager, who most recently worked as communications director for Governor-elect Mark Warner of Virginia.
Mr. Elleithee's job will most likely include keeping up with his candidate, who likes to travel alone to campaign appearances in her pickup truck. She is planning a "red truck tour" from the Alabama border through the entire state, where she says she believes she can sway voters who have not yet heard from her.
Whether Ms. Reno's down-home approach is a reflection of her personal style or a deliberate strategy created by public relations advisers like the local Vodicka Quintero Group is unclear. 
Some political observers say, however, that some aspects of her strategy are fashioned after the everyman style that worked so well for the late Gov. Lawton Chiles. Mr. Chiles, who died in 1998, earned the nickname Walkin' Lawton when he took a 91-day walking tour of the state from the Alabama line to Key Largo in 1970.
"She is a very down-to-earth woman, and that is exactly the way Lawton Chiles was; to some extent, there is a similarity there," said Barbara Corwin, who was a close adviser of Mr. Chiles for 23 years. "I don't know with her being a female that she could carry the good-old-boy laid-back attitude that Lawton had. Women have to carry a higher profile in the political arena."
So far, Ms. Reno's approach seems to have caught on in some sections of the state. She has been met by packed audiences in heavily Democratic South Florida, where people call her refreshing, earnest, cool. But she is likely to be a tough if not impossible sell in the staunchly Republican Panhandle, if diners at the Coffee Cup Restaurant in Pensacola are any indication.
"I just couldn't vote for Reno," said Suzanne Peele, 56, who works part time for a trauma intervention program. "She seems like a principled person with good values, but I don't believe she has the leadership qualities that are needed. She didn't show enough independence from the president, and the Justice Department should stand apart from the executive branch."
The sense of Ms. Reno in South Florida could hardly be more different. At her appearance at a community for the elderly in Boca Raton on Thursday, 500 retirees pushed walkers and fold-up chairs to squeeze into an event intended for 250 people. 
"She has the knowledge, she has the determination, she has the ability," said Isabella Fink, 84. Besides, Ms. Fink said, "She just envelops the audience. It's just plain love that people have for her." 
Even though other well-known Democratic contenders dropped out after she entered the race, Ms. Reno knows the challenges that lie ahead if she wins the primary next fall. People still question her about Elian Gonzalez and her affliction with Parkinson's disease and associate her with Bill Clinton's misdeeds. On top of that, she is running against an incumbent who is the brother of a president leading the nation in war.
As a result she has to choose her words carefully. 
"I wish for this country and for the president of the United States success in bringing the terrorists to justice," Ms. Reno said in an interview. "I wish that it be done consistent with our Constitution and our laws and that it be done without infringing on our freedom, and if the president of the United State can do that, more power to him. And if Jeb uses his coattails, more power to him, but I will still be talking about the issues that are important to the people of the state of Florida."

HEADLINE: Reforming Elections, a Year Later 

 BODY:
Washington indirectly took notice of a painful anniversary last week. A year after the Supreme Court intervened to bring the 2000 presidential election to its messy conclusion, the House of Representatives passed a bill to overhaul the nation's flawed voting process. A key group of senators from both parties agreed the next day to embrace a stronger measure that is expected to be voted on in January. The President should ultimately sign a bill that more closely resembles the Senate's approach to ensure that the federal government adequately protects the integrity of national elections. 
 Most Americans assumed Congress would fix such a glaring problem, one so basic to the health of our democracy, without tarrying so long. That it took a year to come this far is due to the clashing partisan agendas that invariably intrude on election matters -- with Democrats eager to make it easier to vote, and Republicans harder to commit fraud -- and to the extreme deference still paid to states' rights, even when not owed. 
 The House bill that passed by a resounding vote of 362 to 63 establishes goals for states to meet in improving their election procedures and provides them with $2.65 billion to do so, including $400 million for jurisdictions to replace their infamous punch-card systems. Having the federal government underwrite elections to this degree is unprecedented. It is also timely. Elections have never ranked high on most states' spending priorities, and current economic conditions have depleted state treasuries.
Regrettably, the House bill stops short of imposing some meaningful mandates on states. For too many of the bill's laudable goals, states are granted great discretion in deciding how, or whether, to meet them. This is true when it comes to making polls accessible to voters with disabilities, affording voters a chance to correct a miscast ballot and granting voters the right to a provisional ballot when they do not appear on precinct lists. 
Most alarming, states would still not be forced to meet a uniform, national standard for error rates in elections. Americans surely do not expect that a costly federal overhaul of elections could still result in a patchwork system, with states offering varying degrees of reliability. In a national election, ballots in one state should not face a significantly higher probability of not getting counted than ballots in another.
By contrast, the Senate bill would impose more stringent mandates. States would be required to offer provisional ballots and make computerized voter lists accessible in polling places by the 2004 election. Technology that enables voters to correct undervotes (ballots with no candidate selected) and overvotes (more than one candidate) would be required by the 2006 midterm elections. That deadline should be moved up.
The bill includes some sensible federal mandates aimed at reducing fraud. These include requiring ID checks for first-time voters who did not register in person. Making it easier to vote and harder to cheat now becomes the Senate's bipartisan cause. Once the Senate bill passes, President Bush and House leaders ought to embrace it as well. Americans want national elections to be governed by a strong set of uniform standards, and they want the changes made soon.

HEADLINE: New Jersey's High Rollers 

 BODY:
It should not come as a surprise that New Jersey's outgoing Legislature has indulged in a last-minute spending spree. As any political force cedes power -- in this case the state's Republicans, who turn over the Trenton statehouse to Democrats in a few weeks -- there is often a frantic, last-chance aspect to the final days in office. In New Jersey, lawmakers are piling the sides of pork so high that the scene has begun to look like slapstick comedy. 
 Governor-elect James McGreevey, a Democrat who replaces Donald DiFrancesco, a Republican, has pleaded with outgoing legislators, including members of his own party, to freeze state funds. He argues that New Jersey is facing a deficit of $1.9 billion, a financial hole that starts his term with very few pleasant options. But making Mr. McGreevey's life easy is not on the Legislature's priority list. Instead, every pet project is having its day: one would increase pension benefits for retiring legislators, a special favor to a well-heeled Democrat who switched to the Republican Party just when it needed him most. Another favor would lower the tax on cigars -- apparently still a staple in some political quarters. Legislators are considering money for dredging, dams, new driver's licenses and historical site restoration -- all courtesy of the very politicians who boast that they are the state's fiscal conservatives. 
 Two important proposals are also dangerously high on the wish list of some members of the Trenton crowd. One is a plan to revive the flagging town of Camden. The other would authorize all kinds of expensive extras in the name of creating the Newark Arena. Camden and Newark need help, but with more artful plans that promote urban development with something other than state spending.
Mr. McGreevey, who believes he has scuttled these plans for now, has talked about a targeted Camden revival plan that is similar to plans pushed by former Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania. That would be an improvement on the State Senate's $180 million bill, which throws money at everything in the town. In the wake of Sept. 11, the revival of Camden must be done cautiously. The legislative proposal for a downtown arena in Newark also threatens to turn into a $1 billion pork feast that deserves to die of its own weight or be trimmed to something that spares the state all but the most minimal support.
Governing in the next few years will be difficult enough for Mr. McGreevey and the next Legislature. If the outgoing legislators spend all their money, the incoming crowd will have to raise taxes or cut local funds, requiring local communities to raise property taxes. Those options could still become necessary if revenues are as bad as Mr. McGreevey predicts, but at this point, New Jersey's legislators should be careful not to squander what little they still have.

HEADLINE: Competition Fierce for Stake in New York Gambling Market 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
From urban vacant lots on New York's western edge to swatches of grassland and woods on the southern flank of the Catskill Mountains, and in corporate boardrooms from Rochester to Reno, a quiet gold rush is under way.
 When Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature acted in October to create the biggest expansion of legalized gambling in the state's history, the obvious winners were Indian tribes and racetracks. The tribes secured approval for as many as six casinos, and the tracks won the right to install video gambling machines, little different from slot machines. 
 But the new law will also create another set of major victors, if it survives the expected legal challenges: the companies that win contracts to build and operate casinos, and supply them with gambling equipment. 
The companies, ranging from billion-dollar corporations to local entrepreneurs hoping that lightning will strike, have been buying property, hiring architects, romancing tribal and government officials and investing in lobbyists and campaign contributions. Some entered this competition years ago, others more recently, and all have stepped up their efforts in the last few months.
To the gambling industry, the October law represents a once-in-a-generation opportunity, the opening of a vast New York market that has been closed to legal gambling beyond horse races and the state lottery.
If the new law survives court battles, and the proposed casinos win state and federal approvals, that new market will produce revenues of $3 billion to $4 billion a year, industry officials and analysts predict.
"We are not talking about a drop in the bucket here," said G. Thomas Baker, chief executive of International Game Technology, or I.G.T., the world's largest maker of gambling machines. "This is a significant market."
Harrah's, the world's second-largest casino company, is one of several companies that have made a proposal to the Seneca Nation of Indians, hoping the tribe will choose them to build and run as many as three casinos in western New York. Harrah's says it has also discussed a Catskills casino with another tribe -- it will not say which one -- and scouted locations, armed with a feasibility study it conducted on the region several years ago.
Such casinos in New York would take some business away from Atlantic City, doubling the resolve of casino companies there to get a piece of the action in New York.
"If someone's going to cannibalize us, I want to be the cannibal," said Philip G. Satre, chief executive of Harrah's, which has two Atlantic City casinos. He said his company was talking with the Senecas "long before the bill was passed."
Park Place Entertainment, the world's largest casino company, has a development deal with the St. Regis Mohawk Tribe for a casino at Kutsher's Country Club, outside of Monticello in the Catskills, a resort that Park Place has an option to buy. That project is further along than any other in New York, and construction could begin as early as next year.
The Delaware North Companies of Buffalo is another bidder to build and run casinos for the Senecas, who have taken proposals from several companies. Like many of its competitors, Delaware North has bought up potential casino sites in Buffalo and Niagara Falls, and possibly elsewhere, and commissioned mock-ups to show tribal officials. And like its competitors, it guards that information jealously, refusing to disclose those locations or show the models to reporters.
Delaware North, a $1.3-billion-a-year conglomerate, is a national leader in food service at sports stadiums and airports. It owns eight horse or dog racing tracks and operates resort hotels. Its chairman, Jeremy M. Jacobs, owns the Fleet Center in Boston and the Bruins professional hockey team that plays its home games there.
The company has ventured into the gambling field, with its racetracks and video gambling machines at one track in West Virginia, but it has never run a casino.
"We've got a long history in New York, and we think that makes a difference," said Louis M. Jacobs, executive vice president of Delaware North.
Other local companies, large and small, with no gambling experience at all, are also vying for a role. Probably the largest is Flaum Management, a Rochester-based real estate company. Flaum has bought three vacant lots as possible casino sites, in and around the Catskills town of Mamakating, near Route 17 in Sullivan County.
"We started accumulating land five years ago in anticipation that something might happen," said David M. Flaum, chairman and chief executive. "This is a really big opportunity for us. We're speaking to several tribes. I can't tell you which ones, but because we have this great land, we're getting a lot of phone calls."
As for his company's lack of experience in gambling, he said, "Casino management is not rocket science."
Several real estate developers and speculators have bought Catskills property in recent years, saying that they have no immediate plans to be casino operators but merely hope to cash in on the economic boom they expect casinos to bring to the region. Most prominent among them is Louis R. Cappelli, a Westchester County developer with close ties to the Pataki administration, who has bought the Concord and Grossinger's, two of the Catskills' largest resorts.
In the last decade, more than 200 Indian casinos have sprung up across the country, including two in upstate New York, run by the Mohawks and the Oneida Nation. Most Indian casinos are modest affairs, far from urban areas, and the tribes usually operate the casinos themselves, hiring a few outsiders to help. Only a few tribes -- generally those with the biggest operations -- have hired companies like Harrah's or Sun International to run their casinos.
"The closer you are to a population center, the better off you are, and the more those arrangements with outside management make sense," said Richard Schiff, deputy chief of staff of the National Indian Gaming Commission, a federal agency.
New York tribes have signaled that they plan to go with companies that can supply expertise and large-scale capital investment.
The new gambling law allows for three Seneca casinos in western New York, and three in the Catskills. The tribes that would get the Catskills casinos are not specified, but it is widely assumed that one would go to the Mohawks, and other tribes have expressed interest in getting into the business.
The National Indian Gaming Commission, which must approve management contracts, generally limits them to five years and caps the management company's take at 30 percent of revenues. Several tribes have used that five-year period to learn casino management, and then taken over the operations.
Jason N. Ader, a gambling industry analyst at Bear Stearns, said the likeliest corporate winner in the New York rush is International Game Technology, of Reno, Nev., which controls more than 70 percent of the slot machine market.
"No matter who gets the deal to manage the facilities," he said, "they have to have the games, and the equipment companies are going to have a windfall."
If all the planned projects come to pass, New York would have 12,000 to 20,000 slot and slot-type machines at casinos and racetracks. (The machines at the tracks would technically be part of the state lottery system, though they would not be all that distinguishable from the machines in casinos.)
To put that into perspective, the two Connecticut casinos have fewer than 9,000, while Atlantic City has 36,000. Those machines sell for about $10,000 apiece, so the initial sales could reach $200 million, and slots are typically replaced every five to seven years.
Gambling machine makers have been quietly lobbying casino operators who might get into the New York market -- and, to some extent, the tribes themselves -- in hopes of winning contracts.
"Trust me, we're in contact with every possible casino operator," said a top executive of one gambling machine maker.
Mr. Baker of I.G.T. said, "Our people are in touch back there," but he would not elaborate.
New York is drawing such intense interest because of its enormous, largely untapped markets. New Yorkers who are determined to play casino-style games already have myriad options -- a train ride to Atlantic City, a bus trip to Connecticut -- but this is something else entirely.
The new law points to a future in which casino-style gambling would be an easy, even casual part of everyday life for millions of New Yorkers, with video lottery terminals at tracks like Aqueduct in Queens, Yonkers Raceway and several upstate tracks; a full-fledged casino in downtown Buffalo and another in downtown Niagara Falls; and as many as three casinos in the Catskills, barely an hour's drive from New York City.
The two Connecticut casinos, Foxwoods and the Mohegan Sun, are widely regarded as the most successful in the world, with estimated combined revenues (they do not make actual figures public) of $1.9 billion a year. Their success has been attributed to having a vast New England market to themselves.
More than seven million people live within 100 miles of the Connecticut casinos, according to a Bear Stearns analysis. For casinos in Sullivan County, that figure would be about 19 million people within 100 or so miles.
"When you put a casino near a large population base, the market grows significantly," said Mr. Satre of Harrah's.
In other words, when gambling suddenly becomes convenient, many people who did not gamble before will start, and those who already gambled will gamble more.

HEADLINE: The Strength That Is New York 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "Out of Many, New York," by Mario Vargas Llosa (Op-Ed, Dec. 11), hypothesizes that New York's wondrous diversity catalyzes the hatred of our fanatical enemies. Missing, however, from the author's examples is the dichotomy between the very rich and the very poor -- and the regrettable fact that the wealthy do so little to uplift the needy. 
 We must explore why so many of the world's dispossessed are disappointed by America. Except in high-profile disaster relief missions, our nation, which often describes itself as motivated by religious charity, has done next to nothing to bring the poor of the world into the orbit of economic self-sufficiency. None of this excuses Sept. 11, but it is food for thought as the United States rethinks its agendas, domestic and foreign.

ROBERT J. ALLEN
New York, Dec. 12, 2001

HEADLINE: As Welfare Comes to an End, So Do the Jobs 

BYLINE:  By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
The subway cars on the W line snake from Queens through the heart of Manhattan and on to Brooklyn, collecting dirt and debris from thousands of riders. At the end of the line, on an elevated platform in sight of Coney Island's Ferris wheel, a dozen people in green vests sweep, scrape and swab the grime away.
 Transit-system employees doing the same tasks on a neighboring platform earn from $11 to $19 an hour, with union benefits. But the "green vests" are not working for pay. Like 300 other people cleaning subway cars and stations for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, they are recruits from New York City's workfare program -- by far the largest in the nation -- laboring in exchange for a welfare grant and the hope of being hired. 
 Daisy Torres, a 34-year-old mother of three who was raised on welfare, gets a subway car's floor so clean that her supervisor swears you could eat off it. James Howard, 42, a 10th grade dropout who did odd jobs off the books to supplement his family's public assistance grant in years past, had almost perfect attendance. 
They were striving to join the 122 subway car cleaners who had gone on to permanent jobs with the authority, out of hundreds who began the program. But after many assurances that they were on a list to be hired, Ms. Torres and Mr. Howard were among dozens who got a double dose of bad news last month. Because of the deepening recession, the authority had imposed a hiring freeze. And, under federal law, the city's Human Resources Administration informed them, their welfare benefits were at an end.
They and the other "green vests," recruited over the past 18 months, are only a few among the thousands who have participated in the Work Experience Program that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani made the centerpiece of his welfare overhaul. But their circumstances illustrate both Mr. Giuliani's extraordinary success in reshaping the city's safety net around work, and the new pitfalls, even for those who have followed the rules, as time limits and bad times converge.
In states from New Hampshire to Hawaii, the first welfare families are reaching the five-year federal limit just as the economy slumps. But New York City has by far the largest number of people working for their benefits, and nowhere else are so many of them reaching the cutoff at the same time.
Although state law has spread a safety net of sorts for those losing federal benefits, some may already be falling through it. 
In a welfare office in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, where signs declare "Your Clock is Ticking," and "Make an Effort, Not an Excuse," Mr. Howard veered between fatalism and anger. "I made lots of efforts," he said. "Working out there, freezing, wearing three pairs of socks and two coats, just to get the job. And now they won't even give me a chance." 
Ms. Torres, fingering a stack of "outstanding" job evaluations and scary welfare notices in the family's one-bedroom Brooklyn apartment, clung to hope. "My struggle and my goal is all about my kids," she said, eyeing Guillermo, 12, Elisa, 8, and Giovanni, 6, as Christmas lights twinkled from the fire escape.
Its champions say that workfare, which evolved under the commissioner of the Human Resources Administration, Jason A. Turner, into an elaborate mix of work assignments, job training and job searches, has been a way for welfare recipients to give back to the city and a path to real jobs for many.
Its critics contend that it has been a dead end for many poor people in need of education and training, a way to cut and divert people from public benefits and create a tide of cheap labor that has swept thousands of paying jobs from city payrolls. 
The authority's program provides evidence for both arguments. Hailed as a national model when it was announced in 1996, it started two years ago in a more modest version. Of 9,509 people sent to the subways on workfare since December 1999, the authority said, 4,400 showed up, and 301 have been hired, 122 of them as subway car cleaners. The authority's director of labor relations, Gary Dellaverson, said that hiring record compared favorably with those of other workfare sites in the city.
"I'm proud of the project," said Mr. Dellaverson, who negotiated it in collective bargaining with the transit workers' union six years ago.
Gabriella Bello, a single mother of four with little knowledge of English and less education, is an example of how well the authority's workfare program turned out for some. After many years on welfare and four months of cleaning subway cars at the 179th Street terminal in Queens in exchange for her family's grant -- at a cost to the city of about $1.80 an hour -- Ms. Bello was hired in October of last year. Her hourly union wage rose to $13 this month, and she also receives the full $200 in monthly child-support paid by the younger children's father, rather than the $50 that the city passes through to mothers on welfare whose grants average $594 a month. 
"I feel free," said Ms. Bello, who left school in the Dominican Republic at 9 to work as a housekeeper for her mother. "I feel happy because I work to get my money."
But many of those assigned to the subways by the city had the worst of work and welfare. New leadership of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union Local 100 faults its predecessors for agreeing to a workfare program that a local vice president, Neil Persaud, said leaves welfare recipients without a paycheck and under constant threat that their benefits will be cut off -- "at the mercy of the boss," Mr. Persaud said. In his zeal to be hired, Mr. Howard, for example, became the Coney Island terminal's designated cleaner. He was called to dispose of bodily waste in subway cars, to heave garbage from the dank station below the tracks, to scour an employee bathroom that he was not allowed to use.
"This job would do wonders for my family," he explained the day after Thanksgiving, when he still hoped he might be hired. 
Exactly what workfare recruits were told about the chance of being hired is a matter of dispute. City officials say that no promises were made, and that hiring is dependent on vacancies -- which dwindled this year as turnover slowed in a souring economy. 
But in spring 2000, a Human Resources Administration memo to contract agencies called the subway program "an excellent opportunity" for recipients being prepared to move from welfare to work, and stated that after 90 days of successfully performing the work, "candidates who express an interest and have demonstrated initiative and a readiness to work (i.e. good attendance, punctuality, ability to follow directions, enthusiasm, etc.) will then be processed for hire" -- that is, after routine paperwork and medical exams they would be moved into union jobs starting at $30,000 a year.
Teachers at the contract agencies, where the cleaners spend two days of the work week in a supervised job search or in classes, said that as 90 days stretched into a year, vacancies were so scarce that some mothers broke down, torn by the needs of sick children, pressure for perfect attendance and looming time limits.
Mr. Dellaverson called the memo "misleading." As for five-year welfare time limits, he said, they have nothing to do with the authority.
Time limits had everything to do with the anxiety of veteran workfare cleaners at the end of the W line. 
"My time is almost up," Mr. Howard said in late November, gripping a broom with calloused hands. He looked back at the utility closet where he had eaten a bag lunch amid bottles of bleach, after cleaning the employees-only lunchroom upstairs. "I really thought I had the job," he said. "Now I don't know what's going to happen next month -- I don't want to lose my home."
During a prosperous decade, welfare policy focused so strongly on personal responsibility that the role of large economic forces and simple calamity almost disappeared from view -- until Sept. 11. Now, those seeking to make the transition face a badly weakened economy.
But hard times never really stopped for Mr. Howard. In the 1980's, he worked in factories that relocated to places where labor was cheaper. By the early 1990's, he said, he was doing whatever day jobs he found to help his disabled wife, Gaynell, raise their three children on public assistance. When she grew too ill to keep up with the new welfare demands, he became the official head of household and was responsible for fulfilling the workfare requirement. Eventually Mrs. Howard -- diabetic, blind in one eye, and with a history of psychiatric hospitalization -- qualified for a monthly $545 Supplemental Security Income check.
"If I lose my benefits, S.S.I. is the only thing that's going to cover the rent," Mr. Howard said, holding the notice that said his family had been denied transition to Safety Net, the state-financed aid for which it was still eligible when welfare benefits ended, because Mr. Howard had failed to apply in October. But at the time, his documents from the authority corroborated, he was finally being "processed for hire." 
Ms. Torres, usually a beaming presence over her sudsy mop, said she had cried in the Safety Net office, begging to be allowed to keep the subway post, since the station manager was sure she would be hired in the next round. Caseworkers told her there was nothing they could do. Instead, like several thousand of 30,000 recipients who reached the limit of welfare benefits on Dec. 2, she was offered a temporary, subsidized position as a Parks Department laborer and told that if she refused, her family would lose all aid.
To an extraordinary degree, Mr. Turner, the welfare commissioner, has succeeded in reorganizing a notoriously unmanageable bureaucracy around his work-first philosophy. City and state welfare officials point to recent studies finding that over all, the economic circumstances of poor New Yorkers improved substantially in the late 1990's, while the welfare rolls shrank to about 387,000 cases, half the 1995 peak. They insist that the transition to Safety Net went smoothly .
But on Nov. 26, when Mr. Howard went to the welfare labyrinth for help in keeping his family housed and fed, a different reality awaited. 
At the Manhattan address listed on the Safety Net letter, he was sent back to his local welfare office, the Bay Ridge Job Center. As toddlers cried and tugged at parents, the line inched forward near a poster that declared, "Winners Make the Grade; Whiners Make Excuses." One woman was in a wheelchair, another on crutches. Some clutched threats of eviction, medical bills, printouts of bureaucratic error. When his turn came, Mr. Howard was sent upstairs, to wait for his caseworker -- who could not help and sent him down to the line again . 
His wife joined him there, sent from her Supplemental Security Income office, she said, when she asked for help keeping food stamps.
"It's too late," another caseworker told them later, directing Mrs. Howard to an office in downtown Brooklyn, and giving Mr. Howard a number to call to appeal; it was constantly busy.
Later that week, on one of his last days working in the subway, Mr. Howard cleared 25 loads of trash from the station parking lot. When he paused to rest, a supervisor brusquely ordered him back to his mop.
"I'm not a slave," Mr. Howard shouted. "I'm a human being." 
Ms. Torres is hanging on. A new notice postponed her Parks Department orientation, scheduled for Nov. 29, without explanation. She does not know what Safety Net benefits, if any, will arrive this week; when she reads her daughter's Christmas list, she said, "it breaks my heart." 
But she is still cleaning subway cars under the Coney Island sea gulls, praying that the work she does can become her job.

HEADLINE: Can the Internet Be Left to the Market? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "The Broadband Economy," by Karen Kornbluh (Op-Ed, Dec. 10): Turning the broadband Internet into a regulated public utility isn't the answer for getting high-speed Internet services to the public.
 High-speed access is already available to most American homes, even in rural areas. 
The real question is whether Americans are willing to pay for it. The price is high but reasonable -- with most services running around $50 per month. If people choose not to avail themselves of it, there is no public policy issue to discuss. 
 Ms. Kornbluh's implication that capitalism is fine but that some infrastructure projects are just too big for the private sector to pull off is simply not the case. First, the subsidies to speed up this industry would have to come from taxes paid by the private sector in the first place. And contrary to myth, even the great infrastructure companies of the past -- electricity, phone service and railroads -- experienced tremendous rivalry before governments turned them into monopoly "utilities."

WAYNE CREWS
ADAM THIERER
Washington, Dec. 10, 2001

The writers are co-directors of technology policy, Cato Institute.

LENGTH: 159 words

HEADLINE: Can the Internet Be Left to the Market? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Karen Kornbluh ("The Broadband Economy," Op-Ed, Dec. 10) rightly points to the potential role government can play in correcting the "last mile" problem -- connecting homes and businesses to the broadband backbone. 
 The nationwide fiber-optic network is increasingly seen as a public asset. 
It is important to ensure that all have equal access to it. Telecommunications companies offer cheaper and faster service where population density is greatest and profits are the highest. Rural areas are increasingly being left behind. 
 Access to telecommunications technology is the gateway to economic development opportunities, education, health care and other essential public services. Our nation runs the risk of widening the digital divide unless the government commits to universal, public access to the broadband network.

CYNTHIA PANSING
Oakland, Calif., Dec. 10, 2001

The writer is director of the Common Assets Program at Redefining Progress.

HEADLINE: Economy & Business; 
Military Contractors Set to Begin Rare Experiment in Cooperation

BYLINE:  By LAURA M. HOLSON 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
The nation's response to the attack by suicide bombers on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon in September brought with it a renewed sense of pride in the military, from the pilots who test fighter jets to the makers of radar systems and submarines.
 But for the next 12 months, analysts say, much of the industry's focus will be on Fort Worth, where Lockheed Martin, the nation's largest military contractor, will build the next-generation stealth fighter airplane, the Joint Strike Fighter. 
 If the $200 billion Joint Strike Fighter project is successful -- and it will be many years before anyone knows -- it will be the first fighter jet adapted to fit the needs both of three branches of the American military and of Britain. The United States and Britain plan to buy 3,002 planes: the Air Force, 1,763; the Marines, 609; the Navy, 480; the British Royal Air Force, 90; and the British Royal Navy, 60. 
In an important departure for the industry itself, the cooperative effort, which includes BAE Systems, the British maker of sophisticated military equipment, and Northrop Grumman, could be a template for how industry rivals work together in the future.
Usually, projects are made up of a prime contractor who manages smaller subcontractors, and, indeed, the huge project will produce work for dozens of major subcontractors and hundreds of smaller suppliers involved in the jet's development. But a big difference in this case is that BAE and Northrop are full-fledged partners commanding a combined 32 percent stake. 
"This closely knit team could take prime partners to a new level," said Howard A. Rubel, a military industry analyst at Goldman, Sachs. 
Furthermore, the project will support thousands of jobs at Lockheed, based in Bethesda, Md., and its subcontractors for decades to come. Northrop Grumman, which is based in Los Angeles, will build the central fuselage for the fighter, as well as design its radar and stealth systems, and will hire as many as 1,300 additional engineers by 2003, the company says. 
BAE is expected to hire 250 workers in the United States, as well as add to its payroll in the British Midlands, where major sub assembly will take place. Final assembly will be at Lockheed's plant in Fort Worth.
Just how binding the partnership is will be tested in coming months as lobbyists for Boeing, which lost out to Lockheed to build the fighter jet, try to maneuver the company into the project. If Lockheed succumbs to political pressure and is forced to make room for Boeing, which executives say is unlikely, the move would surely anger both BAE and Northrop. 
Charles Thomas Burbage, an executive vice president of Lockheed and director of its Joint Strike Fighter program, said Lockheed and Boeing executives would meet this month to discuss Boeing's options.
For Boeing, which recently moved its headquarters to Chicago from Seattle, the loss of the contract is only the latest blow. Boeing is facing the elimination of 30,000 jobs, and orders for commercial airplanes which were already dwindling, have declined further, it says, because of the terrorist attacks in September.
The developments have changed the fortunes of investors, as well as of jobholders and seekers. Lockheed Martin's shares, although trading below their 52-week high of $52.98, set on Oct. 29, shortly after the contract was awarded, are up 35.64 percent this year, at $46.05. Boeing shares, which tumbled after the attacks, are down 43.11 percent this year, to $37.55, and Northrop Grumman has gained 13.75 percent this year, to $94.41.
Not all the innovation in coming years will be centered on pilot-operated high-powered fighters. The industry has also trained its sights on advanced surveillance equipment, which would not only make it easier to gather military information, but also put as few lives as possible at risk.
Here Northrop Grumman clearly has an edge. The Global Hawk, an unmanned precision aircraft that can quickly gather and deliver surveillance information from 65,000 feet, is already being tested in Afghanistan. "What is emerging is a need not to do a mission just to find a target, but to track everything all the time," said Robert A. K. Mitchell, a vice president for advanced programs at Northrop. "Now you have the technology to keep track of everything."
The Pentagon plans to buy 60 Global Hawks over the next few years. And if the Global Hawk turns out to be a hit, it could spur demand for different types of unmanned vehicles, including those with commercial applications like mapping, monitoring traffic, even shipping packages for services like Federal Express. The Pentagon has even explored the idea of building a fighter jet that would operate without pilots.
"The question is: 'How comfortable do you feel with a data link and not a man in the loop?' " Mr. Rubel said. "I don't think we are there yet."

HEADLINE: Economy & Business; 
Frugal Shoppers Worry Retailers

BYLINE:  By KATHLEEN MURRAY

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. 

 BODY:
Loaded down with six shopping bags, Debbie Mahoney looked like a typical holiday shopper as she searched for one final gift in Sears earlier this month. But appearances can be deceiving. 
 "This year is going to be real scaled back," said Ms. Mahoney, a 36-year-old mother from Arlington, Mass., noting most of the bags were from the Gap where her son worked, and she was getting a special one-day 40 percent family discount. "I'm really not doing it up like I have in past years," she said. 
 Ms. Mahoney, who manages a dry cleaning service, said she was worried about her job and uneasy about her husband's as a truck driver. In addition to clothing, she is buying practical things this year, like the bed cover she still hopes to find for her son, and she has sworn off a spree at the after-Christmas sales. "You just don't know what's going to happen, so I feel better if we keep a little money in the bank." 
Retailers are similarly wary, not knowing how long the recession will last, or how much overextended consumers will spend after the holidays.
"The spending outlook for the first half of next year is rueful," said Robert Buchanan, a retail analyst with A. G. Edwards in St. Louis, adding, "It's just as dour for the rest of the economy."
Industry sales in the critical Christmas season are expected to be flat for the first time since the 1990 recession, despite aggressive discounts and special promotions.
Even before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks dampened Americans' spirits, many retailers were slumping. Upscale merchants like Neiman Marcus, Saks Fifth Avenue and Tiffany began to see a decline last year in their fortunes, along with the values of their customers' stock portfolios, leading them to reduce inventory, pare orders and cut expenses.
Also, traditional department stores have been losing market share to specialty retailers and discount stores like Wal-Mart Stores and Target for some time. "We're in a tough economic environment and proceeding accordingly," said Cathy Wright, a spokeswoman for Target, which also owns Marshall Field's and the ailing Mervyn's.
Sales and markdowns have reduced supplies on the shelves at Marshall Field's department stores, and the company predicts sales in the current quarter will be down from a year ago. Federated Department Stores, which owns Macy's and Bloomingdale's, expects sales to decline 7 percent to 10 percent in the fourth quarter. Gap, which has been perhaps the most beleaguered of all specialty apparel stores, has sharply reduced inventories for the holiday season and the first quarter of 2002. It also held its first friends-and-family event, the special-invitation sale attended by Ms. Mahoney, in an attempt to bolster business.
But analysts say the toughest challenges lie ahead, and the promotions are one reason for that. "Some retailers have been stealing business from January and February in December with these huge markdowns," Todd Slater, a retail analyst with Lazard Freres, said. "You can't do that indefinitely."
Gross profit margins at Gap, which also owns Old Navy and Banana Republic, slipped to 31 percent in 2001 from 37 percent a year earlier and 42 percent in 1999. Wal-Mart, Kohl's and Costco Wholesale have felt some squeeze as well, but their margins have declined by only a fraction of a percentage point as consumers have become more cost-conscious in a stalled economy.
After initially losing customers in the weeks following Sept. 11, sales rebounded at Wal-Mart, based in Bentonville, Ark., rising 6.7 percent over the previous year in the third quarter. H. Lee Scott Jr., Wal-Mart's chief executive, predicted annual earnings growth would return to its 15 percent target in 2002.
Kohl's, the fast-growing value retailer based in Menomonee Falls, Wis., is also an industry favorite because of its low-cost merchandising and efficient, automated inventory system. It posted sales increases of 6 percent through the third quarter at stores open at least a year, added 62 stores this year and plans to open 70 more in 2002. "Right now it's full speed ahead," David Kandel, a Kohl's spokesman, said.
Industry watchers also expect specialty stores that emphasize home and hearth to do relatively well, siphoning further business from department stores. Bed Bath and Beyond, Home Depot and some book retailers should continue to attract customers who travel less, spend less and cocoon more, Mr. Buchanan of A. G. Edwards said. Online retailing -- which is projected at $67 billion this year, up from $46 billion in 2000, according to the National Retail Federation -- could also gain as consumers shy away from malls and shopping centers.
The bleakest prospects are reserved for department stores and specialty apparel stores. Even some discount chains are struggling. 
Ames Department Stores, the nation's No. 4 discount retailer after Wal-Mart, Target and Kmart, announced this month that it would close 54 stores next year. Ames, which filed for bankruptcy protection in August, had previously closed or planned to close 63 other stores. After the latest closings, it will have 333 stores in the East and Midwest.
Sales have stalled at the former darling Abercrombie & Fitch as its latest fashions have failed to catch on with young people. Many specialty retailers are further dogged by overcapacity -- stores have been added at a rate of 10 percent a year, which might have worked in a boom economy but will not now.
Retailers who fare best in the gloomy months ahead are expected to be those that stick to the basics -- merchandising, marketing and figuring out the most cost-efficient way to do it. For example, J. C. Penney, which has floundered in recent years, posted sales increases of 5 percent in the third quarter of 2001 for stores open at least a year after revamping inventory and marketing to cut costs and lure customers.
Target, which has posted solid sales increases this year, is trying to extend its reach online. In October, the discounter agreed with Amazon.com to cross-list products on each other's Web sites. "It's all about finding win-win situations," Ms. Wright of Target said.
But the crucial challenge will remain finding customers willing to spend. Mr. Slater of Lazard Freres said that both traffic and the amount spent per sales transaction were stronger than expected at many retailers during the start of this holiday season. Also, he said, retailers may benefit as consumers who have become wary of travel and leisure pursuits use the cash meant for those activities to go shopping.
And, of course, not everyone is gloomy. At a mall in Cambridge, Mass., George Georgiev pointed to the new red velvet dress that his 4-year-old daughter was wearing. He and his wife, Boriana, bought the dress on the spur of the moment, and they were clutching shopping bags filled with more purchases. "Our situation is different than many people," he said. "My wife just went back to work, so we feel we can buy what we want this year."
Still, most economists do not expect to see signs of a recovery until the second half of next year. Many in the industry think it could be the third quarter of 2002 or later before things start improving in retail.
"We're paying for unbridled enthusiasm," Mr. Buchanan, the A. G. Edwards analyst, said. He said retailers had opened too many stores, apparel producers had built too many plants and consumers had too much debt. "It's going to take a while to get out of this."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Retailers, like this Kmart in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., are lowering prices. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Economy & Business; 
Automakers' Big Sales Now May Cut Business Next Year

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: FARMINGTON HILLS, Mich. 

 BODY:
Car buyers have a really pleasant prob lem a great variety of vehicles from which to choose, and the choice has been made all the better by all the aggressive incentives that the Big Three rolled out to spur demand after Sept. 11.
 But what is good for consumers this year could spell pain for the industry next year. Most analysts say the post-Sept. 11 interest-free financing blitz stole buyers from 2002. That means there will be too many cars next year and not enough buyers. 
 Interest-free financing deals, started by General Motors and adopted by Ford Motor and the Chrysler Group of DaimlerChrysler, raised sales to record levels, including more than 1.7 million cars and light trucks in October, the biggest sales month on record. That was good news for the beleaguered economy, as well as for car buyers, but for the Big Three and their stockholders, it was bad news in terms of the bottom line.
Take Ford. The cost of incentives jumped to 16 percent of revenue in 2001 from 11 percent of revenue in 2000, the company's chief financial officer, I. Martin Inglis, said in October. Each percentage point increase slices away $1 billion of pretax profits, a phenomenon that contributed to Ford's first projected annual net loss since 1992 -- $880 million, or 48 cents a share, according to consensus analysts' projections compiled by Thomson Financial/First Call.
"The sales number can be hard to read, but the profits are clearly going to be under pressure," said Nicholas Lobaccaro, an analyst at Lehman Brothers. "Ford and Chrysler will suffer the most. This is just a weak time in their product cycles, and all the cost-cutting in the world probably won't get them in the black."
G.M. led the push to interest-free financing because it is in a stronger position than its rivals with a fresh lineup of sport utility vehicles and pickups and is gaining market share after years of declines. Ford and Chrysler matched the G.M. offer, grudgingly, in order to stay competitive.
Most analysts criticize using incentives to buy sales, but G.M. has its reasons. The company has about 2.5 retirees per active worker in the United States, and its market share has shrunk from about 60 percent in 1950 to about 28 percent today, making it more burdensome to pay benefits to retirees. Now G.M. must find a way to make its short-term gains in market share last.
G.M. hired Robert A. Lutz, Detroit's favorite "car guy" and the champion of the PT Cruiser, to add pizazz to its lineup. Ford brought back an eye-catching design of its Thunderbird and installed Nicholas V. Scheele, who turned around Jaguar, as chief operating officer. Chrysler has tried to put a new stamp on the S.U.V. with its Jeep Liberty. Unfortunately, Ford and Chrysler have scheduled few significant vehicle introductions, and Mr. Lutz has only just begun. Next year could be painful for the Big Three.
G.M. is expected to earn $1.85 a share next year, according to Thomson Financial/First Call consensus estimates. The current consensus for Ford is 57 cents, and analysts expect Chrysler to lose money, but not its parent, DaimlerChrysler.
While the Big Three battle over incentives, the real threat next year will continue to be foreign manufacturers, even more so in a market that most analysts expect to shrink significantly. Analysts expect the industry, which will sell about 17 million cars and light trucks this year, to sell about 15.5 million next year. American car buyers are increasingly drawn to imports, which account for more than one-third of sales. Toyota, Honda and Hyundai all gained market share through the first 11 months of 2001; G.M. kept even, and Ford and Chrysler lost share, according to Ward's AutoInfoBank.
"People who have to rely more on high volume and deals will be more subject to whims of the market," said Roy Coons, a sales manager for Volkswagen cars at the Bill Cook Automotive Group here. "It's important that people have a desire for a product as opposed to a need."
And the need is there in some people. Take William Ashford, a 56-year-old Detroit Fire Department captain who is ready to retire. He wants a silver Porsche Carrera. For almost two decades, he has had a motorized model of one in his basement. Now, he figures he might be able to afford to buy the real thing. Almost. There is still the question of insuring it.
"I live in the city of Detroit, where they charge you astronomical figures for no-name cars," he says. "What are they going to charge for this?"
Captain Ashford, a mild-mannered man, gestures toward a Carrera in the showroom of Bill Cook Imported Cars at the Bob Cook Automotive Group in this suburb of Detroit, where one street, Grand River Avenue, is crowded with dealers for many automakers, domestic and foreign.
For the car, he says, "I might move to Phoenix," where he reckons that insurance would be more affordable.
He is serious. He has asked his wife.
His father told him long ago not to buy a nice car. He didn't have a garage, or even a driveway.
"I got the driveway, I got the garage," he says. "Now, can I afford the insurance?"
Maybe in Phoenix.
