HEADLINE: Deal Bolsters Satellites as Cable TV Competitors 

BYLINE:  By AMY HARMON and JENNIFER 8. LEE 

 BODY:
Move over, cable television. Vivendi Universal's purchase of a stake in EchoStar, the satellite television company, is the latest sign that the companies selling pizza-size satellite dishes have emerged as potent competitors to cable operators for delivering video programming.
 For nearly a decade, satellite companies have been slowly taking subscribers away from cable companies. They have had the greatest success in rural areas and among high-income households willing to pay several hundred dollars up front as well as high monthly fees for access to exclusive sporting events and movies. 
 But the two major American satellite services, Echostar and DirecTV, have broader ambitions. Recently they have made inroads into the densely wired suburban areas that have long been cable strongholds, garnering more than 20 percent of the total subscription television market. 
The two companies now hope to merge in an effort to create the nation's largest pay-television provider and compete with cable companies in providing such high-technology options as digital video recorders and interactive television. 
The plan gained an ally last week when Vivendi agreed to pay $1.5 billion for 10 percent of EchoStar. The deal provides EchoStar with the financial backing it needs to push forward its merger with DirecTV.
Vivendi, an upstart French media company with few choices when it comes to finding a vehicle to distribute the material it produces, will also bolster EchoStar's offerings with interactive technology and programming from its television and movie studios.
That means cable operators may have to hasten the introduction of features they have long promised, like video-on-demand. For consumers, it could mean price competition at a time when cable rates are skyrocketing. Since 1996, cable rates have increased 35 percent.
"Right now, large cable companies dictate what content gets a chance to make it in the American market," said Gene Kimmelman, co-director of the Washington office of Consumers Union. "The hope is that this will enable satellite to compete for the lunch-bucket crowd and that as a result, we'll finally see some pricing pressure on cable. "
Satellite operators still face several political and technological obstacles in their effort to dominate the cable companies. 
Attorneys general of several states have indicated that they are prepared to file lawsuits to block EchoStar's planned merger with DirecTV on antitrust grounds. 
Together, the companies would control more than 90 percent of the satellite television market, and rural communities not wired for cable have complained that the merged company would have a monopoly. 
In addition, satellite customers still have to pay a fee for dish installation, although the price has dropped to under $200 in many areas and some promotions offer a dish free. 
Moreover, satellite providers offer local programming like nightly news in only the top 40 or so markets of 210 nationwide. 
Cable operators, with direct wiring into 65 million households nationwide, are better positioned to offer high-speed Internet access. Some analysts say that the growth in satellite television may be slowing.
This year, for the first time since the industry began in 1994, satellite television attracted fewer new subscribers than the previous year.
Still, Vivendi is gambling that the EchoStar merger with DirecTV, owned by the Hughes Electronics unit of General Motors, will be approved, and that the combined company will serve as a powerful platform for its programming.
In Vivendi's recent buying spree of media companies, what has attracted the most attention are its purchase last year of Universal Studios and its agreement, expected to be announced today, to acquire the television and film units of USA Networks Inc. for about $10.7 billion. 
But some analysts say it is the smaller, decidedly less flashy EchoStar deal that may ultimately do far more to shift the balance of power among the world's media giants. 
For the first time, EchoStar, the nation's sixth-largest pay-TV provider, has a programming partner. 
EchoStar's chairman, Charles Ergen, argues that the satellite industry has been held back because the major cable firms hold stakes in many of the nation's major producers of programming. 
"One of the reasons that interactivity in the U.S. has not taken off as much as the rest of the world is that we have had a hard time getting content providers to work with us," Mr. Ergen said last week in a conference call after the Vivendi deal was announced. 
If the merger goes through, Mr. Ergen added, satellite television operators will be able to compete more effectively on price and program offerings because the larger subscription base will give it a stronger negotiating position with programming producers.
Indeed, satellite television has made more inroads internationally than it has in the United States, especially in countries like Spain and Italy that do not have extensive cable systems. 
This success in other countries may be one reason Vivendi and its chairman, Jean-Marie Messier, are willing to bet on satellite's potential in the United States. In addition to its programming, Vivendi also brings EchoStar its interactive television technology through its subsidiary Canal Plus, a leading provider of television software. The software can be found in more than 11 million set-top boxes.
In Europe, where interactive television is a year and a half ahead of the United States, Canal Plus users can gamble, shop and play games. 
Cable companies in the United States have invested billions of dollars in laying the groundwork for sophisticated interactive networks. Company executives say these investments are on the verge of paying off through video-on-demand and high-speed Internet access, areas where satellite television lags. 
"Satellite will erode market share of cable on a global basis because it is easier to implement," said Harold L. Vogel, a media analyst and author of "Entertainment Industry Economics" (Cambridge University Press, 2001). "You throw up a dish, and you've got it. "
Satellite has one distinct advantage over cable operators, its national reach. For at least the near future, most cable operators will remain geographically fragmented, with disparate systems. About 7,500 of the nation's cable operators have fewer than 3,000 subscribers. But satellite companies can market nationwide, even more so if the merger of EchoStar and DirecTV is approved.
Satellite television companies are starting aggressive sales campaigns in areas where cable is weak. They are aiming at those customers whose cable bills have increased unusually fast in the last several years, who cannot receive digital services or who feel that their cable company offers poor customer service. 
One such region appears to be the northern suburbs of New York City, where Cablevision Systems raised basic rates by 12 percent in some areas last January. 
EchoStar in particular has been aggressively offering low-end packages, like a $9-a-month package for 100 channels. 
Satellite television is generally more expensive than traditional, analog cable, with basic service costing an average of $27 a month for satellite compared with $16 for analog cable. However, digital cable is more expensive, at $49 for a basic package.
When DirecTV first came on the market in 1994, cable operators thought that satellite television would simply be a niche player. But cable operators have been forced to upgrade their systems and services to defend their territories. 
Cable operators are closely watching how Washington reacts to the planned DirecTV and EchoStar merger. 
They are leery of opposing it because, if it does not go through, Rupert Murdoch, chairman of News Corporation. and a formidable rival, may seek to gain control of DirecTV. Mr. Murdoch, a longtime believer in the potential of satellite, dominates the satellite market in Europe and Asia. 
Vivendi has now become the first global media firm to challenge Mr. Murdoch on that turf. 
"When you have a worldwide content powerhouse like Vivendi investing $1.5 billion in a company, that's a confirmation that satellite is competing very well against cable today," said Jim Stroud, a senior analyst with the Carmel Group, a consulting firm.

HEADLINE: Economy & Business; 
For Policy Makers, the Question Is: How Much Is Enough?

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
When it comes to engineering an economic recovery, the question now is whether policy makers have done too much, too little or just enough.
 Even before it became clear after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks that the United States had entered its 10th recession since World War II and its first in a decade, the nation had wheeled out its big policy guns. 
 The Federal Reserve started cutting interest rates back on Jan. 3, when most forecasters were predicting nothing more than a slowdown in what at the time was the longest business expansion on record. The Fed continued to ease monetary policy throughout the year, and last week it cut rates for an 11th time to cap off one of the most aggressive efforts in the central bank's history to reduce borrowing costs and restore the economy's vitality. 
By summer, President Bush and Congress had put fiscal policy to work as well, including nearly $40 billion in immediate rebate checks in the $1.35 trillion, 10-year tax cut championed by Republicans. As the year drew to a close, Congress was enmeshed in negotiations on an economic stimulus package that would provide more tax cuts and extra help for unemployed workers.
Some economists argue that the combination of monetary and fiscal policy will reignite economic growth early in the new year and set off an expansion so robust that the Fed will have to reverse course and begin raising rates by springtime.
Other analysts contend this recession will prove difficult to end, in part because businesses are still recovering from an investment boom gone bust. In their view, the economy might need more help to recover.
Or maybe Washington got it just right, and the downturn will give way to a healthy recovery by the middle of next year.
"Left to its own devices, the economy would have a very strong tendency to reaccelerate," said Kenneth T. Mayland of ClearView Economics, a consulting firm.
"Layer on top of that very expansionary monetary policy and very significant fiscal policy," he said. "Then layer on top of that the positive effects of lower energy prices. Because of all those reasons, I'm supremely confident that in relatively short order the economy will get back on a healthy growth track."
The more pessimistic analysts say that policy is packing only a limited punch in this recession, which has been characterized not by a broad-based decline in demand but by a retrenchment in business investment.
They say long-term interest rates remain relatively high, banks are less willing to lend, consumers are carrying heavy debt loads and many companies do not want to purchase more equipment no matter how low their borrowing costs.
James W. Paulsen, chief investment strategist for Wells Capital Management, an investment firm based in San Francisco, predicted policy makers might end up considering more fiscal stimulus.
"Monetary policy alone is just not good enough any more," he said.
So far, however, the optimists seem to outnumber the pessimists, both among economists and investors.
The futures markets are betting that the Fed will begin raising rates by spring to keep inflation in check as the economy recovers. The bond market seems so convinced that a strong recovery is coming that long-term rates are right about where they were a year ago, before the magnitude of the economy's problems became clear.
Still, there is some concern among economists that the Fed could face a problem if the economy continues to deteriorate.
During 2001, the Fed cut rates by a total of 4.75 percentage points, leaving its target for the benchmark federal funds rate, the interest charged on overnight loans among banks, at 1.75 percent. Should the recession resist the policy medicine dispensed so far -- or should the economy suffer a fresh shock, like another terrorist attack -- the Fed would be limited in its response because it has very little room left to cut rates.
Japan, which has been in and out of recession for a decade, already faces that problem; the Bank of Japan has cut its official short-term rate to almost nothing, and still has not been able to revive the economy.
The United States is in much stronger shape than Japan, which is suffering from near-paralysis in its banking system after a collapse in real estate prices and an accompanying surge in bad loans.
But one school of economists says the United States cannot ignore the risk that it could confront the same problems that are plaguing Japan: deflation, or a generalized decline in prices, and a liquidity trap, in which official interest rates are as low as they can go, but individuals and businesses will not borrow and spend.
Fed officials do not see deflation as a threat now, and they have signaled that they will not hold off on rate cuts simply to keep monetary ammunition in their arsenal.
Indeed, the Fed has suggested that it still has room for cuts if needed. After its most recent cut, it said that inflation was likely to decline from its already low level. As inflation slows, the "real" level of interest rates -- the nominal rate minus the inflation rate -- increases, meaning monetary policy grows tighter if the Fed leaves rates steady.
In a recession, the Fed usually pushes the real rate below zero. The real rate is already negative if inflation is judged by the Consumer Price Index, which climbed 1.9 percent in the 12 months through November. But Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, prefers a measure known as the core personal consumption deflator, which rose 1.6 percent over the last 12 months, leaving the real fed funds rate slightly positive.
The Fed also tends to keep cutting rates as long as the unemployment rate is rising -- even though unemployment tends to lag behind other economic indicators in responding to slowdowns and recessions. Most forecasters see unemployment continuing to rise from its current level of 5.7 percent for at least the next few months.
As for fiscal policy, Congress and the Bush administration expect to run budget deficits for the next few years at least. Traditional economic theory holds that governments should run a deficit during downturns. But Mr. Greenspan, and many members of Congress, especially Democrats, subscribe to the theory that persistent deficits will push up long-term interest rates, holding back the economy.
It is not clear if the two parties will seek to move the government back into surplus and revive the goal of paying down the national debt, or let the deficits continue in the name of paying for national security and giving the economy a short-term lift.
Democrats tend to see budget surpluses and fiscal responsibility as contributors to low interest rates and prosperity. Republicans tend to see surpluses and debt reduction as byproducts of prosperity.
That debate will be just one of many that rages into, and maybe throughout, 2002.

HEADLINE: Technology & Media; 
Telecommunications Industry Too Devastated Even for Vultures

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
The resounding boom in telecommunications investments from 1996 to 2000 fizzled in 2001, when at least 27 telecommunications companies, each with more than $100 million of liabilities, filed for bankruptcy protection. The industry may require a year, or perhaps even two, before a muted recovery starts to take place.
 Even the vulture investors, like hedge funds, private equity companies and funds within investment banks that specialize in distressed businesses, may not be attracted to the carcasses of once-ambitious companies that now litter the industry's landscape. 
 It is painfully clear that the telecommunications debacle eclipsed in size all recent investment bubbles, whether they involved dot-coms or oil wildcatters. 
"It's hard to tell when the pain in telecommunications will ease because the crisis is so extensive," said Edward I. Altman, a bankruptcy expert at the Stern School of Business of New York University.
Telecommunications companies accounted for nearly half the $45 billion of defaults in high-yield bonds in 2001, according to a study of the securities by Mr. Altman and Pablo Arman, a research associate at N.Y.U. The telecommunications industry had a default rate of 18.4 percent, compared with an overall default rate of 4.5 percent.
Vulture investors may find few opportunities among the telecommunications carnage. While they often seek to restructure ailing companies, as they did with such recession-battered industries as retailing or real estate in the early 1990's, they also look at companies' cash flow.
"What currently makes telecom bankruptcies unique in the history of restructuring is that many of these companies had little positive cash flow to begin with," said Jeffrey R. Manning, a managing director of Legg Mason, a financial services company in Baltimore.
The vultures also like to glean value from troubled companies' assets in legal proceedings, but that is difficult in an industry that embraces technologies that are subject to rapid changes. For example, much of the fiber strands and laser-based equipment in communications networks will be obsolete in a few years.
"It's not like a steel mill you can buy and idle for two years while you work things out," Mr. Manning said. "In two years the company and its technology could be worthless."
There are additional reasons behind the debacle. One is that the huge buildup in capacity on transcontinental and transoceanic communications networks was fueled by a similar expansion in the number of the communications companies. Few of these start-up concerns would generate enough cash to be profitable.
When financing for such ventures dried up, these companies slowed or halted purchases of communications equipment. That generated weakness at large equipment makers like Lucent Technologies and Nortel Networks and the smaller producers of fiber optic equipment.
Parallel crises gripped the wireless communications industry in Europe, where large carriers, in hindsight, overpaid governments for next-generation mobile Internet licenses, and in the long-distance industry in the United States, where intense competition reduced revenue for heavyweights like AT&T, WorldCom and Sprint.
Of course, not all is grim in telecommunications, an industry that provided a major underpinning for the economic boom of the late 1990's. Some important areas of the industry are still relatively insulated from distress, like the local telephone businesses of Verizon Communications, SBC Communications and BellSouth.
Large wireless carriers like Cingular Wireless, jointly owned by SBC and BellSouth; AT&T Wireless Services; and Sprint PCS are also doing fairly well.
Still, about 450,000 telecommunications jobs disappeared around the world in 2001, after breakneck expansion during the last five years.
After Congress approved the Telecommunications Act of 1996, which strengthened competition in areas like the Internet and wireless and long-distance communications, investment in the industry surged. Capital spending climbed at an average rate of 17.7 percent a year from 1996 to 2000, compared with average annual growth of 7.5 percent in the 30 years before 1996, according to Credit Lyonnais Securities.
"It's difficult to put the current situation into historical context because never before has there been the level of spending as in 1996 to 2000," Gabriel Lowy, an analyst at Credit Lyonnais, said. Mr. Lowy forecast that 2001 and 2002 would be the worst years for telecommunications equipment spending since the mid-1960's.
But some in the industry do not share his gloomy assessment. Telefonos de Mexico and Forstmann Little, the leveraged-buyout firm, for example, recently found value and may inject $800 million into XO Communications in exchange for a controlling stake in the ailing broadband communications company, formerly known as Nextlink Communications. Forstmann has submitted a similar restructuring proposal for McLeodUSA, a telephone company based in Cedar Rapids, Iowa.
Indeed, there is no shortage of optimism at companies that are pinning their hopes on better times in 2002, like the Covad Communications Group, a provider of fast Internet service that won a judge's approval last week to emerge from bankruptcy. "By the end of the year we should see a modest recovery," said Charles E. Hoffman, chief executive of Covad, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif.
Nevertheless, analysts agree that the industry as a whole is likely to go through more consolidation in 2002. Reed E. Hundt, a former chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, for example, says there may be one big deal that will set off a wave of consolidation.

HEADLINE: Diller Likely to Disturb Some Hollywood Ways 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD WEINRAUB

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16 

 BODY:
In taking over Universal Studios, Barry Diller is expected to undertake significant shifts in the financing and production of movies and television that could ripple across the entertainment industry, longtime associates said today.
 At the same time, Mr. Diller, whose attempts to buy CBS and NBC have been thwarted in recent years, is expected to revive bids for a major broadcast network once he is placed in charge of Universal's entertainment operations. 
 Vivendi Universal is expected to announce on Monday that it has agreed to acquire the television and film units of Mr. Diller's USA Networks for about $10.7 billion. The deal will place Mr. Diller in charge of Universal's entertainment and theme park operations as well as USA's remaining businesses, which include Ticketmaster, the Home Shopping Network and Expedia, the travel Web site. 
Not only will the deal make Mr. Diller, 59, one of the most powerful and most wealthy men in Hollywood, but it could also set the stage for a series of changes in the direction of the studio that could have a broad impact on the film and television business.
Mr. Diller, who once ran Paramount and Fox studios, has said publicly as well as privately that studios in recent years had abrogated their responsibilities in holding the financial line, that talent agents, producers, directors and stars had assumed a dominance over the studio and television business that appalled him.
As a result, several entertainment industry executives said, Mr. Diller is expected to examine and even place a lid on lucrative deals that place studios in financially risky straits. These deals include paying stars $20 million or $25 million a film, giving directors so-called "first dollar gross," or profits from every box-office dollar, and arrangements in which studios pay production companies hundreds of millions of dollars to make films without much input.
Universal has two such deals. One is with Imagine Entertainment, a company owned by Brian Grazer and Ron Howard, which has made films that include "Apollo 13" and "Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas,"." The other is with Working Title, a British production outfit whose films include "Four Weddings and a Funeral." 
Privately, Mr. Diller has railed against such deals, which greatly diminish a studio's leverage despite substantial financial outlays.
"Over the years Barry became more and more disenchanted with the movie business -- the economic margins were shrinking and shrinking and the egos were getting bigger and bigger," said Leonard Goldberg, a top producer and former studio chief and a longtime friend of Mr. Diller who helped start his career. "It became harder for him to justify the way the business was going."
Mr. Diller has already told the current leadership of Universal (Ron Meyer, a friend who is chairman of Universal Studios, and Stacy Snider, chairwoman of Universal Pictures) that he has full confidence in them and wants them to stay. Under Mr. Meyer and Ms. Snider, the studio over the last few years has had one of the most successful runs ever, with hits like "Erin Brockovich," "The Mummy" series, "The Fast and the Furious" and "American Pie."
Mr. Diller has told friends that the two have "done a first-rate job" and that he would support them. At the same time, Mr. Diller has said that he will not impose his own culture on the already successful culture of Universal.
But Mr. Diller also told one friend that he wanted to "stir things up" at Universal -- as he has done throughout his career -- and would certainly participate in the decision-making process involving films and television.
Mr. Diller's disillusionment with the movie-making business was tempered two years ago when his company, USA Films, produced the movie "Traffic," the critically acclaimed fictional exploration of the war against drugs. The movie, released last year, cost $40 million to $45 million and took in about $250 million at the box office worldwide. It also won four Academy Awards.
People connected to the movie and others close to Mr. Diller said he was planning to shut down USA Films until "Traffic" was released. The movie serves as a paradigm for what Mr. Diller wants in a film: the star, Michael Douglas, and others were paid relatively low fees, and the movie itself was a critical and financial success.
Over the years, Mr. Diller has championed other movies that are, in some ways, similar to "Traffic." These movies, including "Reds," "Ordinary People," "Terms of Endearment" and "Broadcast News," are serious and critically praised and, in most cases, earned money. But Mr. Diller also made the Fox film "Die Hard," in 1988, spending an unusual $30 million for the successful action movie. At the time, the cost was criticized as excessive. Today, few studio films cost as little as $30 million.
Mr. Diller, who has been a subject of continuing fascination in Hollywood for years, may have a considerable effect on the studio culture if he plays hardball with agents, stars, directors and producers. Not only is Mr. Diller expected to set financial limits on deals, his friends say, but he will play a hands-on role on placing limits on the creative side. That is, Universal under Mr. Diller is not expected to hand over films to directors and some stars who have gained almost total control over the final versions.
On the television side, Mr. Diller has told friends that he will spend his early months merging the USA Networks and its properties into the Universal structure. The new company will be combined with, among others, Mr. Diller's USA Network, the Sci-Fi Channel and USA Films.
Mr. Diller is also expected eventually to make another bid for one of the broadcast networks, which he sees as crucial to the financial viability of companies that own studios. Vivendi, in contrast to several other media conglomerates like Walt Disney and Viacom, has been unable to market and leverage its products on television because it has no cable or broadcast channels in the United States. Walt Disney owns ABC and Viacom owns Paramount Studios in addition to CBS and MTV.
"Barry's feeling about television is it's a terrible business," said one person who has spoken to Mr. Diller recently. "You spend all this money on development, you hire producers and writers, you take all the risks and the odds are slim that you'll make back any money, especially if you give pieces of the show to the talent."
Mr. Diller has told friends over the years that syndicated shows -- like "Hercules" and "Xena: Warrior Princess" -- are potentially far more profitable and less risky than network series. Mr. Diller, whose current company, Studios USA, also produces the popular NBC show "Law and Order" and its spinoffs, has also gained commitments from the network to present the shows on cable almost at the same time, increasing the programs' financial value for his company.
Actually, Mr. Diller's background has centered more on television than on films. In his early 20's, Mr. Diller was hired as an assistant by Mr. Goldberg, then ABC's vice president in charge of programming. At the time, Mr. Diller, a college dropout from U.C.L.A., was an agent at William Morris representing Marlo Thomas.
Mr. Diller, who later conceived the idea of "Movie of the Week" with Mr. Goldberg, was soon placed in charge of buying studio movies for television. 
Years later, when Mr. Diller was hired by Rupert Murdoch to serve as chairman of Fox Inc. and create the Fox network, Mr. Diller endorsed successful on-the-edge shows like "Married . . . with Children," "In Living Color" and "The Simpsons." The shows were hardly upscale, like Mr. Diller's favorite movies. But Mr. Diller nurtured these programs and others because he found the concepts funny and, more important, these programs helped define the Fox network in contrast to other more staid broadcast networks.
"Barry understands and appreciates the highbrow but not at the expense of the lowbrow," said an executive who worked for him for years. "Don't forget he put on some tacky reality cop shows on Fox. They made real good business sense. Maybe they weren't to his personal taste, but they made money."

HEADLINE: Economy & Business; 
For Microsoft,a Season of Triumph

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
For most technology companies, the fall of 2001 was a season to forget, with its deepening sales slump, losses and layoffs. But for Microsoft, it was a time of triumph, even some vindication. In the federal antitrust case that Microsoft fought so long, with so little success, things turned in the company's favor when the Bush administration decided to settle in November.
 Within weeks, Microsoft announced a settlement with plaintiffs in more than 100 private class-action antitrust suits. To be sure, protests remain. Some states that sued Microsoft are urging a federal judge to toughen provisions of the settlement with the Justice Department, and there are objections to the class-action deal. A European investigation also continues, although Microsoft says it wants to settle that case as well. In all, however, Microsoft has made rapid, dramatic strides toward finally putting its antitrust troubles behind it. 
 The proposed settlement in the crucial federal case is widely seen as a Microsoft victory. It would not restrict the company's product designs, allowing Microsoft to fold software into its Windows operating system for potentially huge new markets, including online shopping, personal identification and downloading music and movies over the Internet. Those features are found in the recently released Windows XP.
And the drastic sanction of splitting Microsoft up -- the remedy championed by the Clinton administration, and approved by a lower court judge, but regarded quite skeptically in a federal appeals court ruling in June -- was rejected by the Bush administration. 
But the settlement terms do require Microsoft to share technical information with competitors and industry partners more openly. In addition, Microsoft would be prohibited from bullying other companies with anticompetitive contracts.
Some Microsoft rivals and industry commentators argue that the case could do a lot to encourage competition, by forcing Microsoft to change its corporate behavior.
Microsoft's legal team is certainly echoing the behavioral theme. "The client has learned a lot through all this," said William H. Neukom, the tall, silver-haired general counsel and legal field general in Microsoft's antitrust battles.
Mr. Neukom, 60, is stepping down next year, and his designated successor, Bradley P. Smith, suggested that priorities for Microsoft would be to establish a "strong track record of compliance" with the settlement order and to "strengthen our ties with the rest of the industry."
But legal pressure is not the only thing forcing Microsoft to change. Technology trends -- notably the spread of Internet technology -- are equally responsible.
Over all, investment in technology may have slowed, but Bill Gates, the Microsoft chairman, believes that some cooling off may be healthy. With the get-rich-instantly mentality of the dot-com bubble gone, Mr. Gates said, chatting with journalists in October, "I think the environment for doing major research and development -- real innovation -- is better now than it was before." Certainly it is for Microsoft, which is sitting on $36 billion in cash.
Microsoft is putting some of its capital to work by investing heavily in the development of "Web services," mainly clever software sent over the Internet to automate all kinds of business and personal tasks. A company's data will be linked with a supplier's to replenish needed parts automatically, for example. Or a person's scheduling data, stored on a PC or hand-held computer, will interact with the dentist's data to set up an appointment or with an airline to arrange travel.
To realize these goals will require open communications in software, which raises privacy and security issues that must be resolved. The move will also require businesses to form partnerships and trusted relationships with other companies. This will mean a change of many corporate cultures, including Microsoft's.
Consequently, over the next several years, it will be very difficult to determine the legacy of Microsoft's antitrust conflicts, because so many other forces will also be shaping the company and the industry.

HEADLINE: Arts in America: It's Museum Time Down South; 
From Virginia to Louisiana, a Building Boom for Culture

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: MOBILE, Ala. 

 BODY:
On the shore of a shaded pond a few miles from the Gulf of Mexico construction machinery roars and screeches in a din that is now familiar across the southeastern United States.
 This is the sound of art museums being built. Here it is a new building for the Mobile Museum of Art, which is to cost $15 million and open next year. 
 Across this region, which has long felt culturally overshadowed by other parts of the country, an extraordinary building boom is under way. New art museums, or large additions to existing ones, are being planned, built and opened in more than a dozen cities. 
In Florida the Norton Museum of Art in West Palm Beach is raising $20 million for a new wing, only a few years after raising $30 million to double its size and add to its endowment. Museums in Tampa, Boca Raton and Fort Lauderdale have also begun building campaigns.
Two major projects are under way in North Carolina and two more in Georgia, with projected costs totaling over $150 million. Museums in Tennessee, Alabama and Mississippi are also part of the boom, along with others on the borders of the region, in Louisiana and Virginia.
This boom is based partly on the desire of many Southerners to bring more fine art to their communities. Although some museums here have superior collections that are languishing in storage for lack of display space, directors of some others are still uncertain what they will hang on their new walls.
In many cities business leaders are supporting these projects in the hope that they will draw tourists and attract more talented work forces. The economic prosperity of the 1980's and 90's made many of these business figures rich, and they have contributed millions of dollars to museum fund-raising campaigns.
Museum directors, acutely aware that donors want to use museums as tools for economic development, are competing with one another to produce the most striking buildings. Several have hired renowned architects and asked them to come up with buildings so unusual that they may become tourist attractions in their own right.
"There's a kind of breaking out of the shell of that inferiority complex we might have had," said Joseph B. Schenk, director of the Mobile Museum of Art. "We're behind the curve of museums in New England or the upper Midwest or California. But during the 1990's people here realized they were doing well enough to begin concentrating on quality-of-life issues. There was also a fair amount of reverse migration from the North, which brought with it not just people and ideas but also art collections."
Frank Gehry, the architect whose dazzling Guggenheim Museum turned the dreary Spanish port of Bilbao into a worldwide tourist destination, is designing a new museum in Biloxi, Miss. It is to house the work of a single artist, George E. Ohr, a Biloxi potter and sculptor who died in 1918. A local arts patron and former mayor, Jerry OKeefe, and his family have donated $1 million to the museum building fund and raised another $7 million. The Ohr-OKeefe Museum is scheduled to be completed in 2004 at a cost of $16 million.
"We see the Gehry building as something that can bring us to a whole new level of tourism," said Marjorie Grady, the museum's executive director. "Our conservative projection is for 100,000 visitors in the first year, and it could easily be much more."
In Savannah, Ga., Moshe Safdie, designer of the Skirball Cultural Center in Los Angeles, has been chosen to design a new building for the Telfair Museum of Art. He had to revise his design in the face of local criticism, but a new version has now been accepted, and the $18 million building is to open in 2004.
Some promoters of this wave of new construction wonder whether there is enough outstanding art in the South to fill these museums, or enough money to buy it. Diane Lesko, executive director of the Telfair Museum, said she shared that concern.
"I would hope every new building is being built for reason, to fill a need, and not just for vanity," she said. "If you do it just to pull out works in storage that are not first or even second tier, you're not going to make it. People may come once to see the building and the display of the collection, but that's it."
Major museum building projects in North Carolina include the new Nasher Museum of Art in Durham, set to open in 2003 at a cost of $15 million. It will be affiliated with Duke University, and half the cost was donated by a Duke graduate, Raymond Nasher. The project involves the construction of five buildings around a 10,000-square-foot atrium, and Mr. Nasher has said he hoped it would become one of the most important university museums in the world.
The Nasher Museum is being designed by Rafael Vinoly, designer of the new Kimmel Center for the Arts in Philadelphia. Mr. Vinoly has also been chosen to design another project in the South, a $46 million expansion of the Tampa Museum of Art that will quadruple its exhibition space and serve as the anchor for a new waterfront cultural district.
Less than 50 miles southeast of Durham, in Raleigh, an even more ambitious museum project is unfolding. The North Carolina Museum of Art there has begun a campaign aimed at raising $89 million for a campus of exhibition halls that will provide 180,000 square feet of new space.
"We Southern folks take a while to catch up, but we're catching up now," the museum director, Lawrence J. Wheeler, said in an interview. "The South has changed. It's more cosmopolitan than it used to be. There's a definite growth in the number of people who appreciate art, as well as in the number of patrons and the available resources.
"At the same time you have a real shift in the perception of what art museums can be," he added. "People realize that they're not just culturally and economically beneficial, but that they can become very important centers of community life." 
Taking note of what he called a tendency among Southerners to value tradition and history and to turn their backs on the creations of their own times or recent history, Mr. Wheeler said: "People with money have always preferred the familiar, things that had history written on them. They've loved old houses, old silver, decorative arts, furniture, old rugs and pictures -- that sort of thing. You had to look hard to find collections of contemporary art. But that's also changing. We've had a lot of contemporary-art exhibitions, and they've become more and more popular. I don't worry about whether there will be audiences for the new."
With competition among museums a clear though intangible factor in the current building surge, it is not surprising that the North Carolina Museum of Art bills itself as "the Southeast's premier visual arts museum," while the High Museum of Art in Atlanta stakes the same claim, calling itself "the leading art museum in the Southeast."
The High Museum, which opened in 1983 with an award-winning design by Richard Meier, could not stand still with so much construction across the region, and it has begun raising an estimated $100 million for renovating its building, constructing a new wing and strengthening its endowment.
"We may be at another in a series of rebirths of the South, asserting a higher level of cultural aspiration after having achieved a higher level of economic success," said Michael Shapiro, director of the High. "It's what occurred in other, older cities beginning in the late 19th century."
"One thing that may evolve from it is alternative exhibition pathways," Mr. Shapiro said. "The traditional trajectory is New York to Chicago to Los Angeles or maybe San Francisco. Now there might be one from Atlanta to Houston to some place like Denver or Seattle or Phoenix."
Like other arts administrators who are overseeing expansion projects in the Southeast, Mr. Shapiro said his financing has remained secure since the shocks of Sept. 11. "Our plans are moving ahead absolutely on track," he said, "and in fact we have received some of our largest donations since Sept. 11."
Many of these projects are being planned and built with unusually strong emphasis on education. Museums seek to offer libraries with computer stations, interactive exhibits, and rooms full of hands-on activities to engage young people.
One new Southern institution, the Frist Center for the Visual Arts in Nashville, is built around an educational complex and a series of empty galleries. Working on the assumption that it is now prohibitively expensive for new museums to build world-class collections, the Frist does not plan to bid for art at auction. Instead it will concentrate on serving as a kunsthalle, a site where shows from other places are presented.
The Frist, which opened in April, is housed in a lovingly restored former post office, complete with handsome corridors and Art Deco details. Most of the $45 million cost was donated by a wealthy local family, one of whose most prominent members is the United States Senator Bill Frist.
As its first show the Frist presented a collection of European masterworks from the Art Gallery of Ontario that included paintings by artists ranging from Rembrandt and Tintoretto to Picasso and Dufy. It is now displaying treasures of medieval and Byzantine art from the Walters Art Museum in Baltimore and illuminated manuscripts from collections in Philadelphia.
"We want to provide a space for people to come and see some of the very finest art that exists in the world, but that's only part of it," said Chase Rynd, director of the Frist. "We're going to seize on to each exhibition to educate people about that moment or medium or historical period. We hope to inspire a whole generation of people who are not familiar with the visual arts."

HEADLINE: THE STEM CELL DEBATE; 
Defining the Undefinable: Being Alive

BYLINE:  By NATALIE ANGIER 

 BODY:
Much as people may wish these days for the comforts of a few black and white distinctions -- between good and evil, democracy and tyranny, friends and fiends -- our restless color wheel of a world refuses to comply. And that law of equivocation and qualification, scientists say, extends down to the most basic distinction of all: whether something is alive or not.
 Obvious though the differences may seem between a sleeping cat and its pillow, or a patch of lichen and its rock, scientists have had a devilishly difficult time specifying, delimiting and agreeing on the characteristics that define life, and that exclude the apparently nonliving. 
 The question is not one of mere semantics or taxonomics. As the nation once again takes up the angst-riven issue of extracting stem cells from human embryos for possible use in the treatment of a raft of diseases, researchers must weigh not only the question of when human life begins, but what being alive really means. 
"People have long sought to define and understand it," said Dr. Mark A. Bedau, a philosopher of biology at Reed College in Oregon. "The question is especially interesting now that science and technology are continually pushing the boundaries of what living systems or lifelike systems exist, and what they may look like in the future."
As an example of the trickiness that technology can bring to the definition of life, scientists cite new experiments showing that monkey eggs can be chemically treated and modified to the point where they begin behaving enough like embryos to generate stem cells -- all without the addition of sperm normally required for embryogenesis, and without any capacity to grow into a baby monkey.
Assuming that human eggs could be similarly stripped down and par thenogenetically reinvented, how "alive" would these wholly unnatural and almost entirely fabricated stem cell factories be? How much more alive must they be adjudged, scientists ask, than are the chemical reactions in a test tube that yield synthetic versions of vital hormones, or that attempt to mimic the conditions early in the earth's history, when life began?
"We've gotten to the point where we have RNA molecules that replicate in a test tube," just as RNA is thought to have done at the dawn of life four billion years ago, said Dr. Jeffrey L. Bada, a professor of marine chemistry at the University of California at San Diego, who studies the origin of life.
"But no one has dared to call that living yet," Dr. Bada said. "We have to incorporate all kinds of chemicals to make that replication happen." Keeping embryos alive in the laboratory, he said, or manipulating eggs for research, "is not too much different than working with evolving RNA molecules in a test tube."
As Dr. Lawrence M. Krauss, the chairman of the physics department at Case Western Reserve University, sees it, an embryo floating in a petri dish is little more than a chemical factory, not so much alive as prelude to life, and no worthier of being considered a mini-human being than a block of uncarved marble is worthy of being called Michelangelo's Pieta.
"The distinction between organic material that has potential one day to do something, and something already functioning as human being, is very great," said Dr. Krauss, who often writes about the effects of science on society. "I'm amazed when people view the potential as if it's real."
A number of scientists argue that humans are too mired in anthropocentric, or at least biocentric thinking, and thus are likely to award membership in Club Life solely to organic life forms, while withholding it from worthy entities or systems that display many properties of life without being carbon-based.
Some say that the economy and the Internet, for example, are alive in the same sense that an ant colony is alive; all are super organisms, with the individual functions widely distributed yet intimately connected, mutually responsive, dynamic and ever-changing.
Those in the field of so-called artificial life believe that many properties of life can be captured in digital format, and that by viewing the performance and behavior of these computerized species, researchers may better understand what life outside the terminal is all about.
A-lifers, as they are sometimes known, write computer programs that begin with relatively simple codes, or instructions, which, once liberated to run free on anything from desktop P.C.'s to university supercomputers, follow their own paths and aggregate into spectacularly diverse digital "ecosystems."
One of the most famous such programs is Tierra, created in the early 1990's by Dr. Thomas S. Ray, a professor of zoology at the University of Oklahoma, and since disseminated to programmers around the world. Tierra began with a bit of computer code 85 bytes long called the Ancestor, which spawned daughter codes, which in turn generated other daughter programs, some of them 10 or 100 times as long as the original Ancestor.
The replication parameters were less than perfect, just as DNA replication in the carbon-based world is less than perfect, resulting in minor changes, or mutations, from one generation of Tierrans to the next. The organisms assembled themselves into habitats, he said. They competed, they cooperated, they cheated, they parasitized, they parasitized the parasites. They reproduced with varying success, and, as living things are wont to do, they died.
Most vividly of all, said Dr. Ray, Tierra abided by Darwinian law: it evolved. "For me, the central, defining property of life is evolution by natural selection," he said. "And that's a property I've captured in my work."
So while he won't flatly say that Tierra life is alive, he won't dismiss it as a mere model of life either. "We're creating things in a twilight zone between life and nonlife," he said. "It leads to the recognition that life isn't cut-and-dried, yes-or-no. There are shades of life and aliveness." Yet when asked if he felt sorrow at the "death" of any of his Tierrans, he said, "No, no more than I would over the death of a virus or bacterium."
Other scientists are more skeptical about the possibility of machine life approaching real life, or of a computer or robot being so nimbly programmed that it attains some form of awareness, a conviction that it is alive and that, like HAL of "2001: A Space Odyssey," it does not want to die.
"There are lots of variations on the idea that computers, if not already alive, are on their way to becoming alive, and that for better or worse they will be a successor species to the human race," said Jaron Lanier, a computer scientist and pioneer in virtual reality. "I've always objected to that, which has made me the black sheep at a lot of computer conferences."
But Mr. Lanier argues that computer scientists who think of computers as alive, or practically sentient, write bad computer programs that make everybody stupider. He cites the classic Turing test of a computer's sophistication, devised by the great British mathematician Alan Turing. 
According to Turing, if a judge cannot distinguish between the answers given by a computer and those from a person, then the computer must be considered essentially conscious, and should be given equal rights.
Mr. Lanier proposes another interpretation of such a result. "Turing assumed that the computer in this case has become smarter or more humanlike," he said. "But the equally likely conclusion is that the person has become dumber and more computerlike."
"Consider all the ways that we bend to a mechanized process by doing stupid or irrational things," he added, as when college students are advised to begin building up a good credit rating by borrowing money and paying interest to feed data into the credit rating system. "So students are bending over backward and doing economically foolish things to make the credit algorithm look smart," he said.
Ultimately, in Mr. Lanier's view, the experience of being alive is a subjective one that may not be amenable to definition or algorithmic recapitulation. "Science studies repeatable phenomena and empirical things that can be tested," he said. "But the experience of being alive is not detectable by instruments, and at some point we may have to admit it's a big question mark that we're never going to be able to answer."
But like a beckoning finger, a question mark can prove irresistible, and professional thinkers have long mulled over the definition of life.
Aristotle constructed a stepladder of life "essences." "Aristotle talked of the vegetative soul, which is basically equivalent to life at the cellular level," said Dr. Lee M. Silver, a professor of molecular biology and public affairs at Princeton. "Then there was his sensitive soul, equivalent to organisms with a functioning nervous system, and finally his rational soul, the human being."
As Aristotle saw it, then, not only were human beings generally superior to all other species; they were, at their core, more alive.
At the other end of the scala natura is the virus, a source of many lively scientific debates. To live means to use energy, some have argued, to metabolize, to eat. Viruses do none of these things. "They show no properties of life," said Dr. Lynn Margulis, a professor of biology at the University of Massachusetts. "No metabolism, no self-maintenance. They're about as alive as is sugar or salt."
Yet some virologists defend the animate nature of their subjects by pointing out that viruses secondarily metabolize, by forcing their host cells to devote most of their metabolic energy to the production of new viruses.
The pathogens are all too clever at getting around, and they even evolve. "Viruses are smart enough to direct their own reproduction," said Dr. Arnold Levine, a virologist and the president of Rockefeller University in New York. "I've always thought of them as alive, although in a dormant state."
An even thornier case is the prion, a nasty infectious protein that lacks even the virus's nucleic blueprint to make more of itself, yet somehow manages to make more of itself in the brains of its unfortunate hosts, leading to devastating illnesses like mad cow disease and kuru. Can something that possesses a core trait of life -- the impulse to go forth and multiply -- be blithely dismissed as lifeless?
And then there is bronze disease, a k a rust. "Rust can be contagious," said Dr. J. Doyne Farmer, a professor at the Santa Fe Institute in New Mexico, who has worked on problems modeling biological systems. "The more rust you get on a car's body, the more the rust propagates. Nobody would say that bronze disease is alive, but already, even at the elementary level, there's some notion of contagion, and something that seems alive."
In this spirit of inclusiveness, many life theorists emphasize systems rather than individuals as a way of grasping the meaning of life. "To focus on the superficial characteristics of what makes a particular fly or a particular human alive is to miss the underlying unified explanation for those hallmarks," said Dr. Bedau of Reed College.
In his view, the key to life is something he calls "supple adaptation," the capacity of populations or groups to respond to changing circumstances by continually creating new adaptations. Thus, the dinosaurs died out not because they expired one by one, but because their population somehow lost all capacity to respond to shifting conditions. Their suppleness fossilized, and they soon followed suit.
In this vein, some experts say, the current stem cell debate, by focusing on human embryos afloat in the laboratory and divorced from their ordinary biological and evolutionary context, ignores the connectivity of the human race, the social, emotional and ultimately physical link among people that is epitomized in the relationship between the mother and her gestating fetus.
"Until very recently in human history, the moment when somebody was said to be there was with the quickening," said Dr. Barbara Katz Rothman, a bioethicist and professor of sociology at the City University of New York. "The moment a woman felt movement, when the baby communicated itself to the woman and she communicated the quickening to others, was the moment that the baby entered the social world. It was an inherently social act: thud! I'm here."
A days-old embryo in a petri dish, or frozen away in a fertility clinic, she said, makes no thud and has no umbilicus to the world around it. It must of necessity await definition by the lives that flicker around it, who are themselves caught up in the uncertainties and disputes that are life's most assured gifts.

HEADLINE: Climate Change: The Signs Are There 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Drastic Shifts in Climate Are Likely, Experts Warn" (news article, Dec. 12): 
 What clues help assess vulnerability to abrupt climate change? Variability and rates of change are crucial. 
More variance -- wide swings from norms and intensified weather extremes -- may indicate greater sensitivity to change. Ice cores reveal that greater variability has heralded past rapid change. 
 In the late 1990's, the pace of warming increased. Moreover, changes are occurring in multiple climate system components -- icecover, forest cover, deep ocean and atmospheric temperatures. 
We naturally underestimate the potential for sudden change; but signs of instability are growing. For this reason, along with health, environmental and security concerns, it is time to phase out fossil fuel dependence. An economic stimulus package that rewards the transition to clean energy could help revitalize the economy and give the climate a chance to restabilize.

PAUL R. EPSTEIN, M.D.
Boston, Dec. 12, 2001

The writer is associate director, Center for Health and the Global Environment, Harvard Medical School.

HEADLINE: A Port Authority Tenure Shadowed by Crisis 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

 BODY:
It galls Lewis M. Eisenberg, who stepped down last week as chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, that through some caprice of history, his time at the agency will be bracketed by two painful bookends: the rebuilding of the agency's trophy property, the World Trade Center, after the 1993 bombing, and the toppling of the towers Sept. 11.
 "I had thought the bookends of my time would have been things such as improved efficiency and converting assets to produce more capital for the agency's core transportation mission," Mr. Eisenberg said in an interview. "I don't like to think of it the other way." 
 But with an equanimity that marked his tenure at the often fractious agency, Mr. Eisenberg, 59, found a more positive legacy in the rubble of the twin towers: Gov. George E. Pataki's announcement last week of a $544 million plan to build a temporary PATH station beneath the trade center site that would allow service to resume between Lower Manhattan and New Jersey. It would be a big step, said Mr. Pataki and Acting Gov. Donald T. DeFrancesco of New Jersey, toward revitalizing downtown and "renewing the spirit of New York."
Mr. Eisenberg, a New Jerseyan, said Mr. Pataki's praise was a far cry from the derision New Yorkers once reserved for the PATH line and its Lower Manhattan station, long considered a deficit-ridden afterthought to the construction of the trade center that benefited only New Jersey and drained money from other projects. 
"PATH had always been a four-letter word for New Yorkers, and now it is the first major appropriation by the Port Authority after Sept. 11 and it is announced by a New York governor," Mr. Eisenberg said. "If those combined statements by the two governors don't bespeak a quintessential regionalism, I don't know what does."
Regional cooperation is the reason the Port Authority was created 80 years ago, but in 1999, squabbling between Governor Pataki and New Jersey's governor, Christie Whitman, created an impasse that stalled major projects for 18 months. Many people credit Mr. Eisenberg with seeing the agency through those troubles. 
"It was difficult for the two states to collaborate on issues, but Lew succeeded in getting one of the Port Authority's biggest achievements -- sale of the World Trade Center -- and he got the agency back into transportation and out of real estate," said Robert Yaro, executive director of the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit group that promotes regionalism. "He does not walk on water, but he has done exceptionally well."
Still, there are those who see Mr. Eisenberg's term as chairman as continuing the erosion of the port agency's independence from the two governors. Jameson W. Doig, a Princeton University history professor who has written a history of the agency, said that while the agency's board was once made up of independent captains of regional industry, it is now increasingly filled by political appointees who seem tied and perhaps beholden to the governor who appointed them.
To Professor Doig, Mr. Eisenberg's personal style in the governors' disputes was perhaps "too passive." He may have been willing and "sharp enough" to know the direction in which the agency should move, the historian said, "but he was not a regional development person, and the board surrounding him lacked the independent strength and understanding."
James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, disagreed, saying that during the impasse between the governors, Mr. Eisenberg kept the agency moving forward. "It just seems he is an extremely steady person, and is not prone to any outbursts and tries to put in quality leadership," Mr. Hughes said.
During Mr. Eisenberg's tenure, the agency invested more than $10 billion in the region and adopted a $9.5 billion five-year capital program that will generate $14 billion in spending. It raised money with long-term leases, including to the World Trade Center, the Vista Hotel and the Newark Legal Center. It opened the "train-to-the-plane" link at Newark International Airport and is building a similar rail line to Kennedy International Airport. 
In the interview, Mr. Eisenberg played down his role in the agency's accomplishments, instead crediting its 7,200 staff members and the governors. He does own up to a talent for surrounding himself with competent, committed staff members, a knack he said he got from his father, who he said often told him, "Even a weak swimmer can be carried to shore on a strong wave."
A former partner at Goldman Sachs who still heads the investment firm Granite Capital International Group, Mr. Eisenberg was appointed a Port Authority commissioner in 1994 by Governor Whitman after serving on her committee charged with finding cost-saving ways to privatize public services. A longtime Republican fund-raiser, he admits his view then was of an agency grown bloated under the oversight of Democratic administrations in each state. 
His mission was to streamline the Port Authority and speed up the sale of real estate, from office buildings to industrial parks, that it had acquired over 20 years. Mrs. Whitman chose him as chairman the next year. The streamlining included the elimination of 2,000 of the Port Authority's 9,200 jobs. 
In the year before the trade center attack, Mr. Eisenberg devoted much of his time to helping Mr. DiFrancesco come up with a plan to build a new sports arena for Newark and a Disney-like family entertainment complex in the Meadowlands. Mr. DiFrancesco nominated him to head the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, which would build and oversee the two projects, and Mr. Eisenberg had drafted a letter of resignation, dated Sept. 12, that was in his desk at the Port Authority headquarters in the trade center when the planes hit.
"I was going to the New Jersey Sports Authority, but Osama bin Laden had other plans," he said.
The big plans for the sports authority and Newark arena have foundered, but Mr. Eisenberg's ambitions have not. He said he was considering a run next year for the United States Senate seat held by Robert G. Torricelli. Mr. Eisenberg would bring a similar edge in personal wealth that his former Goldman Sachs colleague, Jon S. Corzine, a Democrat, brought to his successful run last year for New Jersey's other Senate seat.
Mr. Eisenberg's replacement as Port Authority chairman is Jack G. Sinagra, a Republican who is a former New Jersey state senator. Mr. Eisenberg will continue to be a Port Authority commissioner, and is the only New Jersey resident to be appointed to the Lower Manhattan Redevelopment Board created last month by Mr. Pataki to oversee the downtown rebuilding.
Asked how his popularity on the east side of the Hudson might sit with New Jersey voters should he run for elective office, Mr. Eisenberg said, "Let's just hope that they look at me as a regional citizen."

HEADLINE: City Report Says the Economy Will Shrink 3.1% Next Year 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
New York City's economy will shrink next year for the first time since 1991, according to a report that was issued yesterday by City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi. The report predicts that the aftershocks of the attack on the World Trade Center will contribute to a net loss in jobs, a slowing of growth in wages and a sharp decline in the amount of money that the city will be able to collect in taxes in the next year.
 The report, an annual look at the city's finances and economy, predicts that the city's economy will shrink by 3.1 percent in 2002. It would be the city's first yearlong decline since the recession of 1991, and Mr. Hevesi's report suggests that much of it will be a result of the attack, rather than the national recession. The city's economy grew by 5.2 percent in 2000 and by an estimated 1.4 percent this year. 
 "The city's economy was weakening before Sept. 11, but was still stronger than the national economy," Mr. Hevesi said in a statement. "Now, due to the impact of the trade center attack, New York City's economy is expected to be weaker than the national economy. The nation is expected to recover in the second half of 2002, but the outlook is not as good for the city."
The city had been creating jobs at a rate faster than the nation until Sept. 11. Then, in October alone, the government reported the loss of 79,000 jobs in the city, a 1.6 percent decline, which is more than five times the national figure of a 0.3 percent decline in jobs that month.
Through the end of this year, the report estimates, the city will have gained an estimated 17,000 jobs, down sharply from last year. 
Next year, the Hevesi report estimates, the city will suffer a net loss of 68,200 jobs, driving its unemployment rate to 6.7 percent, up from an average of 5.7 percent in the last two years. 
The report presents a grim picture of jobs lost; a drop in the amount spent in the city by tourists; a rise in the amount of empty commercial real estate; and decreases in the amount of taxes the city can expect to take in. "The city," the report says bluntly, "has had a devastating year."
In a letter that he sent yesterday to members of the City Council, Mr. Hevesi wrote that his office's previous estimate that the World Trade Center disaster could cost as much as $105 billion in the next two years "may even be on the low side." 
Mr. Hevesi's report estimates that tax revenues will decline in the current fiscal year by 7.1 percent, or $1.6 billion. (They grew last year by 4.2 percent.) But he predicts that the amount taken in will begin to increase again in 2003, and that by 2004 the city will be able to recover the lost revenue.
But it also holds hope that the money spent by the government and the insurance industry on the cleanup of the trade center site and on compensation to the relatives of the victims and to the owners of affected businesses could lead the city to begin showing signs of recovery next year.
"The sooner the task of reconstruction begins, the sooner the recovery will start," the report said.

HEADLINE: New Wave of the Homeless Floods Cities' Shelters 

BYLINE:  By PAM BELLUCK 

 BODY:
With unemployment rising and housing costs still high, cities around the country are experiencing a new and sudden wave of homelessness. Shelters are overflowing, and more people this year are sleeping on floors in dingy social service centers, living in cars or spending nights on the streets. 
 In New York, Boston and other cities, homelessness is at record levels, a consequence of a faltering economy that has crumbled even further after the Sept. 11 attacks. 
 A survey by the U.S. Conference of Mayors released last week found that requests for emergency shelter in 27 cities had increased an average of 13 percent over last year. The report said the increases were 26 percent in Trenton; 25 percent in Kansas City, Mo.; 22 percent in Chicago; 20 percent in Denver; and 20 percent in New Orleans. 
An unusual confluence of factors seems to be responsible for the surge. Housing prices, which soared in the expansion of the 1990's, have not gone down, even though the economy has tumbled. A stream of layoffs has newly unemployed people taking low-wage jobs that might have otherwise gone to the poor. Benefits for welfare recipients are expiring under government-imposed deadlines. And charitable donations to programs that help the disadvantaged are down considerably, officials around the country said, because of the economy and the outpouring of donations for people affected by Sept. 11.
"This is an unprecedented convergence of calamities," said Xavier De Souza Briggs, an assistant professor of public policy at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. "It's really a crisis."
More than half the cities surveyed by the mayors' group reported that in the last year people had remained homeless longer, an average of six months. 
There is no total number for the homeless nationwide. Experts said it was difficult to compare the situation with statistics in previous decades, because counting methods have improved. Yet, several experts said they believed that the increases reported by cities like Boston and Chicago reflected a national trend.
"My impression is there is more homelessness now than there was 20 years ago," Gary Burtless, an economist at the Brookings Institution, said, adding that he believed that economic factors were not the sole explanation.
"I think that there must be a greater segment of our population that has tenuous connections to family and friends, and therefore has fewer resources to fall back on when something very bad happens like when they lose their job," he said.
An increasing proportion of the homeless are families with children, compared with the chronically homeless who often have serious mental illness or substance abuse problems. Requests for shelter from families with children increased in three-quarters of the cities surveyed. In more than half, families had to be broken up to be accommodated in shelters.
Some newly homeless people have jobs but do not earn enough to allow use of a home. Low-cost housing is so tight that one-third of the vouchers for the Section 8 subsidized-housing program are being returned unused, according to the Department of Housing and Urban Development. 
Several experts and advocates for the homeless predicted that the number of homeless people would rise in coming months as states and cities, facing budget crises and burdened with security costs, scaled back on financing for housing and other programs that help keep people from becoming homeless, like rent assistance and health care.
A senior policy analyst for the Coalition for the Homeless in New York, Patrick Markee, said: "Now, especially since Sept. 11, we're seeing the recession effect, low-wage workers who were just holding on, messengers, people who work in restaurants turning up at our door. We're going to see it get worse over the next few months."
In Rhode Island, the state is dropping a $5 million housing program from its budget. Yet this month, a crush of homeless people forced the opening of a shelter in an old convent in Warwick, the first new shelter for the homeless in the state in 10 years. This year, 120 families with children have slept on the floor of Travelers Aid, a social service center in Providence that is not a shelter.
In New York, the number of people in shelters, 29,802 as of last month, is the highest ever. According to the Coalition for the Homeless, the number of families in shelters has grown 50 percent in three years, to 6,669, while the percentage of children in shelters has risen 60 percent, to 12,576. Mr. Markee said 1,500 families were being housed in welfare hotels, three times as many as three years ago. 
In Boston, officials conducted a census of the homeless on Dec. 10 and found 6,001 homeless people, a record, said Kelley Cronin, director of the Emergency Shelter Commission. Ms. Cronin added that the number of people on the street, 277, was also the highest on record.
Chicago reported in the mayors' survey that the number of people who were homeless or receiving emergency assistance to keep them from becoming homeless had jumped, to 19,421 from 15,682 last year. 
In a school district in Sacramento, Liane Ramirez, who works with homeless families, said she had already seen twice as many families living in their cars as she had seen in the previous few years combined.
"We feel like we're seeing a lot more first-time scared-to-death homeless," Ms. Ramirez said. "And we're looking at working homeless, not just welfare homeless."
Some aspects of the problem seem clearly related to the terrorist attacks.
Before Sept. 11, the Boston Rescue Mission, a large shelter, had a $90,000 contract with Delta Air Lines to clean the carpets of its planes. The contract, which the airline had been planning to double, employed 30 homeless people from the shelter, said John Samaan, the president of the mission. After Sept. 11, Delta halved the contract instead, putting one-third of the workers out of work. 
In Portland, Ore., the Goose Hollow Family Shelter, the largest family shelter in the city in the winter, usually receives thousands of dollars in donations in September, said Chuck Currie, its director. This year, it received one contribution, for $100.
"I've heard other agencies say contributions have dropped 20 percent to 70 percent," Mr. Currie said.
Programs that provide services to the homeless are also bracing for the state budget cuts.
In Illinois, homeless services are highly likely to be affected by state plans for a $485 million budget cut.
"It's going to send programs like ours into a tailspin," said Diane Nilan, an administrator at a large shelter in Aurora, a Chicago suburb whose shelter has been so crowded that Ms. Nilan has asked for a portable classroom to add space.
In many cities, shelters said they were seeing more people who became homeless after having lost jobs or being priced out of apartments.
In Dallas, Oscar Turner, 52, was laid off from his $8-an-hour job as a Wal-Mart greeter in early October and has been staying at free shelters, unable to afford the small rent that he had paid before. Mr. Turner has looked for work with the city as a crossing guard or maintenance worker, but so far, he said, "it's not going too good."
In Charlotte, N.C., Tyrone Hicklen, 43, was laid off at a party-supply store and has been living in shelters for two months. Unable to find work, he is heading to Kansas to enroll in a truck-driving school.
In Rhode Island, John Swenson, 44, took refuge at the Warwick shelter with his 10-year-old son, Michael, after he could not find work at his home in Hyannis, Mass., and lost a part-time job cooking hamburgers in Warwick. 
"It's kind of late in life to be needing something," said Mr. Swenson, unemployed for the first time in 15 years and used to $14-an-hour jobs. 
"I knew there were shelters," he said, "and that's part of what kept me out of them. On the Cape, I helped paint the shelter in Hyannis. I went from painting a shelter to being in one."
