HEADLINE: Move in Congress Would Relax a New Disclosure Law 

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 

 BODY:
In the closing days of the Congressional session, a senior House Republican is trying to loosen year-old disclosure requirements intended to shed light on the spending and fund-raising of certain tax-exempt groups engaged in politics.
 The law won large majorities in the House and the Senate last year, becoming the first major change in campaign finance requirements in more than two decades. Now Representative Bill Thomas, Republican of California, is working to amend it to eliminate what he considers redundant and burdensome provisions, aides said today. 
 The law was enacted to bring accountability to a growing number of secretive groups, conservative and liberal alike, that were active in political advertising and direct-mail appeals but that were not subject to federal reporting requirements because they did not explicitly advocate election or defeat of a candidate. 
Even some sponsors of the law say it has had unintended consequences, forcing candidates for state legislatures who already file contribution reports with their states to make reports to the Internal Revenue Service as well.
In the Senate, Kay Bailey Hutchison, Republican of Texas, and two Democrats, Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut and Russell D. Feingold of Wisconsin, have offered a proposal, less sweeping than Mr. Thomas's, that would relieve state and local groups of duplicative paperwork. But the initiative awaits action by Mr. Thomas, because changes in tax-related law must originate in the House and its Ways and Means Committee, where he is chairman.
One Republican staff member said the Thomas proposal might be attached to an economic stimulus package.
Another Republican aide called such a tactic unlikely, saying it would be too controversial. But he said the measure might nonetheless come up for a vote this week.
A number of House Democrats and groups that want to restrict campaign spending say the measure should not be rushed through Congress with little scrutiny.
"There has been ample opportunity to correct this problem, but not behind closed doors in a stimulus package," said Representative Lloyd Doggett, a Texas Democrat who was a sponsor of the law enacted last year. "I think we have to be very careful in addressing any concerns that state and local organizations raise not to create new loopholes."
Barbara Ann Clay, a spokeswoman for Mr. Thomas's committee, said she had no comment on the issue.
But another Republican aide, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified, said the chairman wanted only to end redundant paperwork and would keep intact the core requirements that secretive political action committees report to the federal government. "We don't want to create any loopholes," he said.
The aide said that under the proposal, the law would no longer require reporting to the I.R.S. by state and local tax-exempt groups that engage only in local political activities and that report to states having disclosure rules "substantially similar" to those of the federal government. Mr. Thomas would also eliminate the annual I.R.S. filing requirement for state and national groups that already report to the Federal Election Commission or to states.
An array of interests including state legislators and the American Society of Association Executives have been pushing for such changes.
"This isn't about disclosure," said Jim Clarke, senior vice president of the society, which represents leaders of a variety of professional and trade associations. "It's trying to take groups that are in good faith disclosing and not making them have to do it twice."
But critics say the changes would go too far. They fear that once the legislation emerges in its final form, it will not clearly define what "substantially similar" means in its discussion of how state disclosure rules must approach the requirements of federal ones. The result, they say, will be a cutback on information available to the public, because some states have loose reporting requirements.
Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, called the proposal "another attempt to dismantle what's left of any restraints on unlimited campaign contributions."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative Bill Thomas, the Ways and Means chairman. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Democratic Lawmakers Oppose New Spending Near Session's End 

BYLINE:  By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 17 

 BODY:
Democratic leaders tried to cut off spending today by the Republicans who control the New Jersey Legislature, warning that they would not support any measures that would worsen a deficit predicted to be about $1.4 billion this fiscal year.
 The Democrats, who will take over the Legislature and the governor's office next month, fended off a revision in the corporate tax structure that would have lowered most companies' taxes and that business leaders said was essential to stimulating the state's economy, although a vote could still be scheduled after New Year, in the Legislature's final week. 
 "The Republicans running the show in the Legislature and the governor's office seem to want to run out the clock on their time in charge by spending until they literally don't have the power to spend any more," said Senator Richard J. Codey, the minority leader. 
When the new Legislature meets on Jan. 8, Democrats will have a firm upper hand in Trenton, which they have not enjoyed since the early 1990's.
The Republicans are ceding control of the Assembly and the governor's office for the first time in 10 years. The Senate will be evenly split, 20-20, and its leadership shared.
Mr. Codey also said that when he serves as acting governor for three and a half days before Governor-elect James E. McGreevey takes office next month, he will order a recertification, or an official accounting, of the state's revenues. Mr. McGreevey has been urging Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco to recertify the revenues since shortly after the November election.
As Mr. Codey, along with the Assembly speaker-elect, Albio Sires, made the call for an end to new spending, the Legislature was facing votes this afternoon on about 150 bills. Many were scheduled for a vote only late last week.
Among the bills not voted on was a proposal to recalculate New Jersey's corporate income tax, which would result in lower taxes for large corporations with headquarters in the state. When the bill was approved by the Senate Budget Committee last week, it was opposed by all of the Democratic committee members, including Senator Bernard F. Kenny, one of its original sponsors.
Committee members were told that the measure, to be phased in over five years, would cost the treasury about $12 million in its first year.
Today, the Democrats, including Senator Codey, did support a bill providing tuition aid for children and spouses of victims of the Sept. 11 terror attacks. It was approved in a 39-to-0 vote.
The Assembly is scheduled to meet on Thursday, but the Senate has only one more voting day, Jan. 7, before the session closes.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Amgen Deal May Signal Biotech Consolidation
Amgen formally announced its $16 billion acquisition of Immunex, the largest of a recent spate of acquisitions sweeping through the biotechnology industry.
 The deal set off speculation that more such acquisitions might be in the offing and that the fragmented biotechnology industry might finally be starting a consolidation that some experts say is long overdue. Page C4. 

Norway to Cut Its Oil Production
Norway said it would cut its oil output by 150,000 barrels a day, a pledge that still seems to fall short of reductions demanded by OPEC before it initiates its own cutback. C6.

U.S. Presses for Cutbacks in Steel
United States trade officials pressed steel-making countries from around the world to reduce production and lift prices. C2.

Price Isn't Only Factor in Cruise Deal
When shareholders of P&O Princess Cruises meet next month to vote on a proposed $2.9 billion merger with Royal Caribbean Cruises, they will also consider an unsolicited $4.6 billion bid from Carnival. But price may not be the only factor to consider. There is also the question of regulatory approval. C7.

Stocks Climb in a Broad Rally
Stocks rose broadly on the prospect of a traditional Christmas rally. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 80.82 points, or 0.8 percent, to 9,891.97. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 11.29 points, or 1 percent, to 1,134.36, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 34.28 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,987.45. C9.

More Talks Sought on Stimulus
Republicans and Democrats headed into the final steps of their negotiations over an economic recovery package, seeking a final round of talks even as they pursued strategies to blame each other if they fail. A18.

Republic New York Pleads Guilty
Republic New York pleaded guilty to fraud and agreed to pay $606 million in restitution for its role in a scheme that cost investors millions of dollars. The company acknowledged that some of its employees overstated the value of assets in the accounts of Martin A. Armstrong, the New Jersey investment adviser who is awaiting trial on charges that he cheated Japanese investors. The phony statements covered up losses and allowed Mr. Armstrong to commingle client money to advance his scheme, prosecutors say. C7.

Galveston to Vote on Port Merger
When Galveston residents vote today on the proposed acquisition of the Galveston port by the Houston port, their pride may well scuttle the deal. Some welcome it, but others resent the theft of their history. C2.

Sun Life of Canada to Buy Rival
Sun Life Financial Services of Canada agreed to acquire Clarica Life Insurance for $4.7 billion in stock. World Business, Section W.

Setback for Overhaul in Japan
Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan agreed with ruling-party lawmakers to put off a decision on merging eight state-run financial institutions. World Business, Section W.

Prada Struggles With Debt Load
Beneath the glamour at the opening of Prada's store in SoHo was a sense of anxiety caused by the company's struggle with debt. D9.

Enron Trouble Derails Art Collection
The collapse of Enron has derailed an ambitious effort to create a major corporate art collection in Houston. E1.

HEADLINE: WITH SEATS EMPTY, AIRLINES CUT FARES TOBARGAIN LEVELS 

BYLINE:  By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Airlines desperate to fill seats in the economic downturn that deepened after Sept. 11 are cutting some fares to levels not seen in years. 
 The deals include several destinations, like Hawaii and the Caribbean, that have rarely been put on sale during the winter season. On some routes to Europe and Asia where bargains could be found in previous years, the discounts are deeper than usual. 
 For example, a round-trip coach ticket from Los Angeles to Tokyo is on sale for as little as $398 on American Airlines. Coach seats to London from New York are being offered as low as $198 round trip by several airlines, while business-class tickets to several cities in Europe from the Midwest and East Coast that have full published fares of more than $6,000 are now going for $1,200. 
Still, some travelers have been disappointed to find few bargains on the routes that they want to fly. Especially in the United States, tickets to many cities continue to be offered at high prices that were set during the peak of the travel boom, which ended last year. Many of the best fares are already sold out during peak travel periods like the coming Christmas and New Year's holidays. And most such fares carry many restrictions. 
But there are still some bargains to be had on specific routes, according to travel agents. "There are pockets and pockets of good deals," said Tom Parsons, chief executive of Bestfares.com, a Web-based discount travel agency. "The best of the best is overseas."
American Airlines and United Airlines recently extended a range of deals, including round-trip flights to London from San Francisco for $398 and to San Juan, P.R., from New York for $269. Tickets must be bought by Dec. 28 for reservations through May 19. 
In addition, Southwest Airlines, the low-fare king, is offering a coast-to-coast round-trip fare of $198 for some seats between now and June 7. The sale ends on Dec. 27. Southwest mainly flies from secondary airports; most transcontinental trips require one or two stops.
Virtually all such bargain fares must be bought in advance, are not refundable, are restricted to certain days of the week, and may require a Saturday stay. Many of the sales end this month.
The low prices appear to have helped overcome some people's jitters about flying after the terrorist hijackings on Sept. 11 -- which is the point. 
Passenger traffic dropped by 40 percent after the attacks. It has since moved back up to some degree. "The people we talk to find that there is no crisis in consumer confidence right now," said Karl Peterson, chief executive of Hotwire, a discount travel agency on the Internet. "People are willing to fly."
At most airlines, the average percentage of seats filled on each plane has returned to the 60 to 70 percent levels that prevailed before Sept. 11. But that is after the carriers cut the number of seats they offer by 15 to 25 percent. Overall traffic is still down about 20 percent.
Most important to the airlines, many of those missing passengers are business travelers, who paid the highest fares and were responsible for the bulk of airline profits. The weakness in business travel started early this year, with the downturn in the economy, and has been worsened by the terrorist attacks. 
Mr. Peterson said he attended a seminar earlier this month with 50 other chief executives from a variety of industries. Many, he said, acknowledged that they were using the events of Sept. 11 as an excuse to reduce expenses by limiting business travel.
Some airlines have experimented with reducing business fares but most have not cut their walk-up fares, arguing that price reductions do not stimulate an increase in business travel. 
As a result, the airlines have had to depend on presumably more flexible leisure passengers to fill their seats. But that has required deeper discounts, and most of the major carriers are losing millions of dollars a day. 
"People are getting a real bargain out there," said Douglas M. Steenland, the president of Northwest Airlines, "because the industry at present is not covering its costs."
Mr. Parsons agreed. "If you are paying 3 cents a mile and it costs the airlines 10 to 12 cents a mile, you know you are getting a good deal," he said, alluding to some of the lowest fares to Asia. 
The best bargains he sees right now, Mr. Parsons added, are to the Caribbean. US Airways is offering round-trip tickets for around $250 to destinations like Jamaica, the Bahamas and the Cayman Islands from Boston, New York and Washington, as much as 60 percent lower than prices last winter.
Most airlines offer an extra 10 percent discount if tickets are purchased on their Web sites.
"We usually don't see 85-degree- weather destinations go on sale for January, February and March when you have all those snowbirds in the Northeast," Mr. Parsons said.
On trans-Atlantic routes, where passenger traffic has been hit especially hard by the economic downturn, US Airways and Northwest Airlines are offering discounts of more than 80 percent off full-fare business-class tickets to a variety of European cities. But these tickets must be bought by this Sunday and used before Jan. 10. Coach fares have also come down significantly on many routes. 
There are many routes where few bargain tickets can be found. For example, nearly all discount tickets to Florida before and after Christmas and New Year's have been sold. It is also difficult to find cheap seats to cities in Arizona, Las Vegas and many other destinations west of the Rocky Mountains.
Mr. Parsons said it was wise to lock in bargains to warm-weather destinations like the Caribbean now for trips in February and March because fares might rise, especially when the cold weather settles in on the East Coast after an unusually mild fall.
But he added that it could be smart to wait before buying a ticket to Europe for travel in the first half of 2002 because prices might drop further. "If you are departing after March 15," Mr. Parsons said, "my advice is to put your feet up, have a cup of coffee and wait."
Mr. Peterson of Hotwire, though, recommended grabbing bargains now because, he said, the industry cannot afford to keep offering such low fares.
Referring to a $198 transcontinental fare, he said: "That is a fantastic deal that people should not be banking on being out there in the next six months. My advice is don't count on it going any lower."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: COMMUNITY; 
A School Finds Strength in a Network of Grief

BYLINE:  By JANE GROSS 

 BODY:
The catalog of loss at Xavier High School is both familiar and harrowing: 60 dead in the World Trade Center terror attack, including alumni, as well as close relatives of teachers, staff members, and students past and present.
 Three boys without fathers. An assistant headmaster without a son. The autumn alumni magazine remade with a memorial cover of yearbook pictures -- 10 fresh-faced teenagers in black tie, class of '74 to '96, all of them gone in an unimaginable cloud of smoke and concrete. 
 Grief, then, hangs heavy in the hallways, classrooms and chapel on West 16th Street in Manhattan. Young and old alike remain dazed and pale three months later. "This is something we'll be dealing with for a long, long time to come," says the Rev. Daniel J. Gatti, Xavier class of 1959 and the school's president. 
Xavier faces a test of moving forward that is dreadful, to be sure, but it is one the Jesuit school is equipped to meet. Unlike, say, Cantor Fitzgerald, this is a religious institution, led by clergy, not bond traders. Unlike a firehouse, with its muscular bravado, this is a place where young men are taught to talk openly and with a sense of vulnerability about faith and God.
Here, then, there is an identifiable path out of the darkness, a set of well-established rituals to help 1,000 students, teachers and staff members move from grief to renewal. And so to spend several days inside this 150-year-old school is to appreciate one of the rarer phenomena of the trade center disaster: a wounded place that is actually coping, in specific, regular and reliable ways.
In religion classes, instead of murky abstractions, questions of the deepest and most painful kind are asked and, at least sometimes, answered. At the school, despite no escape from the hurtful reminders, there is daily access to church, and thus to prayer and the chance to try to figure out what good might come of the obvious evil.
"They can challenge our hearts but not change them," repeats the Rev. David S. Ciancimino, class of '77 and Xavier's headmaster, at the many memorial Masses he has offered. "That is our great sanctuary, if you will."
In the classroom, students are often instructors. The Rev. John Garvey, who teaches religion, recalled the day in November when his faith was at its shakiest. The school was tentatively steadying itself when an airplane crashed in the Rockaways, home to scores of Xavier students and staff members. Of the five people killed on the ground, four had Xavier connections. 
Into a quiet classroom, where Father Garvey was struggling to grade papers, came James Dowdell, 17, whose father, Kevin, had died at the World Trade Center along with five other firefighters from Rescue Company 4 in Queens. James had been to the Rockaways crash site, near his home, eager to help, even if it meant passing out cups of water to rescue workers.
When his father's fire company arrived on the scene of the plane crash, James told Father Garvey, they greeted him as "one of us now." The teenager could barely contain his pride.
"I was really down," Father Garvey said. "I had the 'whys.' When James came in, my presumption was I had to take care of this boy, swallow my grief and be there for him. But he reminded me that we had to go, be, do, act, stop the 'what ifs' and deal with what is. He was the voice of hope, love and caring."
Xavier has also drawn on its legendary network, the generations of Irish and Italian families from the farthest reaches of the five boroughs who have sent their sons here, propelling them into the city's middle class. Everyone who has ever gone to Xavier knows everyone else, or so it seems. They played on the same Catholic Youth Organization basketball teams, went to the same colleges, drank at the same bars, surfed the same beaches, worked at the same firehouses and brokerage firms. 
These connections, a source of jobs and social life in good times, now provide sustenance of another kind in the face of unfathomable loss. For James Dowdell, that means leaning on people he has known since childhood, among them Jayne Lee, Xavier's college counselor and a neighbor in Breezy Point, Queens. 
Mrs. Lee held James in her arms the day school resumed after Sept. 11 -- with extended homeroom periods for organized discussion and a Mass for the dead -- and told him her heart was broken. Since then, he has visited her office daily, lured by the candy she has put out for 900 teenage boys, each stricken in his own way. 
James's grades are holding up, unlike those of many of his fellow students. He postponed his SAT to November from October, made an early-decision application to Iona College, where his brother, Patrick, goes, and says he is "doing O.K." Running track helps, although James has switched from cross-country to sprints because long runs give him too much opportunity to ruminate.
James can also turn for comfort to John Burke, Xavier's assistant headmaster and another Breezy Point neighbor. Mr. Burke, too, is caught in the wide, dark net of grief, having lost his son Matt, class of '91 and a budding broker at Cantor Fitzgerald. Many of Matt's friends died as well: James Riches, a basketball star from the class of '89; Charles Herron, class of '96 and a colleague at Cantor; Sean Lugano, an Xavier classmate whose uncle is the school's defensive line coach and whose cousin is a sophomore.
Mr. Burke finds solace in numbers. "You don't want to say to anyone, 'Gee, I'm glad your relative died,' " he said. "But if this had happened and my Matt had been the only person killed. . . ." He paused to gulp back the tears. "It's devastating enough. But it would be more devastating in loneliness."
Loneliness is the last thing anyone need worry about at Xavier, which, the school likes to say, has been turning out "men for others" since 1847. At the adjacent church, a Mass for the school's dead, in late September, drew more than 1,500 people. Father Gatti described communion as gridlock. A police officer outside, an Xavier alumnus, closed the street to traffic. Then, with a megaphone, he led the crowd in a chorus of the school's fight song: "maroon and blue, we'll see you through."
When the two hijacked jets exploded into the World Trade Center, the administrators at Xavier knew they had a tragedy on their hands of vast, personal dimensions. Nearly 100 students -- the children of firefighters, police officers and anyone who worked in the twin towers -- were summoned to the library. Among them were two boys, in addition to James Dowdell, who would soon learn that their fathers were lost: Constantine Economus, a freshman, and Robert Twomey, a junior, whose uncle was also killed. 
Keeping watch over the traumatized boys was Lorraine Longing, the director of guidance. She knew, but told nobody until the end of the day, that her sister-in-law was among the missing, and her brother was kneeling in prayer in the Xavier chapel. Along with other school officials, Ms. Longing orchestrated an orderly dismissal that day, found beds in the Jesuit residence upstairs for the few boys who could not get home and began planning the healing process.
In the months since, using her own evolving reactions as a guide, Ms. Longing has been meeting with guidance counselors, faculty members and students, as well as sending home letters to their parents. She tells them to be alert for fatigue, headaches, loss of appetite, lapses in concentration, slipping grades. 
"I don't want anyone to think that because three months have passed, we have all felt what we're going to feel," she said. Ms. Longing, on some days, looks as peaked as the students. Along with her mother and sister, she is helping her brother care for his sons, one just shy of 2 years old and the other an infant.
Xavier students, faculty members and administrators say that anger is a bigger stumbling block than loss of faith. Father Gatti points to the surge of patriotism and generosity as proof "that God can work good out of anything and everything."
James Dowdell, after a recent Xavier retreat, said, "There's not a question that my dad's up there with God, and that's nice."
Even Mr. Burke, despite a momentary reservation, settles into a peaceful place. "We have a retarded child, a grandson who's blind and now I've lost my son," he said. "Give me a break. I'm human. Of course it tests your faith. But faith is a choice and this is an environment that nurtures it."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Bids Get Higher To Buy Red Sox

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Another day, another dollar; another day of bidding, another few hundred million dollars. That is the direction the sale of the Boston Red Sox has taken.
 Prospective purchasers engaged in yet another round of bids yesterday, this time not only for the majority interest in the team but also for the rest of the team. Totals bids -- for the Red Sox, Fenway Park and 80 percent of the New England Sports Network -- were expected to approach or surpass $700 million. 
 Representatives of the Jean R. Yawkey Trust, which owns 53 percent of the team, did not disclose any details of the bidding, but four groups had been expected to remain in the running for the right to spend the most money ever for a baseball team at a time when Major League Baseball officials are loudly lamenting the game's economy.
This latest round of bids was apparently prompted by an unexpected, perhaps preemptive, move three weeks ago by Charles Dolan of Cablevision. 
Dolan submitted a bid for the Yawkey share said to be $405 million, then added $250 million that he said he would pay the limited partners so that he could own 100 percent of the team.
A person with knowledge of the sale process said it was decided to have another round of bids to determine if other prospective buyers wanted to duplicate Dolan's decision to go for the whole team. 
The limited partners, who are scheduled to meet Thursday with John Harrington, the Red Sox chief executive, can decide individually if they want to sell their shares. But they will decide together to approve or reject the bidder Harrington recommends selling the Yawkey share to.
Under terms of the ownership agreement, a bidder must gain approval of a majority of the 23 limited-partner shares to buy 53 percent of the team. Those shares are divided, based on ownership percentage, among the four individuals, two companies and two trusts that make up the limited partners.
Harrington owns one limited-partner share. The Yawkey Trust has three shares, meaning Harrington would need eight more shares for his recommendation to be accepted. The two largest limited-partner shareholders are the Aramark Corporation, the Fenway concessionaire (7.5 shares), and the Dexter Group (6.5 shares).
Dolan's bid three weeks ago was said to be the highest of that round. His $405 million was reportedly followed by $380 million from Joseph O'Donnell and Stephen Karp, Boston entrepreneurs, and $330 million from the group headed by Tom Werner, former managing partner of the San Diego Padres.
But another bidder, a group headed by Miles Prentice, a New York lawyer, reportedly came in with another bid that topped Dolan's after being bolstered by the addition of the Quadrangle Group, a private investment fund. 
Prentice did not return a telephone call yesterday seeking comment, but a spokesman confirmed that he remained in the chase. The other three bidding finalists were expected to be Dolan, O'Donnell and Karp, and the Werner group.
Not entirely clear is the presence of John Henry in the Werner group, which also includes The New York Times Company. Henry owns the Florida Marlins but is in the process of selling the team to Jeffrey Loria, the New York art dealer, who is the managing partner of the Montreal Expos, one of the two teams Commissioner Bud Selig wants to eliminate before next season. 
Because legal challenges have delayed Selig's plan, it is very likely that the Expos will not be eliminated this winter. The only way for Loria to be permitted to buy the Marlins, thus freeing Henry to be a part-owner of the Red Sox, would be for someone else to assume operation of the Expos for next season.

HEADLINE: Up a Texas Channel Without a Dock 

BYLINE:  By KATE MURPHY 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Dec. 17 

 BODY:
Residents of Galveston cling to the century-old glory days when their port city was the largest and most prosperous in Texas. But their port has long since been upstaged by Houston's, 50 miles up a ship channel to the northwest.
 Now Houston's port, the nation's second largest by cargo volume, is bursting at the seams, and the acquisition of the Galveston port is seen as the best route to expansion. When Galveston residents vote on the merger on Tuesday, though, their pride may well scuttle it. Some residents welcome the deal, or at least see the economic necessity of it, but others resent Houston's "nouveau riche" and "parasites" stealing their history. 
 A merger would be a boon to Houston's economy, reeling from the demise of its largest corporate citizen, Enron, and recent layoffs at Compaq Computer and Continental Airlines. Galveston, a cash-hungry island town where housing projects surround Victorian mansions, has no tax base for improving the port.
"I want it to happen -- it's got to happen," said William J. Messina, general manager of maritime services at the Houston office of Maersk Sealand, a Norwegian international shipping line. "There's no more room at the Port of Houston."
Without Galveston, shippers would soon have to dock at distant ports like Charleston and New Orleans, and truck their goods inland. "It's an added expense and will waste valuable time," said Jim Morrison, vice president of the West Gulf Maritime Association, a regional trade group representing shipping lines, stevedores and terminal operators. 
The diversion of marine traffic would also hurt local manufacturers of goods for export, who face higher costs, as well as consumers, who will pay more for imports. In terms of cargo volume, Houston has grown an average of 4.5 percent a year in the last five years, driven mainly by the import and export of petroleum products, plastics, organic chemicals and cereals. Top trading partners include Mexico, Saudi Arabia, Venezuela, the Netherlands and Belgium. Houston plans to build additional docks in Bayport -- between Houston and Galveston -- but needs Galveston, too.
Also, the Galveston port is closer to the open sea. "It's an extra five hours in transit time to go up the channel," said Michael Bird, who manages the Houston office of Transmarine Navigation, a shipper based in Long Beach, Calif. It is worth it if the cargo is destined for Houston, he said. But Transmarine's freight, like half the cargo loaded and unloaded in Houston, is generally going or coming from elsewhere. It would be less costly to transfer goods to trains and trucks in Galveston. 
The channel is also too shallow for the "new mega-cargo-vessels that are on the drawing board," Mr. Morrison said.
Stevedores, who load and unload cargo, would also like to see the merger approved. "It would help my customers, and whatever helps my customers helps me," said Frank Fogarty, vice president of P & O Ports Texas Inc., a stevedore company with crews in both Houston and Galveston. He said the merger would attract more business to the ports, which means more business for him.
"It's a win for everybody," Mr. Fogarty said, giving the Houston port room to grow and improving Galveston's docks. "They're rickety, the pilings need to be replaced and there are big holes in the wharves," he said.
The merger calls for the Port of Houston Authority to spend $30 million on renovating the Galveston port. The authority has also pledged to retire $21 million of the smaller port's debt and make annual payments to Galveston of around $2 million for a decade. On top of that, a University of Houston-Clear Lake study predicts the merger will bring 2,100 jobs and some $90 million in business to Galveston in the next 5 to 10 years. 
Many in Galveston are resisting. "People here have long memories," said Harris L. Kempner Jr., who runs Kempner Capital Management. Though he supports the merger, he disdainfully refers to Houstonians as "mainlanders."
Houston port officials have spent the last year lobbying Galveston officials and making their case to often hostile residents at town hall meetings. "We've faced some pretty rough crowds, but I hope we've been able to convince them," said Thomas Kornegay, executive director of the Port of Houston Authority, who prefers not to speculate on the outcome of the election.
Though Houston port officials have won the endorsement of the Galveston mayor, city council and the local economic development council, voters are evenly divided.
"The merger was a huge underdog a couple of months ago, but now I think the odds are about even," Mayor Roger Quiroga of Galveston said. "We're on the edge of our seats."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The ship Spirit being loaded in Galveston, Tex., earlier this year. The city's docks are said to be in need of extensive repairs, and a merger with the Port of Houston would provide money for those repairs. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: A Defender of Faith in Reason 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Hail and Farewell," by Anthony Lewis (column, Dec. 15): 
 Faith in reason is the direct, logical outgrowth of the Judeo-Christian tradition. Fundamentalist religious faith, exhibited in most of the great religions today, can only constrain and harm the human enterprise. 
 We continue to wage war on subjugation by race and gender. Reason must be applied to the world's homophobia, nationalism, economic disparity and health inequality in order to vanquish these evils.
With faith in reason, the hard work and the great promise for us lie ahead.

ROBBINS WINSLOW
Naples, Fla., Dec. 15, 2001

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
Nets' Rise Exposes the Knicks' Decay

BYLINE:  By HARVEY ARATON 

 BODY:
THERE he stood, in the fast-emptying lower stands of Madison Square Garden, watching the corporate ticket holders scramble from their seats as if free cellphone service were suddenly available outside. "Terrible, just terrible, for us to come in here and win like this," Lewis Katz, the principal owner of the New Jersey Nets, said mischievously.
 He was wearing a black leather jacket with Nets on the back and holding his own cellphone and making no attempt to minimize his glee or his team's 114-96 tutorial victory over the Knicks Sunday night. 
 "The Nets are for real," Katz crowed. "We can play with anyone in the conference right now." 
Be it mere symbolism or actual proof, there must be some relevance to Katz's contention that a seismic power shift in the East has finally occurred, based on New Jersey's 3-0 swing through Chicago, Miami and New York. Compared to the Nets' conference-leading 15-7 mark, the combined record of the three dominant Eastern franchises for much of the 1990's stands at a sobering 20 up and 48 down this morning.
Up, up and over the rim went the Nets rookie Richard Jefferson late in the fourth quarter Sunday night, for Jason Kidd's garbage-time underhand setup from out by the arc. The resulting slam punctuated the Nets' second stylistic statement made to their longtime tormentors, the first blowout of the Knicks occurring last month at the Nets' house across the Hudson, west of Eden.
Even the remaining Knicks fans got a charge out of the Kidd-Jefferson improvisation, with the conspicuous exception of three nonpaying attendees on the baseline near the Knicks' bench. There sat the Knicks' ruling triumvirate -- James L. Dolan, Steve Mills and Scott Layden -- stunned, stone-faced and stupefied by their team's fourth consecutive defeat under the new coach, Don Chaney.
For the time being, and if only because two decades of covering pro basketball has taught me to avoid overreacting in December, I am inclined to adopt the posture of Keith Van Horn more than owner Katz's. 
"It takes more than 22 games to establish a dominance or a fan base," Van Horn said. 
The Knicks have played their way out of these ruts before. They can't be as bad as they have looked recently and it's premature to claim the Nets, as entertaining as they are, won't come back to earth and the pack. After his 27-point outburst Sunday night, Kerry Kittles was last seen limping into the locker room. It was his ankle, not a knee, but it was also a reminder of how fragile most N.B.A. equations can be, especially the Nets'.
Have the Knicks suffered psychological damage after the unequivocal surrender of the little coach whose obsessive mission had been their collective advance? Chaney has inherited a team that is apparently short on standup guys. Larry Johnson was a galvanizing influence -- not to mention a rare Knick, when healthy, with low-post skills -- but he's gone. Latrell Sprewell talks a lot but there is a difference between honesty and leadership. It is possible that Jeff Van Gundy's surprise exit was enough to nudge the Knicks toward the slide they must take eventually, given their roster deficiencies and salary-cap straits.
The more pragmatic explanation and one that is much fairer to Chaney is that Van Gundy just picked an opportune time to quit. The Knicks had won five of six but close inspection of the five reveals one victory of note, at Milwaukee. They barely beat a struggling Atlanta team twice. They rallied at home against woeful Houston. The notion that Marcus Camby would solve all ills was as silly as the promotion of him as a premier center. Even Camby says he is not a center -- he's a wonderfully athletic off-the-ball presence at both ends of the floor.
"I've never seen them double-team this much," Van Horn said, referring to the open looks the Nets, a superb passing team thanks to Kidd, had from the perimeter Sunday night. "They've always had faith in their man defense, and played us that way."
The Knicks no longer have that luxury, with Camby giving away bulk most nights, with Sprewell trying to guard the likes of Kenyon Martin and with two other defensive liabilities -- Allan Houston and Mark Jackson -- in their starting lineup. This all speaks to the work the personnel maven Layden has done since Dolan's disastrous decision not to hold onto Patrick Ewing for one last season. That would have allowed the Knicks to begin whittling down the payroll, slot by slot. With all of Layden's maneuvering, all the spending, Layden's Knicks are old, small and have not a single transcendent offensive talent.
Only in a conference devoid of a dominant power and in obvious transition can they still legitimately set their sights on a midrange playoff position, while Lewis Katz points his Nets even higher.
"Look at what Kidd has done for Kittles, Martin and Van Horn," he said. "The Nets are a contender -- a good, young team that should, absent injury, get better and better."
The Knicks have more reporters crowding into their press-row seats. They have famous celebrities phoning for front-row exposure. They have more shapely dancers and draw bigger crowds, even when they are faking sellouts. 
The New Jersey Nets will never own New York. They just want out of the Meadowlands and into a new arena in Newark, and Katz knows the time to be lobbying hard is now.
"If the state doesn't make a favorable decision now, I believe the team will move away," he said. He meant out of New Jersey, not the metropolitan area, because the YankeeNets' startup network doesn't need winter programming from Nashville or New Orleans.
Katz went on about how much sense the arena makes for Newark, for the state, and why enterprise-zone taxes should pay for a private arena in a bad economy and with New Jersey's governor-elect, James E. McGreevey, soon to inherit huge budget deficits. Once upon a time, the Katz ownership team talked about sharing profits in Newark, but then George Steinbrenner became a partner, and now Katz says, "We're at a stage where it's pure business."
Like any distracted chief executive, he flipped open his cellphone and made plans to meet someone outside. The arena was almost empty. While Dolan, Mills and Layden were huddling solemnly in a corridor beneath the stands, Lewis Katz walked out of Madison Square Garden a winner.

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Europe: Britain: Airbus Cuts Jobs 

BYLINE:  By Kerry Shaw (NYT) 

 BODY:
 The European aviation giant Airbus Industrie said that it would eliminate 500 jobs in Britain, and announced cost-cutting measures that would save the equivalent of 9,400 jobs in France, Germany and Spain. The chief executive of Airbus, Noel Forgeard, insisted that these measures did not include layoffs, but instead reduced the number of work hours per year. 
"When we get rid of overtime, or move to part-time unemployment we reduce the number of men employed," Mr. Forgeard told Bloomberg News. The year has been a difficult one for the industry; eight days after the Sept. 11 attacks, its American rival, Boeing, announced that it was laying off 30,000 workers. As recently as October, the parent company of Airbus, EADS, insisted that it would not need to lay off anyone. Kerry Shaw (NYT)
